lead_paragraph: An 8-year-old girl who died after being held for a week in Customs and Border Protection custody last month was seen by medical professionals 11 times before she was taken to a hospital, according to new details provided by the agency, which is conducting an internal investigation.

headline: Judge in Disney World Case Steps Aside but Blasts DeSantis’s Lawyers
abstract: The judge accused Gov. Ron DeSantis’s lawyers, who wanted him off the case, of “rank judge shopping.” But he disqualified himself because a relative owns Disney stock.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Florida disqualified himself from a court case brought by Disney against Gov. Ron DeSantis, but not before blasting the governor’s legal team for engaging in “rank judge shopping.”

headline: The Dress Code Was ‘Fly and Gay’
abstract: By talking frequently for the first year of the pandemic, Ahmad Maksoud and Josef Perou brought each other light in a dark time. Then they finally met.
lead_paragraph: Ahmad Maksoud and Josef Matthew Perou first met in March 2020, a time that was far from joyful. Both work as models and performers, and were similarly impacted by pandemic lockdowns. Cut off from performance work in their respective cities — Mr. Maksoud in New York and Mr. Perou in London — they were craving connection to their art communities.

headline: When Everything Was Up for Debate — Except Their Chemistry
abstract: Stephanie Spies and Andrew Markoff were both star debaters in high school and college. Now? There’s a lot to agree upon.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Shepard Markoff was in awe of Stephanie Nicole Spies even before they first met. Both were debate competitors, and Ms. Spies was considered a legend for her talent, Mr. Markoff said. Mr. Markoff, also an accomplished debater, had seen her compete in high school and then in college. He was dazzled.

headline: He Acted Out a Charades Clue Three Years Later
abstract: Katie Schad jokingly jotted down “Marry Me Katie” as a game clue for Adam Purdy at a Thanksgiving gathering. He saved it for his proposal.
lead_paragraph: Katie Dawn Schad and Adam Robert Purdy began a fun, flirty friendship a decade after they bumped into each other at their dorm their first week at Wesleyan in 2009.

headline: The Slap That Changed Everything
abstract: I kept trying to laugh off and normalize sexual aggression by men. Eventually, it all caught up to me.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a man on the street catcalled me and then spanked my left butt cheek. Although I was wearing a thick winter coat and the slap did not leave a mark, my skin was pulsating from it. I felt dirty. And while I did not see his hand or even look directly at his face, I could not stop visualizing the grime caked beneath his fingernails.

headline: From Fairly Low Expectations, a Wonderful Surprise
abstract: Ross Uhrich and Jessica Carter Altman, the daughter of Lynda Carter Altman, who played Wonder Woman in the 1970s, expected their first encounter to be brief. It wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: On a fall evening in 2017, Dr. Ross Martin Uhrich headed to a bar in Washington to meet a woman he had matched with on Bumble. He had low expectations. So low, in fact, that he put the ingredients for a chicken stew in his slow cooker and set a timer for two and a half hours. He planned to return home early, eat dinner, and go straight to bed — he had to be up at 4 a.m. for his surgical residency.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine’s and Sweden’s bids to join NATO.
lead_paragraph: At meetings yesterday in Oslo and Bulboaca, Moldova, top world officials discussed Ukraine’s application for membership in NATO. The talks demonstrated how Russia’s invasion has forged closer ties among Western nations, expanding and strengthening the military alliance — precisely what the Kremlin wanted to prevent.

headline: Tiananmen Exhibit Is ‘a Symbol of Defiance’
abstract: A new display on the 1989 massacre is set to open in Manhattan, two years after a Tiananmen museum closed in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we will look at plans for a New York City memorial to the victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre. We’ll also update you on a legal skirmish over cannabis regulation.

headline: A spell-off that wasn’t, and a gantlet of schwas: Takeaways from the spelling bee.
abstract: All of the finalists Thursday night could spell schwa, no doubt. It was the sound it makes that foiled many of them.
lead_paragraph: After 14 rounds of words like “probouleutic” and “zwitterion” and “schistorrhachis,” Dev Shah, an eighth grader from Florida, reached the apotheosis of his craft, correctly spelling “psammophile” to win the Scripps National Spelling Bee on Thursday night.

headline: Word of the Day: dismissive
abstract: This word has appeared in 174 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word dismissive has appeared in 174 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 8 in “How to Help a Teen Who Can’t Sleep” by Catherine Pearson:

headline: Big, Incredible Journeys in an Incredibly Big Country
abstract: Trips across Australia are often necessarily trips at a striking scale.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, my colleague Hikari Hida and I reported on an amazing, improbable journey underway on Australia’s east coast.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: She Attacked Israel and the N.Y.P.D. It Made Her Law School a Target.
abstract: A student gave a commencement address at the famously progressive CUNY law school. Two weeks later, she was attacked by the tabloids and the mayor, and the school disavowed her speech.
lead_paragraph: Commencement season rarely passes without incident. In a bit of counterprogramming, last week the actress Michelle Yeoh addressed Harvard Law School’s Class of 2023, talking about “leaping off high perches into scary voids.” Nevertheless, it was a Yemeni immigrant named Fatima Mousa Mohammed, speaking to her graduating class of the City University of New York School of Law, whose words — absent the genre’s heavy-handed metaphors if not the heavy hand itself — left a more powerful impression on the news cycle.

headline: Investors Have Soured on China’s Stocks, Renewing Fears About Economy
abstract: They initially reacted enthusiastically to China’s reversal of pandemic restrictions but have since taken a dimmer view of the country’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: The wager was supposed to be a no-brainer. China was reopening after nearly three years of pandemic lockdowns, and investors expected that its economy, the world’s second largest, would come roaring back to life. Chinese stocks soared.

headline: A Barcelona Star Chases Trophies and Answers
abstract: In her quest to become a “complete” player, Aitana Bonmatí wants to know everything. As she prepares for a fourth Champions League final, it’s working.
lead_paragraph: Aitana Bonmatí always asks the same question. Every game Barcelona Femení plays generates a flood of performance data. The team’s fitness coaches know how far each player ran, how fast, how long. There is so much information, in fact, that they need two days to download it and tabulate it and parse it. Only then is it passed back to the squad.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse."

headline: What’s Behind All This ‘Shrink’?
abstract: Shrink is the retail industry’s term for inventory lost to theft or other factors. But it's sometimes used as an excuse for poor business performance, some argue.
lead_paragraph: Shrink is the retail industry’s term for inventory lost to theft or other factors. But it's sometimes used as an excuse for poor business performance, some argue.

headline: A.I.’s Inner Conflict, Nvidia Joins the Trillion-Dollar Club, and Hard Questions
abstract: “It’s like if you were told that there’s going to be a world-conquering dictator and it’s Mr. Bean.”
lead_paragraph: A few days after a lawyer used ChatGPT to write a brief filled with made-up cases, a group of A.I. experts released a letter warning of the “risk of extinction” from the technology. But will A.I. ever be good enough to pose such a threat?

headline: In India’s Gang Rape Culture, All Women Are Victims
abstract: Sexual violence against women has become normalized, and all Indian men are complicit.
lead_paragraph: GOA, India — My niece was just 4 years old when she turned to my sister-in-law in a packed movie theater in Mumbai and asked about gang rape for the first time.

headline: Fareed Zakaria on Where Russia’s War in Ukraine Stands — and Much More
abstract: The journalist discusses how Moscow’s invasion, U.S.-China relations and the rise of nonaligned countries affect America’s place in the global order.
lead_paragraph: A lot about the world has changed since February 2022, when Russia invaded Ukraine. The war itself has brought a number of surprises, from the tenacity of Ukraine’s resistance to the limits of Western sanctions. Meanwhile, competition between the United States and China has escalated into something resembling a new Cold War, India just surpassed China as the most populous country in the world and countries representing about two-thirds of the world’s population have chosen not to align themselves with the U.S. position on the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

headline: The First Name of a Supreme Court Justice Is Not Justice
abstract: In recent years, the judiciary has shown little but contempt for other governing institutions. It has earned a little in return.
lead_paragraph: Although the Supreme Court has been deciding cases at a glacial pace this term — and that with an almost comically small docket of only 59 merits cases — the justices have found other ways to keep busy. They have been spinning their ethical lapses (Justice Clarence Thomas), blowing off congressional oversight (Chief Justice John Roberts), giving interviews whining about public criticism (Justice Samuel Alito) and presenting awards to one another (Justice Elena Kagan to Mr. Roberts).

headline: Newly Published, From Graphic Novels to Hot Dogs
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: THE MAN IN THE MCINTOSH SUIT, by Rina Ayuyang. (Drawn & Quarterly, $24.95.) Ayuyang evokes the hardship and racism experienced by Filipino immigrants in this Depression-era noir, in which a migrant worker abandons the strawberry fields of rural California in search of his estranged wife in San Francisco.

headline: This Kind of Walk Is Much More Than a Workout
abstract: Incorporating awe into your daily stroll can bring mental and physical benefits. Here’s how to get started.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first installment of Well’s five-week newsletter series dedicated to walking tips and inspiration.

headline: How to Start Birding
abstract: Alli Smith, of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, offers beginner tips for exploring the wide world of birds.
lead_paragraph: This summer, as part of The New York Times birding project, The Times will be sharing a series of prompts to help readers learn how to get started birding. Begin with something foundational: Learn to identify a few of the birds most commonly seen near where you live.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Fareed Zakaria
abstract: The June 2, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Fareed Zakaria. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The Republican Obsession With ‘Work Requirements’ Is Telling
abstract: The G.O.P. has a twisted view of the safety net.
lead_paragraph: Work requirements for federal assistance programs do not, well, work.

headline: ‘The View’ Has Narrowed
abstract: Like so much of America, this influential show is less interested in vigorous debate.
lead_paragraph: The ladies of “The View” were in high spirits. A piece of news they’d been hankering for had broken at last: President Biden, a revered figure around their talk show table, had kicked off his re-election campaign.

headline: A Major Problem With Compulsory Mental Health Care Is the Medication
abstract: An underdiscussed issue with forced mental health care.
lead_paragraph: If severe mental illness, untreated, underlies the feeling of encroaching anarchy and menace around the homeless encampments of San Francisco or in the subways of New York City, then the remedy appears obvious. Let’s rescue those who, as New York’s mayor, Eric Adams, says, “slip through the cracks” of our mental health care systems; let’s give people “the treatment and care they need.”

headline: In This Thriller, the Psycho Killers Have a Southern Drawl
abstract: Stephen King reviews S.A. Cosby’s latest novel, “All the Sinners Bleed.”
lead_paragraph: Titus Crown is an ex-F.B.I. agent who gets a sheriff’s job, almost by accident, in a rural Virginia community. He’s Black. Mr. Spearman teaches geography and wears a coat of many countries on Earth Day. He’s white. Given the name of the town and county where these two live — Charon — one can expect bad things to happen, and they certainly do. As in S.A. Cosby’s previous two novels, “Blacktop Wasteland” and “Razorblade Tears,” the body count is high and the action pretty much nonstop.

headline: Help! United Owed Us $8,370 in Cash, But Offered Credit. That’s Not What We Paid For.
abstract: A couple had to cancel a South America trip for which they’d bought refundable tickets. The airline wouldn’t cough up the cash, and they felt like they’d hit the brick wall of bureaucracy — until our columnist stepped in.
lead_paragraph: On June 3, 2022, my husband and I booked one-way tickets from San Diego to Buenos Aires, which cost $8,370, and a separate reservation returning a few weeks later from Santiago, Chile, for $4,500 for me, plus miles for my husband’s ticket, all on United. Because of health issues, we intended to book refundable tickets. But we noticed right away from the email confirmations that the flights down were nonrefundable — perhaps our mistake. I called United immediately, and an agent changed those tickets to refundable for a $300 fee. So far, so good. When we did eventually cancel the trip, the $8,370 was “refunded” as electronic travel certificates, which makes no sense. We paid with a credit card! Two follow-up appeals have been denied. Can you help? Ellen, La Jolla, Calif.

headline: To Watch a Trump Town Hall on Fox Is to Enter an Entirely Different World
abstract: Trump’s Fox News town hall is a reminder of the ferocity of his voters’ support.
lead_paragraph: Every now and then, it’s important to watch Fox News in prime time. No, not because the programs are particularly good or because the hosts tell their audience the truth. Fox is writing Dominion Voting Systems a $787.5 million check for very good reasons, and it still faces a multibillion-dollar lawsuit from Smartmatic over the channel’s election reporting. But to watch Fox News is to begin to understand millions of your fellow Americans. And there was no better time to start understanding the 2024 Republican primary contest than Thursday night, during Donald Trump’s town hall in Iowa, hosted by Sean Hannity.

headline: Period Fiction: 2 Middle Grade Books About Menstruation and the Politics Beyond It
abstract: Decades after “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret,” an anthology and a novel let readers see periods through the eyes of diverse protagonists.
lead_paragraph: One of the only books about menstruation that I remember reading as a kid was “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret.” I expect this is the case for a number of others, Generation X or not. The 1970 Judy Blume book became famous for its frank, unapologetic depiction of preteen girls on the verge or in the midst of puberty. As I write this, a film version, starring, among others, Rachel McAdams, has been released in theaters to great critical response.

headline: An Indictment of Human Culture, Narrated by a Mountain Lion
abstract: Henry Hoke’s latest novel, “Open Throat,” follows an observant — and starving — cougar living in the Los Angeles hills surrounding the Hollywood sign.
lead_paragraph: There is a moment toward the end of “Open Throat,” Henry Hoke’s slim jewel of a novel, where the narrator, a mountain lion living in the desert hills surrounding Los Angeles’s Hollywood sign, falls asleep and dreams of Disneyland. It will be hard for those who haven’t yet read this propulsive novel to understand, but the lion’s waking life at this moment is so precarious that this slippage into pleasant dream left me scared to turn the page.

headline: Little Spain Is All but Gone. Will Our Lady of Guadalupe Be Next?
abstract: The church on West 14th Street, the first in Manhattan created for a Spanish-speaking congregation a century ago, has been deconsecrated. Its future is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: The Church of Our Lady of Guadalupe, a Catholic house of worship on West 14th Street, is a grandly inventive architectural oddity and the mother of all Hispanic storefront churches in New York City. Manhattan’s first church created for a Spanish-speaking congregation, it was cobbled together out of two adjacent rowhouses in 1902 and 1917. Against this simple brownstone backdrop, a resplendent three-story Spanish Baroque entrance — now with details painted blue, white, gold, and a purple the shade of rioja — was added in 1921.

headline: Seven Standouts From the New York Design Festival
abstract: Bees, seeds, metal and stone all made appearances for the event that makes the city a design hub.
lead_paragraph: NYCxDesign, a design festival held each May in New York City, wrapped up its 11th edition last week with a strong array of group shows across boroughs — in Soho showrooms, artist studios and backyards in Brooklyn, vacant office spaces in Chinatown and galleries in between.

headline: Why North Korea’s Latest Nuclear Claims Are Raising Alarms
abstract: North Korea has signaled that it has made significant progress in its nuclear programs. Whether true or not, it is worrying to the United States and its allies in the region.
lead_paragraph: North Korea has signaled that it has made significant progress in its nuclear programs. Whether true or not, it is worrying to the United States and its allies in the region.

headline: U.S. Job Growth Remains Strong Despite Economic Clouds
abstract: Employers added 339,000 workers in May, the Labor Department said, though the report also offered signs of shakiness.
lead_paragraph: American employers added an unanticipated barrage of workers in May, reaffirming the labor market’s vigor.

headline: It’s the End of Computer Programming as We Know It. (And I Feel Fine.)
abstract: Don’t bother learning to code.
lead_paragraph: I was 5 or 6 when I got my first sense of the joys of computer programming. This was in the early 1980s, when few people had a computer. One day, my dad brought home a Sinclair ZX Spectrum, one of the world’s early affordable, mass-market PCs. The device looked like a chunky keyboard; it had 48 kilobytes of memory (my phone has about 125,000 times as much RAM); and it used your TV as a display. Software, mainly games, came on cassette tapes that you loaded into the computer with a connection to a tape player — the floppy drive of its time.

headline: ‘Lots of Explosions and Shooting Outside’: Giving Birth in Wartime Ukraine
abstract: The mental burden of Russia’s invasion has exacted a heavy toll on civilians. As the fighting drags on, pregnant women are among those facing the toughest trials.
lead_paragraph: Amina Tsoi’s twin babies are healthy girls. They squabble, as siblings do, and they both have a curious appetite for cheese, “like little mice,” their mother says. But they are small for 1-year-olds, a legacy of their premature birth during the first weeks of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Can New Jersey’s New Festival Top Coachella or SXSW? It Thinks So.
abstract: A new arts festival featuring local and marquee-name talent is coming to the Garden State.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey, along with the first lady, Tammy Murphy, had a vision: A new performance festival in their home state that could rival South by Southwest in Texas or Bonnaroo in Tennessee. And they had a plan to distinguish it.

headline: She Lost Her Career, Family and Freedom. She’s Still Fighting to Change Iran.
abstract: Fighting for change has cost Narges Mohammadi her career, separated her from family and deprived her of liberty. But a jail cell has not succeeded in silencing her.
lead_paragraph: When Narges Mohammadi was just a little girl, her mother told her to never become political. The price of fighting the system in a country like Iran would be too high.

headline: Apple Is Stepping Into the Metaverse. Will Anyone Care?
abstract: Interest in the futuristic, immersive digital world is fading just as Apple plans to debut a virtual reality device.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg embraced a digital world known as the metaverse when he said in November 2021 that he was changing his company’s name from Facebook to Meta.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Closes on Another Bachelor Pad, Paying Above List Price
abstract: The $35.2 million purchase on Central Park South was among New York City’s largest sales in May. The biggest was a townhouse that sold for $41 million on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: The media mogul Rupert Murdoch has closed on his purchase of a mansion-size apartment overlooking Central Park, paying $35.2 million, which was well above the asking price.

headline: Fed May Still ‘Skip’ June Rate Increase Even Amid Strong Hiring
abstract: Federal Reserve officials are expected to leave rates unchanged at their June 13-14 meeting. Fresh jobs data might make the choice harder.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials have signaled that they could hold interest rates steady at their upcoming meeting in June — pausing after 10 straight rate increases to assess whether their changes so far are sufficient to slow the economy and wrestle down rapid inflation.

headline: Making the Most of 900 Square Feet
abstract: The tiny house had three bedrooms, but the children’s were shoe-box size. Updating them required ingenuity and ideas from “An American in Paris.”
lead_paragraph: The tiny house had three bedrooms, but the children’s were shoe-box size. Updating them required ingenuity and ideas from “An American in Paris.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 2, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Summertime in America, Beneath the Surface
abstract: A new book of photographs by Larry Sultan captures recreational swimmers at public pools in 1970s and ‘80s California.
lead_paragraph: From the early 1970s to the early ’80s, the conceptual artist and photographer Larry Sultan repeatedly outfitted himself with goggles, an underwater camera and a hand-held flash and submerged himself in community pools across the San Francisco Bay Area. Influenced by the images he found in a Red Cross manual, he photographed underwater scenes of parents teaching their children to swim, lone swimmers treading water and people playing and holding their breath under the surface.

headline: A TriBeCa Loft Where Rafael Viñoly Worked, and Played the Piano
abstract: The architect had used the prewar apartment on West Broadway as a design studio and a place to make music. It is now on the market for $2.5 million.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years of his life, the architect Rafael Viñoly kept a private studio in TriBeCa near his main residence, where he would work on building designs while also indulging his passion for music.

headline: An Avian Murder Case on a Quiet Back Porch
abstract: A nest was assaulted. Was it the cowbird or the sparrow?
lead_paragraph: I open the pantry door and the eastern phoebe flies off the nest. Her cup-shaped home is made of mud, covered in moss and cantilevered over a glass light fixture — an avian Fallingwater. Her nest placement makes sense. Before eastern phoebes lived so close to humans, they built their nests on cliffs. Every year for 35 years, we’ve had an eastern phoebe nest under the eaves of our back porch. Without her, it would not be spring.

headline: Priced Out of the City, They Bought a Tiny Suburban Home. Now What?
abstract: The 900-square-foot house had three bedrooms, but the children’s were shoe-box size. Updating them required ingenuity and ideas from “An American in Paris.”
lead_paragraph: Much has been written about “good enough” marriages, but what of “good enough” houses in “I guess we have to live somewhere” neighborhoods?

headline: Will a Dollar General Ruin a Rural Crossroads?
abstract: A fight over a proposed chain store is also about what “country” means to different people in a small community.
lead_paragraph: Anne Hartley’s brick house in Ebony, Va., overlooks windswept fields, a Methodist church, a general store and the intersection of two country roads, a pastoral setting that evokes an Edward Hopper painting or a faded postcard from the South.

headline: ‘It’s About Connections’: Alicia Graf Mack Remakes Juilliard Dance
abstract: Mack, whom one student called an agent of change, wants to “create a place where people feel like themselves” — and a model for the professional world.
lead_paragraph: When Alicia Graf Mack taught the final ballet class for students graduating in spring from the dance division of Juilliard, it was a gentle, valedictory session: a lot of laughter, inside jokes and memories, a few tears. She’s a warm, gracious teacher who sometimes calls herself Mama Mack, and she got a little teary herself.

headline: One N.B.A. Finals Team Will Get a Trophy. But Will Either Get Respect?
abstract: Both the Denver Nuggets and the Miami Heat believe they have been disrespected and are using that as motivation as they compete for a championship.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Nuggets’ mascot, Rocky, an anthropomorphic mountain lion with a lightning bolt for a tail, dragged a pickax as he stormed around, trying to figure out where all the chatter was coming from. He needed to quiet the voices. They were disrespecting his team.

headline: Our Quick Take on Upcoming Major Supreme Court Cases and the Day’s Top Stories
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Two Dead Humpback Whales Are Seen Off Coast of New York
abstract: The animals, observed floating off Long Island and Staten Island this week, were the latest casualties of a species that faces many threats.
lead_paragraph: Two dead humpback whales have been spotted floating in waters not far from New York City, the federal authorities said on Thursday, in another worrying sign for a species that faces a number of threats.

headline: Biden Administration Bans Drilling Around Native American Cultural Site
abstract: The Interior Department will withdraw public lands around Chaco Canyon from new oil and gas leasing for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration took action on Friday to block new oil and gas leasing on federal land around Chaco Canyon in New Mexico, one of the nation’s oldest and most culturally significant Native American sites. Interior Secretary Deb Haaland announced that her agency would withdraw public lands within a 10-mile radius of Chaco Canyon and the area around it, known as Chaco Culture National Historical Park, from access to new oil and gas leasing for 20 years, following through on a 2021 pledge by President Biden to protect the area from drilling. The move will not affect existing oil and gas leases on the land or drilling on private property within the 10-mile radius.

headline: America’s Big City Brain Drain
abstract: Why the college-educated are leaving coastal hubs in large numbers.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, well-paid and college-educated Americans have shed major cities like New York, San Francisco and Washington for places like Philadelphia or Birmingham, Ala.

headline: The Three Other Trump Investigations
abstract: The Manhattan case isn’t Trump’s only legal problem.
lead_paragraph: In the coming months, Donald Trump’s mounting legal troubles could get even worse. At least three investigations could bring more criminal charges against him.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include an outer space road trip, a reimagining of “Peter Pan” and a nautical adventure based on a true story.
lead_paragraph: In 2257, humans inhabit space colonies and teenagers can go off-roading in space rovers. At least that’s the world that Caleb (Isaiah Russell-Bailey) inhabits when we meet him and his friends: Dylan (Billy Barratt), Borney (Orson Hong) and Marcus (Thomas Boyce). After his mother’s death, Caleb was cared for by his single dad, Michael (Scott Mescudi, a.k.a. Kid Cudi), who was killed while working in the lunar mines. The film begins as the recently orphaned Caleb is to be sent to live on a faraway planet called Omega. Before he’s forced to leave, though, he takes advantage of a lockdown prompted by an impending meteor shower to gather his buddies, steal a rover and go explore a mysterious crater that may or may not hold treasure. They bring along Addison (Mckenna Grace), who has just arrived from Earth, since she has access to some codes they need for the mission. From the get-go, this fun, fast-paced, emotional sci-fi adventure has enough action to captivate young kids and preteens. Directed by Kyle Patrick Alvarez (“C.O.G.”), “Crater” is worth a look. Think of it as “Stand by Me” in space.

headline: Markets Await Clues for Fed’s Next Move in May Jobs Report
abstract: With the fight over the debt ceiling resolved, investors are turning to other concerns, including inflation and interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Market futures are looking up today after the Senate approved the bipartisan debt limit deal, averting a national fiscal crisis. (More on that below.)

headline: Senegal Deploys Military and Blocks Social Media After Deadly Clashes
abstract: Demonstrators battled with the police to protest a two-year prison sentence given to a leading opposition figure. At least nine people died in the confrontations.
lead_paragraph: The government of Senegal said on Friday that it has deployed the military in the capital, Dakar, and other cities and shut down social media platforms in response to Thursday’s deadly clashes between protesters and security forces — a new escalation of tensions rarely seen in the West African country.

headline: Stuyvesant High School Admitted 762 New Students. Only 7 Are Black.
abstract: New York City’s specialized high schools represent perhaps the highest-profile symbol of segregation in the nation’s largest school system.
lead_paragraph: About 10 percent of offers to New York City’s most elite public high schools went to Black and Latino students this year, education officials announced on Thursday, in a school system where they make up more than two-thirds of the student population overall.

headline: Broadway’s American Airlines Theater to Be Renamed for Todd Haimes
abstract: Roundabout Theater Company’s flagship theater will honor Haimes, the transformational leader who died in April.
lead_paragraph: Roundabout Theater Company, the nonprofit with the biggest footprint on Broadway, has decided to rename its flagship theater, which currently bears the name American Airlines, in honor of its recently deceased and transformational leader, Todd Haimes.

headline: A Conversation With Gavin Newsom About the ‘California Effect’
abstract: Conor Dougherty of The New York Times spoke with the governor about leveraging California’s market power to influence policies in other states.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom is angry.

headline: ‘The Stakes Could Not Have Been Higher’: Biden Praises Debt-Ceiling Deal
abstract: The president addressed the nation from the Oval Office on Friday evening, after congressional passage of legislation to prevent economic calamity.
lead_paragraph: President Biden hailed a rare example of bipartisan cooperation in Washington on Friday, saying in his first prime-time address from the Oval Office that this week’s legislative budget deal averts economic calamity from a default on the nation’s debt.

headline: After Mass Shootings in Serbia, Few Are Ready to Give Up Their Guns
abstract: Two massacres have prompted the government to tighten already strict rules, but the nation’s gun culture is deep-rooted and complex.
lead_paragraph: He learned how to shoot a gun from his grandfather before he started school, and he fought in three wars as a soldier in the Yugoslav and then the Serbian Army during the Balkan conflicts of the 1990s.

headline: As Price of Oil Slides, OPEC Plus May Weigh Further Production Cuts
abstract: The group of major oil producers and Russia will meet this weekend to discuss a swoon in oil prices.
lead_paragraph: Just two months after surprising markets by announcing oil output cuts, officials from OPEC, Russia and other countries meeting in Vienna this weekend find themselves pondering whether they need to dial down production again.

headline: Teenagers Can Expect a Strong Summer Job Market
abstract: Amusement parks, restaurants, pools and other entertainment spots will need workers. Here’s what to know about finding a job.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers seeking work will probably find ample jobs with good pay available this summer, economists say.

headline: A Russian official says Ukrainian shelling has forced the evacuation of 2,500 people from his border region.
abstract: ‘The conditions are quite difficult,’ the local governor of the region said on social media.
lead_paragraph: About 2,500 people have been evacuated in Russia’s Belgorod region after days of Ukrainian shelling and incursions, according to the local governor, underscoring the rapid transformation of parts of the country’s western border into a war zone.

headline: The Treasury Paradox
abstract: Treasuries have been threatened by a possible U.S. debt default, yet they remain more attractive than just about everything else, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Treasury bonds have been at the heart of the debt ceiling drama.

headline: Ajay Banga Era Begins at the World Bank
abstract: The incoming president will be under pressure to juggle the global institution’s ambitions to combat climate change and fight poverty.
lead_paragraph: Ajay Banga officially became the 14th president of the World Bank on Friday and urged staff to join him in developing a “new playbook” for a global institution whose relevance has come into question in recent years.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Are the Hamptons still hip? Plus: How to spend 36 hours in Los Angeles, and the problematic investigation process for the James Beard awards.
lead_paragraph: Are the Hamptons still hip? Plus: How to spend 36 hours in Los Angeles, and the problematic investigation process for the James Beard awards.

headline: Imagining a New Filipino American Neighborhood Into Being, Starting With Food
abstract: In Los Angeles, a tiny pop-up market aims to become a cultural hub for a community.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, mellow ’90s R&B pumped from a tiny strip of a parking lot off Seventh Street in downtown Los Angeles. Cooks in sleeveless T-shirts danced as they worked, flipping mushroom skewers and longganisa patties on long charcoal grills.

headline: A Lost (and Found) John Coltrane Recording, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Claud, Silvana Estrada, Hannah Georgas and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Tina Turner Left Her Abusive Marriage, So They Could Too
abstract: The honesty and power of the singer’s accounts of abuse in the ’80s resonated with generations of women. Many saw pieces of her story in theirs.
lead_paragraph: For Felisha Robinson, it was the scene in the biopic “What’s Love Got to Do With It” in which Tina Turner runs across the highway, face bloodied from having been beaten by her then-husband and performing partner, Ike Turner, to escape her abusive marriage with nothing but 36 cents and a Mobil card in her pocket.

headline: What Makes a Great Performance? Backstage Drama, That’s What.
abstract: “The Motive and the Cue,” a new play in London, imagines fraught behind-the-scenes maneuvering by John Gielgud, Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor during rehearsals for a classic Broadway production.
lead_paragraph: “The classicist who wants to be modern, meeting the modernist who wants to be classical.” So says Elizabeth Taylor, summing up the fractious encounter between the revered Shakespearian actor John Gielgud, and her new husband, the actor Richard Burton. It’s 1964, Taylor and Burton are the most famous couple in the world, and Burton is rehearsing the role of Hamlet for a Broadway production that Gielgud is directing.

headline: For Turkey, Erdogan Victory Brings More Risky Economic Policy
abstract: The Turkish lira has hit a new low, and analysts see few improvements ahead as re-elected President Erdogan pursues unconventional economic policies.
lead_paragraph: Since winning re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has publicly doubled down on his idiosyncratic economic policies.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a dreamlike documentary from Brazil, a wry comedy from Quebec and a thriller set in the aftermath of Kosovo’s bloody civil war.
lead_paragraph: Ana Vaz’s debut feature is a work of nocturnal ethnography — a documentary that invites us into a thicket of sound and darkling images so we may emerge with a fresh understanding of the world around us. “It Is Night in America” captures Brasília, Vaz’s hometown in Brazil, through two layers of obfuscation. The film is shot on grainy, expired 16-millimeter film stock, and with a blue tint that turns even daytime scenes into something out of a twilight zone. The camera’s subjects are the wildlife of the city — owls, capybaras, snakes, foxes and more — seen in the Brasília zoo and on the streets; the soundtrack is a viscous fog of ambient noise — crickets, wind, vehicle horns — interspersed with recordings of phone calls to forest officers to report sightings of animals. These dreamlike visions all accumulate into a parable about aggressive urbanization in the name of progress. What happens when our faunal kin are made invaders in their own homes? Vaz suggests that we learn to look not just ahead but also sideways, at the things that take refuge in the shadows, in the background and in the night.

headline: The Best Blueberry Muffins in Boston
abstract: Also set for summer: roasted salmon with rhubarb, fast-track baby back ribs and pickleback slaw.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. In 1985, we published a recipe for the blueberry muffins that the pastry chef Gunther Moesinger served at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Boston. Marian Burros, who adapted the recipe, judged them among her favorite muffins in the city. A few years later, a reader wrote to Marian to say that, actually, the best blueberry muffins in Boston were the ones once served at the now-closed Jordan Marsh department store. Marian, ever intrepid, tracked down that recipe (above) so you can judge for yourself.

headline: With a Doppelgänger Novel, Deborah Levy Embodies Strangeness
abstract: The author writes about “the body in the world.” In her new book “August Blue,” she explores the split self via the story of a woman confronted with her double.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning in a Turkish cafe in ‌north London, Deborah Levy unknotted the silk scarf ‌around her neck in preparation. “The sharing breakfast has arrived,” the writer announced as plates of fruit, cheese and fried eggs were placed in front of her.

abstract: Are you prepared for the challenges of summer? Take our quiz to find out.

headline: Pence Won’t Face Charges in Documents Inquiry
abstract: The Justice Department informed the former vice president of its decision days before he was expected to announce his campaign for president.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has declined to pursue charges against former Vice President Mike Pence in its investigation into his retention of classified documents at his home in Indiana, informing him in a brief letter on Thursday night, according to three people familiar with the situation.

headline: The Debt Limit Deal and Climate Action
abstract: Tucked into the measure are changes to how the government approves projects at the center of the country’s climate goals.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Congress have wrangled a big political deal to raise the country’s debt ceiling.

headline: One Man’s Mission to Make Running Everyone’s Sport
abstract: Martinus Evans wants to make running more inclusive. His new book beckons back-of-the-packers to lace up.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday morning jog through Prospect Park, Martinus Evans was received like a conquering champion. Every few minutes, a passing runner would smile and nod, congratulating him as they sped by.

headline: The Great Debt Ceiling Drama’s Finale
abstract: Readers cheer the accord and the president but voice frustration over the process. Also: The Trump tape; anti-Trump Republicans; Amazon workers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 5 Dishes Everyone Should Know How to Grill
abstract: Practice the basics with these recipes, which all deserve heavy rotation during your summer cookout season.
lead_paragraph: Grilling may be the world’s oldest, most universal cooking method, but that doesn’t guarantee automatic success. Just ask the person who routinely burns the burgers or whose fish always sticks to the grate.

headline: Patriarchy, Shiv and That Last-Minute ‘Succession’ Decision
abstract: Still grappling with the finale of the hit HBO series? An article by a feminist theorist could be surprisingly helpful with understanding the deals that patriarchal systems offer women.
lead_paragraph: Did you watch the finale of “Succession” on HBO this week? If so, did the final shot of Tom and Shiv in their car make you think of “Bargaining With Patriarchy,” Deniz Kandiyoti’s 1988 article that is a classic feminist text?

headline: Foo Fighters Are Shaken Yet Still Standing on ‘But Here We Are’
abstract: The band’s first album since the death of its drummer Taylor Hawkins is explosive, emotional and inspired.
lead_paragraph: For all Dave Grohl’s grinning joviality, it’s easy to forget that his long-running rock group Foo Fighters was, initially, a solo project born of grief. The former Nirvana drummer recorded Foo Fighters’ self-titled debut album in autumn 1994 to fill the sudden, haunting quiet in the months after his bandmate Kurt Cobain’s death by suicide. His songs were pummeling but tuneful, and his sense of melody seemed just as innate as his command of rhythm.

lead_paragraph: Wordle Golf score card.

headline: Buffalo Leaders Weren’t Ready for Blizzard That Killed 31, Report Says
abstract: The city was hit with an overwhelming storm in December. Emergency warnings did not adequately convey how life-threatening it would be, according to a team of researchers.
lead_paragraph: Five months after a blizzard devastated western New York, killing 31 residents of Buffalo, a report released on Friday cited multiple failures in the city’s response to the blinding snowfall that whipped through the region for three days, trapping many people in their cars, homes and workplaces.

headline: Saudi Soccer League Creates Huge Fund to Sign Global Stars
abstract: A coordinated effort financed by the kingdom’s Public Investment Fund is offering huge paydays to some of the sport’s biggest stars if they join Saudi Arabia’s best teams.
lead_paragraph: The lists have been drawn up and the financing secured. Saudi Arabia is looking to lure some of the world’s best known soccer players to join Cristiano Ronaldo in its national league. And to close the deals, it is relying on money, the one commodity it knows it can offer more of than any of its rival leagues.

headline: Many in Guam Lack Power and Water a Week After Typhoon Mawar
abstract: The storm was the strongest to strike the U.S. Pacific territory in at least two decades.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people across the island of Guam remained without power, water and cellphone service on Friday, more than a week after the U.S. territory was pummeled by the strongest typhoon in at least two decades, which flooded homes, downed coconut and mango trees, and disrupted basic services.

headline: A Trans Model’s Path to Success and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: How to Use A.I. to Edit and Generate Stunning Photos
abstract: An A.I.-powered version of  Photoshop and the image generator Midjourney live up to the hype.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Welcome back to On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Would Like You to Know About His Workouts
abstract: It’s been a tough run for Meta, and the boss seems to be getting out some aggression with military-style endurance routines and Brazilian jujitsu.
lead_paragraph: Close your eyes. Picture Mark Zuckerberg. What do you see?

headline: Review: Julia Wolfe’s ‘unEarth’ Is Crowded Out by Multimedia
abstract: Not for the first time this season at the New York Philharmonic, a premiere was muddled by obvious, sometimes intrusive video art.
lead_paragraph: Since moving back into David Geffen Hall this season, the New York Philharmonic has tried to use its newly renovated, technologically adept space to give extra multimedia glamour to a few premieres.

headline: Ilya Kabakov, 89, Dies; Soviet-Born Artist Depicted Grimness With Wit
abstract: In often fantastical paintings, drawings and immersive installations, he explored the privations and indignities of the Soviet life he would flee, landing on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Ilya Kabakov, a celebrated artist whose immersive installations, paintings and drawings told sardonically witty stories about the dreams and interior lives of those who had endured the deprivations and degradations of the Soviet era he grew up in, died on May 27 in a hospital near his home and studio in Mattituck, N.Y., on the East End of Long Island. He was 89.

headline: Perfectly Grilled Chicken, Roasted Mushroom Larb and Spaghetti With Fried Eggs
abstract: With mom-approved sheet-pan shrimp with white beans and lemon.
lead_paragraph: Wouldn’t it be nice to work the grill in a state of total relaxation, with a drink in hand, instead of anxiously poking at the food to make sure you’re doing it right? I think so, and so I’ve decided that this is the summer I’ll finally get better at grilling. Hopefully I’ll progress from a place of basic competence to something like sure-handedness.

headline: Group Challenges Arkansas Law That Would Criminalize Access to Some Books
abstract: A lawsuit says the edict “forces bookstores and libraries to self-censor in a way that is antithetical to their core purposes.”
lead_paragraph: A new state law in Arkansas that could send librarians and booksellers to prison was challenged on Friday in a federal lawsuit filed by libraries, independent bookstores and publishers who said the legislation was unconstitutional.

headline: The Debt-Limit Deal Suggests Debt Will Keep Growing, Fast
abstract: Negotiations to prevent a government default reaffirmed that the big drivers of future deficits are all off the table in a divided Washington.
lead_paragraph: The bipartisan deal to avert a government default this week featured modest cuts to a relatively small corner of the federal budget. As a curb on the growth of the nation’s $31.4 trillion debt load, it was a minor breakthrough, at best.

headline: Nikki Haley’s Husband Will Deploy to Africa for Year With National Guard
abstract: Michael Haley, a major in the South Carolina Army National Guard, served in Afghanistan in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The husband of Nikki Haley, the Republican presidential candidate and former governor of South Carolina, is preparing to deploy to Africa with the Army National Guard, a military tour that is expected to last a year and for most of the G.O.P. primary race.

headline: On Reading ‘Beloved’ Over and Over Again
abstract: Salamishah Tillet, a Pulitzer-winning critic, discusses the book she has read the most over the course of her life — Toni Morrison’s classic novel of slavery and trauma.
lead_paragraph: For readers, a book’s meaning can change with every encounter, depending on the circumstances and experiences they bring to it each time. On this week’s podcast, Gilbert Cruz talks to Salamishah Tillet, a Pulitzer-winning contributing critic at large for The Times, about her abiding love for Toni Morrison’s novel “Beloved” — in which a mother chooses to kill her own daughter rather than let her live in slavery — and about the ways that Tillet’s personal experiences have affected her view of the book.

headline: Facing Death and Other Fears, and Coming Away Stronger
abstract: Lorenzo Vinti and Gregory DelliCarpini Jr. were married for only two years before they were hit with life’s difficulties, including Mr. Vinti’s cancer diagnosis and the death of his father.
lead_paragraph: A few days after their wedding on June 3, 2017, Lorenzo Vinti and Gregory DelliCarpini Jr. honeymooned in Thailand and Vietnam. Shortly after returning to Forest Hills, Queens, they decided to begin a new chapter in their careers and marriage.

headline: G.M. and Stellantis Paid $364 Million in Fuel Economy Fines
abstract: The automakers paid the federal government for falling short of efficiency standards for cars and trucks in recent years.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and Stellantis paid a combined $363.8 million in penalties for failing to meet federal fuel-economy standards for cars and trucks they produced in previous years, according to federal government documents posted on Friday.

headline: Put ‘Succession’ in the TV Pantheon
abstract: How dramatic unity, black comedy and political ambiguity made the show an all-time great.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I critiqued “Succession,” mildly, for the overestimation of elite power in its portrait of American democracy. Today I come to praise it — for a perfect series finale and a successful final season that together raised the show to the top rank of TV serials, the most successful examples of the central popular art form of our time.

headline: How to Play Cornhole Like a Pro
abstract: A few simple tricks will do wonders for your game.
lead_paragraph: A few simple tricks will do wonders for your game.

headline: A Weakened Arlene Could Bring Heavy Rain to South Florida
abstract: The first named tropical storm of the Atlantic hurricane season was downgraded to a post-tropical cyclone on Saturday. It was west of Key West, Fla., and moving southeast toward Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Arlene was downgraded to a post-tropical cyclone on Saturday, a day after it formed in the Gulf of Mexico and became the first named storm of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season.

headline: Moons, Junes and 7 Summer Tunes
abstract: Listen to a playlist that summons the heady days of a fresh season.

headline: Yes, You Can Make a Wedding Cake
abstract: It may just be the best gift you can give, and more manageable than you think with these expert tips.
lead_paragraph: Ever scroll through a friend’s wedding registry and feel uninspired by the cavalcade of appliances and trinkets? Consider going rogue and asking the couple if you can give them something major: a wedding cake.

headline: Padma Lakshmi Is Leaving ‘Top Chef’ After Its 20th Season
abstract: The host said she wanted to concentrate on her new show, “Taste the Nation,” her writing and “other creative pursuits.”
lead_paragraph: Padma Lakshmi announced on Friday that she was leaving the Bravo reality-competition juggernaut “Top Chef,” which she has hosted for 19 of the show’s 20 seasons, calling it a “difficult decision” made “after much soul-searching.”

headline: Ukraine’s counteroffensive promises to be deadly. These recruits signed up anyway.
abstract: “We’re going to die, probably,” one recruit said bluntly, as he trained on Friday with several hundred others at a military camp in Yorkshire, England.
lead_paragraph: As Ukrainian commanders gear up for a pivotal counteroffensive to push Russian forces back in Ukraine’s war, 23-year-old Vadym, a military recruit from Kyiv, says he wants to be on its front lines, even if it means losing his life.

headline: A Fresh New Way of Living
abstract: The Fresh Air Fund offers a summer escape from New York City.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the Bronx of the late 1980s, Emanuel Adjekum never felt he lacked things to see or places to go. He loved the city sounds, playing whiffle ball and simply being in the mix of neighbors who looked after one another, gathered for block parties and organized trips to Six Flags Great Adventure. He couldn’t imagine loving the outdoors more.

headline: In Finland, NATO’s Newest Member, Blinken Details Russia’s ‘Failures’
abstract: A speech by the U.S. Secretary of State struck a triumphal tone, while also warning against a rush to short-term solutions to the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Friday took the stage in NATO’s newest member, Finland, to say that further strengthening Ukraine’s defenses against Russia was a “prerequisite” for diplomacy to end the war in Ukraine and to warn against short-term cease-fires that might play to Moscow’s advantage.

headline: Lawyers Unable to Find Document Trump Discussed in Recorded Conversation
abstract: Prosecutors issued a subpoena for a description of military options for Iran mentioned by the former president during an interview. But Mr. Trump’s legal team said they could find no such document.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after learning that former President Donald J. Trump had been recorded discussing what appeared to be classified material describing military options for confronting Iran, federal prosecutors issued a subpoena to his lawyers seeking the return of all records that resembled the document he mentioned, two people familiar with the matter said on Friday.

headline: How to Fix the National Drug Shortage
abstract: The way health care providers negotiate drug prices has put the squeeze on manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: The Times reported last month that drug shortages in the United States are approaching record levels, with thousands of patients facing delays in getting cancer treatments, a drug that reverses lead poisoning, a sterile fluid needed to stop the heart for bypass surgery and antibiotics for strep throat, among many other medicines. One doctor described the shortages as a national health emergency.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Moving Bison Calf, Calling It an ‘Act of Compassion’
abstract: “It was in the water, begging for help to get out,” Clifford Walters said of his encounter in Yellowstone National Park. The calf later had to be euthanized.
lead_paragraph: Clifford Walters said he was only trying to save a struggling newborn bison when he made a sudden decision to push it up from a riverbank in Yellowstone National Park.

headline: Wonking Out: Zooming and the Future of Cities
abstract: Thinking beyond the doughnut effect
lead_paragraph: Back in 1999, when I was still a more or less pure academic teaching at M.I.T., I wrote a book on spatial economics with Masahisa Fujita, at the University of Kyoto, and Anthony Venables, then at the London School of Economics. We were able to do much of the collaboration remotely, exchanging chapter drafts by email. But to finalize the project, we felt the need to spend some time meeting face-to-face, gathering (as best I can remember) for about a week of intense work in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: NPR’s Terence Samuel Is Named Top Editor of USA Today
abstract: Mr. Samuel, who will start in July, has overseen NPR’s news gathering.
lead_paragraph: Terence Samuel, a top news executive at National Public Radio, will be the next editor in chief of USA Today.

headline: Claressa Shields Sets Aside Friendship in Goal of Dominating Her Sport
abstract: Shields, who is undefeated in professional boxing, faces Maricela Cornejo in Detroit on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The first time Claressa Shields and Maricela Cornejo went head-to-head, they co-starred in a YouTube video.

headline: Is It Wrong to Bring a Child Into Our Warming World?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on personal responsibility and climate change.
lead_paragraph: I have always loved babies and children. I babysat throughout high school and college, and do so even now as a full-time engineer. My fiancé was drawn to me because of how much he appreciated my talent with and love for children. We have many little nieces, nephews and cousins whom we love but don’t get to see often. We also have always been clear with each other that we would try to have biological children soon after getting married.

headline: For Her New Play, Tori Sampson Revisited Her ‘Black Power Household’
abstract: “This Land Was Made,” at the Vineyard Theater, is rooted in the playwright’s personal connection to a political movement’s awakening.
lead_paragraph: The narrator of “This Land Was Made,” the playwright Tori Sampson’s speculative account of the Black Panther Party’s powder-keg origins, is an aspiring writer named Sassy. “Consider me your time-traveling griot,” she tells the audience with wry buoyanc‌y, evoking the West African tradition of storytellers who propagated endangered legacies.

headline: A Biography Sheds Light on an Unknown Brazilian Hero
abstract: Larry Rohter’s “Into the Amazon” celebrates the exploits of Cândido Rondon, the trailblazing explorer, scientist, statesman and more.
lead_paragraph: True progress requires reckoning with the past. A plethora of recent books has revealed a much more complex story than that which many of us were taught — one of hidden figures and once-marginalized peoples whose contributions shaped our world. In “Into the Amazon,” the journalist Larry Rohter delivers an exhaustively researched account of yet another vital, challenging character generally unknown to the English-speaking world.

headline: More Than 260 Dead and 900 Injured in Train Crash in India
abstract: The rail disaster, in the eastern state of Odisha, was among the deadliest in a nation with a history of rail safety problems.
lead_paragraph: More than 260 people were killed and hundreds more injured when a passenger train derailed and struck two other trains in eastern India on Friday, officials said, a rail disaster whose toll was exceptionally large even by the standards of a nation with a long history of deadly crashes.

headline: Kaija Saariaho, 70, Pathbreaking Composer of Singular Colors, Is Dead
abstract: She brought new textures to modernist music, sometimes using electronics, and became the first female composer to have two operas staged by the Met.
lead_paragraph: Kaija Saariaho, a Finnish composer who was brought up in the male-dominated world of high modernism and who forged an artistic identity wholly her own as she rose to the top ranks of contemporary classical music, died on Friday at her home in Paris. She was 70.

headline: Deadly Train Derailments in India
abstract: Video showing rescuers trying to free people trapped in the wreckage after two trains derailed in the eastern state of Odisha.
lead_paragraph: Video showing rescuers trying to free people trapped in the wreckage after two trains derailed in the eastern state of Odisha.

headline: Redd Holt, Drummer on ’60s Instrumental Pop Hits, Dies at 91
abstract: He was a member of the Ramsey Lewis Trio when it reached the Top 10 with “The ‘In’ Crowd,” and he later had a hit as a co-leader with the funky “Soulful Strut.”
lead_paragraph: Redd Holt, a drummer who in the 1960s, before jazz fusion became a popular term, struck a beat that had both the kick of funk and the delicacy of jazz on a number of surprisingly popular instrumental records, died on May 23 in Chicago. He was 91.

headline: R.N.C. Rules for First Debate Pose Challenge for Underfunded Candidates
abstract: Republican presidential candidates hoping to join the first G.O.P. primary debate on Aug. 23 must have a minimum of 40,000 unique donors to their campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee on Friday laid out its criteria for candidates to qualify for the first Republican presidential primary debate, establishing a key fund-raising threshold and requiring candidates to pledge to support the eventual party nominee.

headline: Harvey Pitt, S.E.C. Chair Who Resigned Amid Scandals, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Pitt, who served under President George W. Bush, oversaw a swift reopening of stock exchanges after 9/11 but was tarnished by later missteps.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Pitt, a legal wunderkind who lasted just 18 months as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission under President George W. Bush, died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 78.

headline: Steve Garvey, All-Star for the Dodgers and Padres, Explores Senate Run in California
abstract: Mr. Garvey, 74, a Republican, said he would decide in the next few weeks whether to run for the seat of Senator Dianne Feinstein, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: Steve Garvey, a perennial baseball All-Star in the 1970s and 1980s for the Los Angeles Dodgers and San Diego Padres, said on Friday that he was weighing a run for the United States Senate in California as a Republican.

headline: This Year’s Spelling Bee Champion Didn’t Schweat the Schwa
abstract: After three years of studying, it took Dev Shah about 45 seconds to reach the apotheosis of his craft and become the national champion on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: After 14 rounds of words like “probouleutic” and “zwitterion” and “schistorrhachis,” Dev Shah, an eighth grader from Florida, had to wait through one more commercial break. If he spelled the next word correctly, he would win the Scripps National Spelling Bee.

headline: Sabalenka Skips French Open News Conference Citing Her Mental Health
abstract: The Belarusian player faced questions about the war earlier in the week from a Ukrainian reporter. On Friday, with the tournament’s blessing, she did not attend her postmatch news conference.
lead_paragraph: Aryna Sabalenka’s day began with a routine demolition of Kamilla Rakhimova of Russia that propelled the world’s second-ranked player, who is from Belarus, into the second week of the French Open as expected.

headline: What the Latest Investigations Into Catholic Church Sex Abuse Mean
abstract: About 20 state attorneys general have mounted investigations that have cataloged decades of abuse but yielded few criminal prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: The nearly 900-page report landed like a grenade when Josh Shapiro, then the attorney general of Pennsylvania, delivered it on a stage in Harrisburg, Pa., five years ago. It detailed widespread sexual abuse of children in the Catholic Church throughout Pennsylvania, and a “sophisticated” cover-up by senior church officials. Victims of abuse and their families, sometimes visibly weeping, joined Mr. Shapiro on the stage.

headline: Remains Match Traits of Missing Call Center Workers in Mexico, Officials Say
abstract: A grisly discovery in western Mexico this week has become a stark reminder of the fate of the country’s tens of thousands of disappeared people.
lead_paragraph: The News

headline: The U.S. Job Market Defies Expectations
abstract: Also, Biden is set to speak about the debt deal. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: American employers added 339,000 jobs last month, according to data released today — a surprisingly strong showing. The notable increase from the previous month reaffirmed the job market’s vigor despite a swirl of economic headwinds.

headline: Atlanta Prosecutors Contact Firms That Consulted With Trump Campaign
abstract: The two companies were hired in 2020 to investigate voter fraud, but reported that they found no proof that significant fraud had occurred.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Atlanta investigating election interference by Donald J. Trump and his allies recently contacted two consulting companies that were hired by the Trump campaign in 2020 to research myriad claims of vote fraud but ended up finding no proof that significant fraud had occurred, according to people with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Are You Even a Miami Heat Fan if You Watch the N.B.A. Finals Somewhere Else?
abstract: In South Florida, Flanigan’s, a fishing-themed restaurant chain, is the hot spot to watch the Miami Heat play the Denver Nuggets.
lead_paragraph: People are used to waiting in lines behind velvet ropes to squeeze into the hottest bars and clubs in Miami. But when the Miami Heat are playing for an N.B.A. title, the trendiest place to be is a fishing-themed bar and grill.

headline: Georgia Officials Target Bail Fund in Crackdown on ‘Cop City’ Protests
abstract: The arrest of three activists for financial crimes has been assailed as retaliation for lawful protests. Officials said the three had “facilitated and encouraged domestic terrorism.”
lead_paragraph: Atlanta police officers and agents from the Georgia Bureau of Investigation swarmed a house this week that has long been known in the city as a hub of activism.

headline: Two More Oath Keepers Members Receive Sentences for Sedition in Jan. 6 Case
abstract: A federal judge veered toward leniency with more junior members of the group who were involved in the attack on the Capitol, issuing lighter sentences than prosecutors had sought.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge sentenced two members of the Oath Keepers militia to less than four years in prison for seditious conspiracy on Friday, placing a brake on the government’s effort to impose lengthy terms on members of the group for roles in the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Don Bateman, Who Kept Airplanes From Crashing, Dies at 91
abstract: His cockpit warning system, which alerts the crew if an aircraft is heading toward a mountain, a building or the ocean, has saved thousands of lives.
lead_paragraph: Don Bateman, an engineer who invented a cockpit device that warns airplane pilots with colorful screen displays and dire audible alerts like “Caution Terrain!” and “Pull Up!” when they are in danger of crashing into mountains, buildings or water — an innovation that has likely saved thousands of lives — died on May 21 at his home in Bellevue, Wash. He was 91.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended paperbacks from the Book Review, including books by Patrick Radden Keefe, Emma Straub and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended paperbacks from the Book Review, including books by Patrick Radden Keefe, Emma Straub and more.

headline: U.S. Will Try to Bring China Into Arms Control Talks
abstract: The nuclear order established during the Cold War is under more stress than at any point since 1962, but efforts to negotiate with Beijing are unlikely to succeed anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: The White House will renew its effort to draw China into discussions about entering arms control talks, President Biden’s national security adviser said on Friday, and will attempt to establish a global accord that specifies that artificial intelligence programs can never be used to authorize the use of nuclear weapons without a human in the decision loop.

headline: As Kyiv Reckons With Deaths by a Shelter, Russia Evacuates Border Towns
abstract: In Ukraine’s capital, residents struggled with the question of who was to blame for a shelter closed off to two women and a child. In Russia, the authorities described evacuations in a border region.
lead_paragraph: Outside a children’s clinic turned bomb shelter in Kyiv, a huddle of passers-by wrestled with a question that has haunted Ukraine’s capital for over a day: Who is to blame for their neighbors’ deaths?

headline: Washington State Woman Is Arrested After Refusing TB Treatment
abstract: A judge issued an arrest warrant in February for a woman with tuberculosis who was later seen taking a city bus to a casino, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A Washington State woman who for over a year refused a court order to receive treatment for tuberculosis was taken into custody on Thursday, more than three months after a civil warrant was issued for her arrest, the authorities said.

headline: Thomas Buergenthal, Holocaust Survivor and Judge, Dies at 89
abstract: He said his survival of the Holocaust at 10 years old allowed him to understand “what it is like to be a victim of human rights violations.”
lead_paragraph: Thomas Buergenthal, who said his survival in a Nazi death camp when he was 10 years old equipped him to become a human rights lawyer and venerable judge on the World Court, died on Monday at his home in Miami. He was 89.

headline: Alabama Basketball Manager Says He, Not Player, Was at Deadly Shooting
abstract: A freshman player sued The Times after it placed him at a crime scene. The newspaper will correct its coverage.
lead_paragraph: A student manager of Alabama’s men’s basketball team said Friday that he had been a passenger in the car of a star player, Brandon Miller, during a January shooting in Tuscaloosa. One person was killed and Mr. Miller’s car was hit by stray bullets in the episode, which involved multiple vehicles.

headline: Churchill Downs to Cease Racing as It Investigates Deaths of Horses
abstract: The track, the home of the Kentucky Derby, is moving races to another location while officials look into why 12 thoroughbreds have died at Churchill Downs in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Horse racing will be suspended at Churchill Downs and moved to a different Kentucky racetrack as federal and state regulators continue to investigate the deaths of 12 horses at Churchill in the past five weeks, the company said in a statement on Friday.

headline: Haitian Businessman Gets Life Sentence in Assassination of Haiti’s President
abstract: Despite cooperating with prosecutors, Rodolphe Jaar was given the maximum term by a judge in Miami, the first sentence handed down in what the authorities say was a sprawling plot.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Florida sentenced a businessman and former drug trafficker with Haitian and Chilean citizenship to life in prison on Friday for his role in the 2021 assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti.

headline: Go Forth and Argue
abstract: For University of Chicago graduates, I celebrated the need to profoundly disagree.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, I was the invited speaker for the Class Day Ceremony at the University of Chicago, my alma mater. Campus political groups issued a statement of protest and a few students walked out of the ceremony. Here’s the speech I gave.

headline: Cynthia Weil, Who Put Words to That ‘Lovin’ Feeling,’ Dies at 82
abstract: With her husband and songwriting partner, Barry Mann, she wrote lyrics for timeless hits by the Righteous Brothers, the Animals and Dolly Parton.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Weil, who with her writing partner and husband, Barry Mann, formed one of the most potent songwriting teams of the 1960s and beyond, churning out enduring hits like the Drifters’ “On Broadway” and the Righteous Brothers’ “You’ve Lost that Lovin’ Feelin’,” signature tunes of the baby boomer era, died on Thursday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 82.

headline: President Biden Speaks About the Debt Ceiling Deal
abstract: President Biden addressed the nation after Congress passed legislation that narrowly averted the first-ever default on the country’s debt.
lead_paragraph: President Biden addressed the nation after Congress passed legislation that narrowly averted the first-ever default on the country’s debt.

headline: Three ‘Forever Chemicals’ Makers Settle Public Water Lawsuits
abstract: The $1.19 billion agreement, announced by Chemours, DuPont and Corteva, wouldn’t resolve all the claims against them.
lead_paragraph: Three major chemical companies on Friday said they would pay more than $1 billion to settle the first in a wave of claims that they and other companies contaminated drinking water across the country with so-called forever chemicals that have been linked to cancer and other illnesses.

headline: Tim Robinson and the Golden Age of Cringe Comedy
abstract: His sketch show, “I Think You Should Leave,” zeroes in on the panic-inducing feelings of living in a society where we can’t agree on the rules.
lead_paragraph: Tim Robinson loves spicy food.

headline: Stumper
abstract: Proceed with caution through this themeless puzzle by John Westwig.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is John Westwig’s seventh grid for The Times, his third Saturday puzzle in a row and his first construction for us that features span entries, which always bring me joy. These are terrific: a beautiful stack of three across the equator, all with a common trait, and a single, bright debut in the middle of the vertical column that serves as a deadpan revealer of sorts, if one would allow such a thing in a themeless puzzle.

headline: Kaija Saariaho: 11 Essential Works
abstract: This poetic composer, who died on Friday, wrote indelible, simmering operas, concertos, orchestral explosions, choral meditations and solos.
lead_paragraph: Kaija Saariaho, the poetic and powerful composer who died on Friday at 70, was also subtle and suggestive with words.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For This Runner, There Is No Shame in Bringing Up The Rear
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “You’re slow, buddy. Go home.”

headline: Editors’ Note: June 3, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on March 16 about a fatal shooting that involved members of the University of Alabama basketball team misidentified the person who was in the car with one player, Brandon Miller, when the shooting occurred.

headline: U.S. Defense Chief Vows to Continue Military Actions Near China
abstract: He said “risky intercepts” by Chinese planes in international airspace would not deter the United States and allies from patrolling, and he restated U.S. support for Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: The United States military will keep passing through Asian skies and seas where China has become increasingly pugnacious, the Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said in Singapore, where the Chinese defense minister’s refusal to hold talks with him has highlighted the rifts between Beijing and Washington.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Welcome to CringeTok, Where Being Insufferable Can Be Lucrative
abstract: On TikTok, cringe comedy creators are gaining large followings and brand deals by impersonating terrible people.
lead_paragraph: During a three-part special examining the crimes of the serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer that aired last November on “Dr. Phil,” Phil McGraw, the host of the daytime talk show, played a TikTok video of a 27-year-old woman named Stanzi Potenza as evidence that true-crime fandom had gone too far. In the video, Ms. Potenza said she was so obsessed with Netflix’s “Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story” that she stayed home from work in diapers to binge the series uninterrupted.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Tear Down a Crumbling Highway Nearly Everyone Hates
abstract: The Interstate 81 viaduct in Syracuse effectively destroyed a Black neighborhood when it was built, and it has been falling apart ever since. But getting rid of it is complicated.
lead_paragraph: These days, hardly anyone in Syracuse sees the hulking Interstate 81 viaduct as anything but a menace, an ugly 1.4-mile overpass that spews noise and pollution and has steadily worsened race relations in the city.

headline: India’s Train Crash: What We Know
abstract: Three trains, with more than 2,200 people onboard, were involved in the crash in Odisha State, the deadliest such disaster in decades. The death toll approached 300.
lead_paragraph: A train crash in eastern India on Friday was the country’s worst rail disaster in two decades, killing more than 270 people and renewing questions about rail safety in a country that has invested heavily in the system — relied on by millions of people every day — in recent years after a long history of deadly crashes.

headline: What Does Good Psychedelic Therapy Look Like?
abstract: As MDMA and psilocybin treatments become more mainstream, the therapy component has come under scrutiny. Here’s what’s common in many sessions — and what’s not.
lead_paragraph: Psychedelic therapy is on its way to becoming a mainstream medical treatment in mental health care. In 2020 and 2022, residents of Oregon and Colorado voted to legalize the use of psilocybin, the psychoactive ingredient in hallucinogenic mushrooms, and the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve it and MDMA, or Ecstasy, to treat depression and post-traumatic stress disorder by 2024.

headline: What It’s Like to Be a Queer Teenager in America Today
abstract: Social acceptance among young people has increased significantly in only a decade. But the mental health of L.G.B.T.Q. teens is suffering.
