lead_paragraph: Social acceptance among young people has increased significantly in only a decade. But the mental health of L.G.B.T.Q. teens is suffering.

headline: As Older TikTok Creators Flourish, Brands Are Signing Them Up
abstract: No matter what their age or finances, some elder influencers are finding that being on the app can bring them extra cash, or even help them extend their careers.
lead_paragraph: In one of Jenny Krupa’s TikTok videos, her neighbor has been hurt. Ms. Krupa’s concern? She wants to see “if the paramedics are hot.” In another video, she lets a man who ghosted her know she’s TikTok famous — and he “really screwed up.”

headline: Isabel Allende Has a Message: History Repeats Itself
abstract: In her new novel, “The Wind Knows My Name,” the prolific author introduces characters who narrowly survive real-life events.
lead_paragraph: If the measure of a civilization is the way in which it cares for its most vulnerable, by most standards, ours isn’t doing too well.

headline: Trump Lawyer’s Notes Could Be a Key in the Classified Documents Inquiry
abstract: M. Evan Corcoran recorded recollections of his legal work last year for Donald Trump. The recording is now in the hands of prosecutors, unnerving some aides to the former president.
lead_paragraph: Turning on his iPhone one day last year, the lawyer M. Evan Corcoran recorded his reflections about a high-profile new job: representing former President Donald J. Trump in an investigation into his handling of classified documents.

headline: Reconsidering the Reputation of a Magnet for Roman Scandal
abstract: In “Messalina,” Honor Cargill-Martin looks at the limited evidence with empathy, arguing that a notorious empress was also a canny politician.
lead_paragraph: The past is as much a foreign language as a foreign country, full of words and names that have lost their force. Not that long ago, one of the worst insults for a woman was “Messalina,” after the third wife of the Roman emperor Claudius, who was damned by antiquity as a sex-crazed schemer.

headline: Vigilante Justice Rises in Haiti and Crime Plummets
abstract: Civilians have killed at least 160 gang members in Haiti, a human rights group says. Residents say they feel safer, but others worry that it will lead to even more violence.
lead_paragraph: The 14 presumed gang members under arrest were arriving at a police station in Haiti’s capital, when a group of people overpowered the police, rounded up the suspects outside and used gasoline to burn them alive.

headline: Why Do We Brand the Summer?
abstract: Barefoot-Boy Summer? Side Chick Summer? It’s officially the season of out-there predictions for the summer ahead.
lead_paragraph: As trees open their blooms, the predictions come on like an allergy attack.

headline: Biden’s Debt Deal Strategy: Win in the Fine Print
abstract: The president and his negotiators believe they worked out a deal that allowed Republicans to claim big spending cuts even as the reality was far more modest.
lead_paragraph: Shalanda Young couldn’t sleep.

headline: 6 Podcasts to Make Sense of A.I.
abstract: As the technology’s rapid rise sets off alarms about the risks to society, these shows will help put the boom into context.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, artificial intelligence has advanced so rapidly that it feels dizzying, and a growing chorus of industry insiders, academics and politicians are sounding the alarm about risks to society. The effects have already been wide-ranging — colleges are struggling to weed out A.I.-generated essays, disinformation researchers are contending with a whole new category of deepfakes, and the threat of A.I. screenwriting is central to the current Hollywood writers’ strike.

headline: What You Don’t Know About Your Neighbors Can Hurt You
abstract: In “The Whispers,” Ashley Audrain explores the combustibility of secrets and rage among mothers in a small community.
lead_paragraph: The other night at dinner, a friend told me that her debut thriller would be promoted as upmarket women’s fiction. My heart sank. I know that bookstores and sales teams rely on categories, but this one has always rubbed me the wrong way. If women’s fiction is meant to illuminate the ways in which women exist in the world — casting a light on their triumphs, strengths, oppressions and fears — shouldn’t the books in this category also be essential reading for men?

headline: With Rainbow Flags, 2 Students Test China’s Shrinking L.G.B.T.Q. Space
abstract: The students at an elite college in China found themselves on a collision course with the authorities amid a crackdown on gay and transgender expression.
lead_paragraph: Karolyn Li still remembers reading the brochure from China’s prestigious Tsinghua University when she was in high school preparing to apply to college. It highlighted a graduate who had co-founded an L.G.B.T.Q. rights group, a suggestion of inclusivity on campus that surprised Ms. Li, who identifies as queer.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Ron DeSantis’s First Campaign Trip
abstract: He swung back at Donald Trump. He vowed to vanquish the “woke mob” and turn the country into mega-Florida. He had normal encounters with voters that didn’t become memes.
lead_paragraph: After his unusual, buzzy and ill-fated presidential debut on Twitter last week, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida carried out a far more traditional campaign tour this week, barnstorming Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina to sell himself as the strongest Republican alternative to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Muzz, a Muslim Dating App, Takes Its Matchmaking on the Road
abstract: The marriage and dating app, which assists young Muslims in finding “the one,” hosted a singles event in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: On a Thursday evening in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, about 250 Muslims gathered in a halal Italian restaurant for a singles dating event. Some of them shied away from cameras, citing privacy concerns, while others said they were afraid of appearing “desperate.”

headline: In Russian Schools, It’s Recite Your ABC’s and ‘Love Your Army’
abstract: The curriculum for young Russians is increasingly emphasizing patriotism and the heroism of Moscow’s army, while demonizing the West as “gangsters.” One school features a “sniper”-themed math class.
lead_paragraph: A new version of the ABC’s in Russia’s Far East starts with “A is for Army, B is for Brotherhood” — and injects a snappy phrase with every letter, like, “Love your Army.”

headline: How Did Birds First Take Off?
abstract: It took 150 million years for feathered dinosaurs to master flight and become the birds we see overhead today.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, “Jurassic Park” helped inspire 9-year-old Stephen Brusatte to become a paleontologist. So Dr. Brusatte was thrilled to advise the producers of last year’s “Jurassic World: Dominion” on what scientists had learned about dinosaurs since he was a child.

headline: The Exclusive, Elusive World of Real Tennis
abstract: “If you wanted to design a game that was going to put people off from playing it,” one court tennis enthusiast said, “you would probably design a real tennis court.”
lead_paragraph: Up on the second floor, hidden behind the facade of a tall Haussmann building not far from the Arc de Triomphe, is the Jeu de Paume Club, the only active court tennis club in Paris.

headline: ‘The Idol’ Creators: ‘This Is Not Going to Be for Everybody’
abstract: In an interview, the Weeknd, Sam Levinson and Lily-Rose Depp discussed their controversial new HBO drama. “Running headfirst into that fire is what thrills us all,” Levinson said.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the director Sam Levinson and his stars, Abel Tesfaye (a.k.a. the Weeknd) and Lily-Rose Depp, walked into the Lumière Theater at the Cannes Film Festival for the premiere of the first two episodes of their show, “The Idol,” to a standing ovation. The lights hadn’t yet dimmed, but pomp and celebrity fuel Cannes, where ovations are cheap. By the time the screening was over, the amped-up crowd was on its feet again and critics were racing out to fire off some of the most scathing reviews to emerge from this year’s event, with pans studded with barbs like “regressive,” “chauvinistic,” “skin-crawling” and “grim disaster.”

headline: Two Black Members of Native Tribes Were Arrested. The Law Sees Only One as Indian.
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling barred Oklahoma from prosecuting crimes committed by Native Americans on tribal land, but some Black tribal members are still being prosecuted because they lack “Indian blood.”
lead_paragraph: Early one morning in September 2020, Michael J. Hill called the police after hearing banging on the doors and windows of his home in Okmulgee, Okla. — part of a swath of the state that the Supreme Court had recently ruled to be tribal land.

headline: Can Old-World Ceramics Survive Modern Tastes?
abstract: A style of pottery made for centuries in a small Romanian town has recently become a hot commodity.
lead_paragraph: Sorin Giubega’s grandfather was a potter. So was his father. And at 8 years old, Mr. Giubega said, he started to play on a pottery wheel, too.

headline: Car Bombing in Russian-Occupied Ukraine Shows Reach of War
abstract: The blast in the Zaporizhzhia region of southern Ukraine killed a cafe owner who was registered to run in elections seen as an attempt to legitimize Moscow’s illegal annexation of the area.
lead_paragraph: A car bomb killed at least one person on Friday night in Russian-occupied southern Ukraine, according to Ukrainian and Russian officials, highlighting the war’s reach far beyond the front lines as Ukrainian partisans aim to undermine their occupiers.

headline: He’s the Biggest Power Broker in Canada Whom You’ve Never Heard Of
abstract: This week, the government announced a new clerk of the Privy Council, an unsung role that is one of the most important in the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the history of the Canadian government, few jobs have been as little publicized as the clerk of the Privy Council, soon to be filled by the recently appointed John Hannaford, a senior public servant and former diplomat. While most Canadians would be hard pressed to define his new job, Mr. Hannaford is not to be underestimated.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, May 27-June 2
abstract: Did you reach the highest level, or were you at sea?
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: Our Live-In Super Is Retiring. Should We Hire Another, or Contract It Out?
abstract: There are services for hire that will fulfill the duties of a building superintendent. Here are the pros and cons.
lead_paragraph: Q: Our long term live-in superintendent of a 50-unit co-op is retiring. Is it necessary to hire another live-in super, or can his responsibilities, which are relatively light, be contracted out?

headline: States Are Silencing the Will of Millions of Voters
abstract: Texas is joining dozens of states that have asserted dominance over cities through a practice known as state pre-emption.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott, Republican of Texas, is expected to sign a bill in the next few days that would make it immeasurably more difficult for cities in the state to govern themselves. The bill would strip cities of the ability to set standards for local workplaces, to ensure civil rights and to improve their environments, trampling on the rights of voters who elected local officials to do just that.

headline: What It Means to Be a Witness Three Generations Later
abstract: “The Postcard” by Anne Berest makes clear the urgency of third-generation Holocaust storytellers.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, I received an extraordinary message on Twitter.

headline: How Are Black Americans Progressing?
abstract: A series from Headway looks back at historical gains for their lessons today.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Jackie on My Mind
abstract: Before she was an iconic first lady, Jackie was a clever Camera Girl.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I think about Jackie Kennedy several times a day.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Has a Rare Quality for a Republican House Speaker
abstract: He actually seem to care about the institution he leads.
lead_paragraph: Among the various reassessments of Kevin McCarthy following his successful debt ceiling negotiations, the one with the widest implications belongs to Matthew Continetti, who writes in The Washington Free Beacon that “McCarthy’s superpower is his desire to be speaker. He likes and wants his job.”

headline: A High Court Held in Low Esteem
abstract: Readers discuss calls for stronger ethics guidelines for the justices and less partisanship.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This May Be the Most Important Thing Happening in the World Today
abstract: Fewer children are starving, fewer moms are dying and terrible diseases are retreating.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — One of the misimpressions people have about the world is that it’s going to hell.

headline: What Will Be the Theme of Summer?
abstract: As summer commences, so do our pronouncements for what it will be like. In branding, as in all things, moderation is key.
lead_paragraph: The last episode of season eight of “Seinfeld” begins with George learning that the Yankees have given him a three-month severance package. He declares that he’s going to live the next three months to the fullest. He’ll read a book “from beginning to end. In that order.” He’ll play Frisbee golf. “This is gonna be my time,” he declares. “Time to taste the fruits and let the juices drip down my chin. I proclaim this: the Summer of George!”

headline: My Father Taught Me the Benefits of Delusion
abstract: Buried in delusion is the hope that, despite all the odds and evidence to the contrary, things might just go your way.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, at the height of my father’s homelessness, he took me on vacation. By “height,” I mean shelters were a thing of the past. He was living on the street and didn’t have a car, so we took mine. The hot, white Florida sun ran along the corner of the windshield as we drove in a loop around Fort Myers Beach.

headline: Listen to This American Life: The Show of Delights
abstract: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: India’s Worst Rail Disaster in Decades Convulses Country Dependent on Trains
abstract: The disaster killed at least 288 people, and a preliminary government report described it as a “three-way accident” involving two passenger trains and an idled cargo train. Officials were investigating possible signal failure.
lead_paragraph: As giant excavators tried to untangle crushed trains on Saturday at the scene of India’s worst rail disaster in decades, a solemn scene was playing out at a small school a few hundred yards away.

headline: Larking, Library Sales and Yellow Silk Pajamas
abstract: An editor recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Who Is Liable for A.I. Creations?
abstract: Tools like ChatGPT could open a new line of questions around tech products and harmful content.
lead_paragraph: A string of challenges to Section 230 — the law that shields online platforms from liability for user-generated content — have failed over the last several weeks. Most recently, the Supreme Court declined on Tuesday to review a suit about exploitative content on Reddit. But the debate over what responsibility tech companies have for harmful content is far from settled — and generative artificial intelligence tools like the ChatGPT chatbot could open a new line of questions.

headline: The Dodgers and the Yankees Finally Look Like Themselves
abstract: Both teams have been winning with smoke and mirrors thanks to injuries. A series against each other in Los Angeles offers a test of just how good they are.
lead_paragraph: The juggernaut franchises faced off in the World Series 11 times between 1941 and 1981. But since then, they had been limited to 16 interleague games against each other heading into this weekend. And the last time they met, the Yankees and the Dodgers didn’t even look the part.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Treat a Workout Injury: Heat or Ice?
abstract: Sports physicians have long recommended the R.I.C.E. method — rest, ice, compression, elevation — for muscle injuries, but guidance is changing.
lead_paragraph: The prevailing theory on how to treat sprains and strains, especially from exercise, has been to follow the R.I.C.E. sequence — rest, ice, compression and elevation.

headline: U.S. Vows to Continue Patrols Near China and Urges Nuclear Talks
abstract: Speeches by two top officials illustrated the depth of concern over the rift between the nations. China called it provocation.
lead_paragraph: The United States pressed Beijing on two fronts this weekend, warning both of the near-term risks of military mishaps and of the looming dangers of a nuclear arms rivalry, prompting a vehement accusation from a Chinese general that Washington was stoking confrontation.

headline: ‘Doing the Work’ and the Obsession With Superficial Self-Improvement
abstract: I simply decline.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I noticed that the TikTok algorithm kept serving me videos of 20-somethings speaking directly to camera, admonishing me to “do the work.” They wanted me to know that they were doing the work and that doing the work would eventually turn them into self-actualized beings poised for greater success in life.

headline: 3 Israeli Soldiers Killed in Rare Attack on Egyptian Border
abstract: The suspect was identified by the Israeli and Egyptian authorities as an Egyptian security officer. The deadly event may be connected to a thwarted drug smuggling attempt, the Israelis said.
lead_paragraph: A man identified by the Israeli and Egyptian authorities as an Egyptian security officer entered Israeli territory on Saturday and killed three Israeli soldiers in two separate shooting incidents in a remote desert area along the border between the two countries, according to an initial investigation by the Israeli military.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: ‘Everything Changed’: The War Arrives on Russians’ Doorstep
abstract: With cross-border strikes, residents of the Russian region of Belgorod are starting to understand the horrors of war being waged at their doorstep.
lead_paragraph: Over the last five days of May, Ruslan, an English teacher in a Russian town near the Ukrainian border, heard the distinct sound of a multiple rocket launcher strike for the first time. Shelling would begin around 3 a.m., sometimes shaking his house, and continue through the morning.

headline: Nikola Jokic, an Elusive Superstar, Has a Hold on Denver
abstract: Jokic, the Nuggets center, may be the best player in the N.B.A., but he avoids the spotlight. Still, in his own way, he has endeared himself to a city hungry for someone to believe in.
lead_paragraph: About two miles from downtown Denver, the yellows, oranges and reds of a spray-painted mural fill the cracked, gray cement wall of a building that houses a temporary employment agency. The mural rises about 20 feet and depicts an expressionless Nikola Jokic next to a much more emotive Jamal Murray, his eyes narrowed and arms extended as though he is wielding a bow and arrow.

headline: India’s Worst Train Crash in Decades Kills Hundreds
abstract: Rescuers searched for victims at the crash site, where two passenger trains and a freight train were involved in what a government report called a “three-way accident.”
lead_paragraph: Rescuers searched for victims at the crash site, where two passenger trains and a freight train were involved in what a government report called a “three-way accident.”

headline: Judge Finds Tennessee Law Aimed at Restricting Drag Shows Unconstitutional
abstract: The law, one of the first aimed at curbing drag performances in front of children, had been on hold for nearly two months as the legal battle went on.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said late Friday that a law in Tennessee aimed at restricting drag shows was unconstitutional, saying it was overly broad and violated the First Amendment.

headline: Biden Signs Fiscal Responsibility Act in End to Debt Limit Crisis
abstract: Now that the bill is law, the nation will not risk running out of money to pay its obligations for two years.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed the Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023 into law on Saturday, ending for now the threat of economic calamity from a default on the nation’s debt and putting limits on spending for two years.

headline: Texas Governor Signs Bill Banning Transgender Care for Minors
abstract: The measure makes Texas the largest state to ban transition medical treatment for people under 18.
lead_paragraph: Greg Abbott, the Republican governor of Texas, signed a bill on Friday to ban hormone and puberty blocking treatments, as well as surgeries, for transgender minors.

headline: Coco Gauff Has a Chance to Play the Wise Veteran at the French Open
abstract: Gauff, now 19 and in her fifth season on the tour, took on Mirra Andreeva, who is 16 and the latest teenager to go on a tear in women’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: Tennis moves fast.

headline: These are some of the deadliest rail disasters in India’s recent history.
abstract: Friday’s crash is remarkable even in a country with a long history of train deaths.
lead_paragraph: The train crash that killed at least 275 people, and injured hundreds more, in India is remarkable even in a country with a long history of train deaths.

headline: New Hampshire Man Is Arrested After Threatening to Kill U.S. Senator
abstract: In a voice mail message, the man told the senator that he was “a dead man walking,” according to federal court documents. He was angry about the blocking of military promotions, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A man from New Hampshire faces up to 10 years in prison after threatening to kill a United States senator because he was angry that the senator was “blocking military promotions,” according to federal court documents.

headline: Growing Protests in Serbia Demand Social Changes After Mass Shootings
abstract: The protests, which have gathered momentum since two massacres in May, are denouncing a “culture of violence” and the increasingly authoritarian rule of the country’s leader.
lead_paragraph: Protests in Serbia over back-to-back mass shootings last month ballooned on Saturday into the biggest street demonstrations in the capital, Belgrade, since demonstrators toppled Slobodan Milosevic as Serbia’s president in 2000.

headline: Flying Colors
abstract: Rafael Musa’s Sunday puzzle sets the tone for June.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: MetLife Stadium Gets an N.H.L. Outdoor Doubleheader, of Sorts
abstract: Over two days in February 2024, the N.F.L. stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., will host the Rangers against the Islanders, and the Devils against the Flyers.
lead_paragraph: Outdoor N.H.L. hockey will make its debut in New Jersey next year when MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford will host a four-team doubleheader of sorts in the league’s so-called Stadium Series.

headline: DeSantis Relied Heavily on Big Donors in Initial Money Haul
abstract: The Florida governor’s campaign said it had around 40,000 donors in May, an average of more than $200 per donor — a figure far higher than is typical for a campaign heavily funded by grass-roots support.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida made a splash when he announced that he had raised a record $8.2 million in his first 24 hours as a presidential candidate. New figures disclosed by the campaign reveal that he relied heavily on larger contributors to set that record.

headline: Republicans Gather in Iowa to Ride, Eat and Disagree
abstract: Eight presidential hopefuls, with Donald Trump absent, spoke at an annual political rally in Des Moines to highlight their conservative bona fides.
lead_paragraph: As the politicians and Republican Party officials tossed out the red meat on Saturday at an event at the Iowa State Fairgrounds, Wayne Johnson, a 70-year-old farmer and financial consultant from Forest City, Iowa, had some quieter thoughts about the next president he would like to see.

headline: Hong Kong Remembered the Tiananmen Massacre, Until It Couldn’t
abstract: With candlelight vigils to the victims of the 1989 crushed student uprising in Beijing now only a memory, the anniversary is also a reminder of the freedoms Hong Kong has lost.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Hong Kong was the only place in China where the victims of the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy activists at Tiananmen Square in Beijing could be publicly mourned in a candlelight vigil. This year, Hong Kong is notable for all the ways it is being made to forget the 1989 massacre.

headline: Explosions Hit Southern Ukraine as Both Sides Brace for Counteroffensive
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky, in an unusually personal speech, urged his compatriots to show their gratitude to the country’s soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Explosions rang out across the front line in Ukraine on Sunday as both sides sought to gain an advantage before an expected Ukrainian campaign to retake territory captured by Russia, with the death of a 2-year-old girl underscoring the 15-month war’s enduring toll on civilians.

headline: The Big Number: 49%
abstract: Cubicles sit empty and office pantries wait for the one day a week when their workers might actually come in. Here’s what office life looks like today.
lead_paragraph: Cubicles sit empty and office pantries wait for the one day a week when their workers might actually come in. Here’s what office life looks like today.

headline: From Flowing Water to Flowing Data
abstract: “Stream” can indicate the steady movement of virtually anything, “cacophony” included.
lead_paragraph: In 1926, a bootlegger arrived home on Christmas Eve to find his wife in the arms of another man. His cheerful expression changed to one of woe; tears streamed down his jowls. He retrieved a revolver from under the tree and fired two shots.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Why We Write Explainers: An Explainer
abstract: New York Times guides to mystifying subjects may seem as if they come together in a matter of minutes, but they often take hours of research.
lead_paragraph: In early April, when former President Donald J. Trump was charged with 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, The New York Times published an article with the headline “The Case Against Donald Trump: What Comes Next?”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘I Whisked Myself Down to the Street in Search of a Guy With a Clipboard’
abstract: Seeking a crucial hour of quiet, observations while on the D and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How a Neurodiverse Musical Theater Artist Spends Sundays
abstract: Sarah Kaufman writes, acts, sings and makes podcasts and TikToks — and not to mention works a day job.
lead_paragraph: This month, Sarah Kaufman will play the witch in the musical “Into the Woods” at the A.R.T./New York Mezzanine Theater in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Inside the Complicated Reality of Being America’s Oldest President
abstract: President Biden is asking voters to keep him in the White House until age 86, renewing attention to an issue that polls show troubles most Americans.
lead_paragraph: There was the time last winter when President Biden was awakened at 3 a.m. while on a trip to Asia and told that a missile had struck Poland, touching off a panic that Russia might have expanded the war in Ukraine to a NATO ally. Within hours in the middle of the night, Mr. Biden consulted his top advisers, called the president of Poland and the NATO secretary general, and gathered fellow world leaders to deal with the crisis.

headline: In a Contentious Lawmaking Season, Red States Got Redder and Blue Ones Bluer
abstract: With single-party statehouse control at its highest level in decades, legislators across much of the country leaned into cultural issues and bulldozed the opposition.
lead_paragraph: America’s state capitals are as polarized as they have been in decades, with lawmakers imposing unflinchingly conservative or liberal agendas this year, even in politically diverse places.

headline: Caribou Meat and Moon Signs: Inuit Lessons for Soldiers in the Arctic
abstract: Humbled by centuries of fatal colonial expeditions, Canada’s military is learning Arctic survival strategies from the austere area’s only inhabitants.
lead_paragraph: A moon dog hung low over the horizon. It showed up on the first day of the Canadian soldiers’ patrol, and the Inuit rangers guiding them in the country’s far north spotted it right away: Ice crystals in the clouds were bending the light, making two illusory moons appear in the sky.

headline: What Happened When a Brooklyn Neighborhood Policed Itself for Five Days
abstract: On a two-block stretch of Brownsville in April, the police stepped aside and let residents respond to 911 calls. It was a bold experiment that some believe could redefine law enforcement in New York City.
lead_paragraph: It had been a quiet April afternoon until about a dozen teenagers began running up Pitkin Avenue in Brownsville, yelling and cursing. They were chasing a girl of about 14 and it was clear they wanted a fight.

headline: No Shame. No Sorrow. Divorce Means It’s Party Time in Mauritania.
abstract: It is common for people in this West African desert nation to divorce many times. And when they do, the women celebrate.
lead_paragraph: The henna artist bent over her client’s hand, glancing at the smartphone to get the precise details of the pattern chosen by her customer, a young woman living in an ancient desert city in the West African nation of Mauritania.

headline: Corrections: June 4, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about what to watch on television this weekend described incorrectly the new season of “Painting With John.” It is the third season of the show, but it has not been determined that it will be the final season.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For Women in Mauritania, Divorce Is Cause for Joy, Not Sorrow
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Snapchat is the new ululation.”

headline: After Walking Offstage, a Concert Pianist Changes Her Tune
abstract: An artist refashions herself amid personal and global crises in Deborah Levy’s new novel, “August Blue.”
lead_paragraph: In the work of Deborah Levy, certain elements recur in ever new arrangements: swimming, seafood, bees and silence; brokenness and recovery; the patriarchy. These themes are so consistent across Levy’s diverse body of writing, which includes poetry, plays, memoirs and novels (two of which have been Booker Prize finalists), that her real medium might be called recomposition.

headline: Lecher Actress Victim Spy
abstract: In “Lucky Dogs,” Helen Schulman spins a #MeToo case into an irreverent but surprisingly sympathetic look at two women on opposite sides of a sexual assault scandal.
lead_paragraph: That Harvey Weinstein hired a private international spy agency called Black Cube to help squash stories about his sex crimes always seemed stranger than fiction. Well, now it is fiction.

headline: Former CNN Chief Jeff Zucker Has a New Job at RedBird IMI. What Is It?
abstract: Mr. Zucker is C.E.O. of a $1 billion investment venture backed by RedBird Capital Partners and International Media Investments, an Emirati firm.
lead_paragraph: Since leaving CNN a year ago, Jeff Zucker, the network’s former president, has been on the hunt for deals, flush with $1 billion in backing from big investors in the worlds of media and finance.

headline: There Are Better Ways to Solve a Housing Crisis Than This
abstract: The overriding cause of homelessness in New York City is a lack of housing in the region, which has sent rents skyrocketing.
lead_paragraph: Politicians in New York, faced with a housing crisis that has driven more than 80,000 people into homeless shelters and renters to the brink, are simply throwing up their hands.

headline: How to Live When You’ve Lost Everything
abstract: In a new novel by Andre Dubus III, a man searches for hope and dignity after a long run of misfortune.
lead_paragraph: Tom Lowe is, well, low. Destitute. About as close to rock bottom as he can get. He was once a successful carpenter with his own business, a gorgeous house he designed and built himself — with the help of an (eventually disastrous) adjustable-rate mortgage — and a wife and child he adored. Now he’s divorced, estranged from his 19-year-old son and living in Section 8 housing in Amesbury, Mass. Worst of all, Tom, the narrator of Andre Dubus III’s novel “Such Kindness,” isn’t able to work.

headline: In a Year of Capitol Feuds, Oregon Has a Political Breakdown
abstract: Bipartisan collaboration was once a point of pride in Oregon, where Republicans have brought the Senate to a halt with a political boycott.
lead_paragraph: For the past month, the Oregon Senate has started its daily proceedings by dispatching a search party.

headline: It Took Cold Calculations to Get the Story First
abstract: “Battle of Ink and Ice” revives the headline-grabbing debate over which explorer reached the North Pole soonest — and which newspaper broke the news.
lead_paragraph: It began with a cable. “REACHED NORTH POLE,” the American explorer Frederick Cook wired on Sept. 1, 1909, to James Gorden Bennett Jr., the Paris-based publisher of The New York Herald, which teed up Cook’s 2,000-word “EXCLUSIVE ACCOUNT” of his discovery.

headline: These Activists Distrust Voting Machines. Just Don’t Call Them Election Deniers.
abstract: As election activists rally against new voting machines, they are drifting into territory now dominated by conspiracy theorists.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Lulu Friesdat made election integrity her life’s work. Drawing support from activists and academics, she co-founded Smart Elections, a nonpartisan group that is opposed to some voting machines that Ms. Friesdat believes would increase wait times and cost a small fortune to purchase and maintain.

headline: A Pacifist Sect From Russia Is Shaken by War, and Modernity
abstract: The Ukraine conflict is causing soul-searching among the Doukhobors, a peace-loving group that emigrated to Canada in 1899.
lead_paragraph: When he was growing up among the Doukhobors, a pacifist religious group that emigrated to Canada from czarist Russia, J.J. Verigin would sometimes arrive home from school to find naked elderly women trying to burn down his family’s house.

headline: Could Jeff Zucker Fix CNN? He Seems to Think So.
abstract: It’s been more than a year since he was forced from the top job at the network. Since then, he has made no secret of his frustrations with his exit — or his low regard for the man who replaced him, Chris Licht.
lead_paragraph: The seminar was to be on media leadership. Dozens of students filling a classroom at Yale University in April were there to learn about the business from a man who had commanded attention in TV control rooms and corporate boardrooms for decades before a stunning exit last year.

headline: The Jurors Sentenced a Missouri Man to Death. Now Some Are Not So Sure.
abstract: Michael Tisius was convicted of murdering two jail guards. He is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The murders were so brazen, so brutal, they stunned the people of Missouri.

headline: Who Owns the Benin Bronzes? The Answer Just Got More Complicated.
abstract: Restitution efforts were underway, fueled by news that a museum was being planned in Nigeria to house the treasures. Then a surprising announcement sowed uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: After years of ignored pleas and stonewalled requests, deals were finally coming together to return some of Africa’s most prized treasures to the continent.

headline: For These Bird Flu Researchers, Work Is a Day at the Very ‘Icky’ Beach
abstract: The H5N1 virus poses “a great unknown threat” to birds and humans alike. Understanding and thwarting it begins with excrement collection.
lead_paragraph: It was a glorious day for field work on the shores of the Delaware Bay. The late afternoon sun cast a warm glow over the gently sloping beach. The receding tide revealed a smattering of shells. The dune grasses rustled in the breeze. The beach vines were in bloom. And the bird droppings were fresh and plentiful.

headline: A Negro Leagues Star Is Still Sharing His Story
abstract: A pastor for more than 50 years, William Greason, 98, occasionally tells tales of a lifetime ago, when he mentored Willie Mays and played in the last Negro World Series.
lead_paragraph: The older pastor, wearing a long purple robe, ascended the steps to the pulpit. “God has always had a plan and a purpose for each of our lives,” the Rev. William H. Greason said in a slow, gentle voice. From the pews came affirmations of “Amen!” and “All right!”

headline: What Ozempic Reveals About Desire
abstract: Can new weight-loss drugs curb addictions?
lead_paragraph: Mary Boyer, a 41-year-old tech worker, started taking the drug Mounjaro last October to treat obesity. She has since lost more than 40 pounds, going from 267 when she started to 221 when she weighed herself recently. “I’m losing, like, a pound and a half a week pretty steadily,” she said.

headline: Could Air Travel Get Even More Miserable? Yes, and Here’s Why.
abstract: The looming headache of this summer’s travel season only strengthens the argument against the JetBlue/Spirit merger.
lead_paragraph: Were you planning on a last-minute trip to Orlando to visit Gov. Ron DeSantis’s favorite amusement park? “Prices are currently high for your search,” warns Google Flights. Well, yes they are.

headline: Ian Bostridge on Music’s Fuzzy Boundaries of Identity
abstract: The beloved tenor’s latest book and album emerged from a time when the pandemic forced him to question what exactly he does when he sings.
lead_paragraph: Spring this year has been a particular joy for touring singers like me. The cloud of Covid seems to have evaporated: Restrictions have been lifted, audiences have (nervously) returned and the prospect of being stranded in foreign parts with a positive test is gone, not to mention the diminishing threat of serious or voice-impacting illness. Things will never be the same — they never are — but some semblance of normalcy has returned.

headline: An Unstoppable Verstappen Wins Again
abstract: A wire-to-wire victory for Max Verstappen in Barcelona gave Red Bull seven wins in seven starts, and renewed talk of a season sweep.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton drove aggressively and overtook rivals, sometimes with apparent ease. George Russell gained several places by zipping up the run-off area at the start and held off a late challenge from Sergio Pérez. It was a great day for Mercedes.

headline: China and U.S. Lay Out Rival Visions for Asia as Ships Nearly Collide
abstract: China’s defense minister says the best way to avoid accidental conflict is for countries outside the region, like the United States, to leave and “mind your own business.”
lead_paragraph: Senior military officials from the United States and China used a conference in Singapore to push competing visions of Asia’s future security: a U.S.-led safety net of well-armed partnerships versus a region where China is the center of a new international order.

headline: A Mets Hall of Fame Class That Specializes in Honesty
abstract: As the team continues to celebrate its history, Gary Cohen, Howie Rose, Al Leiter and Howard Johnson were honored for their contributions over the years.
lead_paragraph: He sat in the audience watching it all, like a proud grandfather at a college graduation. Fred Wilpon, 86, had owned the Mets when their new class of Hall of Famers — Howard Johnson, Al Leiter and the broadcasters Gary Cohen and Howie Rose — made their marks with the team. At a news conference before the ceremony on Saturday, Wilpon beamed.

headline: The Sun Is Calling
abstract: Make your cookout, picnic or beach trip a little easier.
lead_paragraph: It’s June. The weather forecast is starting to look like summer, and I’m looking forward to my favorite sunny-day activity: eating outside.

headline: Rectal Cancer Patients Could Be Spared the Effects of Radiation
abstract: A large “de-escalation” trial suggests that tens of thousands of people annually may be able to rely on only chemotherapy and surgery to treat their illness.
lead_paragraph: Rectal cancer researchers have pulled off a daunting feat, demonstrating in a large clinical trial that patients do just as well without radiation therapy as with it.

headline: Here’s How We Can End the War in Ukraine
abstract: It is time for the United States to provide Ukraine with the support it needs to win against Russia.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Bodies Remain Unidentified as Relatives Struggle to Reach India Train Crash Site
abstract: Most of the victims’ families live in towns and villages hundreds of miles away, officials and medics said.
lead_paragraph: Families of the victims of India’s worst rail disaster in two decades were on Sunday still struggling to reach the town where the disaster happened. The delays meant that many bodies remain unidentified and unclaimed, local officials and doctors said.

headline: ‘None of Us Were Born Looking for a Screen. We Were All Born Looking for a Face.’
abstract: A conversation about nurturing our relationships in a digital world.
lead_paragraph: In the first two installments of this three-part series on the role of technology in our lives, I addressed practical questions: How do we help kids navigate a technological world? How do we discern what technology to adopt? There are also fundamental philosophical questions that new technology raises that often go unaddressed: How does technology change our understanding of what it is to be human? What assumptions does digital technology carry about what makes a good life? Our answers to these deeper questions silently guide the choices and habits we embrace in our daily lives.

headline: College Grads, Do ‘Follow Your Passions’
abstract: Advice for college graduates. Also: Right-to-shelter laws; the work commute; teaching reading; Ron DeSantis and Clarence Thomas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Chuck Todd to Leave ‘Meet the Press’
abstract: He will be succeeded by Kristen Welker, NBC’s chief White House correspondent and the co-anchor of “Weekend Today.”
lead_paragraph: Chuck Todd said on Sunday that he was stepping down from NBC’s “Meet the Press” after nine years in the moderator’s chair and would be succeeded by the network’s chief White House correspondent, Kristen Welker.

headline: Hollywood Directors Reach Deal With Studios as Writers’ Strike Continues
abstract: The tentative agreement includes improvements in wages and guardrails around artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: The union that represents thousands of movie and television directors reached a tentative agreement with the Hollywood studios on a three-year contract early Sunday morning, a deal that ensures labor peace with one major guild as the writers’ strike enters its sixth week.

headline: Einstein and a Theory of Disinformation
abstract: Time is relative depending on your frame of reference. Maybe truth is too?
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Ivanka Trump offered her Twitter followers a bit of wisdom from one of the world’s favorite geniuses to impress her legions of Twitter followers. “If the facts don’t fit the theory, change the facts. — Albert Einstein.”

headline: A Superquick Sicilian Pasta With Anchovies and Cauliflower
abstract: With a nutty, crunchy bread crumb topping.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Anna Francese Gass has a fine new recipe for pasta with anchovies, cauliflower and nutty bread crumbs (above), her adaptation of a Sicilian pasta alla Paolina con cavolfiore from Palermo, in which you melt oil-packed anchovies in a hot pan, then combine them with tomato sauce and a blend of cinnamon and cloves. A crunchy mixture of almonds and bread crumbs goes on top. The combination is incredible, a taste of the Mediterranean that you can enjoy wherever you hang your hat.

headline: The Man Reimagining Disney Classics for Today’s World
abstract: Sean Bailey is in charge of live-action remakes of films like “The Little Mermaid.” It’s a job that puts him in the middle of a partisan divide.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Sean Bailey has run Disney’s animated film “reimagining” factory with quiet efficiency and superhero-sized results. His live-action “Aladdin” collected $1.1 billion at the box office, while a photorealistic “The Lion King” took in $1.7 billion. A live-action “Beauty and the Beast” delivered $1.3 billion.

headline: For Claressa Shields, Repeat Titles Haven’t Come With Knockouts
abstract: It’s tougher in women’s boxing to get victories by stoppage, which forces champions like Shields to adapt their style.
lead_paragraph: When Claressa Shields threw a looping right hand during her middleweight title defense in Detroit on Saturday night, the punch would sometimes make contact and either clip the jaw of the challenger, Maricela Cornejo, or bounce off her left shoulder.

headline: In Israel, Tough Questions Follow Fatal Attack on the Egyptian Border
abstract: Israeli officials were investigating a series of mishaps and failings that led to the killings of three Israeli soldiers by an Egyptian border guard.
lead_paragraph: A breached emergency gate at Israel’s southern border with Egypt that was held closed only with plastic handcuffs; the passage of hours before two Israeli soldiers’ bodies were discovered; and the botched pursuit of an infiltrator that led to the death of a third soldier.

headline: Hong Kong Police Tighten Security on Tiananmen Square Anniversary
abstract: The police searched bags and detained demonstrators, including the pro-democracy activist Alexandra Wong, on the anniversary of China’s Tiananmen Square massacre.
lead_paragraph: The police searched bags and detained demonstrators, including the pro-democracy activist Alexandra Wong, on the anniversary of China’s Tiananmen Square massacre.

headline: Saudi Arabia Says It Will Cut Production to Stem a Slide in Oil Prices
abstract: OPEC Plus, the group of major oil producers, said it would continue its recent cuts in output, but Saudi Arabia said it would cut further for at least a month.
lead_paragraph: The group of major oil-producing countries known as OPEC Plus agreed on Sunday to embark on a complex effort to adjust production as it aimed to halt the recent slide in oil prices, including an additional cut in output of one million barrels a day by Saudi Arabia.

headline: Hundreds Were Mistakenly Told They Might Have Cancer, Test Company Says
abstract: Grail, which makes a blood test for cancer, said a vendor’s software issue caused inaccurate letters to be sent to about 400 customers last month.
lead_paragraph: A company that developed a blood test that detects dozens of types of cancer has acknowledged that about 400 of its customers were mistakenly told last month that they might have the disease.

headline: U.N. Body Condemns Torture of Guantánamo Prisoner Awaiting Capital Trial
abstract: The panel denounced the United States and seven other nations. It also called for the release of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, who is accused of orchestrating the bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations human rights panel has issued a damning report that blames the United States and seven other nations for the C.I.A.’s “torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment” of a Saudi prisoner who now awaits a death penalty trial at Guantánamo Bay.

headline: Peter Simonischek, Beloved Austrian Actor, Is Dead at 76
abstract: He played a prankster and adoring father in “Toni Erdmann,” the Oscar-nominated 2016 comedy that made him an international star, but he had long been a celebrity at home.
lead_paragraph: Peter Simonischek, an eminent Austrian theater actor who found international fame as the shambolic prankster and adoring father in Maren Ade’s Oscar-nominated 2016 German film “Toni Erdmann,” died on May 29 at his home in Vienna. He was 76.

headline: ‘Sor Juana’ Review: Undone by Love
abstract: Ballet Hispánico debuts two works: one about the 17th-century nun and poet Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz, and the other, “Papagayos,” featuring a supernatural hat.
lead_paragraph: In 17th-century Mexico, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz was a nun, a poet, an intellectual, a composer and a defender of women’s rights to education and the pursuit of knowledge. While not obscure, especially not in Mexico, she is something of an enigma, her life and work subject to many interpretations. It’s too bad that “Sor Juana,” a new creation by the choreographer Michelle Manzanales, doesn’t bring her into sharper focus.

headline: Investigators Seek Answers About Plane Crash That Followed Sonic Boom Scare
abstract: Four people died when a small private jet crashed in Virginia after failing to respond to air traffic controllers and flying over Washington, D.C. The military scrambled F-16s to intercept it.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities on Monday were investigating what caused an unresponsive private aircraft to fly over Washington, D.C., on Sunday, triggering a response by military jets that caused a sonic boom to be heard across much of the region before the small plane crashed in Virginia, killing all four people onboard.

headline: How the India Train Crash Unfolded
abstract: The sequence of events as three trains collided in one of India’s deadliest rail accidents.
lead_paragraph: The sequence of events as three trains collided in one of India’s deadliest rail accidents.

headline: Allstate Is No Longer Offering New Policies in California
abstract: Like State Farm, which announced a similar move last week, Allstate cited worsening climate conditions that had made doing business there difficult.
lead_paragraph: California property owners hoping to open new insurance policies are no longer able to do so with one of the nation’s largest homeowner insurance companies.

headline: Macron Faces Fresh Test as Outlook for French Finances Dims
abstract: S&P Global restated a negative outlook for France’s ability to repay mounting debt. Two other ratings agencies have lowered their views in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: To the list of challenges facing President Emmanuel Macron after raucous nationwide demonstrations over his pension measures, add a new one: a cascade of warnings over France’s finances.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Rescue Efforts End in India Train Crash
abstract: Plus, Beijing is forcing Hong Kong to forget Tiananmen Square.
lead_paragraph: Officials investigating one of the deadliest train wrecks in India’s history were focusing on the possibility that a signal failure had caused the disaster. The crash in the eastern state of Odisha on Friday left at least 275 people dead, and more than 1,100 injured, in what officials in a preliminary government report described as a “three-way accident” involving two passenger trains and an idle freight train.

headline: Kaija Saariaho’s Luminous Music Was a Personal Invitation
abstract: The Finnish composer, who died at 70, is remembered by one of her longtime collaborators.
lead_paragraph: The history of classical music is a history of creators of distinct originality. Its evolution has always happened through the work of visionary individuals and their ability to expand our understanding of the world through their works. These artists widen our horizons, invent, search, open doors and create paths for others. It takes extraordinary force, and courage, to follow an inner voice that no one else knows or understands yet.

headline: California Officials Investigating Flight of Migrants to Sacramento
abstract: The state attorney general said the migrants carried documents that specified a Florida government agency and a company that dropped migrants in Martha’s Vineyard last year.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen migrants from Venezuela and Colombia were abruptly flown on a private chartered jet to California and dropped off outside a church building in Sacramento on Friday, state officials said, accusing a contractor for a state-funded Florida program of transporting the group from outside a Texas migrant center under a false promise of jobs if the migrants agreed to be taken to California.

headline: In Utah, Scriptures (and Satire) Enter Debates Over Book Bans
abstract: In one school district, the Bible and the Book of Mormon were flagged for “sensitive materials review.”
lead_paragraph: Public schools are closed for the summer in Utah, leaving their libraries quieter than usual. But the books on their shelves are now the subject of a skirmish — one that is distinct from many other culture clashes over education in the United States.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands March Against Poland’s Governing Party
abstract: Supporters and members of opposition parties protested against the conservative Law and Justice party in Poland’s largest antigovernment gathering in years.
lead_paragraph: Supporters and members of opposition parties protested against the conservative Law and Justice party in Poland’s largest antigovernment gathering in years.

headline: Immense Crowds Protest Poland’s Governing Conservative Party
abstract: The country’s largest antigovernment gathering in years sought to reclaim the legacy of the Solidarity movement that led the struggle against a Communist system imposed by Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through Warsaw on Sunday in a huge display of opposition to the governing party before an October general election, summoning memories of Poland’s rejection of Communist Party rule decades before.

headline: Will Alcaraz and Djokovic Finally Get to Play Each Other at the French Open?
abstract: If everything goes right in the quarterfinals for Alcaraz and Djokovic, the two most dominant players on the men’s tour, the duel everyone has been waiting for will happen.
lead_paragraph: Eight days ago, 128 men began competing in singles at the French Open. Pretty much everyone has been focused on two of them.

headline: Silent Greeting
abstract: Eric Rollfing lets us in.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: India Vows Punishment for Those Responsible for Deadly Train Crash
abstract: Officials suggested human error, even sabotage, could have led to the crash that killed 275, as crews raced to restore service and families struggled to reach the site to identify loved ones.
lead_paragraph: The crushed train cars were cleared and the jumbled tracks straightened and rejoined, as workers labored on Sunday to quickly restore an important rail line in east India two days after the country’s worst train disaster in decades.

headline: Review: In ‘Love + Science,’ a Meet Cute Becomes a Medical Mystery
abstract: In 1980s Manhattan, two medical students find themselves at the forefront of the AIDS crisis in David J. Glass’s new play at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: The two medical students in “Love + Science” a new play by David J. Glass, quickly tumble into bed together and then spend five years too afraid to kiss.

headline: Money for Show Horses, Not Work Horses, on India’s Rails
abstract: Train travel in the country has gotten much safer, Friday’s disaster notwithstanding, but the government still puts high-profile projects ahead of basic safety improvements, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: In a country where major industry and political fortunes alike are often tied to a vast, interwoven rail system, India has lavished public resources on new trains, but its purse strings have been much tighter when it comes to ensuring the safety of those already racing along its tracks.

headline: Roger Craig, Teacher of an Era-Defining Pitch, Is Dead at 93
abstract: After winning three World Series as a player, Craig became a coach and spread the gospel of the split-fingered fastball, what one player of the time called “the pitch of the ’80s.”
lead_paragraph: Roger Craig, who pitched or managed in five World Series and changed the face of pitching in the 1980s as the guru of the split-fingered fastball, died on Sunday. He was 93.

headline: Citing Doubt, Officials Free Woman Convicted in 4 Children’s Deaths in 2003
abstract: An Australian jury found that Kathleen Folbigg had smothered her children. But scientists now say that they probably died from natural causes.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, Kathleen Folbigg was convicted of smothering all four of her young children. Australian tabloids called her the country’s worst female serial killer.

headline: The Evolving, Enduring Superstardom of Yannick Noah
abstract: To the world, Noah is the last Frenchman to win his country’s Grand Slam tournament. In France, his legacy and life loom over every man who has played tennis.
lead_paragraph: Yannick Noah was nervous.

headline: With Prince Harry to Testify in Hacking Case, Royals Prepare to Cringe
abstract: A media spectacle will unfold this week as the prince prepares to take the stand against newspapers he says invaded his privacy by hacking his cellphone.
lead_paragraph: Follow our updates as Prince Harry testifies in court.

headline: Man Missing in Iowa Building Collapse Is Found Dead
abstract: Two other men remained missing a week after part of a building collapsed in Davenport, Iowa. Documents issued by city officials show the owner had been warned that part of the building was unstable.
lead_paragraph: The body of one of three men missing after the partial collapse of an apartment building in Davenport, Iowa, has been recovered a week after a section of the six-story structure collapsed, a spokeswoman for the city said on Sunday.

headline: Takeaways From Nikki Haley’s Mild CNN Town Hall
abstract: The former South Carolina governor, who also served as United Nations ambassador under Donald Trump, emphasized her experience and vision. Will it be enough for her to stand out?
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, who was the first prominent Republican to announce a challenge to former President Donald J. Trump in the 2024 race, has yet to see her presidential campaign catch fire. On Sunday night, she had a fresh opportunity to make the case for her candidacy during a 90-minute CNN town hall in prime time, in an effort to emerge from the low single digits in polls where she has been mired.

headline: Donald Trump Wants to Throw America a ‘Most Spectacular’ Party
abstract: His proposed celebration to mark the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence is exquisitely on brand.
lead_paragraph: Break out those party pants: Donald Trump wants to throw America a birthday bash for the ages!

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Burden of Proof’ and the Tony Awards
abstract: A brother investigates his sister’s 1987 disappearance in a new true crime series from HBO, and the 76th Annual Tony Awards air live on CBS.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 5-11. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Investigations into a train crash in India.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in India have intensified the investigation into the causes of a devastating three-way train crash in which 275 people died. While officials were looking into the malfunction of an electronic signaling system, they had not ruled out human error — or even sabotage — and vowed punishment for those responsible, India’s railway minister, Ashwini Vaishnaw, said yesterday.

headline: Jacinda Ardern, New Zealand’s Ex-Leader, Is Now Dame Jacinda Ardern
abstract: Ms. Ardern, who stepped down as prime minister in January, said she had considered declining the title, but accepted it as a way to show gratitude.
lead_paragraph: Jacinda Ardern was awarded the title of dame on Monday for service to New Zealand, barely four months after ending her term as prime minister, during which she became the global face of a compassionate brand of liberal politics.

headline: Russia says it repelled a large-scale Ukrainian assault.
abstract: Ukrainian ground forces tried to break through Russian defenses in eastern Ukraine, in an area of the front that had not shifted significantly for months, and staged large-scale assaults across much of the frontline, Russian authorities and military bloggers aligned with the Kremlin said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian ground forces tried to break through Russian defenses in eastern Ukraine, in an area of the front that had not shifted significantly for months, and staged large-scale assaults across much of the frontline, Russian authorities and military bloggers aligned with the Kremlin said Monday.

headline: A Good Walk, Filmed
abstract: Peter Callahan, a filmmaker in Hastings-on-Hudson, is the writer, director and star of a movie that takes its entire story from one man’s afternoon walk around his town.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. I’m on duty today as my colleague James Barron caps off a well-earned vacation. Today we’ll talk to a local filmmaker who uses Hastings-on-Hudson, the New York City suburb, as his muse.

headline: Word of the Day: endeavor
abstract: This word has appeared in 299 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word endeavor has appeared in 299 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 25 in “An Art Patron’s Mission to Share Her Collection With the World” by Laura Rysman:

headline: Quotation of the Day: Vigilantes Make Streets in Haiti Calm Yet Uneasy
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 5, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Fear has changed sides.”

headline: Amsterdam Train Service Resumes After Disruption
abstract: The cause of the problem, which prompted widespread travel delays starting Sunday, had still not been determined.
lead_paragraph: Train service to and from Amsterdam was running normally on Monday afternoon after all trains were canceled a day earlier for technical reasons, even though the main problem had not been fully solved.

headline: A Political Earthquake in Texas
abstract: The highest levels of politics in the state are in chaos after the impeachment of a leading right-wing politician.
lead_paragraph: The highest levels of politics in the state are in chaos after the impeachment of a leading right-wing politician.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The 2024 G.O.P. Field Balloons, Adding 3 New Candidates
abstract: Chris Christie and Mike Pence and Doug Burgum announced their presidential campaigns this week.
lead_paragraph: The growing field of Republicans running for president expanded by three this week, with former Vice President Mike Pence, former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota getting into the race. The field continues to expand in part because hopefuls see opportunity in the struggle of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida to become the undisputed challenger to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: M.T.A. Looks Beyond Enforcement After $690 Million in Fare Evasion
abstract: A study proposed new approaches to get riders to pay to ride New York City’s transit system, including replacing subway turnstiles with fare gates that are harder to jump over.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has mostly relied on the same approach to deter people from sneaking into New York City’s subways without paying. As passengers trickle in, police officers stand next to turnstiles and write tickets to those who jump them.

headline: ‘Pass Him’: How a British For-Profit College Made Millions
abstract: Oxford Business College and others like it make millions, largely by recruiting immigrants. They operate in an opaque corner of the British education system.
lead_paragraph: College recruiters walked immigrant neighborhoods, knocking on doors or stopping people in shopping malls, selling the merits of a business-school education and adding a surprising offer: Get paid to enroll.

headline: No Corrections: June 5, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 5, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: How to Amplify Your Wordle Game
abstract: Introducing Wordle Golf, a new competitive way to play the daily guessing game.
lead_paragraph: According to the PGA, the odds of an average golfer making a hole in one are 12,500 to 1. The odds of solving Wordle on the first guess are around a couple thousand to one. (We can’t give away our secret sauce!) Basically, it’s easier to solve Wordle than to play golf.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A one-bedroom bungalow with a guesthouse in Los Osos, an 1870 Victorian in San Francisco and a three-bedroom cabin in Lake Arrowhead.
lead_paragraph: This house is a 10-minute drive from the El Moro Elfin Forest, a 90-acre nature preserve popular with hikers and bird-watchers. It is also close to the shoreline of Morro Bay and to Baywood Park Beach.

headline: I’m Traveling in Both the City and the Country. What Shoes Should I Pack?
abstract: A suitcase can fit only so many shoes. A reader wonders which will guarantee style and comfort on an all-terrain vacation.
lead_paragraph: Packing shoes for summer travel is like trying to solve a Sudoku puzzle: You need to figure out how all the exigencies add up in multiple directions before you make a choice. After all, shoes are bulky, so you don’t want to take too many, which means each pair has to play multiple parts.

headline: See the States That Have Passed Laws Directed at Young Trans People
abstract: More than 20 Republican-led states have passed bills regulating the lives of transgender children and adolescents since the start of 2021.
lead_paragraph: State laws restricting transition care for minors have surged over the past few months, as part of a Republican movement to regulate the lives of transgender youth.

headline: Please Don’t Call My Job a Calling
abstract: The idea that a job is a passion obfuscates the reality that a job is an economic contract — setting up the conditions for exploitation.
lead_paragraph: Last month, in an interview about Warner Bros. Discovery’s $50 million streaming profit in the first quarter of 2023, the company’s chief executive, David Zaslav, told CNBC that he believed the Writers Guild of America strike would ultimately end because of “a love for the business and a love for working.”

headline: In Richard Ford’s New Novel, One More Trip for Old Times’ Sake
abstract: “Be Mine” is the fifth book featuring Ford’s keen observer of American life, Frank Bascombe.
lead_paragraph: Richard Ford has long been our chief literary appraiser of bad men’s wear. Philip Roth also had an eye for this sort of thing. In “American Pastoral,” a loud shirt worn by a country-club type is “WASP motley.” But Ford is in a league of his own.

headline: Guess How Much This Debt Ceiling Nonsense Is Costing Us
abstract: The cost, financial and otherwise, of these debt-ceiling games is enormous.
lead_paragraph: Crisis averted; the debt ceiling has been raised. Before you turn your attention back to your summer travel plans and the challenges of inflation, let’s take stock of what these political shenanigans cost us.

headline: Where Whales, Puffins and Icebergs Jostle for Your Attention
abstract: Each spring, opalescent icebergs from the Greenland ice sheet pass through Iceberg Alley, off the eastern edge of Canada, on a slow-motion journey southward.
lead_paragraph: “I never trust the mind of an iceberg,” Cecil Stockley told me. He estimates its length, multiplies by five and keeps his boat at least that distance away.

headline: The Mystery of the Vanishing Kestrels: What’s Happening to This Flashy Falcon?
abstract: The number of American kestrels has dropped sharply. That goes against the trend for birds of prey, broadly seen as a conservation bright spot.
lead_paragraph: At first, people thought it might be a housing shortage.

headline: I’m in High School. I Hope Affirmative Action Is Rejected and Replaced With Something Stronger.
abstract: Asian students lose out with this college admissions system, but so do low-income ones.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court will soon decide the fate of race-based affirmative action in college admissions. Its ruling will be of particular interest to my class — high school juniors who would be the first affected by a change in admissions policies.

headline: A Gay Riot at a Doughnut Shop? The Legend Has Some Holes.
abstract: As Los Angeles prepares to commemorate the long-gone Cooper Do-nuts, accounts of a renowned 1959 uprising at one of its stores are being called into question.
lead_paragraph: The story still resonates: More than 60 years ago, Los Angeles police officers were routinely harassing the gay and transgender people who gathered at Cooper Do-nuts, a 24-hour spot in the city’s seedy gay circuit known as the Run.

headline: The Lifelong Gift of Sibling Friendship
abstract: Whether you’ve always been close, or wish you got along better, here’s how to bolster your connection.
lead_paragraph: Sisters Audrey Findlay, 75, and Barbara Rowe, 63,  start every weekday with an 8 a.m. phone call. An hour or so later, they head to work together at Findlay Rowe, the gift shop they opened 12 years ago. (Previously, they worked at the same health care company for 13 years, where Ms. Findlay was the general manager and Ms. Rowe was the payroll manager.)

headline: The Relief: Finding an Apartment. The Remorse: Living In It.
abstract: A couple felt obligated to take the first apartment they saw in a crazy rental market. Then they wanted to move again, but cooler heads prevailed.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Strassberg was fortunate. She had a deep and important relationship that lasted four years — with her studio apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: When Society Collapses, These Traders Win Big
abstract: In “Chaos Kings,” Scott Patterson profiles the financiers who build their portfolios around daily losses, and — when disaster strikes — seismic gains.
lead_paragraph: Almost everyone knows someone who seems to take a perverse pleasure in imagining worst-case scenarios. In life, this is usually a coping mechanism devised to cushion the blows of disappointment. In markets, it is a way to make billions of dollars.

headline: Nazi Symbols on Ukraine’s Front Lines Highlight Thorny Issues of History
abstract: Troops’ use of patches bearing Nazi emblems risks fueling Russian propaganda and spreading imagery that the West has spent a half-century trying to eliminate.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Since Russia began its invasion of Ukraine last year, the Ukrainian government and NATO allies have posted, then quietly deleted, three seemingly innocuous photographs from their social media feeds: a soldier standing in a group, another resting in a trench and an emergency worker posing in front of a truck.

headline: The Supreme Court Is Wrong About Andy Warhol
abstract: The artist was never concerned about copyright. He cared more about the right to copy, as an artistic method and a design for living.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court got it wrong.

headline: A Hijacked Plane, a Childhood Trauma Long Repressed
abstract: In a new memoir, the historian Martha Hodes explores her recollections of being held hostage on an airplane in 1970.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s and early ’70s, a new form of terrorism rattled the international order. Militants from a nascent Marxist-nationalist revolutionary movement called the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine began to hijack passenger planes — repeatedly, all over the globe — in an attempt to bring about the release of Palestinian prisoners in Israel and Europe.

headline: Schools Received Billions in Stimulus Funds. It May Not Be Doing Enough.
abstract: Pandemic aid was supposed to help students recover from learning loss, but results have been mixed.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic shut down schools across the country, the federal government responded with billions of dollars to help districts support remote learning, serve free meals to students and safely reopen schools.

headline: Why America Desperately Needed Ted Lasso
abstract: He is a broken human being who has not yet lost faith in the promise of wholeness.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I didn’t watch the first season of “Ted Lasso” until the second season was already underway on Apple TV+. I wish I’d been watching from the very beginning, when it first began streaming in 2020. It would have made me feel better during a national election season — not because the show is even winkingly political but because its characters are so utterly, inescapably human. Humanity felt sorely lacking from public life in those days.

headline: Twitter’s U.S. Ad Sales Plunge 59% as Woes Continue
abstract: In internal forecasts, the company projected that ad sales would keep declining, handing a tough challenge to its new chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk recently said Twitter’s advertising business was on the upswing. “Almost all advertisers have come back,” he asserted, adding that the social media company could soon become profitable.

headline: Blessings to You, Chris Christie
abstract: Biden-Trump, the sequel, has quite a few plot twists.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. A recent CNN poll shows that 20 percent of Democrats favor Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for the party’s nomination, 8 percent want Marianne Williamson and another 8 percent want someone else. That’s 36 percent saying they aren’t thrilled with the presumptive nominee. Do you think this is some kind of polling fluke or an ominous political sign for Joe Biden?

headline: ‘It’s Intoxicating’: 39 Tony-Nominated Performers on Why They Act
abstract: Each year we photograph Tony nominees, and talk with them about their craft. This year we focused on actors.
lead_paragraph: What draws an actor to the stage? There’s the desire to be seen, sure, and a passion for storytelling. For some it feels like a calling; for others, a compulsion. A way to connect, or to feel. In preparation for this year’s Tony Awards, which take place on June 11, we asked Tony-nominated performers to reflect on why they do what they do. And, as we have done since 2018 (with a break for the pandemic), we took their pictures.

headline: 144 Picture Prompts to Inspire Student Writing
abstract: A school year’s worth of short, accessible image-driven posts that invite a variety of kinds of writing.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been publishing our Picture Prompts series four days a week since 2016. Below, we’ve rounded up all the prompts we published for the 2022-23 school year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Hundreds Dead in India Train Crash, and Other Top Stories
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: The New Afghanistan, Through the Eyes of Three Women
abstract: How lives have changed under the Taliban’s increasingly restrictive rule.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: Millennials Just Keep Voting
abstract: They are voting at higher rates than younger adults once did, helping the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: In the 2018 elections — the midterms of Donald Trump’s presidency — turnout among younger voters surged. Almost twice as many people in their late 20s and early 30s voted that year as had done so in the midterms four years earlier. And they strongly backed Democratic candidates, helping the party retake control of Congress.

headline: In Rare Victory for Media, Hong Kong Court Overturns Conviction of Journalist
abstract: A court ruled that “substantial and grave injustice” was done to Choy Yuk-ling, an investigative journalist who also goes by the name Bao Choy.
lead_paragraph: In a rare victory for journalism amid a crackdown on the news media in Hong Kong, the city’s top court on Monday overturned the conviction of a prominent reporter who had produced a documentary that was critical of the police.

headline: ‘Apes Together Strong’ Review: Rooting for the Small Investors
abstract: The 2021 “short squeeze” of GameStop was a rare victory for the little guy. This documentary explains why the house — Wall Street wealth, that is — almost always wins.
lead_paragraph: If we accept the proposition that having money is sexy, we should also be able to admit that the most aggressive ways of making lots of money — the banking schemes and strategies that compound the wealth of the already rich — are not. Are they unfair to the working class? Certainly. Possibly criminal? Sure. But sexy, no. Among the more nefarious activities known to capitalism, big investing is particularly dry.
