The lifelong friends hit the sports jackpot this month when the Miami Heat and Florida Panthers both ran the playoff gauntlet and made it to the finals, where they are now vying for N.B.A. and N.H.L. titles simultaneously.

headline: See What Canadian Wildfire Smoke Looked Like in 8 Places This Week
abstract: Imagery from EarthCam shows how smoke from hundreds of wildfires in Canada enveloped cities in the Northeast and Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Imagery from EarthCam shows how smoke from hundreds of wildfires in Canada enveloped cities in the Northeast and Midwest.

headline: A Russian Pianist Speaks Out Against the War From Home
abstract: Polina Osetinskaya, a critic of the invasion who has stayed in Moscow even as the government cracks down on dissent, will play a Baroque program in New York.
lead_paragraph: When Russia invaded Ukraine last year, the pianist Polina Osetinskaya, who lives in Moscow, was distraught. She took to social media to describe a sense of “horror, shame and disgust,” and expressed solidarity with Ukraine, where she had often performed.

headline: What Wedding Night Sex?
abstract: If you fell asleep on the big night, don’t worry. So did many other (still) happily married couples.
lead_paragraph: Emily Lynen, 29, and Amber Lynen, 35, had every intention of having sex on their wedding night.

headline: Manchester City Bends the Story to Its Will
abstract: This season’s City might be Pep Guardiola’s coaching masterpiece: a juggernaut so fearsome that not even Hollywood writers dared suggest it could be beaten.
lead_paragraph: The writers of “Ted Lasso,” the acclaimed, sugar-sweet Apple TV comedy, never particularly worried about being hidebound by reality. The world they created was, after all, based on an inherently fantastical premise: an American coach with no knowledge of soccer succeeding in the tumult of the Premier League.

headline: Pope Francis and Silvio Berlusconi Both Hospitalized in Italy
abstract: The health conditions of two of Italy’s most prominent octogenarians have in recent years often kept the country in suspense.
lead_paragraph: Two of Italy’s most powerful octogenarians, Pope Francis and Silvio Berlusconi, whose health conditions have in recent years kept the country in suspense, were both in the hospital on Friday.

headline: She Gave the ‘Father of Gynecology’ His Prowess, Against Her Will
abstract: “Say Anarcha” is J.C. Hallman’s meticulous biography of the enslaved woman who suffered unimaginable horrors at the hands of a lauded doctor.
lead_paragraph: Medical journals are filled with untold stories. We may be able to imagine a moment — the pain of a biopsy, the devastation of a cancer recurrence. But in a research paper, these experiences are necessarily reduced, by the scientific method and privacy concerns, to numbers. Responders and non-responders. Recurrence and no recurrence. Mortality and survival. Rarely, one name leaps at us from the medical literature and demands a personal reckoning. And one such name is Anarcha.

headline: What We Learned From the Trump Indictment
abstract: The indictment said the former president had illegally kept documents concerning “United States nuclear programs; potential vulnerabilities of the United States and its allies to military attack; and plans for possible retaliation in response to a foreign attack.”
lead_paragraph: Indictments against former President Donald J. Trump and a personal aide, Walt Nauta, unsealed Friday reveal a host of embarrassing and potentially devastating new details about a yearlong investigation previously cloaked in secrecy.

headline: F.B.I. Investigating Spy Ring’s Political Contributions
abstract: Prosecutors are scrutinizing a series of campaign contributions made by right-wing operatives who were part of a political spying operation based in Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are investigating possible campaign finance violations in connection with an undercover operation based in Wyoming that aimed to infiltrate progressive groups, political campaigns and the offices of elected representatives before the 2020 election, according to two people familiar with the matter and documents related to the case.

headline: First Favorite Songs Are Like Sonic Baby Pictures
abstract: How a minor 1989 George Harrison single from the “Lethal Weapon 2” soundtrack opened a young listener’s ears.
lead_paragraph: What was your first favorite song?

headline: Don’t Wear the Goggles. Their Vision Is Bleak.
abstract: Why Silicon Valley wants you to live inside a virtual pod.
lead_paragraph: “I will not live in the pod,” runs a mantra on right-wing Twitter. “I will not eat the bugs.” It’s an anathema against the various corporate and governmental forces that supposedly want us all to abandon private property, red meat and other American freedoms in favor of a more sustainable future munching millipedes and living in tiny modular habitats, all under the benevolent eye of Greta Thunberg and the World Economic Forum.

headline: Love Letter: An Old Woman Raising Three Little Children
abstract: “What if I abandon them again by dying?”
lead_paragraph: Desiree Cooper’s grandchildren are her world. However, she never expected, or wanted, to be raising them on her own.

headline: A Sex-Shaming Rant About Margaritas Accidentally Became the Song of the Summer
abstract: Angel Laketa Moore, a comedian and actor​, remixed a ​sexually explicit Evangelical sermon​.
lead_paragraph: The early contender for the song of summer is a TikTok-fueled remix of a sexually explicit Evangelical sermon about margaritas.

headline: Are You Exposed to Too Much Noise? Here’s How to Check.
abstract: Noise can damage your heart as well as your hearing, but there are ways to measure your exposure and reduce your risk.
lead_paragraph: Chronic noise exposure is not just a nuisance, scientists say. It’s a health risk.

headline: The Big Number: 13
abstract: The head of CNN, Chris Licht, was ousted on Wednesday after just 13 months on the job.
lead_paragraph: The head of CNN, Chris Licht, was ousted on Wednesday after just 13 months on the job.

headline: Does Noise Affect Your Life? We Want to Know.
abstract: Noise is a vast — and largely unrecognized — threat to your health. The Times is collecting personal stories and noise measurements from readers like you.
lead_paragraph: Noise affects everybody differently.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kristen Ghodsee
abstract: The June 9, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kristen Ghodsee. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: What Do Binance.US’s New Rules on Trading Dollars Mean for Customers?
abstract: The company said that it would no longer allow trades with U.S. dollars on its platform. Customers were urged to withdraw funds by Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission sued it, the American arm of Binance, the giant cryptocurrency exchange, announced some painful news: It will no longer allow customers to trade on its platform using U.S. dollars.

headline: The Trump Classified Documents Indictment, Annotated
abstract: The indictment unveiled on Friday centers on Donald J. Trump’s handling of sensitive government documents after he left office.
lead_paragraph: The indictment unveiled on Friday centers on Donald J. Trump’s handling of sensitive government documents after he left office.

headline: ‘Deep Blue Sound’ Review: Searching for Orcas and Longing for Community
abstract: In Abe Koogler’s latest play, melancholy islanders try to band together to investigate where their beloved orcas have gone.
lead_paragraph: When a group of friends and neighbors on a Pacific Northwest island go caroling, they create an amusing cacophony: Warbling in mismatched tones and keys, they stand next to each other but not together. So goes the community in Abe Koogler’s new play, “Deep Blue Sound” — friendly and supportive but made up of individuals who can’t quite connect.

headline: N.Y. Lawmakers Pass Clean Slate Act as Session Fizzles to an End
abstract: As the 2023 session ended, the State Legislature passed a bill sealing old criminal records, but failed to reach a deal on a housing package.
lead_paragraph: After a grueling year marked by Democratic infighting, New York State lawmakers concluded the 2023 legislative session this weekend with few marquee policy wins and a notable failure to address the state’s critical housing needs.

headline: Wonking Out: How Low Must Inflation Go?
abstract: Should it be 2 percent or bust? Probably not.
lead_paragraph: Inflation has come down substantially. Gas prices are way down from their peak of $5 a gallon. As a recent White House report points out, grocery prices, which soared last year, are currently falling, and may well fall further in the months ahead:

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended reading from the Book Review, featuring titles by Chelsea Manning, Werner Herzog, and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, featuring titles by Chelsea Manning, Werner Herzog, and more.

headline: The Only Positive of Smokemageddon
abstract: Wildfire smoke creates local cooling — for a while.
lead_paragraph: The rivers of smoke pouring into the United States from Canadian wildfires have lowered temperatures by blocking sunlight from reaching the ground. The unseasonable coolness hasn’t gotten as much attention as the smoke. It may be the only positive aspect of Smokemageddon (or whatever the TV weather forecasters are calling this).

headline: Is ‘Flamin’ Hot’ a True Story? Well … Let Us Explain.
abstract: Richard Montañez, a janitor turned Frito-Lay executive, has said he invented the spicy snack. A new film tells his story, but the evidence isn’t on his side.
lead_paragraph: It is almost certainly a fact that Richard Montañez did not invent Flamin’ Hot Cheetos.

headline: 7 Decades Later, Arthur Miller’s ‘The Hook’ Comes Home to Brooklyn
abstract: An adaptation of Miller’s 1950 screenplay about a Red Hook longshoreman’s killing gets its first American staging aboard the Waterfront Museum.
lead_paragraph: On a barge in Red Hook, Brooklyn, dockworkers chant against their corrupt union boss. “We’re striking this ship!” yells the group’s leader. Old barrels sit on the edge of a bare stage as it sways beneath the actors’ feet.

headline: Boris Johnson Resigns From Parliament
abstract: The former prime minister quit after getting a confidential report about whether he had lied to lawmakers about lockdown-breaking parties.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s former prime minister, Boris Johnson, abruptly resigned his parliamentary seat on Friday, another dramatic twist in the career of one of the country’s most flamboyant and divisive politicians.

headline: Who Is Walt Nauta, the Other Person Indicted Along With Trump?
abstract: Mr. Nauta, as a valet while Mr. Trump was president, had unusual proximity to him, including at meals and on foreign trips.
lead_paragraph: Walt Nauta, the only other person indicted along with former President Donald J. Trump, has been serving as his personal aide after previously working for him in the White House.

headline: Summer Book Preview and 9 Thrillers to Read
abstract: Gilbert Cruz is joined by The Times’s thriller columnist, Sarah Lyall, to talk about some great suspenseful titles to check out this summer. And the editor Joumana Khatib gives her picks for books to look out for between now and Labor Day.
lead_paragraph: There’s no rule that says you have to read thrillers in the summer — some people gobble them up them year round, while others avoid them entirely and read Kafka on the shore — but on a long, lazy vacation day it’s undeniably satisfying to grab onto a galloping narrative and see where it pulls you. This week, Gilbert Cruz talks to our thrillers columnist Sarah Lyall about some classics of the genre, as well as more recent titles she recommends.

headline: Frenchette Bakery to Move Into the Whitney Museum
abstract: The bakery, from the restaurateurs Riad Nasr and Lee Hanson, is expected to open in the museum in the fall, in the Untitled space.
lead_paragraph: A flagship location for Frenchette Bakery will open in the Whitney Museum of American Art, replacing the Danny Meyer restaurant Untitled, which closed at the start of the pandemic.

headline: My Siblings’ Inheritance Depends on Whom They Marry. Is That Wrong?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on conditions parents attach to their wills.
lead_paragraph: Around a decade ago, my mom informed each of her children that she and my stepfather put a codicil in their wills disinheriting any of their children married to someone not recognized as Jewish by her local Orthodox Rabbinate.

headline: Here Is How to Help More Than 20,000 Canadians Displaced by Wildfires
abstract: Federal and provincial governments have pledged to match donations to the Canadian Red Cross for those affected by wildfires in Nova Scotia, Alberta and the Northwest Territories.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s ferocious wildfire season has burned nearly 10 million acres and displaced more than 20,000 people. Many have been able to return home, but others are still stranded away from their communities.

headline: Special Counsel Addresses Federal Criminal Charges Against Trump
abstract: Jack Smith, the special counsel, released an indictment detailing the government’s case that former President Donald J. Trump hoarded classified documents after leaving office and obstructed efforts to reclaim them.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel, released an indictment detailing the government’s case that former President Donald J. Trump hoarded classified documents after leaving office and obstructed efforts to reclaim them.

headline: Firefighters Battle Blazes in British Columbia
abstract: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced by wildfires burning across Canada.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced by wildfires burning across Canada.

headline: D-Day’s Beaches Face Rising Seas and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: William E. Spriggs, Economist Who Pushed for Racial Justice, Dies at 68
abstract: An educator who served in the Obama administration, he championed workers, especially Black workers, and challenged his profession’s racial assumptions.
lead_paragraph: William E. Spriggs, who in a four-decade career in economics sought to root out racial injustice in society and in his own profession, died on Tuesday in Reston, Va. He was 68.

headline: England Limits Use of Puberty-Blocking Drugs to Research Only
abstract: The change is part of a broader push in several countries to limit gender-related medical treatments for young people.
lead_paragraph: The National Health Service of England announced on Friday that it would limit the use of puberty-suppressing drugs to children enrolled in clinical trials. The change comes as the agency’s pediatric gender services have struggled to keep up with soaring demand.

headline: Thoroughly Reading a Men’s Catalog, Making No Purchases
abstract: With the release of the documentary “All Man: The International Male Story,” a writer reflects on his formative experience with the International Male catalog during adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Like Marti Muth — my high school English teacher who slid a copy of “The Normal Heart” across my desk in 1986 and said “Read this” — International Male knew I was gay before I did.

headline: Citronella Candles Don’t Really Work. Stop Buying Them.
Comedian’s Malaysia Joke Prompts Threats and a Diplomatic Incident
abstract: Jocelyn Chia’s line about the 2014 missing airliner was part of a Comedy Cellar set in April. But when video was posted this week, outrage poured in.
lead_paragraph: At the Comedy Cellar in Manhattan this spring, the stand-up comedian Jocelyn Chia performed a routine that she had reliably included in her sets for more than a year, about the historical animosity between Singapore, the city-state in Southeast Asia where she was raised, and its neighbor Malaysia.

headline: Nonprofit Health System Pauses Policy of Cutting Off Care for Patients in Debt
abstract: Allina Health, a large health system in the Midwest, had withheld care for patients who had $4,500 in medical bills.
lead_paragraph: Allina Health, a large nonprofit health system based in Minnesota, announced on Friday that it would stop withholding care from patients with outstanding medical debt as it “re-examines” its policy of cutting off services for those who have accrued at least $4,500 in outstanding bills.

headline: Biden Sticks to ‘Say Nothing’ Strategy on the Trump Indictment
abstract: President Biden and his advisers have concluded that commenting on the indictment would only feed into Republican accusations of a politically motivated prosecution.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his top aides in the West Wing, along with members of his administration and re-election campaign at all levels, are executing a carefully crafted strategy in response to the federal indictment of former President Donald J. Trump: Say nothing.

headline: Indictment Presents Evidence Trump’s Actions Were More Blatant Than Known
abstract: The accounts in the 49-page indictment provide compelling evidence of a shocking indifference toward some of the country’s most sensitive secrets.
lead_paragraph: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump that was unsealed on Friday provided compelling evidence that Mr. Trump’s handling of classified documents was more cavalier, and his efforts to obstruct the government’s attempts to retrieve them more blatant, than previously known.

headline: David Byrne’s ‘Here Lies Love’ Reaches Deal With Broadway Musicians
abstract: After the musicians’ union raised objections to the show’s plans to use recorded music instead of a live band, the show agreed to use 12 musicians.
lead_paragraph: “Here Lies Love,” the new David Byrne musical scheduled to start previews on Broadway next week, has bowed to objections by a labor union and agreed that 12 musicians will be part of the production.

headline: Battles Rage as Ukraine Tries to Retake Russian-Occupied Territory
abstract: Military analysts and U.S. officials said it was too soon to judge the success of Ukraine’s offensive, which is looking for weaknesses to exploit, in the face of fierce resistance.
lead_paragraph: Intense fighting raged across a wide swath of southeastern Ukraine for a second day on Friday, as Ukrainian forces attacked occupying Russian troops in multiple locations, while military analysts and U.S. officials cautioned that it was far too early to gauge the success of Kyiv’s offensive.

headline: The Case Against Donald Trump
abstract: Also, Canadian wildfires rage on. Herre’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors unsealed a 38-count indictment today accusing Donald Trump of mishandling classified documents after leaving the White House and obstructing the government’s efforts to reclaim them.

headline: How to Clear Your Home of Wildfire Smoke
abstract: Start with an air purifier.
lead_paragraph: Start with an air purifier.

headline: Harald zur Hausen, 87, Nobelist Who Found Cause of Cervical Cancer, Dies
abstract: When he proposed that the human papillomavirus caused cervical cancer, he was ridiculed. He persevered, and today a vaccine exists.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Harald zur Hausen, a German virologist who won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2008 for his discovery that the seemingly benign human papillomavirus, known for causing warts, also caused cervical cancer, died on May 29 at his home in Heidelberg, Germany. He was 87.

headline: Donald Trump Should Never Again Be Trusted With the Nation’s Secrets
abstract: He left the Department of Justice with no choice but to indict.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to overstate the gravity of the criminal indictment issued against Donald Trump late Thursday by a federal grand jury. For the first time, a former president has been charged with violating federal laws, laws that he swore to uphold just over six years ago. It is the first time a former leader of the executive branch has been charged with obstructing the very agencies he led, and the first time a former commander in chief has been charged with endangering national security by violating the Espionage Act.

headline: Helen Thorington, Who Brought Sonic Art to the Airwaves, Dies at 94
abstract: A pioneer in radio art and, later internet art, she created a blend of synthesizer compositions and found sounds that opened new artistic terrain.
lead_paragraph: Helen Thorington, whose haunting sonic compositions helped bring the medium of radio art to a national audience and provided the soundscape for filmmakers, artists and choreographers, died on April 13 in Lincoln, Mass. She was 94.

headline: Two Trump Lawyers Quit a Day After His Indictment
abstract: The lawyers, James Trusty and John Rowley, left the former president’s defense team as he faces the most serious legal threat of his career.
lead_paragraph: Two of former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers who had represented him in the classified documents investigation resigned from his legal team the day after he was indicted, according to a statement they released on Friday.

headline: Biden Names Border Patrol Chief as Immigration Policies Draw Scrutiny
abstract: Jason Owens has been the leader of the Del Rio division in Texas, one of the busiest areas for illegal crossings in the past few years.
lead_paragraph: President Biden named a new Border Patrol chief on Friday as U.S. immigration policies have come under renewed scrutiny following the end of Title 42, a pandemic-era restriction that allowed the authorities to expel most migrants for more than three years.

headline: Canada’s Ability to Prevent Forest Fires Lags Behind the Need
abstract: Provincial firefighting agencies are stretched thin, there is no national agency and it’s hard to get approval for controlled burns — factors that have exacerbated recent outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s capacity to prevent wildfires has been shrinking for decades because of budget cuts, a loss of some of the country’s forest service staff, and onerous rules for fire prevention, turning some of its forests into a tinderbox.

headline: Federal charges do not bar Trump from running for president.
abstract: The 45th president could continue his 2024 campaign even if he were convicted of a felony — though it would be extraordinary.
lead_paragraph: The second indictment of former President Donald J. Trump — this time over his hoarding of sensitive government documents — adds to the unusual questions raised by the spectacle of someone running for president while facing charges.

headline: A Trump-Appointed Judge Who Showed Him Favor Gets the Documents Case
abstract: The surprise assignment of Judge Aileen Cannon could be a setback for prosecutors as they unveiled a sweeping classified files indictment.
lead_paragraph: Update: A court clerk has clarified that Judge Aileen M. Cannon was randomly selected for the case and will remain as judge.

headline: Where Documents Were Found at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: These diagrams show the rooms at Donald J. Trump’s residence where prosecutors say he kept sensitive government documents.
lead_paragraph: These diagrams show the rooms at Donald J. Trump’s residence where prosecutors say he kept sensitive government documents.

headline: Carefully, Backhandedly, DeSantis Comes to Trump’s Defense
abstract: In a speech in North Carolina, Ron DeSantis drew on his experience as a Navy lawyer and suggested that either both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton should have been indicted — or neither.
lead_paragraph: Visitors from a foreign planet might think Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida had been delivered a tremendous gift this week when his main presidential rival was charged with mishandling the country’s national security secrets.

headline: Chris Christie says he found the case laid out in the indictment ‘devastating.’
abstract: The former New Jersey governor and federal prosecutor said he expected criticism from his fellow Republicans to grow.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie, the former Republican governor of New Jersey who is now running for president, called the facts in the indictment against his former ally Donald J. Trump “devastating,” and said that the small group of Republicans now critical of the former president’s conduct would grow.

headline: Tough to Grasp
abstract: Find some time for John Hawksley’s heavy-duty themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a beautiful and imposing grid from John Hawksley, who has constructed three previous puzzles for The Times, and they all have interesting geometry. This one’s wide-open center, composed of stacks of five 11-word entries in both the acrosses and the downs, is quite a centerpiece, and nine of those 10 entries are debuts.

headline: Toronto Blue Jays Cut Player Who Defended Anti-Queer Post
abstract: Anthony Bass had reposted a video on social media that called for a boycott of L.G.B.T.Q.-friendly companies.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Blue Jays cut pitcher Anthony Bass, 35, on Friday, after he drew backlash and boos from fans for reposting a video on Instagram that called Target and Bud Light “evil” and “demonic” for being supportive of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

headline: Trump Put National Secrets at Risk, Prosecutors Say in Historic Indictment
abstract: The indictment details evidence that the former president placed national security secrets in jeopardy and schemed to thwart the investigation into the matter.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors laid out an evidence-packed case in an indictment unsealed on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump had put national security secrets at risk by mishandling classified documents he took from the White House and then schemed to block the government from reclaiming the material.

headline: 4 Missing Children Found Alive After 40 Days in Colombian Jungle
abstract: Rescuers had been searching for the children — aged 13, 9, 4 and 1 — ever since they survived a plane crash that killed the three adults on board.
lead_paragraph: After 40 days in the Colombian rainforest, all four children who had been missing since the plane they were traveling in crashed on May 1 have been found alive, according to Colombia’s president.

headline: What to Know About Canada’s Exceptional Wildfire Season
abstract: Wildfires came early this year, are more numerous and have spread across much of the country, burning millions of acres as climate change turns more forest into a tinderbox.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the Canadian wildfires and air quality.

headline: Secretariat’s Legend Rolls on Like, Well, a Tremendous Machine
abstract: Fifty years after Secretariat clinched the Triple Crown with a runaway win in the Belmont Stakes, fans still long to connect with his story.
lead_paragraph: It was a performance for the ages, growing more mythic as time goes on. Having won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes in record fashion, Secretariat rocketed out of the starting gate on June 9, 1973 — his best start yet — and never let up. He moved “liked a tremendous machine,” as the announcer Chic Anderson put it, and crushed his competition by a whopping 31 lengths to win the Belmont Stakes on an uncomfortably warm but utterly joyous afternoon at Belmont Park.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In South Florida, a Packed Calendar Is Reason to Cheer
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I was very pessimistic when the playoffs began. But we’ve come to realize it’s all about the playoffs. You gotta enjoy it. You only get one chance.”

headline: Corrections: June 10, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about evidence found in phone messages that led to the downfall of Milo Djukanovic, the former president of Montenegro, misspelled the family name of a defense attorney. He is Mr. Begovic not Mr. Becovic.

headline: The Heat Say They Love Adversity. They Must Be Happy Now.
abstract: Only one team has come back from a 3-1 series deficit in the N.B.A. finals, but the Miami Heat seem confident they can be the second.
lead_paragraph: The Miami Heat would be the first to assess their path to this late stage of the season as imperfect. Pretty much everything has posed a challenge. The injuries. The losses. Even their experience in the play-in bracket — a loss followed by a come-from-behind win — seems apocryphal, or at least true to form, now that they are facing the Denver Nuggets in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: One Last Job? 60-Somethings With Mob Ties Charged in Jewel Heists
abstract: Four older men with extensive criminal records, including killings and a jailbreak, were charged this week in two brazen armed robberies in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: When four men were charged this week in the brazen armed robberies of two Manhattan jewelers, their ages suggested it might not be their first encounter with the criminal justice system.

headline: As Ukraine Launches Counteroffensive, Definitions of ‘Success’ Vary
abstract: Privately, U.S. and European officials concede that pushing all of Russia’s forces out of occupied Ukrainian land is highly unlikely.
lead_paragraph: After months of anticipation, Ukraine’s forces — newly trained on complex warfare tactics and armed with billions of dollars in sophisticated Western weaponry — launched operations on multiple fronts in the past week in an effort to dislodge entrenched Russian military units, a counteroffensive that many officials in the United States and Europe say could be a turning point in the 15-month war.

headline: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Belmont Stakes?
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert assess the contenders for the 155th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: National Treasure, coming off a victory in the Preakness Stakes on May 20, will try to add another leg of the Triple Crown to his résumé with a win in the 155th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Saycon Sengbloh Unwinds With Lo-Fi YouTube and Fireplace Vibes
abstract: The “Wonder Years” star takes care of herself with satin pillows, costume dramas and food that connects her to her Liberian roots.
lead_paragraph: When Saycon Sengbloh tried out for the role of Lillian Williams, the matriarch in ABC’s reboot of “The Wonder Years,” she was also auditioning to be her boss’s mother. The showrunner, Saladin K. Patterson, had decided that if he was going to remake the beloved sitcom — this time looking at the late 1960s through the lens of a Black family in Alabama — he was going to base the show loosely on his own family, starting with his parents, Bill and Lillian.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 3-June 9
abstract: Most players cracked the code, but there was one tough bird.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: How Do I Force a Developer to Finish Construction Work in My Building?
abstract: Legally, a developer doesn’t need to finish the common areas in a building to start selling apartments. But there is pressure you can apply.
lead_paragraph: Q: Last year I bought a condo in a brand-new six-unit building in Brooklyn. The common areas were still under construction when I closed. Fourteen months later, this work is still not done. My neighbors and I continue to press the developer, and periodically he’ll send a few workers to do a half day of work, hardly sufficient to finish the job. The developer still controls the board, but another apartment is under contract and if the sale closes, the owners will control the board. How can we persuade him to finish the work?

headline: The A.I. Revolution Will Change Work. Nobody Agrees How.
abstract: The tally of how many jobs will be “affected by” world-changing technology is different depending on who you ask.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, researchers at Oxford University published a startling number about the future of work: 47 percent of all United States jobs, they estimated, were “at risk” of automation “over some unspecified number of years, perhaps a decade or two.”

headline: A New Era of Wedding Dress Shopping
abstract: As more brides seek personalized shopping experiences and multiple distinctive designs, the bridal industry is shifting to accommodate them.
lead_paragraph: Four months before Ashley Moore’s April 2023 wedding, she still didn’t have a wedding dress. After hours of searching, and even buying and returning a gown she’d changed her mind about, she finally fell in love with a dress she found at a department store. But what she didn’t love was the price. So Ms. Moore scoured the internet and eventually found the same gown being sold online for less at Mytheresa, a luxury fashion company.

headline: People We Meet on Vacation
abstract: In her debut novel, “You Can’t Stay Here Forever,” Katherine Lin follows a young widow and her best friend to the French Riviera.
lead_paragraph: The Shady Husband Mystery is its own literary subgenre, in which industrious wives unspool their missing or otherwise absent spouses’ misdeeds. Notable titles include Laura Dave’s best seller turned Apple TV+ series, “The Last Thing He Told Me,” and Liane Moriarty’s “The Husband’s Secret.” Katherine Lin enters the canon with her debut novel, “You Can’t Stay Here Forever,” which opens with the consummate “good girl” attorney Ellie Huang Anderson smarting from the sudden loss of her “golden boy” husband, Ian Anderson, in a car accident.

headline: A.I. or Nuclear Weapons: Can You Tell These Quotes Apart?
abstract: Many experts on artificial intelligence are warning of its potential dangers and calling for regulation, just as others once did with the atomic bomb.
lead_paragraph: The comparison seems to be everywhere these days. “It’s like nuclear weapons,” a pioneering artificial intelligence researcher has said. Top A.I. executives have likened their product to nuclear energy. And a group of industry leaders warned last week that A.I. technology could pose an existential threat to humanity, on par with nuclear war.

headline: What Happens When A.I. Enters the Concert Hall
abstract: Artificial intelligence is not new to classical music. But its recent, rapid developments have composers worried, and intrigued.
lead_paragraph: When the composer and vocalist Jen Wang took the stage at the Monk Space in Los Angeles to perform Alvin Lucier’s “The Duke of York” (1971) earlier this year, she sang with a digital rendition of her voice, synthesized by artificial intelligence.

headline: Hospice Is a Profitable Business, but Nonprofits Mostly Do a Better Job
abstract: Nearly three-quarters of hospice organizations are now for-profit. Complaints of fraud and profiteering are growing.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly 20 years that Megan Stainer worked in nursing homes in and around Detroit, she could almost always tell which patients near death were receiving care from nonprofit hospice organizations and which from for-profit hospices.

headline: Masterpieces Galore: When Mozart Met the Enlightenment
abstract: In Patrick Mackie’s “Mozart in Motion,” the socially observant composer embraces modernity.
lead_paragraph: Musicians tend to be wary of ascribing specific meanings to music or making too much of a piece’s extra-musical associations. In one of his Norton Lectures at Harvard in 1973, turning to Beethoven’s “Pastoral” Symphony, Leonard Bernstein asked the audience to forget all about “birds and brooks and rustic pleasures” and instead concentrate on “pure” music. He then demonstrated how every phrase of the entire first movement is derived from little motifs of notes and rhythms in the first four bars of the score.

headline: Trump’s Case Puts the Justice System on Trial, in a Test of Public Credibility
abstract: The former president’s efforts to defend against multiple felony counts by discrediting law enforcement pose a grave challenge to democracy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has a lot at stake in the federal criminal case lodged against him. He could, in theory, go to prison for years. But if he winds up in the dock in front of a jury, it is no exaggeration to suggest that American justice will be on trial as well.

headline: Unanswered in Indictment’s Details on Trump’s Hoarding of Documents: Why?
abstract: The charging document offers some possible hints but does not establish that the former president had a goal beyond simply possessing the material.
lead_paragraph: For all the detailed evidence laid out in the 38-count indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of holding onto hundreds of classified documents and then obstructing the government’s efforts to retrieve them, one mystery remains: Why did he take them and fight so hard to keep them?

headline: Science Fiction From Latin America, With Zombie Dissidents and Aliens in the Amazon
abstract: A new wave of writers is making the genre its own, rooting it in local homelands and histories.
lead_paragraph: A spaceship lands near a small town in the Amazon, leaving the local government to manage an alien invasion. Dissidents who disappeared during a military dictatorship return years later as zombies. Bodies suddenly begin to fuse upon physical contact, forcing Colombians to navigate newly dangerous salsa bars and FARC guerrillas who have merged with tropical birds.

headline: Inside the Hunt for the Idaho Killer
abstract: After four students were stabbed to death in a house near a college campus, investigators scooped up data and forensic evidence, hoping for leads. A new DNA technique finally brought a breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after four University of Idaho students were found slaughtered in a house near campus last November, a growing roster of investigators desperately searching for answers had yet to identify a suspect or even find the murder weapon.

headline: How to Watch the Tony Awards
abstract: Here is all the information you’ll need to tune in on Sunday to the annual ceremony honoring Broadway’s top productions and performers.
lead_paragraph: When are the Tony Awards? We’re so glad you asked!

headline: How Could A.I. Destroy Humanity?
abstract: Researchers and industry leaders have warned that A.I. could pose an existential risk to humanity. But they’ve been light on the details.
lead_paragraph: Last month, hundreds of well-known people in the world of artificial intelligence signed an open letter warning that A.I. could one day destroy humanity.

headline: How a Scratch-Off Lottery Ticket Helped Me Become a Homeowner at 22
abstract: Sydney Bean was young, broke and tolerating a bad roommate to make ends meet. Then she won the lottery.
lead_paragraph: Our downstairs neighbors had been trying to get us evicted.

headline: The Hottest Thing in Real Estate Is a Loan From Two Years Ago
abstract: Real estate agents are pushing sub-3 percent mortgages as an amenity, just like marble countertops or a view of the mountains.
lead_paragraph: The only goal was to not lose money.

headline: ‘This Is the Final Battle’: Trump Casts His Campaign as an Existential Fight Against His Critics
abstract: Donald J. Trump delivered his first post-indictment public remarks on Saturday at the state G.O.P. conventions in Georgia and North Carolina, as his federal indictment dominates the political landscape.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday cast both his indictments by prosecutors and his bid for the White House as part of a “final battle” with “corrupt” forces that he maintained are destroying the country.

headline: Why Do Team Owners Raise the Championship Trophy First?
abstract: It’s a decidedly American tradition, even if it can be a buzz-kill.
lead_paragraph: What an ending. Your favorite N.B.A. team has just clinched a championship. The superstar, drenched in sweat, fulfilled his hero’s journey. The players are exhausted, but jubilant. Some of them are crying.

headline: A 20-Minute Boxing Workout to Build Strength and Endurance
abstract: One short workout can help you build fitness, achieve better balance and even ward off injuries. No punching bag needed.
lead_paragraph: Walking into a boxing gym can be an assault on the senses, whether it’s the ringing of a bell, the smell of accumulated sweat or the quick rat-a-tat of the speed bag.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Wants to Be President. Cheryl Hines Is Along for the Ride.
abstract: The “Curb Your Enthusiasm” actress is beloved in Hollywood. In supporting her husband’s campaign, is she normalizing his often dangerous ideas?
lead_paragraph: On a quiet Thursday in May, there was almost no indication that anyone in Cheryl Hines’s house was running for president. A hockey stick poked out from a bush in front of the Spanish colonial home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. Leaning up against a wall outside were several surfboards, caked with wax, at least one of which belonged to her husband, the 69-year-old environmental lawyer and vaccine skeptic Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who had announced his candidacy for the 2024 Democratic nomination only four weeks earlier.

headline: The Spy Who Called Me
abstract: For years, Spanish society has been rocked by revelations from the secret tapes of José Manuel Villarejo Pérez, a former intelligence agent now facing prison. He told me his story.
lead_paragraph: The wave of scandals that would engulf Spain began with a police raid on a wooded property outside Madrid. It was Nov. 3, 2017, and the target was José Manuel Villarejo Pérez, a former government spy. Villarejo’s name had been circulating in the Spanish press for years. He was rumored to have had powerful friends and to have kept dirt on them all. The impressive variety of allegations against him — forgery, bribery, extortion, influence peddling — had earned him the nickname “king of the sewers.”

headline: From ‘Pariah’ to Partner, Saudi Leader Defies Threats to Isolate Him
abstract: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has repeatedly leveraged Saudi Arabia’s wealth and influence to overcome international condemnation of the kingdom’s human rights violations.
lead_paragraph: President Biden vowed during his quest for the White House to make the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, a “pariah” over the killing and dismemberment of a dissident. He threatened the prince again last fall with “consequences” for defying American wishes on oil policy.

headline: When Chopping Down Trees Is a Gift to the Environment
abstract: We can’t afford to rob biodiversity to pay for the climate.
lead_paragraph: EMINENCE, Mo. — As dawn cracked one morning in mid-May, the botanist Neal Humke and I hiked up a hill eager to check on a landscape in progress. Five years ago, we cut nearly every single tree across 19 acres here, piled and burned the limbs and left the trunks where they lay. The goal was to restore one of the Ozarks’ rarest ecosystems, a type of dry, rocky grassland known as a glade. To bring back the grass, we had to clear it of trees.

headline: Colombia’s Mustard Lovers Grow Desperate Amid Saucy Shortage of Dijon
abstract: Colombians are scrambling to find the beloved French condiment as a new health law removes it from shelves, leaving a tangy void in their hearts and sandwiches.
lead_paragraph: In Colombia, a new illicit product is on the rise. Desperate consumers are sneaking it in suitcases from abroad, hoarding it in their homes, paying outrageous prices online and lining up at clandestine locations to buy it.

headline: Arizona, Low on Water, Weighs Taking It From the Sea. In Mexico.
abstract: A $5 billion plan to desalinate seawater in Mexico and pipe it to Phoenix is testing the notion that desert cities can keep growing as the Earth warms.
lead_paragraph: Fifty miles south of the U.S. border, at the edge of a city on the Gulf of California, a few acres of dusty shrubs could determine the future of Arizona.

headline: With Probes of Russian Lines, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Takes Shape
abstract: Ukraine is using its new arsenal of Western tanks and armored vehicles in what is expected to be one of the largest military operations in Europe since World War II.
lead_paragraph: In the south, Ukrainian soldiers are fighting on an unforgiving landscape, table-flat farmland with little cover for troops trying to advance.

headline: Orange and Smoky Skies Over a Province That Rolled Back Climate Measures
abstract: Doug Ford, Ontario’s premier, has a long history of opposition to renewable energy programs and an agenda that favors highway construction.
lead_paragraph: This was a week when residents of the three largest cities in Eastern Canada — Ottawa, Toronto and Montreal — experienced a phenomenon that has become all too familiar to anyone who lives in Vancouver, Edmonton and Calgary.

headline: Trump’s Indictment Is Unavoidably Political
abstract: The prosecutors’ audience is not only the judge and jurors. It is also the American public.
lead_paragraph: The public filings in most legal cases are of secondary importance. What happens in the courtroom matters far more. But the United States of America v. Donald J. Trump is obviously not a typical case.

headline: Is Masculinity in Crisis?
abstract: Readers discuss a column by David French about the virtues of masculinity and how they get distorted.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bathroom Reading at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: Let’s Make America Great Again — by getting Trump out of politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s shocking how easy it is to imagine Donald Trump campaigning for the presidency from prison.

headline: Does the U.S. Government Want You to Believe in U.F.O.s?
abstract: Are there crashed alien ships kept hidden in hangars?
lead_paragraph: In U.F.O. arcana, one of the figures claiming a whistle-blower’s knowledge of a secret U.S. program to reverse-engineer recovered alien technology is a man named Bob Lazar.

headline: Harry Is a More Interesting Prince Than We Deserved
abstract: He is not the first royal to give evidence. But he is the first to go to court to seek revenge for his life.
lead_paragraph: CORNWALL, England — The urge to fictionalize Prince Harry is addictive. If you are a monarchist, that is what he is for. For the last few years he’s been trying to reclaim himself from our imagined account. Most recently in court 15 in the Rolls Building, London, earlier this week.

headline: Turning the Tide on Animal Suffering
abstract: Peter Singer and the modern animal rights movement have had a global impact — but there’s so much left to do.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, a half-dozen graduate students at Oxford University held what was perhaps the first protest of the modern animal rights movement. They insisted that respecting animals was a moral imperative.

headline: Listen Early to This American Life: Must Be Rats on the Brain
abstract: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows that we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: It’s Not Just Men and Boys Who Are Struggling Right Now
abstract: Don’t forget about the women dying deaths of despair.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a lot of chatter lately about the Problem With Men. Several books have been published that focus on the declining fortunes of American males — notably Richard Reeves’s “Of Boys and Men” and Senator Josh Hawley’s “Manhood.” As summarized by my colleagues on their new podcast “Matter of Opinion”: Men are less likely to graduate from college now, they’re lonely, they’re more likely to die deaths of despair, grapple with alcohol and drug abuse, and they’re participating less in the labor market.

headline: After LIV Golf, What Will Be the Next Saudi Sports Bet?
abstract: The kingdom’s enormous sovereign wealth fund, which backed the golf series, has an appetite for sports. Its deal with the PGA Tour may pave the way for more investments.
lead_paragraph: When the Saudi Arabian-backed LIV Golf series announced an agreement to join with the PGA Tour on Tuesday, it shocked deal makers across the sports world.

headline: Boris Johnson’s Comeback Hopes May Be Dimmer Than He Thinks
abstract: The former British prime minister, who resigned from Parliament on Friday, has found his way back into voters’ good graces before. But analysts say there is now almost no plausible path back to power for him.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to view Boris Johnson’s sudden resignation from Britain’s Parliament on Friday evening as merely another twist in a serpentine career, a tactical retreat rather than a political epitaph.

headline: Appeals Panel Is Examining Guantánamo Judge’s Next Job on Ethics Grounds
abstract: The issue has cast a cloud over the coming proceedings in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case, which are scheduled to last three weeks starting Monday.
lead_paragraph: An appeals panel on Friday limited the authority of the judge presiding in hearings in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case while it considers an ethics challenge, the latest obstacle in the slow-moving path to trial in the longest-running war crimes prosecution at Guantánamo Bay.

headline: Michael Batayeh, Comedian and ‘Breaking Bad’ Actor, Dies at 52
abstract: Mr. Batayeh starred in three episodes of the Emmy-winning series and performed stand-up comedy.
lead_paragraph: Michael Batayeh, an actor best known for his brief role in the Emmy-winning series “Breaking Bad” and a comedian who was popular in the Arab-American community, died at his home in Ypsilanti, Mich. He was 52.

headline: Worldwide, Trump’s Latest Legal Woes Draw Outrage, and Shrugs
abstract: Allies and rivals alike, beholding the messiness of America, must calculate the risks and opportunities in the latest plot twist in Donald Trump’s legal troubles.
lead_paragraph: As details emerged from the indictment charging former President Donald J. Trump with mishandling classified documents, global reaction ranged from strategic silence to unbridled outrage, with room in between for world-weary shrugs, wild conspiracy theories and ominous predictions of American decline.

headline: Syrian Refugee Charged With Attempted Murder After Stabbing in France
abstract: A local prosecutor said that the six victims of the attack, two adults and four very young children, were no longer in life-threatening conditions.
lead_paragraph: A homeless Syrian man in his 30s was charged with attempted murder and detained in France on Saturday in connection with a violent stabbing attack this past week that injured two adults and four young children, a prosecutor said.

headline: Giving Red America a Reason to Love Electric Vehicles
abstract: Federal investment that gives people an economic stake in green energy may be the nation’s best chance to build a consensus to confront global warming.
lead_paragraph: Electric vehicles are rare in Moses Lake, Wash., a small city in the fertile Columbia Basin about a three-hour drive east of Seattle. In that conservative farms-and-factories community, few people have the cash or the inclination. The only electric vehicle I saw during a two-day visit last month was a Tesla in the hotel parking lot.

headline: Pope’s Doctors Say He’s on the Mend, but Advise Rest and No Events
abstract: Francis, who had abdominal surgery on Wednesday, has been advised by his medical team to rest and not recite his usual weekly prayer from his hospital balcony on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis is recovering well after undergoing abdominal surgery this past week, his surgeon said on Saturday, but his doctors advised him not to give his traditional public blessing on Sunday so that he can rest.

headline: Zelensky Signals Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Has Begun
abstract: As waters from the flooding of a burst dam began to recede, Ukrainian forces were trying to break through stout Russian defenses in the south and east.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday offered the strongest confirmation yet that the long-anticipated Ukrainian counteroffensive had begun, as battles along a 600-mile front line offered further evidence that the long-awaited counterattack was underway.

headline: Iga Swiatek, With an Enthralling Duel, Captures Another French Open Trophy
abstract: Swiatek was drawn into a tight match with Karolina Muchova, and emerged with her third singles championship at Roland Garros in four years.
lead_paragraph: Iga Swiatek is once more the queen of clay.

headline: Last Reactor at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Shuts Down After Dam Collapse
abstract: The lone reactor that was still operating at Europe’s largest nuclear plant was shut down because of the threat to its water supply. The reactor had been helping supply energy to the plant itself.
lead_paragraph: The last reactor still producing energy at Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, in southern Ukraine, was put into a “cold shutdown” — a state in which it no longer generates electricity — as a safety precaution after the destruction of a nearby dam threatened the facility’s water supply, Ukrainian energy officials said.

headline: Ted Kaczynski, ‘Unabomber’ Who Attacked Modern Life, Dies at 81
abstract: Alone in a shack in the Montana wilderness, he fashioned homemade bombs and launched a violent one-man campaign to destroy industrial society.
lead_paragraph: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the so-called Unabomber, who attacked academics, businessmen and random civilians with homemade bombs from 1978 to 1995, killing three people and injuring 23 with the stated goal of fomenting the collapse of the modern social order — a violent spree that ended after what was often described as the longest and most costly manhunt in American history — died on Saturday in a federal prison medical center in Butner, N.C. He was 81.

headline: Greta Thunberg Ends Her School Strikes After 251 Weeks
abstract: The climate activist, who has inspired young people around the world to demand action against climate change, graduated from high school on Friday in Sweden.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Greta Thunberg has spent her Fridays in front of the Swedish Parliament in Stockholm instead of in class; after 251 weeks, she is hanging up her cardboard protest sign — as a student.

headline: At Pride Event, Biden Vows to Protect Rights of L.G.B.T.Q. Americans
abstract: “This administration has your back,” the president told a group of Pride Month revelers outside the White House.
lead_paragraph: Standing on a stage decorated with rainbows and speaking to a crowd that included survivors of gay nightclub shootings and transgender rights advocates, President Biden on Saturday said his administration would work to counter a recent series of Republican-led bills and laws targeting the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

headline: Colombian Children Rescued From Jungle Are Said to Be in Good Health
abstract: The four siblings, ages 1 to 13, were eager to play and asked for books just a day after being rescued and having survived 40 days in the jungle, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Four Colombian children who survived in the Colombian jungle for 40 days after their plane crashed were eager to play and asked for books to read, officials said on Saturday, one day after the group was rescued.

headline: Edward Stack, 88, Longtime President of the Baseball Hall of Fame, Dies
abstract: He presided over the annual Hall induction ceremony in Cooperstown, N.Y., for many years. But he also helped keep one star, Pete Rose, from being part of it.
lead_paragraph: Edward Stack, who as the president of the National Baseball Hall of Fame conceived the eligibility rule that continues to prevent the election of Pete Rose, the prolific hitter who has been banned from Major League Baseball for gambling, died on Sunday in Port Washington, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 88.

headline: Biden Denounces Wave of Laws Targeting L.G.B.T.Q. Americans
abstract: President Biden told Pride Month revelers that his administration would work to counter the “callous” and “cynical” bills that have recently passed in many Republican-led states.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told Pride Month revelers that his administration would work to counter the “callous” and “cynical” bills that have recently passed in many Republican-led states.

headline: China Has Had a Spy Base in Cuba for Years, U.S. Official Says
abstract: It was unclear whether the report might complicate Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s rescheduled trip to Beijing for meetings that begin June 18.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese spy base or facilities in Cuba that could intercept electronic signals from nearby U.S. military and commercial buildings have been up and running since before 2019, when they were upgraded, according to a Biden administration official.

headline: Suspect in Natalee Holloway’s Death Pleads Not Guilty to Extorting Her Mother
abstract: More than a decade after being indicted by the United States for wire fraud and extortion, Joran van der Sloot was arraigned in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: Joran van der Sloot, who has been linked to the 2005 disappearance of an American teenager, Natalee Holloway, pleaded not guilty to extortion and fraud charges in court in Birmingham, Ala., on Friday after he was temporarily extradited from Peru to the United States.

headline: Trump Appointee Will Remain Judge in Documents Case, Clerk Says
abstract: The chief clerk of the courts for the Southern District of Florida added that Judge Aileen M. Cannon had been randomly assigned to the case.
lead_paragraph: The criminal case against President Donald J. Trump over his hoarding of classified documents was randomly assigned to Judge Aileen M. Cannon, a court official for the Southern District of Florida said on Saturday.

headline: Video Shows Rescue of 4 Children After 40 Days in Colombian Jungle
abstract: The four siblings had been missing after a plane they were traveling in crashed in the Colombian rainforest in May. Rescuers first found the bodies of the three adults who died in the crash, and then launched a search for the children.
lead_paragraph: The four siblings had been missing after a plane they were traveling in crashed in the Colombian rainforest in May. Rescuers first found the bodies of the three adults who died in the crash, and then launched a search for the children.

headline: Secrecy, Cigars and a Venetian Wedding: How the PGA Tour Made a Deal with Saudi Arabia
abstract: The agreement to remake a global game stunned most of the sporting world after seven weeks of clandestine negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Jay Monahan, the PGA Tour commissioner, had gone unnoticed in Venice last month.

headline: Really Relish
abstract: Savor drifting through this record-setting Sunday puzzle by Sam Ezersky.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Sam Ezersky is the digital puzzles editor for The New York Times; besides helping with the crossword, he oversees other games like Spelling Bee and Letter Boxed. This themeless grid, Sam’s favorite type to construct, is his 40th puzzle for The Times. It has only 118 entries, which is the lowest word count in Sunday puzzle history. On top of that, nearly a quarter of those entries have never appeared in a grid before. Sam likes a challenge, and when you see his byline on a puzzle, he wants you to think: Oh boy, time to buckle up!

headline: Kaczynski Is Said to Have Died by Suicide in Prison
abstract: The man known as the “Unabomber” had been transferred to a federal prison medical center in 2021 after more than 25 years at a maximum security facility.
lead_paragraph: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the “Unabomber,” who killed three people and injured 23 in a bombing spree stretching from 1978 to 1995, died by suicide at a federal prison medical center in North Carolina early Saturday, according to three people familiar with the situation.

headline: Arcangelo’s Belmont Victory Makes Trainer First Woman to Win a Triple Crown Race
abstract: Jena Antonucci became the first female trainer to win a Triple Crown race, a series that spans more than a century. “I wish more people can be like horses,” she said.
lead_paragraph: As the field for the 155th running of the Belmont Stakes edged into the starting gate on Saturday, anyone who has been enthralled with this sport and everyone who loves thoroughbreds was hoping — no, pleading — for something good to happen.

headline: Opera About Refugee Children to Premiere at Spoleto Festival
abstract: “Ruinous Gods,” an exploration of the trauma of mass displacement, will be staged in Charleston, S.C., next year.
lead_paragraph: A chamber opera about refugee children and the trauma of mass displacement will premiere next year at Spoleto Festival USA, the organization in Charleston, S.C., announced on Saturday.

headline: How the Case Against Ted Kaczynski, the ‘Unabomber,’ Unfolded
abstract: The domestic terrorist, who evaded authorities for almost 20 years, killed three people and injured 23 others with his homemade bombs.
lead_paragraph: Ted Kaczynski, the confessed killer who attacked academics, business officials and others over nearly 20 years and became known as the Unabomber, died by suicide on Saturday at a federal prison in Butner, N.C., according to three people familiar with the situation. He was 81.

headline: Trump Supporters’ Violent Rhetoric in His Defense Disturbs Experts
abstract: The former president’s allies have portrayed the indictment as an act of war and called for retribution, which political violence experts say increases the risk of action.
lead_paragraph: The federal indictment of former President Donald J. Trump has unleashed a wave of calls by his supporters for violence and an uprising to defend him, disturbing observers and raising concerns of a dangerous atmosphere ahead of his court appearance in Miami on Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the actress Greta Lee misstated when the second season of “Russian Doll” ended. It was last year, not in April.

headline: Quote of the Day: The Refries That Bind: A Cavernous Cantina Returns
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 11th, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It would be way cheaper if we just went hang gliding over volcanoes.”

headline: Aussie Farmers Unleash Dinosaur Rush as Fossil Findings Rewrite History
abstract: A new understanding of how to search for ancient remains has reinvigorated a region of western Queensland, with tourists flocking to paleontological digs.
lead_paragraph: It took a moment to spot the fragment, initially: fist-size and unnaturally smooth, nestled between shrubs teeming with burrs in an endless expanse of arid plains. But after the first, the others were easier to pick out, gleaming dirty white against the red earth and run through with a honeycomb texture.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Skating Affair
abstract: When her husband takes up a new interest, she begins to wonder what is really going on.
lead_paragraph: I heard a whisper: This is how it ends.

headline: Hands Bound, but Still Reporting
abstract: A pair of zip-tie cuffs, on display in the Museum at The Times, serve as a stark reminder of the risk and significance of on-the-ground journalism.
lead_paragraph: Some journalists who covered the protests over the killing of Daunte Wright in April 2021 worked under an extra hardship: Their hands were tied behind their backs.

headline: Their Reports About a Woman’s Death Set Off a Revolt. Iran Put Them on Trial.
abstract: Two female journalists, Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi, covered some of the first reports of the death of Mahsa Amini in police custody, which ignited nationwide protests against Iran’s clerical rulers.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian journalist Niloufar Hamedi specialized in covering women’s issues. So when her editor noticed an Instagram post about a young woman in a hospital in bad shape after being arrested for violating the country’s strict Islamic dress code, Ms. Hamedi headed straight there.

headline: A Pier Deal Is Full of Developer Perks, but Is It Good for the City?
abstract: Generous incentives will secure a project that keeps New York’s motion picture industry competitive, officials say. Critics call the price too steep.
lead_paragraph: Developers hoping to snap up big city real estate often persuade local officials to shower them with taxpayer-funded incentives to seal the deal and prevent them from taking their business elsewhere.

headline: Thousands of Bylines to His Name, and One That’s Not
abstract: A sports reporter reflects on his 30-year career and the mistake that started it all.
lead_paragraph: It was the day after Christmas in 1991, and as a young journalist, I received quite a gift: my first byline in The New York Times.

headline: ‘I Heard a Voice Coming From Behind a Nearby Stack of Books’
abstract: Taking shelter in the Strand, an encounter with a very tall man and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Failed Affirmative Action Campaign That Shook Democrats
abstract: The Supreme Court will soon rule on race-conscious college admissions, a core Democratic issue. But an analysis of a California referendum points to a divide between the party and voters.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 campaign to restore race-conscious affirmative action in California was close to gospel within the Democratic Party. It drew support from the governor, senators, state legislative leaders and a who’s who of business, nonprofit and labor elites, Black, Latino, white and Asian.

headline: How the Head of a Theater Nonprofit Spends His Sundays
abstract: There is usually a matinee in store for Michael Presser, who is the founder of Inside Broadway.
lead_paragraph: More young people might be tuning into the Tony Awards this weekend thanks to the work of Michael Presser, the founder of Inside Broadway, a nonprofit organization that brings Broadway musicals to New York City schools and New York City schoolchildren to Broadway musicals.

headline: Emily Morse Wants You to Think Seriously About an Open Relationship
abstract: “You need to be self-aware and have self-knowledge about your sexual desires,” the sex therapist, author and podcaster says.
lead_paragraph: “You need to be self-aware and have self-knowledge about your sexual desires,” the sex therapist, author and podcaster says.

headline: With Hollywood Change Stagnating, a Call to ‘Burn It Down’
abstract: The journalist Maureen Ryan is mad as hell about what goes on behind the entertainment-biz scenes. Her new book tells tales, and proposes remedies.
lead_paragraph: As I typed this, striking Writers Guild of America members were skipping the picket lines in New York City because of poor air quality, after smoke drifted down from wildfires in Canada. It was a grimly perfect backdrop to read “Burn It Down,” a new book about the pervasive moral shortcomings of Hollywood by the longtime entertainment reporter and critic Maureen Ryan.

headline: How Walt Nauta, a Personal Aide, Came to Be Charged as Trump’s Co-Conspirator
abstract: A Navy veteran and a regular presence at Donald Trump’s side, he is said to have played a central role in helping to thwart government efforts to retrieve classified documents.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, as former President Donald J. Trump was at the Saudi-backed LIV Golf tournament at his course in Sterling, Va., one of his aides was photographed leaning toward him and dutifully adjusting the collar of his white pullover, a moment of closeness that had become routine for the pair.

headline: Silicon Valley Confronts the Idea That the ‘Singularity’ Is Here
abstract: The frenzy over artificial intelligence may be ushering in the long-awaited moment when technology goes wild. Or maybe it’s the hype that is out of control.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Silicon Valley anticipated the moment when a new technology would come along and change everything. It would unite human and machine, probably for the better but possibly for the worse, and split history into before and after.

headline: It’s All Fun and Games Until Someone Gets Hurt
abstract: Always looking for an edge, some batters stand their ground and let pitches hit them. As Pete Alonso’s wrist injury shows, the downside can be extreme.
lead_paragraph: In the movie “Moneyball,” Peter Brand, a baseball analyst played by Jonah Hill, has a mantra for the type of player his team covets. “He gets on base,” Brand says when his boss points at him.

headline: Faceless, Nameless and Dead by the Dozen in a Train’s Cheapest Cars
abstract: In India’s worst railway disaster in decades, nearly all of the 288 dead were in three crowded cars where passengers stand for long stretches.
lead_paragraph: They cram themselves every day by the millions onto India’s overtaxed trains, chasing a shred of economic opportunity across the vastness of the world’s most populous nation.

headline: ‘Everything Will Die’: A Dam Blast Imperils Ukraine’s Vital Lifeline
abstract: A disaster unfolds in slow motion after an explosion destroyed the dam at the Kakhovka Reservoir, emptying its waters and threatening livelihoods and crucial industries.
lead_paragraph: The view from villagers’ gardens on the northern shore of the Kakhovka Reservoir has changed significantly in the four days since an explosion destroyed the nearby dam and the waters receded.

headline: Why Secrets Lost Their Sizzle
abstract: Unlike previous leaks, the revelations in the Discord leaks have largely failed to capture the American public’s attention.
lead_paragraph: In April, secret documents allegedly photographed by a member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard began making their way into the mainstream media. Many were briefings prepared by military intelligence services, and much of it dealt with the Russia-Ukraine war. They offered Americans a rare window into the government’s most valuable intelligence on one of Europe’s deadliest conflicts since World War II.

headline: Ron DeSantis Thinks Trump Didn’t Go Far Enough
abstract: DeSantis is trying to show that he has both the will and the discipline to do what Trump did not.
lead_paragraph: Campaign books written by politicians are often dismissed as focus-grouped fluff. I disagree. You can learn a lot about people by paying close attention to how they want to be seen. And so it is with Ron DeSantis’s “The Courage to be Free.” It’s not a good book, exactly. But it is a revealing one.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Most Dangerous Person in the World Is Randi Weingarten’
abstract: School closures and culture wars turned classrooms into battlegrounds — and made the head of one of the country’s largest teachers’ unions a lightning rod for criticism.
lead_paragraph: When the former secretary of state and C.I.A. director Mike Pompeo, a man who had dealt firsthand with autocrats like Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping, described Randi Weingarten as “the most dangerous person in the world” last November, it seemed as though he couldn’t possibly be serious.

headline: If the Supreme Court Abolishes Affirmative Action, Here’s What Women Need to Do
abstract: These programs have historically benefited women more than anyone else. Now they must help others in underrepresented communities.
lead_paragraph: Any day now the Supreme Court will decide two cases that will determine the future of affirmative action — one involving race-conscious admissions at the University of North Carolina and a companion case involving Harvard.

headline: What Donald Trump and Reality Winner Have in Common
abstract: The president’s own Justice Department vigorously enforced the Espionage Act, sending people to prison for much less than the actions described in his indictment.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is facing a 37-count indictment in federal court on charges connected to his retention of classified documents at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. The charges include 31 counts of violating the Espionage Act for willfully retaining, without authorization, documents relating to national defense. As a former president with no formal security clearances, Mr. Trump no longer had a legal right to even view the documents, much less keep them.

headline: Summer Reading
abstract: Melissa Kirsch takes a look at some of the big books coming this summer.
lead_paragraph: The books are piling up again. The physical ones on the bedside table; the library queue; the e-bookshelves on which reside the novels impulse-purchased from bed, begun and then forgotten in one insomniac night. My eyes, always, bigger than my attention span.

headline: Their Pot Convictions Were Erased, but They Still Face Deportation
abstract: Immigrants convicted under New York’s discriminatory laws remain in legal limbo.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, New York decriminalized possession of small amounts of marijuana. Two years later, the state legalized recreational marijuana. The laws had the effect of automatically erasing certain low-level convictions related to the drug.

headline: When Truth No Longer Counts, How Does a Memoirist Tell Her Story?
abstract: This is the question at the heart of “To Name the Bigger Lie,” by Sarah Viren, which tries to make sense of two disturbing episodes from her life in the context of a culture where truth itself is increasingly in dispute.
lead_paragraph: It’s an experience I’m betting most of us have had over the last decade: the creeping feeling that a common truth no longer exists. Where once there were facts, now there is strife. Where once there was one America, now there are two. (At least.) Where once there were agreed-upon narratives, now there are competing stories, falsehoods and deceptions.

headline: Tens of Thousands of Dead Fish Wash Ashore on Gulf Coast in Texas
abstract: A “perfect storm” of bad conditions, including high temperatures, starved the fish of oxygen, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of fish washed ashore along the gulf coast of Texas starting on Friday after being starved of oxygen in warm water, officials said.

headline: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Former Leader, Is Arrested in Financial Inquiry
abstract: The arrest of Ms. Sturgeon, who resigned as leader of the Scottish National Party in February, follows that of her husband, previously the party’s chief executive, and of its former treasurer.
lead_paragraph: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s former first minister and once one of Britain’s most prominent politicians, was arrested on Sunday by police officers investigating the finances of the Scottish National Party, which dominates the country’s politics and which she led until her unexpected resignation in February.

headline: I-95 Overpass Collapses in Philadelphia After a Tanker Fire
abstract: Officials urged commuters to be patient as Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania warned that repairs might last “some number of months.”
lead_paragraph: Part of Interstate 95 in northeast Philadelphia was shut down in both directions early on Sunday morning after a tanker truck believed to be carrying gasoline caught fire, causing part of the highway to collapse, officials said.

headline: Wagner Founder Rebuffs Order Over Fighter Contracts With Russian Military
abstract: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the private military force, said he would not comply with an order that would require it to sign a formal contract with Russia’s defense ministry by July 1.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Russia’s Wagner private military company said Sunday that his group would not comply with an order that would require it to sign a formal contract with Russia’s defense ministry by July 1.

headline: Review: Kids Dance Puts on a Show of Courage, Discipline and Heart
abstract: Kids Dance, the performance group of Ballet Tech, returned to the Joyce with a mix of premieres and classics.
lead_paragraph: The roots of Ballet Tech’s Kids Dance took hold not in a dance studio but on the subway. It was 1977 when the choreographer Eliot Feld found himself sharing a train with elementary school children. To an ordinary person, they were just kids, but Feld saw something more: These were potential dancers.

headline: Cloisters U.: The Sounds of Silence in a College Class
abstract: Responses to Molly Worthen’s essay about removing technology from students’ daily lives. Also: Prizes in the arts; a climate question.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fugazetta Is a Better Cheesy Bread
abstract: Ham El-Waylly’s recipe tops a cheese-stuffed focaccia calzone with a tangle of charred onions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There are many ways to dress up focaccia. You can top the bread with fruit or herbs (or fruit and herbs). You can cover it with potatoes and leeks. I like to split the bread and layer the interior with mortadella and pistachio cream, as they do at All’Antico Vinaio in Manhattan. In Argentina, home to a huge population of Italian immigrants, focaccia dough can be used to make fugazza, a kind of pizza hybrid topped with mozzarella, provolone and shaved onions.

headline: Novak Djokovic Captures the French Open and a 23rd Grand Slam Title
abstract: Djokovic beat Casper Ruud to win the men’s singles championship, passing Rafael Nadal for the most major tournament titles in the Open era.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic began his day picturing how it would end, holding his children in his arms, raising another Grand Slam tournament trophy above his head and singing his national anthem as Serbian fans chanted and danced and celebrated his third French Open men’s singles title and much more.
