headline: U.N. Nuclear Official Visits Zaporizhzhia Plant to Assess Safety
abstract: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the head of the United Nations’ atomic agency, is investigating conditions at the plant, which is held by Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: The head of the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog said on Thursday that an embattled nuclear plant in southern Ukraine had enough water in a cooling pond to ensure the plant’s safety, at least for now, after a dam disaster raised concerns about the water supply.

headline: Putin Sent Xi Birthday Greetings. Here Was the Real Message.
abstract: The shows of bonhomie between the two leaders reflect the bond between Russia and China, which could become more fraught as Russian dependence deepens.
lead_paragraph: Birthday best wishes rarely come freighted with so much significance. But when it is Russia’s embattled president, Vladimir V. Putin, flattering his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, even seemingly small gestures send a message to the world, not least to their Western rivals.

headline: Trump and the Fun Factor
abstract: How his legal challenges play into his reputation as an entertainer.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump was indicted on criminal charges in New York City two months ago, I tried to make sense of the political fallout with my colleague Nate Cohn, The Times’s chief political analyst. After poring over traditional markers about fund-raising and poll numbers, Nate mentioned another standard I’ve been thinking about over the past few days: Do Trump’s legal challenges make him more (or less) fun?

headline: A Series of Mistakes Is (Mostly) Forgotten With a Walk-Off Win
abstract: Brandon Nimmo’s hit in the 10th gave the struggling Mets a thrilling victory over the Yankees. It also gave his team a rare chance to relax.
lead_paragraph: When a struggling team scores a thrilling victory — especially in a packed ballpark against a crosstown rival before a day off — the question just has to be asked: How big was this win?

headline: ‘Maggie Moore(s)’ Review: Body Trouble
abstract: Tina Fey and Jon Hamm fail to invigorate this listless murder mystery about two victims who shared the same name.
lead_paragraph: “Some of this actually happened,” we are advised at the beginning of John Slattery’s second feature, “Maggie Moore(s).” At least it’s a variation on the groaningly familiar “based on a true story,” even if both claims are equally meaningless.

headline: ‘Happer’s Comet’ Review: We Live by Night
abstract: The writer-director Tyler Taormina shot this highly experimental feature, which mostly takes place after dark, during the most restrictive phase of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Except in its final shot, “Happer’s Comet” takes place entirely at night. But if it weren’t for occasional glimpses of clocks, discerning the precise time would be tricky. There are plenty of people out and about, performing quiet, personal, often inexplicable tasks in an unidentified pocket of suburbia. (The film was largely shot in Smithtown, Long Island.)

headline: ‘Cadejo Blanco’ Review: Negotiating Guatemalan Street Life
abstract: In this film a young woman searching for her missing sister infiltrates a gang, but the focus is diffuse and the promised thriller never materializes.
lead_paragraph: The description of “Cadejo Blanco,” directed by Justin Lerner, reads like a thriller: After her sister disappears, a young Guatemalan woman infiltrates a gang to try to find her. But there are few thrills in the film, which moves slowly and with too much ease through the world of Guatemalan gangs. It’s beautifully shot and gives an authentic view of street life there, but the characters’ journeys are not sufficiently developed, and the resolutions feel unearned.

headline: ‘The Blackening’ Review: Race Against a Killer
abstract: With more jokes than jump scares, this comedic horror film is as tartly amusing as it is provocative.
lead_paragraph: There are two games at play in “The Blackening,” a comedic horror film with more jokes than jump scares. The first is the titular race-baiting board game with the grotesque Jim Crow-style figurine that Morgan (Yvonne Orji) and her boyfriend, Shawn (Jay Pharoah), discover as they explore the cabin they have rented for a reunion of college friends.

headline: Glenda Jackson, Oscar-Winning Actress Turned Politician, Dies at 87
abstract: She walked away from a successful acting career to enter the British Parliament, before returning to the stage as the title character in an acclaimed “King Lear.”
lead_paragraph: Glenda Jackson, the two-time Oscar winner who renounced a successful film and stage career in her 50s to become a member of the British Parliament, then returned to the stage at 80 as the title character in “King Lear,” died on Thursday at her home in Blackheath, London. She was 87.

headline: The Unexpected Beyoncé Effect: Hotter Inflation
abstract: As fans from around the world spent money to witness the kickoff of the star’s tour in Sweden, they may have caused the country’s inflation rate to stay higher than expected.
lead_paragraph: In Europe’s relentless battle against inflation, another culprit has apparently emerged: Beyoncé.

headline: Gen Z-ers Are Moving Out. Where Are They Looking to Buy Homes?
abstract: A new study suggests that young buyers are most prevalent in smaller cities. But they’re on their way to greater market share.
lead_paragraph: After the pandemic forced many young adults to move back in with their parents, a new study suggests that they’re ready to test the housing market again.

headline: ‘Extraction 2’ Review: No Escape
abstract: Chris Hemsworth returns as an Australian mercenary in this bloated, banal action sequel.
lead_paragraph: “Extraction 2,” a drab, brawny sequel starring Chris Hemsworth as an Australian mercenary, offers a turgid shadow of the type of crowd-pleasing escapism that action blockbusters used to provide.

headline: The White House Renews Its Attack on ‘Surprise Fees’
abstract: President Biden will host executives from several companies, including Airbnb and Live Nation, to announce new efforts to end so-called junk fees as inflation remains high.
lead_paragraph: With inflation still a potent political issue, President Biden is stepping up his war on so-called junk fees.

headline: European Central Bank Raises Rates to Highest Level Since 2001
abstract: Inflation is “projected to remain too high for too long,” the central bank said as it raised interest rates by a quarter point, and signaled more increases may be coming.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank raised interest rates to their highest level in more than two decades on Thursday and warned that there was further to go in order to stamp out inflation.

headline: Pope Francis Will Leave Hospital on Friday, Vatican Says
abstract: The Vatican described the pope’s recovery nine days after undergoing abdominal surgery as “regular.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis will be discharged from the hospital on Friday, according to the Vatican, nine days after the 86-year-old pontiff underwent abdominal surgery for a hernia, an unexpected operation that raised concerns about his health.

headline: Test Cricket’s Last Stand
abstract: The Ashes, a century-old rivalry between England and Australia, is the most venerable showcase for a version of cricket that is losing ground to faster, richer rivals.
lead_paragraph: Not many international sporting contests predate the countries that play them, but few contests are as old as the Ashes.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York City
abstract: This weeks homes are in Greenwich Village, Manhattanville and the Financial District.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 500-square-foot apartment with 10-foot ceilings, a windowed galley kitchen, a bedroom with three closets, and a windowed bathroom with a soaking tub, on the top floor of a six-story prewar elevator building with a live-in superintendent, video intercom, shared laundry, gym, children’s playroom, complimentary storage, courtyard and roof deck. James Michael Angelo, BOND New York, 917-373-8343; bondnewyork.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Ossining, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in New Canaan, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 2,408-square-foot, recently renovated 1940 house with a slate front porch, three fireplaces (one electric), a formal living room, a sunroom/office, an open kitchen/dining area with center-island seating, en suite bedrooms with custom closets, central air-conditioning, a lower level, a side brick patio, a lawn and a two-car garage, on 0.48 acres. Eric Schatz, Schatz Realty Group, 914-274-7021; schatzrealtors.com

headline: What Are the Dirtiest Beaches in California?
abstract: Taking a dip in polluted waters makes it more likely that you’ll develop stomach illnesses, ear infections, rashes and more.
lead_paragraph: Slather up with sunscreen. Grab some flip-flops, towels and maybe a book. And make sure to check your beach’s water quality.

headline: A 40-Foot Wedding Cake in the English Countryside
abstract: Plus: getaways to Athens and the Philippines, portraits of queer tenderness and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The Portuguese artist Joana Vasconcelos is known for her ambitious oversize sculptures that frequently elevate everyday objects. Her 2005 Venice Biennale contribution, “A Noiva” (The Bride), was a chandelier made of 14,000 tampons and “Valkyrie Miss Dior,” the imposing, tentacular fabric-wrapped installation that formed the backdrop of Maria Grazia Chiuri’s fall ’23 show for Dior, took over the show space at Paris’s Jardin des Tuileries. Vasconcelos’s newest project is her most ambitious yet: “Wedding Cake,” an almost 40-foot-high three-tiered wedding cake pavilion in pastel shades of pink, green and blue, was installed this spring on the grounds of Waddesdon Manor in Buckinghamshire, England. The whimsical creation is clad in 25,000 ceramic tiles (manufactured in Vasconcelos’s native Lisbon) and adorned with ceramic cherubs, dolphins and a water feature. Commissioned by the collector and arts philanthropist Lord Jacob Rothschild, the “impossible project,” as the artist describes it, has been five years in the making and is the culmination of Vasconcelos’s long-held fascination with the dynamics of weddings: “Weddings are the most important moment in some women’s lives,” she says. “It’s the transition from one identity to another. All transition moments are marked by symbols. This is my way of working through these symbols and asking if they still make sense.” “Wedding Cake” opens June 18, waddesdon.org.uk.

headline: North Korea Fires 2 Ballistic Missiles
abstract: The launch of the short-range projectiles came the same day the United States and South Korean militaries conducted a joint live-fire drill.
lead_paragraph: North Korea launched two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on Thursday, its first missile test in two months, as the United States and South Korean militaries conducted a joint live-fire exercise near the inter-Korean border.

headline: Indian Politician and Former Wrestling Chief Is Charged With Harassment
abstract: The charges against Brij Bhushan Sharan Singh, follow months of protest by prominent female wrestlers, who complained that the authorities had turned a deaf ear to their allegations.
lead_paragraph: After months of impassioned protest by Olympic wrestlers that drew national attention in India, the police on Thursday filed charges of sexual harassment and intimidation against a powerful ruling-party politician and former chief of India’s wrestling federation.

headline: The Instant Pot Was Beloved. Now Its Maker Has Filed for Bankruptcy.
abstract: Since sales surged during the pandemic, Instant Brands has struggled to find new fans for its beloved Instant Pot and other products.
lead_paragraph: Drop in some ground beef, onions, bell peppers, tomatoes and spices. Press a button, head out for work and return hours later to a perfectly prepared chili.

headline: How a Toilet Plunger Improved CPR
abstract: The conventional method for chest compressions doesn’t have a great success rate. Doctors are pumping it up with a high-tech plunger.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, a 65-year-old man’s heart stopped at home. His wife and son didn’t know CPR, so in desperation they grabbed a toilet plunger to get his heart going until an ambulance showed up.

headline: I Am Not Who You Want Me to Be
abstract: If you think you can define a musician’s identity only by his past work, listen again.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Native American Adoption Law
abstract: At issue in the case was whether a law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees within tribes is constitutional.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a 1978 law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees with their tribes and traditions, handing a victory to tribes that had argued that a blow to the law would upend the basic principles that have allowed them to govern themselves for years.

headline: ‘Menace II Society’ at 30: A Bleak Nightmare Then, a Milestone Now
abstract: With a tragic hero at its heart, the Hughes brothers’ debut drama painted nuanced portraits of characters rarely fleshed out in other films.
lead_paragraph: When it was released 30 years ago, “Menace II Society” was a shock to the system.

headline: Newly Published Visual Books, From Asylum Seekers to Ruth E. Carter
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: ASYLUM, by Umberto Nicola Nicoletti. (Rizzoli, $80.) Nicoletti captures the dignity and pain of L.G.B.T.Q. asylum seekers in these glossy monochrome portraits, accompanied by searing anonymous testimonies drawn from their letters.

headline: Kenyan Cult Survivors, Still Refusing to Eat, Face Suicide Charges
abstract: Dozens of members rescued from a church whose pastor is accused of telling followers to starve themselves appeared in court. A judge sent them to rehab rather than jail to await another hearing.
lead_paragraph: The emaciated survivors of a doomsday cult in Kenya that the authorities say ordered its followers to starve themselves to death held hands and leaned on each other as they staggered into a courtroom on Thursday to face charges of trying to kill themselves.

headline: In Barcelona, City of Mega-Festivals, Small Venues Struggle
abstract: Thousands of visitors flock to the city for events like Sónar and Primavera Sound. But complaints from locals about noise and overcrowding create tough conditions for local acts.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night, a few dozen 20-somethings piled into Sidecar, a well-known concert venue in downtown Barcelona.

headline: Ebony G. Patterson Brings a Crowd to the New York Botanical Garden
abstract: All that glitters isn’t what you expect at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. The vultures have landed.
lead_paragraph: I have to admit, I didn’t notice them at first. They blend seamlessly as shadows into the bright red petunias and purple coleus on the lawn of the New York Botanical Garden’s Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. Only when I stooped to read the label for one velvety red blossom — it was a cockscomb, Celosia “Dracula” — did I notice the knee-high, cast-foam black vulture that was sitting watchfully beside it. When I looked up, I realized there were dozens more. The gardens were full of them.

headline: A ‘Win-Win’ for Restaurants and Migrants: Subsidized Free Meals
abstract: Rethink Food, a nonprofit that feeds the hungry, has started an initiative with New York City that pays restaurants to prepare and distribute meals to migrants.
lead_paragraph: Rethink Food, a nonprofit that feeds the hungry, has started an initiative with New York City that pays restaurants to prepare and distribute meals to migrants.

headline: Men’s College World Series: Future Pros and Plenty of Contenders
abstract: Wake Forest has had the best pitching this baseball season, led by Rhett Lowder. But there are several fellow M.L.B. prospects in the championship field.
lead_paragraph: The 64 teams in the N.C.A.A. baseball tournament have been whittled to eight, and now it’s time for the College World Series, with a pack of future major leaguers on the field, a favorite returning after a long wait and one big long shot. Here’s what to know.

headline: Elizabeth Holmes Says She Can’t Afford $250 Payments to Theranos Victims
abstract: Ms. Holmes was ordered to pay $250 a month to defrauded investors after her prison term. Her lawyers said she had “limited financial resources.”
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the disgraced entrepreneur Elizabeth Holmes said this week that she would be unable to afford to pay $250 each month to victims of her failed blood-testing start-up, Theranos, after leaving prison.

headline: Ticket Giants, Under Pressure From Biden, Promise Transparency on Fees
abstract: Live Nation and SeatGeek said they would show customers the full cost of concerts, after the White House’s complaints that “junk fees” for tickets and hotel stays can mislead consumers.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the Biden administration, some of the biggest companies that handle ticketing for concerts and other live events announced on Thursday that they will make it easier for consumers to see the full price of tickets they want to buy, including the fees that can often add more than 30 percent to the total cost of an order.

headline: ‘Nobody’s Hero’ Review: Little Desires Everywhere
abstract: In this slippery farce, a schlubby coder falls in love with a prostitute and takes in a teenager he suspects is a terrorist.
lead_paragraph: In the first few minutes of Alain Guiraudie’s meandering farce, “Nobody’s Hero,” Médéric (Jean-Charles Clichet) spots a middle-aged woman across the street and immediately declares his love. Contrary to cliché, the gesture is not romantic but droll and startlingly arbitrary — it’s early in the morning, and the two are at an empty suburban intersection. When the lucky lady, Isadora (Noémie Lvovsky), reveals she’s a prostitute, Médéric is unfazed, even after it turns out she’s also married to her pimp, Gérard (Renaud Rutten), an oddly jealous brute who resembles Dennis Hopper in “Blue Velvet.”

headline: The Great Bob Thompson, in Two Parts
abstract: A big retrospective bypassed New York recently but two gallery exhibitions, at 52 Walker and Michael Rosenfeld, more than make up for it.
lead_paragraph: Few painters have used color as vigorously or as variously as Bob Thompson, the remarkable, driven American artist who was born in Louisville, Ky., in 1937, and died in Rome on the brink of his 29th birthday in 1966, worn down by ill health, substance abuse and a seemingly relentless work ethic. But Thompson never doubted his talent and had a voracious appetite for culture in many forms: He consorted with New York’s Beat poets and its free jazz musicians as well as a broad range of artists. His career lasted barely eight years, but he left behind several hundred paintings, drawings and oil studies — a fabulous horde whose magnitude is still not well known.

headline: Bipartisan Proposals Would Hit E-Commerce Like Fast Fashion
abstract: Critics say the law gives an unfair advantage to e-commerce companies from other countries, including some where forced labor is an issue.
lead_paragraph: Two bipartisan bills introduced in Congress this week aim to change a nearly 100-year-old trade rule that allows imported packages that fall under a certain price threshold to receive less oversight in the U.S. customs process.

headline: Four Killer Whales Are Spotted Off New England Coast
abstract: New England Aquarium scientists captured the remarkable sight in photographs on the same day that a fishing crew saw a killer whale in the waters off Cape Cod.
lead_paragraph: After nearly seven hours on a plane on Sunday, two New England Aquarium research scientists had hit a lull in their search for marine mammals in the waters south of Nantucket and Martha’s Vineyard. They thought their day was almost done when one of them saw some splashing.

headline: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and Paula Vogel Are Broadway Bound
abstract: Second Stage, a nonprofit with a focus on living American dramatists, said it will present works by the playwrights on Broadway this season.
lead_paragraph: Second Stage, a nonprofit theater that focuses on work by living American writers, said it will present a well-known piece by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and a new work by Paula Vogel on Broadway this season.

headline: ‘Elemental’ Review: Sparks Fly
abstract: The latest movie from Disney/Pixar tucks a romantic comedy inside a high-concept premise. It’s smoldering and splashy.
lead_paragraph: “Elemental” is the latest Pixar premise to feel like someone laced the cafeteria’s kombucha keg with ayahuasca. Starting eight years ago with “Inside Out,” the animation company has transformed cartoons into a form of group therapy that encourages audiences to ruminate on inner peace, death (“Coco”) and resurrection (“Soul”). This story is simpler (elemental, even). It’s a girl-meets-boy cross-cultural romantic comedy — a good one that woos us to root for the big kiss. But the Pixar-brand psychotropic flourish comes from which cultures. Here, they are water, earth, air and fire — the four classical elements that the ancient philosopher Empedocles used to explain our world — all tenuously coexisting in Element City, a Manhattan analogue founded by the first droplet to ooze out of the primordial sea. The girl, Ember Lumen (voiced by Leah Lewis), is a leggy lick of flame; her crush, Wade Ripple (Mamoudou Athie), is a drip. When she brushes near him, his body roils. Steamy.

headline: Black Real Estate Agent Wins Racial Bias Case Against Hamptons Firm
abstract: Shauncy Claud claimed that Brown Harris Stevens of the Hamptons terminated her contract after she told a supervisor that her white colleagues received more favorable treatment.
lead_paragraph: Brown Harris Stevens of the Hamptons, a branch of one of New York City’s oldest and most prestigious real estate firms, wrongfully terminated the contract of a Black real estate agent who raised concerns about racial discrimination there, a federal judge ruled last week.

headline: German Police Investigate Rammstein Singer Over Sexual Assault Accusations
abstract: Accusations against the band’s frontman had been swirling on social media and in reports by German news outlets for nearly two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Berlin’s state prosecutor said Wednesday that it had launched an investigation into accusations that Till Lindemann, the frontman of the German rock band Rammstein, had drugged and sexually assaulted women.

headline: Smoke From Canada Wildfires Is Returning to New York
abstract: The smoke is expected to be thickest on Friday morning, but forecasters said the region would be spared the orange haze that settled last week.
lead_paragraph: A week after a thick plume of smoke choked the air in New York City, delaying flights, closing schools and sending people to hospitals with respiratory issues, another round of eastward winds is pushing Canadian wildfire smoke toward the East Coast.

headline: Dips for Dinner
abstract: With an assortment of colorful vegetables, fluffy breads and crunchy crackers, any dip can become a vibrant meal.
lead_paragraph: There is a food-related bit on the Hulu series “Only Murders in the Building” that I think of often. It begins in the show’s second episode: At an apartment-lobby memorial for a deceased neighbor, the debt-stricken Oliver Putnam, played by the incomparable Martin Short, rushes to a table of free goodies.

headline: Review: In ‘The Doctor,’ a Rare Case of Physician, Harm Thyself
abstract: Robert Icke’s surgery on a 1912 play about the disease of antisemitism turns it into a riveting debate about identity. But at what cost to the patient?
lead_paragraph: After attempting an abortion at home, a 14-year-old girl lies dying of sepsis at the Elizabeth Institute. No one questions her treatment there; by the time she was admitted, it was too late to save her. But when Ruth Wolff, the Institute’s head doctor, refuses to let a priest perform last rites because it would cause “an unpeaceful death,” ignorance amplified by social media turns a medical decision into a maelstrom. Soon the web is saying Wolff assaulted the priest and killed the girl.

headline: Penguins in Your Fridge? These 7-Year-Olds Have Climate Solutions.
abstract: New Jersey is the first state to require that climate change be taught at all grade levels. The focus is on problem solving, not doom and gloom.
lead_paragraph: Standing at the front of her classroom at Slackwood Elementary School north of Trenton, N.J., one afternoon in June, Michelle Liwacz asked her first graders to consider a problem: Antarctica is getting warmer. What could the penguins that live there do to adapt?

headline: Justice Neil Gorsuch Is a Committed Defender of Tribal Rights
abstract: In soaring opinions steeped in history, Justice Gorsuch has demonstrated a distinctive dedication to Native American rights.
lead_paragraph: In a pair of opinions on Thursday, Justice Neil M. Gorsuch again demonstrated that he is the fiercest proponent of Native American rights on the Supreme Court.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: Golfers take over Los Angeles, while college baseball teams finally start play in Omaha.
lead_paragraph: Golfers take over Los Angeles, while college baseball teams finally start play in Omaha.

headline: Justice Dept. to Release Minneapolis Police Review After George Floyd Murder
abstract: The investigation was launched after Mr. Floyd was murdered during an arrest in 2020, touching off protests nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is expected to announce the results of an investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department on Friday, according to two people familiar with the planning, capping a multiyear examination of the long-troubled agency, whose abuses captured global attention when an officer murdered George Floyd in 2020.

headline: How Do Certain Foods Become National Dishes?
abstract: A new book digs into the histories of some of the world’s most iconic fare.
lead_paragraph: “We have a compulsion to tie food to place,” Anya von Bremzen writes in her new book, but that compulsion, it turns out, has more to do with myth and marketing than with historical fact. “National Dish” is the story of her quest to understand why certain foods, like pizza, ramen and tapas, are adopted as symbols of their places of origin.

headline: ‘Asteroid City’ Review: Our Town and Country
abstract: In his latest film, Wes Anderson and his all-stars go meta with a TV show about a theatrical play that, in turn, is about a small town, U.S.A.
lead_paragraph: “Asteroid City,” the latest from Wes Anderson, is filled with the assiduous visuals, mythic faces and charming curiosities that you expect from this singular filmmaker. It’s comic and often wry, but like some of his other films, it has the soul of a tragedy. It’s partly set in 1955 in a fictional Southwest town, a lonely four corners with a diner, gas station and motor inn. Palm trees and cactuses stipple the town, and reddish buttes rise in the distance. It looks like an ordinary pit stop save for the atomic cloud soon mushrooming in the sky.

headline: Rats, Summer Reads and a Virgin’s Dilemma: Audio Highlights
abstract: Each week, we share the best of audio journalism and storytelling from our new app.
lead_paragraph: This week, we went inside a courtroom where Donald Trump was indicted, again; met a man who couldn’t give up his pet rats; and found joy in running “Slow AF.” Welcome to your weekly newsletter from New York Times Audio, where app editors share their favorite listens.

headline: Highlights From More Than 50 Years of Glenda Jackson Reviews
abstract: The word that keeps recurring in more than half a century’s worth of reviews in The New York Times? Intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Over decades’ worth of reviews of Glenda Jackson’s work — on the stage and on screens both large and small — what struck critic after critic, above all, was her intelligence.

headline: Can Judge Cannon Preside Fairly Over the Trump Trial?
abstract: Readers discuss questions raised about her experience and possible bias. Also: Elizabeth Gilbert’s novel; “doing the work”; honorifics; “above the law.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jury Weighs Case of Men Accused of Stalking U.S. Residents for China
abstract: During a two-week trial, prosecutors made their case that an American private detective, Michael McMahon, and two Chinese citizens did Beijing’s dirty work.
lead_paragraph: A jury is considering the case of a former New York Police Department sergeant and two other men accused of stalking a family in New Jersey on behalf of the Chinese government after their two-week trial wrapped up in Brooklyn federal court on Thursday.

headline: Horace Tapscott Was a Force in L.A. Jazz. A New Set May Expand His Reach.
abstract: “60 Years,” a compilation marking the 60th anniversary of his Pan Afrikan Peoples Arkestra, spotlights the pianist and community organizer, who died in 1999.
lead_paragraph: There’s a name engraved in the sidewalk along Degnan Boulevard in Los Angeles’ Leimert Park neighborhood: Horace Tapscott, the local pianist and organizer whose ensemble, the Pan Afrikan Peoples Arkestra, gave many musicians their first gigs and helped heal a community impacted by racism.

headline: Cyclone Biparjoy Pummels Towns in India
abstract: The storm flooded streets and damaged buildings in coastal areas.
lead_paragraph: The storm flooded streets and damaged buildings in coastal areas.

headline: The Book That Changed Robert Rubin’s Thinking About Poverty
abstract: The former Treasury secretary, whose new book is “The Yellow Pad,” says that Ken Auletta’s “The Underclass” convinced him that “trying to break the cycle of poverty through policy and through private efforts is not just right for moral reasons, but is enormously in the interest of all.”
lead_paragraph: I’m always reading multiple books at the same time, switching between them depending on my interest at the moment and my mood. Right now, I have “The Congressional Journal of Barber B. Conable, Jr., 1968-1984,” “Paris 1919,” by Margaret MacMillan, which I’m rereading, and Edith Wharton’s “The Age of Innocence,” which I just finished.

headline: Man Charged With Killing Mother at Sea in Inheritance Scheme Dies in Jail
abstract: Nathan Carman, 29, of Vernon, Vt., was to go on trial on murder charges in October. He had pleaded not guilty.
lead_paragraph: A Vermont man died in jail on Thursday morning while awaiting trial on federal charges that he had lured his mother on a fishing trip, killed her and sank the boat in a scheme to inherit his family’s estate, the U.S. Marshals Service said.

headline: Brutal Killing of Governor Heralds New Round of Violence in Darfur
abstract: The United Nations blamed Sudanese paramilitaries for the death of the governor of West Darfur, Khamis Abdullah Abakar. Sudan’s war has destabilized a fragile western region devastated by genocide in the early 2000s.
lead_paragraph: The killing of a powerful governor in Darfur, in western Sudan, has heightened worries that fighting between the country’s warring military factions is pushing a region blighted by genocide two decades ago into a new ethnic civil war.

headline: A Fashion Designer’s Classic Milanese Aperitivo
abstract: Damir Doma toasted his latest collection with his creative friends and collaborators.
lead_paragraph: In Milan, there’s one unofficial but very important entertaining rule: Never throw a party on a Saturday night. Monday through Friday, the city is brimming with creative people — the quiet engines running the design and fashion industries — but, when the weekend rolls around, they tend to leave for the nearby Swiss Alps or the Mediterranean coast. Weekdays are when the Milanese gather and the aperitivo, a postwork, pre-dinner cocktail hour, defines the city’s social life. “The Milanese are very busy,” says the fashion designer Damir Doma, 42, a native of Croatia who was raised in Germany and has been living in the northern Italian city since 2016. “Aperitivo brings everyone together for a short moment to have a drink and a chat.”

headline: Hipgnosis, the Album Artists Who Made Pink Floyd’s Pig Fly
De Blasio Owes City $475,000 for Bringing Police on Presidential Campaign
abstract: New York City’s Conflicts of Interest Board said the former mayor must reimburse the city for police officers’ travel, and pay a record fine.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, must reimburse the city nearly $320,000 and pay a $155,000 fine for bringing his security detail on trips during his failed presidential campaign, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board ordered on Thursday.

headline: At the Heart of the Documents Case: Trump’s Attachment to His Boxes
abstract: The former president has long stowed papers and odds and ends in cartons that he liked to keep close. His aides have called it the “beautiful mind” material.
lead_paragraph: During President Donald J. Trump’s years in the White House, his aides began to refer to the boxes full of papers and odds and ends he carted around with him almost everywhere as the “beautiful mind” material.

headline: Finance Executive Accused of Drugging and Raping Teen in Midtown Hotel
abstract: Michael Olson, 54, flew the girl around the country, passing her off as his daughter, prosecutors said. He kept spreadsheets of children he contacted, they said.
lead_paragraph: A 54-year-old finance executive targeted a 14-year-old girl through her Instagram account, passed her off as his daughter on trips around the country, gave her drugs and raped her in New York City hotel rooms, prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office said Thursday.

headline: Jurors Begin Deliberations in First Phase of Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial
abstract: If the jury finds Robert Bowers guilty of carrying out the 2018 massacre, the panel will weigh whether he should be sentenced to death.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks of wrenching testimony, the prosecution and the defense delivered closing arguments on Thursday in the first phase of the federal trial of the man charged with carrying out the deadliest antisemitic attack in the country’s history.

headline: Trump and Johnson Were Accused of Breaking Rules. One Lost Party Support.
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Boris Johnson are at the heart of political tempests at home, facing different accusations and far different results.
lead_paragraph: An angry, aggrieved former leader attacks the institutions he once led for accusing him of flouting the rules and lying about it. His allies whip up supporters against what they call a witch hunt. A country watches nervously, worried that this flamboyant, norm-busting figure could cause lasting damage.

headline: Indigenous Leaders Elated by Supreme Court Ruling on Adoptions
abstract: The decision on Thursday bolsters Indigenous sovereignty by upholding a 1978 law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees within tribes.
lead_paragraph: Maryanna Harstad was stunned and then elated when she heard that the Supreme Court had upheld a law on Thursday aimed at keeping Native American adoptees with their tribes and traditions.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: “The Righteous Gemstones” is back. Otherwise, check out a great new cabaret special or a joyful show about bird watching.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Righteous Gemstones’When to watch: Sunday at 10 p.m., on HBO.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended fiction this week includes a couple of story collections from writers who have long deserved wider recognition — the late Canadian author and musician Steven Heighton, who died last year at 60, and the playfully speculative writer Kelly Link, whose new book offers skewed riffs on traditional fairy tales. Also up: a satire of the publishing world, an ensemble portrait of young adulthood in Iowa City and a debut novel about a British transplant to Berlin.

headline: Retaking Villages Leaves Ukrainian Troops Exposed and Diving for Cover
abstract: The Ukrainian counteroffensive has enjoyed some early successes, but with every step forward, the soldiers are increasingly exposed to Russian firepower.
lead_paragraph: At the first whistle of an incoming shell, the soldiers in a newly liberated but desolate Ukrainian village dived into the weeds on a roadside on Thursday and lay face down as explosions erupted.

headline: Homer Jones Dies at 82; Wide Receiver Specialized in Bombs and Spikes
abstract: For a few years with the Giants, he was among the most feared pass catchers in the N.F.L. — and the acknowledged inventor of an end-zone celebration.
lead_paragraph: Homer Jones, one of the greatest receivers the New York Giants have ever had and one of the fastest in the history of pro football, died on Wednesday in Pittsburg, Texas. He was 82.

headline: A Russian antiwar activist dies in custody after claiming he had been tortured.
abstract: Anatoly Berezikov is the first known person in Russia to die in police custody after being jailed for opposing the invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A Russian activist has died in prison days after describing being tortured and expressing fear for his life, according to his lawyer, in what is believed to be the first known death in custody of a Russian opponent of the war in Ukraine.

headline: Florida Schools Question Content on Gender and Sexuality in A.P. Psychology
abstract: The embattled College Board said it would not change the course.
lead_paragraph: Advanced Placement Psychology is the subject of the latest skirmish in the monthslong battle between the state of Florida and the College Board.

headline: Airman Who Leaked Files Is Indicted on Charges of Mishandling Secrets
abstract: Jack Teixeira, 21, could face up to 60 years in prison after being indicted on six counts of retaining and transmitting classified national defense information.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury on Thursday indicted Jack Teixeira, a Massachusetts Air National Guardsman who posted dozens of secret intelligence reports and other sensitive documents on a social media server, on six counts of retaining and transmitting classified national defense information.

headline: Robert Mondavi Changed Wine. His Grandson Aims to Change Farming.
abstract: Carlo Mondavi takes on climate change by pushing regenerative and organic agriculture, with the help of a smart electric tractor.
lead_paragraph: Robert Mondavi paved the way for Napa Valley to take a place among the leading wine regions of the world and raised the bar for all American producers.

headline: Ocean Warmth Set a Record for May
abstract: North and South America had their warmest Mays on record, as the heat contributed to wildfires and posed risks to people and wildlife.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures are already breaking records this year: Last month was the warmest May for the world’s oceans since record-keeping began in 1850, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Ukraine’s Slow Progress
abstract: Also, Thailand’s leading candidate for prime minister faces an inquiry.
lead_paragraph: For a third straight day, Ukraine did not claim to have retaken any settlements in its counteroffensive, but said its forces were attacking Russian defenses in many areas along the front line.

headline: ‘Flamin’ Hot’: Biden Hosts Screening of the (Kind of) True Story of the Spicy Chip
abstract: The film was shown at the White House to an audience of about 600, including its director, Eva Longoria.
lead_paragraph: President Biden stepped on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday not to meet a foreign dignitary or sign a bill, but to celebrate a sort-of-true story about Flamin’ Hot Cheetos.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Advises Vaccine Makers to Aim at Only One Covid Variant
abstract: An F.D.A. advisory panel told manufacturers to aim the latest coronavirus vaccine for the fall at the dominant SARS-CoV-2 variant.
lead_paragraph: Vaccine makers should target the XBB variant of the coronavirus in a shot to be available in the fall, moving away from the existing formula that protected against the Omicron variant and an early form of the virus, an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration agreed on Thursday.

headline: Irma Capece Minutolo, Opera Singer and Partner to Exiled King, Dies at 87
abstract: A former Naples beauty queen, she became famous as the companion to the playboy Farouk I of Egypt, then carved out a successful opera career.
lead_paragraph: Irma Capece Minutolo, a Neapolitan beauty queen and opera singer whose relationship with the exiled Egyptian king and world-renowned hedonist Farouk I became fodder for gossip columnists around the world, died on June 7 at her home in Rome. She was 87.

headline: Judge Orders Lawyers in Trump Case to Start Getting Security Clearances
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon gave the defense team until Tuesday to begin the process, underscoring how classified information will be fundamental to the trial.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s indictment on charges of illegally retaining national defense information issued an order on Thursday instructing any lawyer who wants to take part in the case to start the process of obtaining a security clearance to handle classified material by early next week.

headline: Five Meerkats Mysteriously Die at the Philadelphia Zoo
abstract: Zoo officials suspect that a marking dye caused the deaths, but they said it could take weeks for test results to confirm.
lead_paragraph: The sudden deaths of five meerkats at the Philadelphia Zoo this month have stunned zookeepers and officials, and a dye used to mark the animals might be to blame.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Iyla and More
abstract: I’m the night editor on The Times’s International desk in Seoul. Here are five bits of entertainment that make me smile, even after the toughest night shift.
lead_paragraph: I’m the night editor on The Times’s International desk in Seoul. Here are five bits of entertainment that make me smile, even after the toughest night shift.

headline: Glenda Jackson, an Unnervingly Energizing Presence at Every Age
abstract: “I had been prepared to be awed, intimidated, even terrified,” Ben Brantley writes of meeting the actress in person five years ago.
lead_paragraph: She didn’t so much enter the restaurant as erupt into it, a fast-burning blaze of psychic exasperation that seemed to set the silverware rattling. Glenda Jackson was five minutes late for our meeting, and she looked ferociously disgusted with herself, with the universe, with the “bloody” London transit system and, most likely, with the prospect of having to talk about herself.

headline: Ukraine Is Finding It ‘Very Difficult to Advance’
abstract: Also, a victory for Native American tribes. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: After a string of notable early successes, progress has slowed in Ukraine’s counteroffensive to retake land occupied by Russian forces. For a third straight day, Ukraine did not claim to have retaken any settlements, and independent analysts say that recent Ukrainian advances in the southeast, where Kyiv began a multipronged assault last week, are better measured in yards than miles.

headline: Medical Group Says B.M.I. Alone Is Not Enough to Assess Health and Weight
abstract: Body mass index has long been a standard, but controversial, measurement of weight and health.
lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association voted to adopt a new policy on Tuesday encouraging doctors not to rely only on body mass index, a long-used but potentially misleading metric, when assessing weight and health. The policy officially recognizes the “historical harm” of B.M.I. and states that the metric has been used “for racist exclusion.”

headline: Border Agency Medical Officer Reassigned After Child’s Death in Officials’ Custody
abstract: Customs and Border Protection has removed its chief medical officer from his position after an 8-year-old girl died in the agency’s custody last month.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has removed its chief medical officer from his position after an 8-year-old girl died in the agency’s custody last month.

headline: At Least 15 Die in Highway Crash in Canada
abstract: A bus and a semitruck collided on a rural stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway in Manitoba on Thursday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: At least 15 people were killed in a crash along the Trans-Canada Highway near Carberry, Manitoba, on Thursday afternoon, after a bus carrying 25 people, mostly older people, collided with a semitruck, the police said.

headline: Disney’s Chief Financial Officer Is Stepping Down
abstract: Christine M. McCarthy, who held the role for eight years, helped stabilize the company during the pandemic and played a key role in Bob Chapek’s ouster.
lead_paragraph: Christine M. McCarthy, who in her eight years as Disney’s chief financial officer helped stabilize the company during the pandemic, when most of Disney was shut down, and played a key role in the ouster of Bob Chapek as chief executive last year, will step down on July 1, she said on Thursday.

headline: Debt Deal Behind Them, Lawmakers Plunge Into Bitter Spending Fight
abstract: House Republicans are pushing to pass measures with spending levels below those agreed to in the debt limit compromise, infuriating Democrats and raising the prospect of a shutdown this fall.
lead_paragraph: After narrowly avoiding a federal default, the Republican-controlled House and the Democratic-led Senate are now on a collision course over spending that could result in a government shutdown this year and automatic spending cuts in early 2025 with severe consequences for the Pentagon and an array of domestic programs.

headline: Counteroffensive Is Grueling and Costly, but Promising, Ukraine and U.S. Say
abstract: American and Ukrainian defense officials said the fight to dislodge dug-in Russian forces occupying southeastern Ukraine was expected to be brutal.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s counteroffensive against formidable Russian defenses has been grueling and bloody, Ukrainian and American officials acknowledged on Thursday, but they insisted that it was making gains and that any verdict on its success was extremely premature.

headline: I Won’t Let Donald Trump Invade My Brain
abstract: How to stay sane during the coming presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: I try to be a reasonable person. I try to be someone who looks out on the world with trusting eyes. Over the decades, I’ve built up certain expectations about how the world works and how people behave. I rely on those expectations as I do my job, analyzing events and anticipating what will happen next.

headline: Russian Ransomware Group Breached Federal Agencies in Cyberattack
abstract: The top U.S. cybersecurity agency said it did not have evidence that the group was acting in coordination with the Russian government.
lead_paragraph: A Russian ransomware group gained access to data from federal agencies, including the Energy Department, in an attack that exploited file transfer software to steal and sell back users’ data, U.S. officials said on Thursday.

headline: Max Homa Takes His Star Turn at the U.S. Open
abstract: The California native had previously played well at Los Angeles Country Club, but first rounds at major tournaments haven’t always gone smoothly. On Thursday, he found his game for a two-under 68.
lead_paragraph: For a decade now, Max Homa has had regrets.

headline: Rickie Fowler Reserves His Flash for the U.S. Open’s First Round
abstract: Fowler no longer wears blinding colors and his shaggy hair is long gone. But after years of struggle at major tournaments, the popular golfer quietly made U.S. Open history on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: No golf fans followed Rickie Fowler on Thursday dressed the same as he was. That used to be a thing in 2010 when Fowler, then 22, rode his relaxed dirt-biking roots and a boy band vibe complete with a top-to-toe orange outfit and a flat-brim hat to enormous popularity.

headline: Review: ‘The Whitney Album’ Looks to Theater to Remake a Painful Past
abstract: Eschewing a conventional narrative, Jillian Walker’s soulful show seeks to heal deep wounds through ritual and celebratory singalongs.
lead_paragraph: In “The Whitney Album,” a heady and ritualistic new show that recently opened at Soho Rep, the playwright and actor Jillian Walker uses Whitney Houston as an object lesson: The pressures heaped on gifted and famous Black women, Walker suggests, are stifling, destructive and rooted in colonial subjugation.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Francis Suarez
abstract: Mr. Suarez, who is entering the Republican presidential race, is a cryptocurrency enthusiast who holds a largely ceremonial job as mayor of Miami.
lead_paragraph: Francis X. Suarez, the two-term mayor of Miami who formally announced his entry into the 2024 presidential race on Thursday, is presenting himself as a fresh face for the Republican Party: a 45-year-old in a field led by a septuagenarian, and a Cuban American in a party whose elected officials are overwhelmingly white.

headline: Shell Station
abstract: Natan Last and the J.A.S.A. crossword class throw us some curveballs.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart take us for a ride on la strada. Molto bene!
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This is another acrostic with a byline that’s new to Times puzzles, a collaboration between David Balton and Jane Stewart. It excerpts a 1991 book called “Neither Here Nor There,” a European travelogue by the journalist and prolific nonfiction author Bill Bryson.

headline: Thieves’ Loot: A Warhol, a Pollock and 9 of Berra’s World Series Rings
abstract: Federal prosecutors announced charges against nine people in a scheme that spanned two decades and targeted museums, halls of fame and businesses in five states.
lead_paragraph: An alarm at the International Boxing Hall of Fame in Canastota, N.Y., blared at about 2 a.m. on a fall morning in 2015, prompting its director to drive to the building and learn that culprits had broken in and stolen six championship belts from the ’40s and ’50s.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Some Starbucks Are Banning Pride Décor, Union Says
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 16, 2023
lead_paragraph: “When I see a large Pride flag in the window I know it’s a welcoming place. I do not understand why all of the sudden they’re raising hell about it in the middle of June.”

headline: Corrections: June 16, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 16, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about American companies that are paying for enriched uranium from Russia misstated the status of an enriched uranium plant in Ohio. The plant is U.S.-owned, not European-owned, and is currently idle.

headline: Deadly Tornado Rips Through Perryton, Texas
abstract: People assessing the damage in Perryton filmed the rubble of a bank, a fire department and a natural gas facility.
lead_paragraph: People assessing the damage in Perryton filmed the rubble of a bank, a fire department and a natural gas facility.

headline: For Two Circus Performers, Love Takes Flight on and Off the Ground
abstract: A shared passion for acrobatics, costumes and bicycles led Ryan Murray and Juanita Cardenas to a wedding ceremony held in midair.
lead_paragraph: For circus performers, it takes a lot to stand out at a festival. But when Ryan Shinji Murray heard about how Juanita Cardenas arrived at the Montreal Complètement Cirque festival in 2015, he was intrigued.

headline: How My Father and I Drew a New Life
abstract: After my mother died, my father had a choice: Give up or reinvent himself.
lead_paragraph: When I was 13, my mother learned that she had multiple sclerosis. By that point she couldn’t drive, get dressed or walk by herself. My father became her sole caretaker, and she was less than appreciative.

headline: A Big Family Just Got a Little Bigger
abstract: Just months after they began dating in 2018, Jonathan Gold introduced Diana Ming, an only child of Chinese immigrants, to his large extended family. She said she felt immediately embraced.
lead_paragraph: Neither Diana Ming nor Jonathan Barrett Gold seemed to want their first date to ever end.

headline: At an ‘Apocalyptic Wedding’, Love (and Smoke) Was in the Air
abstract: Deanna Arthur and Grey Cohen were wed at City Hall in New York as the city’s polluted air broke historical records and an orange haze blanketed the smoke-filled sky.
lead_paragraph: On June 7, the skies were hazy and gray as smoke and ash billowed into New York from wildfires in eastern Canada. Despite the ‘end days are nigh’ gloom of the city, Deanna Marie Arthur and Grey Noah Cohen were strutting through the downtown streets in formal wedding attire — Ms. Arthur in an off-the-shoulder Jenny Yu gown and Mx. Cohen, who uses they/them pronouns and a gender-neutral courtesy title, in a gray tuxedo — and recording the rapidly darkening day with a hand-held video camera.

headline: A Relationship ‘Worth Fighting For’ Despite Some Bumps Along the Way
abstract: Fay Leshner and Andrew Ousley have survived some ups and downs over the years. The pandemic helped them appreciate the life they built.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Douglas Ousley and Fay Eva Leshner met through mutual friends on Aug. 9, 2014 while having cocktails at the now-closed Portuguese restaurant Pão! in SoHo. They bonded instantly, as creative New Yorkers often do.

headline: They Were Not Looking For Anything Serious. Surprise!
abstract: Hugh Baran and Jacob Rozenberg started out as friends with benefits, but eventually wanted to repair the world and host Shabbat together.
lead_paragraph: As Hugh Stephen Baran headed home in April 2015 to the Upper East Side of Manhattan after a Passover Seder with some high school friends in Englewood, N.J., Jacob Ellis Kaplan Rozenberg messaged him on Grindr, a dating app for gay men.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine’s counteroffensive presses on.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia is making gains, albeit at a high cost, Ukrainian and American officials said. But after initially retaking some small settlements and villages, Ukraine’s advances in the Donetsk and Zaporizhzhia regions are better measured in yards than miles, according to independent analysts.

headline: Word of the Day: chastise
abstract: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word chastise has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 21 in “Review: Pulling Back the Curtain on ‘The Magic Flute’ at the Met” by Oussama Zahr:

headline: Australia’s Opportunities and Challenges on the Path to ‘Net Zero’
abstract: Shipping sunshine? Alan Finkel’s take on the nation’s possible future as a leader in clean energy.
lead_paragraph: What does the transition to a zero-emissions future look like for Australia? This is the topic of “Powering Up: Unleashing the Clean Energy Supply Chain,” a new book by Alan Finkel, the former Australian chief scientist, released this week.

headline: Pope Francis Leaves Rome Hospital and Returns to Vatican After Surgery
abstract: Doctors have advised the 86-year-old pontiff to take it easy after an operation to deal with a hernia that caused painful intestinal blockages.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis returned to the Vatican on Friday after he was released from a Rome hospital following abdominal surgery for a hernia, the third time in two years that the 86-year-old pontiff has been hospitalized.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Choose Wisely, Choose Often: Ranked-Choice Voting Returns to New York
abstract: The new voting system was used in the mayor’s race in 2021. It is back this month for the primary races for the City Council.
lead_paragraph: The last time New Yorkers went to the polls, they had to contemplate a governor’s race and a slew of congressional races in the critical 2022 midterm elections.

headline: Southern Baptists’ Fight Over Female Leaders Shows Power of Insurgent Right
abstract: Moves this week to oust women from church leadership in the nation’s largest Protestant denomination offer an early look into the psyche of evangelical America ahead of 2024.
lead_paragraph: Two summers ago, an insurgent group of ultraconservative Southern Baptists branded themselves as pirates, vowing to “take the ship” of the nation’s largest Protestant denomination and steer it farther to the right on issues like sexuality and race.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: ‘Stan Lee’ Review: For the Cameo King, a Struggle to Hold the Spotlight
abstract: Disappointingly, this creation story of Lee gives way to the characters he helped create.
lead_paragraph: Onscreen, Stan Lee — the public face of Marvel Comics and the subject, mostly, of David Gelb’s chipper documentary of the same name — had cameos as an astronaut, a general, a strip club M.C., a beauty pageant judge, a letter carrier, an intergalactic barber, a psych ward resident, a hot dog vendor and many hapless pedestrians. He was never the superhero. But Lee believed that his success was because his superheroes’ neuroses, flaws and ego trips made each one a little bit like him.

headline: What to Know About Ezra Miller and ‘The Flash’
abstract: The 30-year-old star of the much-delayed DC film was in hot water amid a spate of legal troubles. Here’s where those cases stand.
lead_paragraph: “The Flash,” the much-delayed Warner Bros. superhero film about a speedster who travels back in time to try to prevent his mother’s murder, is finally, actually, for real hitting theaters on Friday. Based on the DC Comics character, the new blockbuster has survived three director changes and, most recently, the legal troubles of its star superhero, Ezra Miller.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including stories by K-Ming Chang, Heather Radke on butts and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including stories by K-Ming Chang, Heather Radke on butts and more.

headline: U.S. Soccer Team Thrashes Mexico in Grudge Match in Las Vegas
abstract: Two goals from Christian Pulisic led the United States over Mexico in a nasty Nations League semifinal that was ended early because of homophobic chanting.
lead_paragraph: In the first significant match for either team since the World Cup, the United States soccer team dominated a reeling Mexico, 3-0, in the semifinals of a regional championship tournament on Thursday night in Las Vegas. The victory, on the strength of two goals from the American star Christian Pulisic and another from forward Ricardo Pepi, sent the United States to the final of the tournament, the Concacaf Nations League. The Americans won the inaugural edition of the tournament in 2021.

headline: Mixed Business at an Anxious Art Basel
abstract: Dealers were hoping to send positive signals in the face of a possible downturn, but the Swiss fair’s bustle didn’t always translate into sales.
lead_paragraph: After an underwhelming series of auctions in New York in May, dealers exhibiting at this year’s Art Basel fair in Switzerland — which opened to V.I.P.s on Tuesday and welcomes the general public from Friday onward — hoped to quell concerns about a dip in the art market.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Wes Anderson's "Asteroid City."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Wes Anderson's "Asteroid City."

headline: See How the G.O.P. Has Reacted to the Trump Indictment
abstract: More than half of the Republicans in Congress have made public statements about Trump’s federal indictment. Most are not pleased.
lead_paragraph: More than half of the Republicans in Congress have made public statements about Trump’s federal indictment. Most are not pleased.

headline: What a Motherless Son Knows About Fatherhood
abstract: It would be fair to compare my cumulative understanding of grief and fatherhood, which I’ve acquired intuitively, incrementally and in fragments, to a carefully constructed sequence of images.
lead_paragraph: It would be fair to compare my cumulative understanding of grief and fatherhood, which I’ve acquired intuitively, incrementally and in fragments, to a carefully constructed sequence of images.

headline: Why Do So Few Democrats Want Biden to Run in 2024?
abstract: Obama’s former speechwriter Jon Favreau talks age, approval ratings and other obstacles the president will face in 2024.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Architecture, in Abstract: Quiz No. 3
abstract: Can you identify the cities around the world where these abstract architectural photographs were taken?
lead_paragraph: Can you identify the cities around the world where these abstract architectural photographs were taken?

headline: States Try Easing the Burden of Long-Term Care’s High Cost
abstract: Seeing their own financial benefits, too, Washington and California are among the states creating programs to help older residents.
lead_paragraph: It’s a retirement concern few of us want to face: At some point, four out of five older Americans will need help with daily needs like bathing, dressing, using the toilet or preparing meals.

headline: ‘The Power of Trees:’ Among the ‘Machines’ Fighting Climate Change
abstract: Adrian Benepe of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden believes in trees and is highlighting them in a new exhibit. And New York’s City Council is back on the ballot starting Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’ll meet the Lorax of Brooklyn, who says trees in New York lessen the effects of climate change. Also, early voting for the June 27 primaries begins on Saturday, with ranked-choice voting.

headline: A Bull or a Bear Market? It Doesn’t Matter.
abstract: Stocks still haven’t returned to their last peak, and our columnist is in the camp that says this isn’t a bull market yet. But he’s buying stock anyway.
lead_paragraph: The headlines and market analyses of the last few weeks, saying that stocks are in a bull market, may be a comfort even if they are potentially misleading.

headline: Who Says a Walk Can’t Be a Workout?
abstract: There are simple ways to increase intensity without turning your stroll into a slog.
lead_paragraph: We’re halfway through our monthlong newsletter series dedicated to the joys of walking. This week, we’re making our walk into a workout.

headline: Decoding the Antiwar Messages of Miniature Protesters in Russia
abstract: Fish, asterisks, blank messages and the crossed out Z letter: All of these are symbols of opposition to the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.
lead_paragraph: Fish, asterisks, blank messages and the crossed out Z letter: All of these are symbols of opposition to the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

headline: As Juneteenth Goes National, We Must Preserve the Local
abstract: The holiday has long flourished in local spaces of Black life in America.
lead_paragraph: It’s been two years since Juneteenth became a federal holiday, one we can celebrate together as a nation. The signing of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act into law in 2021 was an expression of real progress in the collective understanding of Black struggle that reinforced our national ideals of liberty and dignity. But I confess my ambivalence. I am worried about what official national recognition might do to what has always been a community-based holiday.

headline: A Better Way to Help Families
abstract: In an important shift in poverty policy, states are starting to provide lower-income families with something new: cash.
lead_paragraph: For the past three decades, federal aid for lower-income families has largely consisted of handing out coupons: housing vouchers for families that need housing; food stamps for families that need food; Medicaid cards for health care.

headline: The Tale the West Tells Itself About Ukraine
abstract: Ukraine’s best path to peace is to be well armed and supported outside NATO — not to join it.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the stories we tell to win the war help us lose the peace. After the 9/11 attacks, the United States decided the Taliban government in Afghanistan was as culpable as the Qaeda terrorists who struck America. It then spent 20 years trying to keep the Taliban entirely out of power, only to cede the whole country to them.

headline: ‘I Cannot Believe We Made It’: In the Flood, a Rescue Behind the Front
abstract: To many, the destruction of a dam on the Dnipro River in Ukraine brought devastation. To some stranded in Russian-occupied territory, it brought freedom.
lead_paragraph: At night, she had looked at the twinkling lights of her home city, just a mile or so away but a world apart. For months, she had been kept away by the dangers of Russia’s war in Ukraine, stranded on a river island, after the front line shifted while she was on vacation.

headline: Is a Revolution in Cancer Treatment Within Reach?
abstract: New treatments are changing once deadly forms of the disease into manageable long-term illnesses. But not all patients are benefiting.
lead_paragraph: Carol MacKenzie had just finished playing a round of golf when she noticed some swelling and pain in her neck. It was 2014, and 18 years had passed since Ms. MacKenzie finished treatment for breast cancer. But it had returned. This time the cancer was growing inside several lymph nodes around her neck, plunging her back into treatment long after she thought that was all behind her.

headline: What Has Happened in Minneapolis Since George Floyd Was Murdered
abstract: A 2022 state review found that racial discrimination was endemic in the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: A cellphone video taken by a teenage bystander showing a white police officer, Derek Chauvin, pressing his knee on the neck of a 46-year-old Black man, George Floyd, on a Minneapolis street corner on May 25, 2020, led to the largest social-justice protest movement in the United States in a half-century.

headline: Hiding Behind the Hedges
abstract: In Los Angeles, the wealthy will pay a fortune to protect their private lives from prying eyes. At least leafy green walls are good for the environment.
lead_paragraph: The homes of Hollywood’s rich and famous have long been enclosed by walls of sky-high ficus, designed to shield their wealthy occupants from paparazzi and peeping Toms alike. Robert Frost may have thought good fences make good neighbors, but in Los Angeles, those fences are planted rather than built.

headline: A New Front in Reparations and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: The N.C.A.A. Wants More Money From TV. Maxing That Out Could Prove Tricky.
abstract: Many college sports championships, including the marquee women’s basketball tournament, have been sold as a bundle. The prospect of selling separately raises questions for dozens of sports.
lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, fans of college sports like softball, baseball, women’s basketball and more than two dozen others have known just where to find N.C.A.A. championships — on ESPN’s spectrum of channels.

headline: Alone Together: 4 Picture Books That Pair Solitude With Friendship
abstract: “Sometimes it’s nice to be alone. Just you, reading your book. … But what if a friend stops by?”
lead_paragraph: Picture books can do anything. Today they take on subjects that were largely ignored during my childhood, such as socioemotional awareness.

headline: Creeping Shariah Has Nothing on the Woke Mob
abstract: How conservatives went from demonizing Muslims to wooing them.
lead_paragraph: In his speech at the Republican convention in 2016, Donald Trump spoke of the mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, where a man with jihadist sympathies murdered 49 people. “As your president, I will do everything in my power to protect our L.G.B.T.Q. citizens from the violence and oppression of a hateful foreign ideology,” he said.

headline: He Ran Sudan’s Most Storied Hotel. Then He Had to Leave Everything Behind.
abstract: Thanasis Pagoulatos led the family business, Khartoum’s oldest inn, through decades of tumult. Sudan’s latest breakdown proved too much.
lead_paragraph: Even as fighter jets tore through Khartoum’s skies in April and the streets became a dystopian war zone amid a showdown between rival Sudanese fighters, Thanasis Pagoulatos had no intention of fleeing.

headline: Tunisians Mourn a Hard-Fought Freedom Rapidly Slipping Away
abstract: When reflecting on their Arab Spring revolution, Tunisians often say that freedom of expression was the only concrete achievement. As the country slides back toward autocracy, that, too, is being quickly eroded.
lead_paragraph: Mosaïque FM, Tunisia’s most popular radio station, comes to life each morning around 5:30 a.m. with the martial strains of the national anthem. Next comes a voice crooning a verse from the Quran, then music and news, followed by the political show “Watch What They Say,” which has chronicled the floundering of the country’s young democracy and its recent U-turn toward autocracy.

headline: There’s No Uber or Lyft. There Is a Communal Tesla.
abstract: An innovative E.V. ride-sharing program is bringing low-cost clean transportation to an agricultural town in California’s Central Valley. Others are following suit.
lead_paragraph: Three mornings a week, Herminia Ibarra makes her way to a fleet of sparkling electric vehicles lined up in a dusty alley alongside a former diesel repair shop. Of the five Chevy Bolts, three Tesla Ys, two Volkswagen e-Golfs and a BMW i3, she always tries to snag her favorite: the red Bolt set up with her Bluetooth. In this E.V., she will pick up the two retired farmworkers who are her regular clients and ferry them on two-lane roads to their dialysis appointments 20 miles away.

headline: Remaking an 825-Square-Foot Island Escape
abstract: The tiny house was theirs for $275,000. But there was one big drawback: Without a foundation, it was sinking into the earth.
lead_paragraph: The tiny house was theirs for $275,000. But there was one big drawback: Without a foundation, it was sinking into the earth.

headline: They Found a Tiny, Affordable Cabin on an Island. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: The 825-square-foot house was theirs for $275,000. But there was one big drawback: Without a foundation, it was sinking into the earth.
lead_paragraph: For an escape in the San Juan Islands, a little more than two hours north of Seattle, Joe Herrin knew he wouldn’t need much.

headline: Making Art Out of Bombshells and Memories in Vietnam
abstract: Tuan Andrew Nguyen’s videos and sculptures uncover haunting artifacts and stories from the Vietnam War. They’re coming soon to the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Not quite 20 minutes into “The Unburied Sounds of a Troubled Horizon,” a film by the artist Tuan Andrew Nguyen, the camera settles on a distinctive-looking monument at the far end of a wooden footbridge. We’re in Quang Tri province, central Vietnam. The bridge spans the Ben Hai River, which for 21 years, from the French debacle at Dien Bien Phu in 1954 to the fall of Saigon in 1975, was the demarcation line between North and South Vietnam. A couple of miles in either direction was the so-called Demilitarized Zone, a “buffer” that became one of the most-bombed places on the planet.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 16, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Amazon’s Freevee Embraces the Judy-Verse
abstract: The free, ad-supported streaming service is quadrupling down on Judge Judith Sheindlin. And she’s bringing her “nepo babies” along.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Judge Judith Sheindlin, the razor-tongued court show star, decamped from the dying medium of daytime broadcast syndication and joined Amazon for a streaming-era experiment.

headline: Murder in a Moneyed Fire Island Enclave
abstract: Gossips, cheaters and hypocrites strut through Emma Rosenblum’s delicious thriller of manners, “Bad Summer People.”
lead_paragraph: Who is the worst of the BAD SUMMER PEOPLE (Flatiron, 261 pp., $28.99) in Emma Rosenblum’s addictive thriller of manners set among the rich and socially anxious in Salcombe, a snooty village on New York’s Fire Island?

headline: After an Epic Meltdown, Ample Hills Creamery Aims to Rise Again
abstract: The Brooklyn-based ice cream chain boomed with the help of Oprah and Disney, then went bust. But the couple behind it are opening new shops and thinking small.
lead_paragraph: It was a sad day in Brooklyn when Ample Hills Creamery closed its doors. Just before last Christmas, the beloved ice cream parlor in Prospect Heights — and all 12 of its remaining scoop shops across the country — shut down after a decade-long roller-coaster ride of brand-building, bankruptcies and heartbreak.

headline: As Blinken Heads to China, a Wall of Suspicion Awaits Him
abstract: Even as Beijing prepares for a visit by the secretary of state, China’s leader has made clear his expectations of more hostile superpower competition.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken makes his long-delayed visit to China beginning Sunday in the hope of slowing the downward spiral of relations between Beijing and Washington. But China’s increasingly assertive, at times outright hostile, stance suggests that the visit will be as much about confrontation as détente.

headline: Reddit Revolts, MrBeast’s YouTube Empire and Peak Trust and Safety?
abstract: Social platforms are entering a strange and uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: Moderators on Reddit have shut down their forums in protest of a new policy that charges users for access to the site’s API. The revolt has put Kevin in child care-wisdom-withdrawal (RIP r/daddit) — and left many other users without their favorite subreddits. But does the incident say something more about the future of the internet?

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How noise could take years off your life. Also in this edition: where to eat in New York City this summer, and the hunt for the Idaho killer.
lead_paragraph: How noise could take years off your life. Also in this edition: where to eat in New York City this summer, and the hunt for the Idaho killer.

headline: Prince Harry and Meghan to Part Ways With Spotify
abstract: The couple’s production company and the streaming service announced an end to their relationship, less than a year after Meghan’s podcast debuted on the platform.
lead_paragraph: Spotify and Archewell Audio, the production company started by Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have ended their partnership less than a year after her podcast, “Archetypes,” debuted on the platform, the companies announced on Friday.

headline: Bill Gates, in First Visit to China Since 2019, Meets With Xi
abstract: China’s president, Xi Jinping, called Mr. Gates “the first American friend I met in Beijing this year.”
lead_paragraph: In a rare encounter with an American business figure, Xi Jinping, China’s leader, met Friday with Bill Gates as officials from Washington were set to arrive in Beijing in an effort to restart bilateral discussions.

headline: Today’s Top News: An Investigation Into the Minneapolis Police, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: The Kids Take the Climate Change Fight to Court
abstract: A group of young environmentalists argue that Montana’s embrace of fossil fuels is robbing them of their future.
lead_paragraph: This week, a historic case has landed in a Montana courtroom. A group of young environmentalists is suing the state, arguing that its embrace of fossil fuels is destroying pristine environments, upending cultural traditions and robbing young residents of a healthy future.

headline: Japan Changes Its Rape Laws to Require Consent
abstract: Japan’s previous laws on sexual assault did not mention permission and required that the crime include physical force. The new law also raises the age of consent to 16, from 13.
lead_paragraph: Japan changed its definition of rape and raised the age of consent to 16, from 13, on Friday, bringing the country’s sex crimes laws closer in line with those in the United States and Europe.

headline: Donald Trump Has a Polling Problem
abstract: Most Republicans still support Trump. But the polls still suggest the federal indictment is hurting him.
lead_paragraph: The 50 percent threshold in a poll can sometimes be distracting. When more than half of people give a certain answer, it often becomes the dominant message to emerge from the poll question. It is the answer that appears to have won. Yet the most important information may nonetheless be lurking elsewhere.

headline: Germany’s security strategy aims to set priorities after Russia’s invasion, but offers few hard commitments.
abstract: Haunted by its responsibility for World War II and Nazi tyranny, Germany embraced the pursuit of peace with the fervor of a convert. But on Wednesday, its government took an important step toward shedding that legacy as war once again transforms the European continent.
