lead_paragraph: In a 1940 review of the film “Pride and Prejudice,” the New York Times critic Bosley Crowther wrote, “Laurence Olivier is Darcy, that’s all there is to it — the arrogant, sardonic Darcy whose pride went before a most felicitous fall.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Where a Photographer’s Curiosity Became a Two-Year Commitment
abstract: In 2021, Jonah Markowitz took an interest in the section of Kensington, Brooklyn, known as “Little Bangladesh.” He hasn’t stopped visiting.
lead_paragraph: Though he grew up just a few miles away, Jonah Markowitz, a photographer and documentarian based in Brooklyn, knew little about the neighborhood of Kensington before 2021. That’s when he noticed, in New York City data from the year before, that an outsize portion of applications for new business licenses came from the area that included Kensington.

headline: Ron DeSantis Is Young, Has Little Kids and Wants America to Know It
abstract: At 44, he is more than three decades younger than Donald Trump and Joe Biden. He is subtly playing up that age gap, even if his right-wing views leave him out of step with many younger voters.
lead_paragraph: As top-tier presidential candidates go, Ron DeSantis is something of a rarity these days. He was born after the Vietnam War, he came of age when computers were common in American homes and he still has young children of his own, rather than enough grandchildren to fill a basketball team.

headline: ‘I Saw a $20 Bill Float Through the Air Into the Intersection’
abstract: Mesmerized by flying cash, returning to a favorite haunt and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How the Head of the Universal Hip Hop Museum Spends His Sundays
abstract: For Rocky Bucano, who fell for the music after buying a Salt-N-Pepa CD in 1986, his work in the Bronx “doesn’t feel like work.”
lead_paragraph: The Universal Hip Hop Museum, which will be part of Bronx Point, a new mixed-use development with affordable housing in the South Bronx, is not scheduled to open until 2025. But that hasn’t stopped Rocky Bucano, the museum’s executive director, from celebrating hip-hop’s 50th anniversary this year.

headline: The ‘Fiercely Loyal’ Adams Adviser Agitating From Inside City Hall
abstract: Ingrid Lewis-Martin may be the second most powerful person in New York City government. But her views, leadership style and ethics have raised questions.
lead_paragraph: In the days after Eric Adams was elected mayor of New York, several of his supporters approached him with some uncomfortable advice.

headline: Why It Seems Everything We Knew About the Global Economy Is No Longer True
abstract: While the world’s eyes were on the pandemic, China and the war in Ukraine, the paths to prosperity and shared interests have grown murkier.
lead_paragraph: When the world’s business and political leaders gathered in 2018 at the annual economic forum in Davos, the mood was jubilant. Growth in every major country was on an upswing. The global economy, declared Christine Lagarde, then the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, “is in a very sweet spot.”

headline: Pharrell Williams, Louis Vuitton’s New Don
abstract: The American star steps into shoes once filled by Virgil Abloh at Louis Vuitton. His first collection debuts in Paris this week.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Pharrell Williams was in the men’s atelier on the second floor of Louis Vuitton’s corporate office in Paris, sunglasses on, surveying his new perch.

headline: What’s Behind the Widening Divide Between New York City and Its Suburbs?
abstract: Tension between the city and its surrounding areas over issues like crime, immigration and congestion pricing has grown since the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Ed Day says he proudly remembers his days as a New York City police commander, fighting crime and helping to restore the city’s luster. But as the executive of suburban Rockland County, Mr. Day now views the city differently.

headline: Samantha Irby Says It’s OK to Hate Your Body
abstract: “The tyranny around loving yourself is bonkers to me,” says the best-selling author and writer for “And Just Like That.”
lead_paragraph: “The tyranny around loving yourself is bonkers to me,” says the best-selling author and writer for “And Just Like That.”

headline: Pride at Work Is Priceless, but It’s Nice to Be Paid
abstract: In June, when rainbow flags are everywhere, including corporate logos, it’s meaningful to see a company support queer employees and allies with compensation.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Why a Huge Coal Power Plant in Bangladesh Keeps Running Out of Coal
abstract: The problems are an early warning for countries, especially poorer ones, that are investing in new coal-burning plants even as solar and wind get cheaper.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s newest, most contested coal-burning power plants began operation in December. By January, it had ground to a halt for a month. Again, in April, it sat idle for 23 days.

headline: A Bear That Looked Like a Raccoon and Had a Dangerous Appetite
abstract: The “dawn bear” may have been one of the earliest carnivorous mammals, and its taste for shellfish may have gotten it in trouble.
lead_paragraph: Some 30 million years ago, a primitive bear roamed near a river in what is now North Dakota. A male, he probably looked like a raccoon and might have eaten like an otter. An inspection of the curious critter’s skeleton provides details of the animal’s brief, and likely painful, life and clues about the evolution of early carnivores.

headline: As Trump Battles Charges, Biden Focuses on the Business of Governing
abstract: The past week appears to provide a blueprint for the way the White House wants to handle the politically touchy subject of former President Donald J. Trump’s legal troubles.
lead_paragraph: Talk of federal indictments, classified documents and anything related to the president’s predecessor are out. Bridge repair, “junk fees” and prescription drug prices are in.

headline: Where Did We Go Wrong in Afghanistan?
abstract: In “By All Means Available,” the veteran strategist Michael G. Vickers tallies achievements and missteps across the Cold War and the war on terror.
lead_paragraph: An implicit question haunts this illuminating and richly detailed memoir by Michael G. Vickers, the senior intelligence official at the center of America’s long war for the greater Middle East. It’s a question that has acquired greater immediacy since it was posed in 1998 by Jimmy Carter’s former national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski: “What is more important in the history of the world?” he said. “Some stirred-up Islamists or the liberation of Central Europe and the end of the Cold War?”

headline: It’s Sunday at the U.S. Open, and the Leaders Are Tied
abstract: Los Angeles Country Club has sometimes seemed forgiving. But the final round could pose a formidable test for the contenders.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open, one of golf’s most fearsome tests, is headed into its final round at Los Angeles Country Club. Although the course has sometimes seemed more forgiving than past Open venues, any championship round has the potential to become excruciating — especially when the final round starts with a tie atop the leaderboard.

headline: Black Experience, Past and Present, Made Haunting and Surreal
abstract: In his new story collection, “Fat Time and Other Stories,” Jeffery Renard Allen distorts reality to explore the lives of Black people.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Ellison brought readers to underground places and dared them to listen for lower frequencies to find a frank and fearsome accounting of Black experience. In the seven decades since the publication of “Invisible Man,” writers ranging from Toni Morrison and Edward P. Jones to Jesmyn Ward and Colson Whitehead have chosen storytelling modes featuring postmodernism, magic realism, and both lyric and gritty realism to explore and ennoble the ordinary and extraordinary lives of Black people past and present.

headline: With Everything Going Wrong, the Cardinals Still See Opportunity
abstract: St. Louis, a perennial playoff contender, is having its worst season in decades, forcing it into an unfamiliar position: an underdog.
lead_paragraph: Oliver Marmol wanted a bagel on Saturday morning. This is New York, so it should have been easy to get one. But this is also 2023, and Marmol manages the St. Louis Cardinals. Nothing comes easily.

headline: He Went After Crypto Companies. Then Someone Came After Him.
abstract: Kyle Roche was a rising star in the field of cryptocurrency law — until his career imploded. Who orchestrated his downfall?
lead_paragraph: When he arrived in London in late January 2022, Kyle Roche was riding high. At just 34 years old, he had established himself as one of the biggest players in the burgeoning field of cryptocurrency litigation. He boasted a law firm bearing his name, lawsuits filed against more than a dozen crypto companies and a huge verdict against the man who claimed to have invented Bitcoin.

headline: How Local Officials Seek Revenge on Their Hometown Newspapers
abstract: When coverage upsets them, towns and counties are revoking newspapers’ lucrative contracts to print public notices.
lead_paragraph: Two of the most powerful women in the village of Delhi in central New York sat face to face in a brick building on Main Street for what would become a fight over the First Amendment.

headline: After a Winter Deluge, California Rivers Are Too Dangerous to Enjoy
abstract: Several counties have banned recreation on rivers that flow from the Sierra Nevada because of swift currents and fatalities.
lead_paragraph: Gwyny Pett has been visiting the Kern River for decades, camping there as a girl and then taking her own children, now grown, to splash in shallows so calm they felt like a private pool. She has seen it in dry cycles like last year, when the river was difficult to explore not because of surging water, but because she turned her ankles on the exposed pebbles.

headline: Black Artists Embrace Ancient Egypt. Egyptians Aren’t Happy About It.
abstract: A new exhibit in a Dutch museum explores how Black musicians have drawn inspiration and pride from the idea that ancient Egypt was an African culture. Egyptians say it distorts their history and identity.
lead_paragraph: A new Dutch museum exhibit declares, “Egypt is a part of Africa,” which might strike most people who have seen a map of the world as an uncontroversial statement.

headline: Addicts Went in for Treatment. Instead They Were Enslaved.
abstract: Families in Indonesia thought they were sending their sons to a rehab facility run by a powerful local official. Those who stayed there say it was a brutal human slavery operation.
lead_paragraph: The Indonesian anti-corruption investigators began hunting for the powerful local official after they caught two of his aides taking a $40,000 bribe.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The High-Risk Feat of Bringing “American Born Chinese” to TV’
abstract: For years, Gene Luen Yang was convinced a single character in his groundbreaking graphic novel would doom any attempt at an adaptation. What changed?
lead_paragraph: Almost everyone who reads “American Born Chinese,” Gene Luen Yang’s groundbreaking graphic novel, is a little afraid of Chin-Kee.

headline: He Lives in the Double Helix of My Cells, but I Do Not Know Him
abstract: Conceived with the help of a sperm donor, I have never known my biological father. Instead I found fathers in teachers, coaches, family friends and my grandfather.
lead_paragraph: I heard my father’s voice for the first time three years ago when I was 14 years old. For years, a CD had been sitting in a clear plastic case in my desk drawer, but I had never been able to get myself to play it. I would pick up the shiny disc, stare at the faded black ink that said “Donor interview,” notice my distorted reflection in the silver circle, then put the CD back down.

headline: The Supreme Court Finally Strikes the Right Balance on Voting Rights
abstract: A new ruling finds Alabama discriminated against Black voters.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important realities of American life is this: No nation can fully undo the effects of 345 years of state-sanctioned bigotry — from slavery to Jim Crow — in 59 years. The period between the arrival of the first slaves on colonial shores in 1619 and the abolition of legalized discrimination with the passage of the Civil Rights Act in 1964 is simply too long, the discrimination too ingrained and the distortion of society too great to wave the wand of legal and cultural reform and quickly realize the dream of American equality.

headline: ‘What the Hell Happened to the California of the ’50s and ’60s?’
abstract: Gavin Newsom wants to build. Not everyone is on board.
lead_paragraph: By the time I talked to Gavin Newsom, the governor of California, he was clearly frustrated. “This is ridiculous,” he said. “These guys write reports and they protest. But we need to build. You can’t be serious about climate and the environment without reforming permitting and procurement in this state.”

headline: Readers in Asia: Tell Us About Your Hometown’s Foods
abstract: We may include your response in the Asia Pacific Morning Briefing.
lead_paragraph: I love talking about the foods of New York City, where I was born and raised. But that’s not just bagels and pizza. Instead, when I have friends in town, I make them try the flavors of my New York City.

headline: Ukraine Appears to Make a Small Gain in the South as Counteroffensive Continues
abstract: A Russian official and military bloggers said Sunday that Kyiv’s forces had retaken another village in their fight to recapture territory, a claim the Russian Defense Ministry denied.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have retaken a small village in the south of the country, a local Russian official and military bloggers said on Sunday, one of the first reports of a territorial gain in the Zaporizhzhia region since the start of a major counteroffensive earlier this month.

headline: The Tyranny of Relentless Positivity
abstract: Samantha Irby is akin to our poet laureate of peevishness.
lead_paragraph: I spend a lot of time — maybe you do, too — thinking about happiness. What is it? How can I get more of it? But there are other times — and maybe this also applies to you — when I just think, forget all that: Life is hard, and who says lasting happiness is even within reach? It’s in those moments that Samantha Irby’s work feels so valuable and refreshing. I spoke to Irby, the best-selling humorist who recently published her fifth book of essays, “Quietly Hostile,” and who is a contributing producer on the new season of “And Just Like That,” the “Sex and the City” revival, about the tyranny of positivity.

headline: 23 Shot, 1 Fatally, at a Juneteenth Celebration in Illinois
abstract: An unknown number of people used multiple weapons to open fire at a Juneteenth celebration in Willowbrook, Ill., officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least one person was killed and 22 others wounded in a shooting just after midnight Sunday at a large Juneteenth celebration in a strip mall parking lot in Willowbrook, Ill., southwest of Chicago, officials said.

headline: Verstappen Wins Another Day of Follow the Leader
abstract: Max Verstappen’s sixth win of the season was his third straight wire-to-wire affair.
lead_paragraph: Maybe beating Max Verstappen is the wrong goal now. Maybe the objective for the world’s (second-best) drivers needs to pivot to something more modest, more achievable, in the short term.

headline: Pope Francis Thanks Well-Wishers for Support During Hospital Stay
abstract: The pontiff, giving a public address for the first time since undergoing abdominal surgery, expressed gratitude for the “affection, care and friendship” he had received.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis prayed with a crowd of thousands in St. Peter’s Square on Sunday, two days after he was discharged from a Rome hospital, giving thanks for the “closeness” he had felt during his hospitalization for abdominal surgery.

headline: ‘A Terrible Tragedy’: Uganda Reels From Deadly Terrorist Attack
abstract: It was one of the worst terrorist acts to hit the nation in decades, as militants burned down dormitories with students still inside and hacked others to death.
lead_paragraph: The militants reached the private boarding school compound just before midnight, as students were going to bed, on a partly cloudy night in a small town in the lush western fields of Uganda.

headline: Mississippi’s Many Education Lessons
abstract: Responses to Nicholas Kristof’s column about education progress in Mississippi. Also: The “frenemy” relationship; predictions about tech; keeping your home safe.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘You Can’t Protect Some Life and Not Others’
abstract: No major political party embodies a consistent ethic of life.
lead_paragraph: With over a year to go until the presidential election, I am already dreading what this next political season will feel like — the polarity, the vitriol, the exhaustion, the online fighting, the misinformation, the possibility of another Trump nomination. I already know that I won’t feel represented by the platforms of either party. I know I’ll feel politically estranged and frustrated.

headline: Lisl Steiner, Photographer Who Glimpsed Luminaries Up Close, Dies at 95
abstract: A flamboyant photojournalist with the moxie to stand up to autocrats, she captured the intimate moments of leading figures of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Lisl Steiner, a flamboyant photojournalist who was celebrated for her intimate, emotive images of history-tilting figures like Fidel Castro, John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as well as luminaries of music, stage and sports, died on June 7 in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 95.

headline: A Cult ‘Hiding in Plain Sight’ Amid the New York Brownstones
abstract: In “The Sullivanians,” Alexander Stille recalls the heyday of an experiment in communal living that blurred the boundaries between therapists, patients and lovers.
lead_paragraph: Legal marijuana notwithstanding, true New Yorkers have long prided themselves on resisting certain Californish things. Malls. Cars. Cults.

headline: A Hot New Tater Tot Casserole
abstract: Romel Bruno’s hot-dish-inspired recipe is full of eggy custard, Cheddar, sausage and scallions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Happy Father’s Day to all who celebrate. For those who do, how about this sausage and egg tater tot casserole (above), a breakfast hot dish in the Midwestern tradition, in advance of a long day of chores around the house? It’s very Pelican Rapids, very Sauk Centre — Minnesota nice! And dads will appreciate it much more than, say, a fancy panda tie.

headline: Lionel Messi, Saudi Arabia and the Deal That Paid Off for Both Sides
abstract: A contract between Messi and Saudi Arabia’s tourism authority offers a glimpse at the details of their multimillion-dollar relationship.
lead_paragraph: As the sun set over a seemingly endless expanse of open sea, Lionel Messi took a seat at the edge of a boat, stretched out a leg and posed for the photograph that would announce the beginning of his public partnership with Saudi Arabia.

headline: ‘Just Disgusting’: A Nevada City Confronts Millions of Smelly Mormon Crickets
abstract: Residents in Elko have tried to use chemicals, pressurized washers and hot water mixed with bleach to remove the insects, which stink when they’re dead.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Mormon crickets have arrived in Elko, Nev., the spindly copper creatures blanketing parts of the city, so staff members at the Shilo Inns Elko on Saturday discussed ways to combat them.

headline: Dozens of Students Killed in Terrorist Attack on Ugandan School
abstract: Militants threw firebombs inside the boys’ residential hall, sparking a fire that engulfed the whole building.
lead_paragraph: Militants threw firebombs inside the boys’ residential hall, sparking a fire that engulfed the whole building.

headline: Pixar’s ‘Elemental’ Falls Flat, Adding to Worries About the Brand
abstract: The original animated film took in $29.5 million at the box office, by far the worst opening in Pixar’s three-decade history. “The Flash,” from Warner Bros., also struggled.
lead_paragraph: Pixar is damaged as a big-screen brand.

headline: Israel Eases West Bank Settlement Rules, Clearing Way for New Homes
abstract: The change could accelerate the construction of thousands of new houses in the occupied territory and puts a far-right minister in charge of giving approvals.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli government on Sunday decided to ease and expedite the process for approving new Jewish settlement construction in the occupied West Bank amid plans to advance thousands of new housing units there.

headline: Revisiting ‘The Light in the Piazza’ Through an Asian American Lens
abstract: A new Encores! staging of the 2005 musical, starring Ruthie Ann Miles, considers what it is like to feel like an outsider, at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Inside a New York City Center studio, at a rehearsal for the Encores! revival of “The Light in the Piazza,” two young lovers in 1950s Italy were meeting for the first time.

headline: Why the Pentagon Papers Leaker Tried to Get Prosecuted Near His Life’s End
abstract: When Daniel Ellsberg was 42, a judge threw out Espionage Act charges against him. At 90, he sought such charges again in hope of challenging their constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: In the last years of his long and remarkable life, Daniel Ellsberg, the disenchanted military analyst who famously leaked the so-called Pentagon Papers in 1971, wanted to be prosecuted. And he hoped I would help pave the way.

headline: Saskia Hamilton, Poet Who Edited Another Poet’s Letters, Dies at 56
abstract: In addition to her prizewinning writing, she was known for editing the correspondence between the poet Robert Lowell and the writer Elizabeth Hardwick.
lead_paragraph: Saskia Hamilton, a prizewinning poet who also shed new light on the tumultuous relationship between the poet Robert Lowell and the writer Elizabeth Hardwick with a 2019 book compiling their letters and those of their friends, died on June 7 at her home in Manhattan. She was 56.

headline: ‘Lizard Boy’ Review: Swipe Right for the Hero With Green Scaly Skin
abstract: Justin Huertas’s indie-rock musical, in which he also stars, follows a young misfit whose first date spirals into a comic book adventure.
lead_paragraph: As “Lizard Boy,” a 2015 musical now making its New York debut at Theater Row, dragged some 20 minutes past its advertised 90, I began to wonder what the net positives of comic books have been on the culture. Presented in a Prospect Theater Company production, after a showing at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last year, this quirky indie-rock show, with book, music and lyrics by Justin Huertas, traffics in that medium’s clichés, down to a protagonist with a stunted understanding of grown-up matters. (And, no, I don’t think the show is meant for kids.)

headline: Northern India Endures a Heat Wave, and a Wave of Deaths
abstract: Some doctors believe the high number of fatalities is tied to the temperatures. But the authorities are still trying to determine how many people died and what exactly killed them.
lead_paragraph: An unusually intense heat wave has swept across northern India in the last four days, with some hospitals in the state of Uttar Pradesh recording a higher-than-usual number of deaths. Doctors there are convinced there’s a link between the punishing temperatures and the deaths of their patients, but officials are investigating what role the dangerous combination of heat and humidity played in the rise in mortality.

headline: Both of the One of Us
abstract: The writer and translator who won the 2022 International Booker Prize talk about their relationship as interpreters of words and feelings, and about the alchemy of translation itself.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Barr Says Documents Case Against Trump Is ‘Entirely of His Own Making’
abstract: The former attorney general, who has become a vocal critic of Donald Trump, was one of two people who served in the former president’s cabinet to question his judgment on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: William P. Barr, who served as attorney general under President Donald J. Trump, excoriated his former boss on Sunday for “reckless conduct” that led to Mr. Trump’s indictment on charges of mishandling classified documents, saying that the case was “entirely of his own making.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Blinken in Beijing
abstract: Also, Times graphics show how Russia likely blew up Ukraine’s dam.
lead_paragraph: Antony Blinken arrived in China yesterday — the first visit by a U.S. secretary of state to China since 2018 — in the hope of slowing the downward spiral of relations between Beijing and Washington.

headline: A Month of Pride, but Also Division
abstract: Pride month events are drawing crowds across the nation, but also backlash.
lead_paragraph: Pride month events are drawing crowds across the nation, but also backlash.

headline: This $5,750-a-Month Brooklyn Apartment Has a Smell Test
abstract: New Yorkers are used to finding quirky situations when apartment hunting, but a ban on cooking meat and fish in the building might be a new one.
lead_paragraph: The real estate listing that appeared briefly in Brooklyn last week sounded beguiling: two spacious, sun-drenched, full-floor apartments in a wide brick townhome in Fort Greene with spectacular outdoor spaces and period details.

headline: Only For Show
abstract: David Liben-Nowell treats us to an old favorite.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: Donald Triplett, ‘Case 1’ in the Study of Autism, Dies at 89
abstract: He was widely considered the first person to be diagnosed with autism. His happy life later became the subject of a book and documentary.
lead_paragraph: Donald Triplett, who as a child was “Case 1” in the history of autism diagnosis and as an adult became an influential case study in how people with autism can find fulfillment, died on Thursday at his home in Forest, a small city in central Mississippi. He was 89.

headline: Wyndham Clark Captures the U.S. Open
abstract: Clark, with only one PGA Tour victory to his name, seemed to come out of nowhere to dominate the field at Los Angeles Country Club.
lead_paragraph: Two Tuesdays ago, as the golf world erupted into chaos and fury, Wyndham Clark did not rush to write a shock-and-awe Twitter post. He did not fume in a meeting with the PGA Tour commissioner about the surprise pact with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund. He did not moralize or criticize or, really, do much of anything other than play golf.

headline: Blinken Meets Xi as China and the U.S. Try to Rein in Tensions
abstract: U.S. diplomats visited Beijing to try to ensure that competition “does not veer into conflict.” The talks pave the way for a possible Biden-Xi meeting.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, on Monday in Beijing, as the two governments sought to pull relations out of a deep chill that has raised global concerns about the growing risk of a conflict between them.

headline: ​North Korea Criticizes Officials for Failed Satellite Launch​
abstract: Top political leaders said the botched May 31 launch, which was meant to put a military spy satellite in orbit, had been “irresponsibly” planned.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s top political leaders “bitterly criticized” officials responsible for a botched attempt to launch a military satellite last month and ordered them to try again, state media reported on Monday.

headline: Rory McIlroy Just Misses a Hollywood Ending at the U.S. Open
abstract: Despite briefly sharing the lead with the eventual champion, Wyndham Clark, McIlroy settled for second but vowed he would get a fifth major title.
lead_paragraph: It might have been fitting if someone from Holywood won this year’s U.S. Open at Los Angeles Country Club. But Rory McIlroy, born in the Northern Ireland town of Holywood, is not having that kind of year.

headline: N.B.A. Draft Preview: After Victor Wembanyama, Watch for These Players
abstract: Wembanyama, the French star, is expected to be the top pick. But prospects like Anthony Black of Arkansas and Iowa’s Kris Murray can help teams, too.
lead_paragraph: The only mystery surrounding the top pick in this year’s N.B.A. draft was resolved a month ago. On May 16, the San Antonio Spurs won the draft lottery, giving them the opportunity — or, perhaps more aptly, the obligation — to select Victor Wembanyama with the first overall pick.

headline: Where Housing Prices Have Crashed and Billions in Wealth Have Vanished
abstract: In New Zealand, high interest rates have sent property prices sliding nearly 18 percent since November 2021.
lead_paragraph: Michael Wilson was hopeful when he put his three-bedroom house up for sale: Over a dozen would-be buyers came to the initial showing.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Shifts in global economic policy.
lead_paragraph: After five years of major disruptions — a pandemic, war in Europe, tensions between the U.S. and China, inflation — the global economic outlook has dimmed. And, as the dust settles, many long-held assumptions about the world economy are now being questioned.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below the Belt’ and a Juneteenth Celebration
abstract: A new documentary from Hillary Clinton about living with endometriosis is on PBS, and a commemoration of Black survival and culture streams live on CNN and OWN.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Ukraine retakes some villages but its forces face minefields and more airstrikes.
abstract: BLAHODATNE, Ukraine — After months of preparation and bolstered by hundreds of donated tanks, armored vehicles and howitzers, Ukraine has notched small successes in the first week and a half of a counteroffensive to drive Russian forces from southern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BLAHODATNE, Ukraine — After months of preparation and bolstered by hundreds of donated tanks, armored vehicles and howitzers, Ukraine has notched small successes in the first week and a half of a counteroffensive to drive Russian forces from southern Ukraine.

headline: Where Are the 2024 Candidates?
abstract: With the Republican field mostly set, the contenders are fanning out across the country.
lead_paragraph: With the Republican field mostly set, the contenders are fanning out across the country.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: In a First-Grade Classroom, Lessons on Optimism and Climate Change
abstract: Cara Buckley, a Climate reporter for The New York Times, visited an elementary school in Lawrenceville, N.J., where students are encouraged to talk about complex environmental issues.
lead_paragraph: In June 2020, New Jersey became the first state in the country to mandate climate change education in schools.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Embrace Early Voting, but Will Their Base Get on Board?
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has said that until Republicans gain power and can change the law, they have “no choice” but to support voting by mail.
lead_paragraph: After years of deriding early and mail-in voting, claiming they lead to fraud and help Democrats to steal elections, top Republicans are changing their position, leading to a split in the party as the 2024 election approaches.

headline: In Rush to Arm Ukraine, Weapons Are Bought but Not Delivered, or Too Broken to Use
abstract: Some of the weapons sent to Ukraine by other countries have been unusable, and hundreds of millions of dollars in contracts paid up front have yet to be fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has paid contractors hundreds of millions of dollars for weapons that have not been delivered, and some of the much-publicized arms donated by its allies have been so decrepit that they were deemed fit only to be cannibalized for spare parts.

headline: Russia Sought to Kill Defector in Florida
abstract: A failed plot to assassinate a C.I.A. spy in 2020 in part led to expulsions of the agency’s chief in Moscow and his Russian counterpart in Washington.
lead_paragraph: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has pursued enemies abroad, his intelligence operatives now appear prepared to cross a line that they previously avoided: trying to kill a valuable informant for the U.S. government on American soil.

headline: ‘I Can’t Continue This Fight Any Longer’
abstract: Why Tyrell Terry walked away from basketball, the millions of dollars that came with it and the identity he had spent his whole life building.
lead_paragraph: The aromatic vineyards of Würzburg and the city’s architectural masterpieces hardly registered with Tyrell Terry as he journeyed to the Franconia region of Germany in December. His life in basketball, once a source of joy to him, had collapsed into a debilitating and lonely loop, and he could see little beyond his own misery. He was venturing nearly 5,000 miles mostly because he needed a friend.

headline: Juneteenth in Brooklyn: Red Velvet Cake Served With a Side of History
abstract: “Hey, we’re still here”: At a time when Black families have been leaving New York, the weekend celebration cultivated a sense of community.
lead_paragraph: All afternoon, people lined up for Shelly Flash’s specialties: jerk cheese nachos and jerk chicken dinner tacos — that’s chicken, coconut rice, black beans, sweet plantains, pickled slaw, chipotle aioli and jerk sour cream inside a soft tortilla.

headline: In Argentina, Inflation Passes 100% (and the Restaurants Are Packed)
abstract: Argentina’s financial crisis has a surprising side effect: a flourishing dining scene in Buenos Aires, as residents rush to spend pesos before they lose more value.
lead_paragraph: Wine glasses clinked in an Art Nouveau culinary gem basking in its restored splendor. It was tasting night in the more than century-old coffeehouse turned restaurant at the old Buenos Aires zoo, as beet tartare, pan-seared squid and a perfect rib-eye floated out of the kitchen, chased by a velvety chocolate mousse.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Brooklyn’s Juneteenth: Red Velvet Cake and a Slice of History
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I had to walk through and just say thank you to my ancestors. We need to enjoy it, because that’s what they would want us to do.”

headline: No Corrections: June 19, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: How Much Can I Express Myself Through My Work Wardrobe?
abstract: A reader wonders how to dress appropriately for a corporate internship — without looking “like a drone.”
lead_paragraph: “What you got to understand is, when you come into work, you give up certain rights.” So says Toby Flenderson, the H.R. character in “The Office,” during Season 5, Episode 26 — a.k.a., “Casual Friday.” The specific right he was talking about was, as it happens, the right to dress as you want. And while the show may have been a comedy, his statement was not entirely a joke.

headline: $3.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Lloyd Wright concrete-block house in Los Angeles, a recently renovated home in Sonoma and a three-story retreat in a gated community in Carmel.
lead_paragraph: This house, which has twice appeared on the cover of Architectural Digest, was designed by Lloyd Wright, after working with his father, Frank Lloyd Wright, on the Hollyhock House, one of Wright’s most significant Los Angeles buildings. It is half a block north of Sunset Boulevard, in the Sunset Square Historic Protection Overlay Zone. Hollywood & Highland, the shopping-and-dining complex, is a little more than a mile away. Driving to downtown Los Angeles takes about half an hour.

headline: The Science of What We Eat Is Failing Us
abstract: Nutrition science needs a credibility revolution.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization recently advised people to avoid using artificial sweeteners for weight loss or to reduce their risk of health issues like heart disease and diabetes. This was based on the agency’s review of available research on artificial sweeteners to date.

headline: Cormac McCarthy Had a Remarkable Literary Career. It Could Never Happen Now.
abstract: The writer had a famously improbable ride to stardom. The fact that he ever escaped obscurity is a testament to just how serendipitous his path was.
lead_paragraph: Cormac McCarthy, who died last week at 89, had a famously unusual career. His first five novels, published over two decades, earned him considerable critical respect but were commercial failures. At one time, all of his books, including his 1985 masterpiece, “Blood Meridian,” fell out of print.

headline: The Homes of Lowndes County, Ala., Are Waiting
abstract: The county is hardly the only place in America plagued with sanitation problems.
lead_paragraph: For generations, the residents of Lowndes County, Ala. — a rural, mostly Black community bordering Montgomery — have lacked access to adequate sanitation. Many people funnel the sewage from their homes directly into their backyards, where it pools atop the dense, clay-like soil. The area has seen a resurgence of hookworm, which thrives in areas with poor sanitation. The parasite can drain people of their energy and impair cognitive development in children.

headline: Meet TV’s 13-Foot-Tall Man
abstract: The giant teenager in Boots Riley’s new series, “I’m a Virgo” is among television’s boldest moves in a while.
lead_paragraph: Brobdingnag is somewhere in the Pacific Northwest. On the map included in Volume II of his 1726 satire “Gulliver’s Travels,” Jonathan Swift depicts it as an enormous peninsula somewhere north of California. Brobdingnag is the land of the giants: When Gulliver is shipwrecked there, he finds a race of people nearly 60 feet tall, wise and moral, repulsed by his descriptions of a venal and warlike British society. The West Coast no longer teems with such gentle giants, but according to the writer, director and musician Boots Riley, there remains one well south of Brobdingnag, near the spot Swift designates P. Monterey — there’s a giant living in Oakland, Calif.

headline: The Thrill of New York, Despite an Awful Lot of One-Month Rentals
abstract: In the last year, a woman from Australia has lived on the Lower East Side, in NoLIta, in Chelsea, and in Brooklyn. She finally has a place in Little Italy with roommates.
lead_paragraph: Natasha Pearce had visited New York City only once, for 10 days at the age of 24, before deciding she wanted to leave Australia and make the city her home.

headline: Let Kids Get Bored. It’s Good for Them.
abstract: A reminder to parents soldiering through the summer: Boredom has its virtues.
lead_paragraph: I have a few particularly vivid memories of my childhood summers: the smell of the grill, the rattle of the cicadas — and the feeling of being bored out of my mind.

headline: Should Medicine Still Bother With Eponyms?
abstract: The names of Nazi-era doctors are still found on diseases and body parts. By expunging them, will doctors forget lessons of the past?
lead_paragraph: Edith Sheffer’s young son always disliked labels such as Asperger’s syndrome. But in 2016, a psychiatrist told him that he should be proud: His condition was named after Dr. Hans Asperger, an Austrian scientist in the 1930s who used his position to help save children like him. By devising a diagnosis that emphasized the children’s intellectual abilities, the psychiatrist said, Dr. Asperger tried to spare them from the Nazi campaign to “euthanize” youths with cognitive disabilities.

headline: Only One State in America Includes the Study of Climate Change for All Grades
abstract: Schools can teach children how important it is for everyone to help.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — One afternoon in late March, family friends discovered a female cardinal resting on their patio, unable to fly. I couldn’t tell for sure from the photo they sent, but I thought perhaps the bird had flown into a window. I forwarded the picture to the experts at Harmony Wildlife Rehabilitation Center, which is near my friends’ house, and asked for advice.

headline: The Gear You Need to Hit the Trail
abstract: Whether you’re planning an afternoon walk through city streets, a multiday trek on a pilgrimage route, or something in between, here’s what you’ll need.
lead_paragraph: From strolling the boulevards of Buenos Aires to hiking in the Canadian Rockies, walking provides good exercise while stretching your mind and soul.

headline: On Being Black and American Overseas
abstract: In “Beyond the Shores,” the historian Tamara J. Walker explores the lives of African Americans drawn to other countries by pleasure, employment and war.
lead_paragraph: In the popular imagination, stories of African American expatriates and travelers to other countries often center on Paris and feature well-known names. We may think of the dancer and singer Josephine Baker, wowing Jazz Age audiences in the City of Light and basking in a freedom she could not enjoy in the United States. Or, perhaps, Black authors like Richard Wright, who moved to the French capital in 1946 and, from that liberatory arrival onward, said he “never felt a moment of sorrow.”

headline: The Art of Being a Flâneur
abstract: Sometimes the best way to explore a city on foot is to simply wander, with no goal in mind other than to follow the sound of church bells, or drift across a leafy square.
lead_paragraph: Your “first care must be to ignore the very dream of haste, walking everywhere very slowly and very much at random,” Henry James advised visitors to Perugia, the capital of the Umbria region in Italy.

headline: Why Robert Kennedy Jr.’s 2024 Bid Is a Headache for Biden
abstract: The unexpected polling strength of an anti-vaccine activist with a celebrated Democratic lineage points to the president’s weaknesses, which his team is aiming to shore up.
lead_paragraph: President Biden might seem to be on cruise control until the heat of the 2024 general election. Nearly all of the nation’s top Democrats have lined up behind him, and the Republican nomination fight seems set to revolve around Donald J. Trump’s legal problems.

headline: Can’t Repeat the Past? An Immersive ‘Great Gatsby’ Thinks You Can.
abstract: The theatrical performance of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1925 novel, opening this month at the Park Central Hotel, is the latest in a very long, heavily sequined line of “Gatsby” adaptations.
lead_paragraph: In the formerly deserted ballroom of a Midtown Manhattan hotel, on a morning in early May, work lights shone on piles of tile and metal debris. A gramophone stood atop a table beside bolts of shimmering cloth. Artificial flowers spilled from bins. A stack of old-timey suitcases reached the ceiling. Plastic coated the carpets. Dust coated the plastic. In just a month, the doors of this space were scheduled to open onto opulent interiors, meant to evoke the moneyed New York of a century ago. For now, I counted a dozen separate folding ladders and choked on the particulate swirling in the air of this construction zone. Ain’t we got fun.

headline: And the Winner for the Cate Blanchett Award for Good Acting Is…
abstract: At the second annual “Las Culturistas” Culture Awards, the comedians Bowen Yang and Matt Rogers put on an affectionate and over-the-top parody of an award show.
lead_paragraph: At the “Las Culturistas” Culture Awards on Saturday night, the winner of the Cate Blanchett Award for Good Acting was … Cate Blanchett.

headline: With Commuters Staying Home, Transit Agencies Try to Reinvent Themselves
abstract: In California, Bay Area Rapid Transit has suffered so much that it needs a state bailout — and possibly a new business model.
lead_paragraph: Rush hour is now anything but at the Montgomery Street station in the heart of San Francisco.

headline: G.O.P. Targets Researchers Who Study Disinformation Ahead of 2024 Election
abstract: A legal campaign against universities and think tanks seeks to undermine the fight against false claims about elections, vaccines and other hot political topics.
lead_paragraph: On Capitol Hill and in the courts, Republican lawmakers and activists are mounting a sweeping legal campaign against universities, think tanks and private companies that study the spread of disinformation, accusing them of colluding with the government to suppress conservative speech online.

headline: A Walk Through the Past in New York
abstract: Ahead of next year’s 400th anniversary of the Dutch colony of New Netherland, the historian and author of “The Island at the Center of the World” offers a walking tour of often-overlooked Native American and Black sites.
lead_paragraph: In the 19 years since my book “The Island at the Center of the World,” about the Dutch settlement that preceded New York, came out, I’ve changed the way I think about the history and geography of New Amsterdam, which occupied the southern tip of Manhattan Island in the 1600s.

headline: Accessible Nature: A Trail Guide for Disabled Hikers
abstract: We highlight a selection of paths, overlooks and other sites in several U.S. parks that outdoor enthusiasts with disabilities can enjoy this summer.
lead_paragraph: I was well into adulthood when I realized that hiking was an activity that I could participate in. I grew up with multiple disabilities and chronic illnesses and thought being “outdoorsy” was only for able-bodied people. I couldn’t find information about hiking as a disabled person, so I spent a lot of time trying to figure it out for myself.

headline: A Walk in Marrakesh: A Spider Web of Passageways
abstract: The medina, the ancient neighborhood where this Moroccan city was born, offers sensory stimulation at every turn.
lead_paragraph: The wail of snake charmers’ horns will lead you to your departure point: Jemaa El Fna. This carnivalesque, open-air market in the medina — the ancient neighborhood where Marrakesh was born — brims with juice stands, restaurants and souvenir shops, to say nothing of musicians and performers.

headline: A Savory Stroll Under the Neon Lights of Singapore
abstract: Mud crabs, skewers, frog porridge and more: Expect an overload for your taste buds along Geylang Road, in the city-state’s red light district.
lead_paragraph: Geylang Road in central Singapore is synonymous with the night, when a dizzying number of neon street signs power on and large groups crowd tables that spill out onto the sidewalk. It’s a tasty spot for a nocturnal stroll, to discover vespertine feasts of local specialties, like crab doused in a bracing white-pepper sauce or steamy porridge showcasing marinated frog legs.

headline: Reframing the West: New Fiction Makes Room for Voices Long Denied
abstract: A wave of novels is drawing from wellsprings of race, class and gender to expand the genre.
lead_paragraph: Their eyes meet across a crowded street in 1870s Dodge City, Kan., the gunslinging bounty hunter and the impulsive rebel, one a dark-haired loner, the other a striking redhead: two young women destined to work out their mutual sparks on the frontier where Owen Wister enshrined the all-male, all-white Western genre novel with “The Virginian,” in 1902.

headline: A Walk in Zadar: A Loop Through History
abstract: A circumnavigation of the city’s Old Town includes a tidal symphony and an architectural synopsis of Croatian history.
lead_paragraph: A nearly two-mile walk circumnavigating Zadar’s Old Town is a journey across a timeline that spans nearly every stage of Croatian history. And it’s a long history, dating back to the 9th century B.C., when the Liburnians first settled this peninsular spit of land on Croatia’s spectacular Dalmatian coast.

headline: A Swiss Army Knife of a Dancer, Making a Virtue of Versatility
abstract: Gaby Diaz, a winner of “So You Think You Can Dance,” has shaped a surprising freelance career that bridges commercial and concert dance.
lead_paragraph: Dance polyglots abound in the entertainment industry. Need a dancer who can pick up hip-hop and contemporary choreography quickly, and maybe also perform in pointe shoes? At most Los Angeles dance auditions, you’ll find not one but several.

headline: A Walk in Paris: Gardens, Greenery and Flower Shops
abstract: Paris is a city of gardens and a walk through it should leave plenty of time to stop and smell the flowers. This one does.
lead_paragraph: This floral-focused stroll in Paris is the favorite of Sandra Sigman, the celebrated florist and author of the book “French Blooms,” about the distinctive French style of flower arrangement. Just short of three miles, it weaves through the gardens, green spaces and flower shops of the 6th and 7th arrondissements.

headline: Germany and China Try to Reset Relations for a Changed World
abstract: This week the two countries will restart government consultations after a pandemic hiatus, but amid the war in Ukraine and rising U.S., Chinese tensions, common ground may be elusive.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Germany and China launched their government consultations a decade ago, Angela Merkel was still chancellor and their relations seemed an endless opportunity for trade and profit. The dialogues were a time for pomp and circumstance, trade deals and signing ceremonies, red carpets and military salutes.

headline: A Walk in St. Louis: A New African American Trail
abstract: A two-mile section of the city’s Brickline Greenway project explores the past and future of the city’s Black community.
lead_paragraph: A few hundred yards from the entrance to CityPark, the splashy new soccer stadium in downtown St. Louis, another urban landmark looms: a cluster of hour-glass-shaped sculptures called “Pillars of the Valley,” by the local artist Damon Davis, that pays tribute to some 20,000 residents of a Black community that was forced from this location in 1959 to make way for a freeway. Standing amid its pillars on a recent afternoon, I leaned in close to read a former resident’s inscription in the stone: “What we lost in the destruction of our Mill Creek Valley neighborhood was a community we relied on to survive.”

headline: A Walk in Sydney: Sea, Bushland and City Views
abstract: Take your time along the Hermitage Foreshore track to admire native flora, take in the skyline and swim at secluded beaches.
lead_paragraph: Few cities are so abundant with forest-like parks, coastal walks and beaches as Sydney, which is best explored on foot. If you do one hike here, the Hermitage Foreshore track has it all. The trail offers a side of Sydney’s eastern suburbs most visitors don’t see. Grand old houses meet lush bush, calm water, endless swimming opportunities and a new city view at every turn. It’s uncrowded and relaxed, and despite the blue-chip surrounds, it is delightfully unpretentious.

headline: A Walk in Seoul: Following the Fortress Wall
abstract: Soak in centuries of history by strolling the Seoul City Wall, which rises high into the mountains.
lead_paragraph: To walk along the Seoul City Wall is to walk in the footsteps of scholars of bygone centuries, trace scars of war and take in the modern behemoth of a city built around it all. Its history stretches back to 1396, to when present-day Seoul first became the capital of what was then a kingdom called Joseon.

headline: In Wales, Roaming a Land of Legends
abstract: Walking 36 miles through the Welsh countryside, a writer considers a proposed new national forest, which is designed to help tackle climate change, boost biodiversity and promote nature tourism.
lead_paragraph: Nine hundred years ago, the Lord Rhys, ruler of the ancient Deheubarth kingdom, established a great seat of religious learning in the heart of mid-Wales. The abbey was called Ystrad Fflur (Strata Florida in the Latin spoken by the Cistercian monks who ran it). It means Vale of the Flowers in English.

headline: A Walk in Rio de Janeiro: Along Fabled Beaches
abstract: A five-mile stretch along Copacabana and Ipanema beaches crackles with energy.
lead_paragraph: For first-timers, a five-mile stroll along Copacabana and Ipanema beaches — Rio de Janeiro’s two most fabled sand parentheses — will stir up feelings even in those who have long and unironically listed “walks on the beach” as a favorite pastime.

headline: The Tropicana, a Relic on the Las Vegas Strip, Could Be Demolished
abstract: The Tropicana Las Vegas, built in 1957, held the city’s longest-running cabaret and was synonymous with its swinging midcentury glory. It could be torn down to make way for a baseball stadium.
lead_paragraph: In 1957, the Tropicana opened as the most lavish hotel and casino in Las Vegas, with a cascading 60-foot fountain and shimmering pool that piped Muzak underwater. The magicians Siegfried and Roy debuted there; Sean Connery’s James Bond stayed the night; and the Corleones of “The Godfather” took over. Feathered showgirls danced in its Folies Bergère cabaret, and the Tropicana became synonymous with the Strip’s swinging midcentury glory.

headline: These Cowboys Build a New Juneteenth Tradition at a Rodeo in Portland
abstract: The cowboy is “a shorthand for independence and grit and all of these things about America,” an organizer said. “But then you combine it with Black culture, and it just wiggles your brain.”
lead_paragraph: Ivan McClellan, a photographer, was captivated the first time he came across Black cowboy culture at a rodeo in Oklahoma years ago.

headline: This Little Amsterdam Improv Club Launched Big American Careers
abstract: Seth Meyers, Jordan Peele, Amber Ruffin and some of the Ted Lasso creators honed their comedy chops thousands of miles from the United States at Boom Chicago, which is turning 30 this year.
lead_paragraph: Seth Meyers had no idea what to expect when he got a job in 1997 performing at a fledgling comedy club in Amsterdam called Boom Chicago. He was in his early 20s, and had never traveled outside of the United States. He had to apply for a passport.

headline: The Racial Wage Gap Is Shrinking
abstract: Though still enormous, the gap has shrunk over the past five years.
lead_paragraph: In the early 2000s, the wage gap between Black and white workers in the U.S. was as large as it had been in 1950.

headline: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Goes on Trial Again
abstract: The new extremism charges could add decades to the prison terms that Aleksei Navalny is already serving.
lead_paragraph: A new trial of Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s jailed opposition leader, began on Monday, with several extremism charges potentially adding decades to the prison sentences that he is already serving.

headline: Once Scorned, Far Right Secures Foothold in Spanish Cities
abstract: Local alliances between the center-right Popular Party and the far-right Vox may foreshadow a broader coalition agreement at the national level.
lead_paragraph: Spain’s far right took office in a string of Spanish cities and in a powerful region over the weekend by forging coalition agreements with the moderate right, in a move that may foreshadow a broader alliance to govern the country after next month’s general elections.

headline: At Least 5 Palestinians Killed in Clashes After Israeli Raid in West Bank
abstract: A 15-year-old boy was among the dead and dozens more were wounded, Palestinian officials said. Eight Israeli security officers were hurt and helicopters were later deployed, the military reported.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli raid into the city of Jenin in the occupied West Bank turned deadly on Monday, with at least five Palestinians killed in a gun battle, and Israeli helicopter gunships were sent into the area for the first time in decades to secure forces trying to extricate armored vehicles that had been disabled by a powerful roadside bomb.

headline: Another Blow to Boris Johnson as U.K. Parliament Ratifies Damning Report
abstract: The former prime minister will lose his pass to Parliament, another stinging penalty from the fallout of lockdown-breaking parties during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Ten days after Boris Johnson abruptly quit Britain’s Parliament, his former colleagues delivered a stinging rebuke to the former prime minister, overwhelmingly ratifying a report that concluded he deliberately misled lawmakers about lockdown-breaking parties held in Downing Street during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Lube That’s Too Chic for the Sock Drawer
abstract: With minimalist labeling and elegant packaging, a new generation of personal lubricants can seem more self-care than sex aid. Make room on the night stand.
lead_paragraph: For Portia Brown, a sex coach in Brooklyn, lube is nonnegotiable. “I don’t think I’ve had sex in the last five years without reaching for a lubricant,” she said.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of June 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: How Should Gig Workers Be Classified?
abstract: Readers discuss how freelance workers should get benefits. Also: A Trump win-lose scenario; World Heritage sites; climate and the young.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tornado Hits Central Mississippi, Killing at Least 1
abstract: The circumstances surrounding the death were not yet known. Weather officials believe multiple tornadoes may have struck the state overnight.
lead_paragraph: At least one person was killed and 19 others were injured after a tornado slammed central Mississippi overnight and destroyed up to 30 structures, the authorities said.

headline: Eye on Expo 2030, Rome Dreams of Reinvigoration
abstract: After years of decline, the city hopes to use a bid for the next world’s fair to re-envision itself as a place that works.
lead_paragraph: Other visitors to the abandoned sports complex on the edge of Rome might just see muddy puddles, graffitied walls and loose cables blighting their view. Not Matteo Gatto.

headline: ‘The Idol’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: Tedros Has Notes
abstract: Turns out that cult-leader types have a lot of opinions about how the women in their lives should look and behave.
lead_paragraph: In her 2022 memoir, “I’m Glad My Mom Died,” the actress Jennette McCurdy wrote candidly about her troubled relationship with her nightmare of a stage mother, who wielded power over every aspect of her life and career. Talking to The New York Times, McCurdy explained the somewhat shocking title she chose for her book, saying, “I feel like I’ve done the processing and put in the work to earn a title or a thought that feels provocative.”

headline: 2023 Is the Year of the Long Walk
abstract: The 500-mile Camino de Santiago has inspired a host of new treks in places from Canada to Bhutan that let travelers take the slow route. Here, a guide to the new trails.
lead_paragraph: The idea of a walking holiday — a long-distance journey on foot, during which you lodge overnight and carry just enough clothing, food and water for each day’s stretch — has long been popular in Europe. But within the last few years, these pilgrimage-style walks have sprung up all over the world.

headline: The U.S. worries about private Chinese companies aiding Russia, Blinken says.
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he urged Chinese officials “to be vigilant” as Washington continues to express concerns over possible military support to Russia.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — While the United States has seen no sign that the Chinese government has decided to send lethal aid to Russia, it is worried that private Chinese companies will provide matériel and technology that Moscow’s military could use in Ukraine, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday.

headline: Fossils Show How Long-Necked Reptiles Lost Their Heads
abstract: The discovery suggests that long necks, which helped some prehistoric reptiles catch food, were tempting targets for predators.
lead_paragraph: In 1830, Henry De la Beche, an English paleontologist, composed a painting of “Duria Antiquior,” a vision of Mesozoic oceans. When picturing a long-necked marine reptile, he depicted its throat clamped between the jaws of a monstrous Ichthyosaurus.

headline: Red Rice and Freedom
abstract: Red foods are traditional for Juneteenth, and we have loads of brightly hued inspiration for you.
lead_paragraph: Today — Juneteenth — marks the recognition of freedom for Africans enslaved in Galveston, Texas, in 1865, more than two years after the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation. Red foods are traditional, and, in the spirit of the holiday, we have loads of brightly hued inspiration for you, whether you make Millie Peartree’s Charleston red rice (above) or Jerrelle Guy’s strawberry pretzel pie. Take a look.

headline: Uruguay’s President Halts Plan to Turn Bronze Nazi Eagle Into Peace Dove
abstract: President Luis Lacalle Pou said that he was canceling a project to melt down and recast a 700-pound relic of World War II after thousands signed a petition calling for it to be preserved in a museum.
lead_paragraph: Two days after announcing a plan to turn a 700-pound Nazi sculpture of an eagle holding a swastika into a peace dove, the Uruguayan president, Luis Lacalle Pou, said that the project had been canceled after thousands signed a petition calling for it to go to a museum instead.

headline: How Classified Evidence Could Complicate the Trump Documents Case
abstract: Prosecutors and defense lawyers appear to be preparing for a pretrial fight over showing sensitive evidence to the jury and the public.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have told the judge overseeing his documents case that they have started the process of obtaining security clearances, the first step of what is likely to be a major fight over classified evidence before his trial.

headline: Creating a Path for More Black Economists
abstract: The dearth of Black economists has many causes, but mentorship is clearly part of the solution.
lead_paragraph: In the 2020-21 academic year, Black students accounted for just under 3 percent of the economics doctorates awarded to U.S. citizens and permanent residents, according to the U.S. Department of Education. That was even lower than their 4.8 percent share of doctorates in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields, according to the federal data. And there’s been no visible improvement in records going back to 1995. Women, Hispanics and Native Americans are also underrepresented, but I’m going to focus on African Americans in this newsletter in recognition of the Juneteenth federal holiday.

headline: Hawaii’s ‘Local Food,’ a Rich Mix That Isn’t Strictly Hawaiian
abstract: A blend of influences and ingredients from the many groups who have settled there, this cooking tradition is still sparking creativity, and some complications.
lead_paragraph: In Honokaʻa, on the north side of the Big Island of Hawaii, the firefighters and paramedics at Station 8 can’t predict when the alarm will blare, but they know that if Maikaʻi Piʻianaiʻa is on duty, they’ll eat well.

headline: In a Flash, How Sasha Calle Became Supergirl
abstract: The actress, making her feature film debut, discusses auditioning for “The Flash” without being told the role, or movie she was up for.
lead_paragraph: Online, many have seen the moment that the actress Sasha Calle, 27, knew her life had been utterly altered: The director of “The Flash,” Andy Muschietti, announced the casting of Calle as Supergirl by posting the video in which he tells her she got the job, beating out hundreds of others. It would be her feature film debut.

headline: Ex-Lawyer Who Killed Girlfriend Dies in Custody Days Before Sentencing
abstract: James Ray III faced a life sentence after being convicted of murder. He was found unconscious in his New Jersey jail cell on Father’s Day.
lead_paragraph: James R. Ray III, a former New York City police officer and lawyer who was awaiting sentencing for murdering his longtime girlfriend, died on Sunday after being found unconscious in a New Jersey jail cell, according to Essex County officials.

headline: ‘Take Care of Maya’ Review: A Chronicle of a Family’s Pain
abstract: In this Netflix documentary about a young girl who was held in a hospital and barred from seeing her family, we hear their side of the story.
lead_paragraph: In 2016 in St. Petersburg, Florida, Maya Kowalski was rushed to the pediatric emergency room for extreme pain. The 10-year-old would be held in the hospital for three months under a state-issued shelter order and barred from seeing her parents, whom doctors suspected of medical child abuse.

headline: Pakistan Declares Day of Mourning for Migrant Ship Disaster Off Greece
abstract: Officials say more than 100 Pakistanis were among those killed when a fishing boat overloaded with migrants capsized in deep Mediterranean waters. The death toll of the disaster is expected to rise.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif of Pakistan declared Monday a day of mourning for Pakistanis who died after a fishing boat crowded with migrants capsized off the coast of Greece last week, and ordered a crackdown on the people involved in trafficking Pakistanis to Europe.

headline: China’s Rebound Hits a Wall, and There Is ‘No Quick Fix’ to Revive It
abstract: Policymakers and investors expected China’s economy to rev up again after Beijing abruptly dropped Covid precautions, but recent data shows alarming signs of a slowdown.
lead_paragraph: When China suddenly dismantled its lockdowns and other Covid precautions last December, officials in Beijing and many investors expected the economy to spring back to life.

headline: At River to River, Dancers Tackle Weighty Topics With a Smile
abstract: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s free summer arts festival presented several pieces, including “duel c” on Governors Island, that employed humor for serious purposes.
lead_paragraph: Now I know what it is like to be herded by a bassoon.

headline: Chris Paul Found Out About the Suns’ Trade From His Son
abstract: Paul, a 12-time All-Star, was on a promotional tour for a book he wrote about his grandfather and his N.B.A. career.
lead_paragraph: Chris Paul was on a plane to New York on Sunday, to promote his new book, when he heard the news in a text from his 14-year-old son, Chris II: He had been traded.

headline: Machines and Morality
abstract: A conversation with an unhinged Bing made me rethink what gives humans moral value.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Digging Up Old Graves to Make Room for Newly Fallen Soldiers
abstract: Funerals have taken on a grim routine in the Ukrainian city of Lviv, and as the fighting grows more intense during the counteroffensive, gravediggers say they are bracing for more bodies.
lead_paragraph: For close to 15 months, the bodies of fallen soldiers have steadily filled up a hillside military cemetery in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv. Now, the old, unmarked graves of those killed in past wars are being exhumed to make way for the seemingly endless stream of dead since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Xi and Blinken Meet
abstract: Also, New Zealand slipped into a recession.
lead_paragraph: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, as the two countries try to pull relations out of a deep chill that has raised global concerns about the growing risk of a conflict between them. The talks show that both countries recognize the stakes of their rivalry.

headline: Jeffrey Epstein Acted Like an Adviser to JPMorgan Executive
abstract: A court document shows that James E. Staley of JPMorgan Chase consulted with Mr. Epstein, a registered sex offender, on a wide variety of matters.
lead_paragraph: James E. Staley, the former top JPMorgan Chase executive who was closest to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein at the bank, relied on him for many years as almost something of a personal adviser, a document shows.

headline: ‘Beowulf’ and Beyond: A Poet Who Embraced Translation
abstract: As seen in a new collection, “The Translations of Seamus Heaney,” the Nobel laureate was a prolific and skilled interpreter of other poets’ work.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, Joe Biden has made much of quoting from Seamus Heaney’s luminous translation of Sophocles’ play “The Cure at Troy”:

headline: Tropical Storm Bret Expected to Dissipate Overnight
abstract: After damaging homes in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the storm was “barely a tropical cyclone,” the National Hurricane Center said.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Bret continued moving west across the Caribbean Sea on Saturday after bringing high winds and heavy rain to several small islands southeast of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.

headline: Max Morath, Pianist Who Staged a One-Man Ragtime Revival, Dies at 96
abstract: A student of both music and history, he entertained audiences in the 1960s and beyond while educating them about a genre whose heyday had ended decades earlier.
lead_paragraph: Max Morath, who stepped out of the 1890s only a lifetime late, and with syncopated piano rhythms and social commentary helped revive the ragtime age on television programs, in concert halls and in nightclubs for nearly a half-century, died on Monday in Duluth, Minn. He was 96.

headline: DeSantis Raises Cash in California and Pokes at Governor
abstract: The Florida governor made a fund-raising stop in Sacramento not far from the home of Gov. Gavin Newsom. The two are in the midst of a mutually beneficial feud.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who is running for the Republican presidential nomination, took his campaign into the backyard of his most vocal Democratic critic on Monday, courting donors at an event near the home of Gov. Gavin Newsom of California weeks after sending two planeloads of migrants to California’s capital.

headline: Greek Coast Guard Under Scrutiny for Response to Migrant Mass Drowning
abstract: Contradictions in the Coast Guard’s account cast new doubts over how the Greeks handled one of the worst maritime disasters in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Shortly after a rickety fishing boat carrying hundreds of smuggled migrants sank in front of a Greek Coast Guard vessel last week, Greek officials explained that they had not intervened because the smugglers didn’t want them to.

headline: Vessel Vanishes on Dive to Titanic Wreck, Setting Off a Search
abstract: A spokesman for the U.S. Coast Guard said the five people on the submersible theoretically had 70 to 96 hours of oxygen before the situation became dire.
lead_paragraph: The submersible vessel carrying five people slipped into the dark waters of the North Atlantic, heading to what remained of the Titanic, 12,500 feet under the sea. The expedition, like many before it, was a testament to the enduring fascination with the storied ship that struck an iceberg and sank off Newfoundland more than a century ago.

headline: The Five Lives Lost in the Titanic Submersible
abstract: On board the submersible were the founder of the company that operates the vessel; a British businessman and explorer; a British father and teenage son from a prominent Pakistani family; and a French maritime expert.
lead_paragraph: Five people were on board the Titan submersible when it lost contact with its support ship during a dive to the Titanic wreckage site in the North Atlantic on Sunday. On Thursday, the U.S. Coast Guard and the company that operated the submersible, OceanGate Expeditions, said that all five people on board were believed to be dead.

headline: Himalayan Glacier Loss Speeding Up, New Report Finds
abstract: Glaciers in the region melted faster between 2010 and 2019 than in the previous decade. “Things are just happening so fast,” one researcher said.
lead_paragraph: New research from scientists in Nepal confirms that ice and snow in the world’s highest mountains are disappearing as a result of rising temperatures and at a faster pace than previously thought. The report from the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development in Kathmandu finds that glaciers in the Hindu Kush and Himalaya mountain range region melted 65 percent faster from 2010 through 2019 than in the previous decade.

headline: OceanGate Expeditions Was Created to Explore Deep Waters
abstract: The company has made headlines for organizing expeditions for paying tourists to travel in submersibles to shipwrecks, including the Titanic.
lead_paragraph: OceanGate Expeditions, the owner of the missing submersible, is a privately owned company headquartered in Everett, Wash., that, since its founding in 2009, has focused on increasing access to deep-ocean exploration.

headline: Trump Says ‘Secret’ Document He Described on Tape Referred to News Clippings
abstract: “There was no document,” the former president said on Fox News as he gave some of his most expansive remarks on the case that led to his federal indictment.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed to a Fox News anchor in an interview on Monday that he did not have a classified document with him in a meeting with a book publisher even though he referred during that meeting to “secret” information in his possession.

headline: Attention-Grabbing Shouts
abstract: Take a deep breath and let it out for this lovely puzzle by Aimee Lucido.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: China Cuts Key Interest Rates, Hoping to Kick-Start Flagging Economy
abstract: The reduction in the rates, which are used to set corporate loans and home mortgages, signaled concern that the country’s postpandemic rebound was stalling.
lead_paragraph: China’s central bank cut key interest rates on Tuesday for loans issued by the state-controlled banking system, in the clearest sign yet of mounting concern in the Chinese government and corporate sector that the country’s economy is stalling.

headline: A Teen Basketball Star Took His Time Growing Up for the N.B.A.
abstract: Scoot Henderson finished high school early to start a two-year apprenticeship for the N.B.A. Now, at 19, his moment has arrived.
lead_paragraph: His lungs were on fire.

headline: The Suburbs Don’t Love New York
abstract: As fewer suburbanites commute to the city, their fear and loathing has grown, as have tensions between city and suburban officials.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’ll look at why New York City and the surrounding suburban jurisdictions are increasingly at odds. We’ll also follow up on the story of the famous wine store that is accused of failing to deliver more than $1 million in orders to customers.

headline: Corrections: June 20, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on June 13 about NATO members conducting major air exercises in Germany as a signal of allied strength against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine misidentified a fighter jet. The jet shown is a Saab Gripen, not a Eurofighter Typhoon.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The aftermath of a devastating shipwreck in Greece.
lead_paragraph: A decision by the Greek Coast Guard not to intervene in a deadly shipwreck has raised concerns that an alignment of interests between smugglers, who are paid to reach Italy, and the Greek authorities, who would rather the migrants be Italy’s problem, led to an avoidable catastrophe.

headline: In Overhaul, Alibaba’s Boss Moves Aside and Two Co-Founders Step Up
abstract: The Chinese tech giant says its top leader, Daniel Zhang, will make way for two long-serving executives: Joseph Tsai takes over as chairman and Eddie Yongming Wu becomes chief executive.
lead_paragraph: In late March, Daniel Zhang unveiled what was called the “most significant” overhaul in the 24-year history of Alibaba, one of China’s original technology conglomerates, splitting the company into six units that would help them seek out investors from the public.

headline: Word of the Day: sabotage
abstract: This word has appeared in 311 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word sabotage has appeared in 311 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 17 in the obituary “Simone Segouin, Teenage Fighter in French Resistance, Dies at 97” by Richard Sandomir:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Ocasio-Cortez’s Unusual Place in N.Y. City Council Races: The Sidelines
