abstract: With early voting in the New York City Council primaries underway, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has yet to endorse any candidate.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez set out to put her imprint on New York City government, using her personal clout and a leadership PAC to boost dozens of left-leaning candidates.

headline: A Brooklyn School Pioneers New Ways to Teach Children With Disabilities
abstract: At P.S. 15 in Red Hook, a unique program for students with intellectual disabilities could serve as a model for other New York City schools.
lead_paragraph: The third graders in Room 221 began their day with a chain of hugs.

headline: Trump Real Estate Deal in Oman Underscores Ethics Concerns
abstract: Details of the former president’s agreement to work with a Saudi firm to develop a hotel and golf complex overlooking the Gulf of Oman highlight the ways his business and political roles intersect.
lead_paragraph: On a remote site at the edge of the Gulf of Oman, thousands of migrant laborers from Bangladesh, India and Pakistan are at work in 103-degree heat, toiling in shifts from dawn until nightfall to build a new city, a multibillion-dollar project backed by Oman’s oil-rich government that has an unusual partner: former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Trump Ties Money and Politics Into Oman Deal
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It is the kind of corruption our founding fathers most worried about.”

headline: How ‘Dark Was the Night, Cold Was the Ground’ Explains America
abstract: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
lead_paragraph: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

headline: In Clémence Michallon’s Debut, a Serial Killer Deceives an Entire Town
abstract: “The Quiet Tenant” offers multiple perspectives on a monster who keeps his victim and his young daughter under the same roof.
lead_paragraph: Clémence Michallon’s assured debut, “The Quiet Tenant,” is an expertly paced psychological thriller that follows three female characters, each compelled and controlled in different ways by the same man.

headline: Your Brain Has Tricked You Into Thinking Everything Is Worse
abstract: Our biased attention means we’ll always feel we’re living in dark times, and our biased memory means we’ll always think the past was brighter.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no political promise is more potent or universal than the vow to restore a golden age. From Caesar Augustus to the Medicis and Adolf Hitler, from President Xi Jinping of China and President “Bongbong” Marcos of the Philippines to Donald Trump’s “Make America Great Again” and Joe Biden’s “America Is Back,” leaders have gained power by vowing a return to the good old days.

headline: The Best Place to Drink Is the Emptiest Bar in the City
abstract: When your hearing starts to go, you just want a place to sit, sip and have a talk: namely, a hotel bar.
lead_paragraph: I’m sipping a bitters and soda in an empty hotel bar — empty but for the mixologist, who’s pouring himself one finger, very deftly, of Pernod, then concealing it down by the sink. Soon my long-lost friend arrives, and the two of us will stay here at the bar for the evening. He looks around to make sure no one is listening — it’s clear as a bare stage. He warms to his story: a brother in trouble, red-pilled and creeping around at sinister rallies. I offer some cautions, some questions. Very naturally, we touch on my bad health. Which, as it happens, is why we’re talking here in a hotel bar. And why we’ll be here for hours to come, no plans to move on later to someplace brighter, or hipper, or darker — nowhere to see or be seen.

headline: The Only Show I Watch Is About So Much More Than Sports
abstract: “Skip and Shannon: Undisputed” is a sports talk show, yes, but America can learn a lot about how to have hard conversations by paying attention to how its hosts interact.
lead_paragraph: As a self-conscious recusant from the so-called prestige TV revolution, I take a certain knowing delight in telling people that the only show — broadcast or streaming — that I watch is “Skip and Shannon: Undisputed,” a daily morning talk program on FS1, Fox’s national sports channel.

headline: We’re Watching the Sky as We Know It Disappear
abstract: The sky has enormous power to shape our lives and to signal how disrupted our climate is becoming.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The first day in early June when my 5-year-old and I camped in Minnesota’s lake country was the usual heaven — perfect calm for canoeing, an osprey overhead as we braved a swim in the cold spring water and a clear blue sky.

abstract: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
lead_paragraph: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

headline: As German Anxieties About Future Rise, Far Right Party Profits
abstract: With Germans facing an era of political and economic turbulence, the Alternative for Germany is resurgent. Mainstream politicians are struggling to respond.
lead_paragraph: The tables were packed at the Waldhaus, a restaurant on the wooded outskirts of an east German town, as the regulars — workers shaking calloused hands, retirees clutching purses in their lap — settled in for a pub gathering of the far-right Alternative for Germany.

headline: How ‘Ted Lasso’ Explains America
abstract: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
lead_paragraph: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

headline: Return to Office Enters the Desperation Phase
abstract: The next stage of getting workers back at their desks includes incentives like $10 to the charity of their choice — and consequences like poor performance evaluations if they don’t make the trek in.
lead_paragraph: Manny Medina, the chief executive of a Seattle-based artificial intelligence sales company, doesn’t mind repeating himself. It comes with the territory, after all. That tolerance proved convenient this year as he faced the same question innumerable times.

headline: ‘They Expected Me to Die on My Own’: Life as a Ukrainian P.O.W.
abstract: Ukrainian captives released in prisoner exchanges say that beatings were common, and that they suffered from woefully inadequate health care and food.
lead_paragraph: Shot through the jaw and tongue by a sniper’s bullet last year in the last days of the grinding siege at the Azovstal steel plant in Ukraine, Senior Sgt. Maksym Kushnir could not eat or talk, and could barely breathe.

headline: John Corbett Knows What You Want From Him
abstract: He was defined by his role in “Sex and the City,” not always comfortably. He’s reprising it in “And Just Like That …” because “I’ve made friends with the idea of, this is just what I do.”
lead_paragraph: Over the years, people have cornered John Corbett on the street, at the grocery store, in coffee shops, to swear fealty. “Every [expletive] person I meet is just, ‘I was Team Aidan!’” he said. He assumes that those people are lying.

headline: But Would They Really Go Back to the Jazz Age?
abstract: A lawn party for would-be Gatsbys and flappers has become an annual New York tradition.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of time travelers in 1920s-era outfits took ferries to Governors Island earlier this month to attend the two-day Jazz Age Lawn Party, one of New York City’s most curious summer traditions.

headline: What the Heck Is Going On With These U.F.O. Stories?
abstract: Leslie Kean helped break the news of a whistle-blower who claims the government possesses materials from a craft of “nonhuman origin.” We discuss her reporting — and what remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Federal Policy on Homelessness Becomes New Target of the Right
abstract: The approach known as Housing First has long enjoyed bipartisan support. But conservatives are pushing efforts to replace it with programs that put more emphasis on sobriety and employment.
lead_paragraph: The bipartisan approach that has dominated federal homelessness policy for more than two decades is under growing conservative attack.

headline: How ‘The Most of Nora Ephron’ Explains America
abstract: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
lead_paragraph: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

headline: The Culture That Explains America
abstract: How can you really understand this country? Read, watch and listen to our columnists’ picks.
lead_paragraph: How can you really understand this country? Read, watch and listen to our columnists’ picks.

headline: The Hotel That Started as a Gift Shop
abstract: Shannon Maldonado quit her job in fashion design to open a home-goods store, Yowie. Now she’s opening a Yowie hotel where nearly all the décor is for sale.
lead_paragraph: When she was growing up, Shannon Maldonado wanted to be a fashion designer.

headline: Final Fantasy XVI Takes on Its ‘Star Wars’ Problem
abstract: Square Enix is trying to make a role-playing game for old fans and new gamers alike, a precarious tightrope for aging franchises.
lead_paragraph: Whenever a new Final Fantasy arrives, fans of the role-playing video games that became famous in the 1990s for using the medium to tell deep, epic stories with large, diverse casts hope that this will be the one to make the franchise relevant again.

headline: With Pandemic Aid Ending, Vermont’s Homeless Are Forced From Hotels
abstract: The state has begun emptying hotels of about 2,800 homeless people living there as part of a pandemic-era program — and offering them tents — after federal funding ran out.
lead_paragraph: As his few remaining hours with a place to live ticked by last Thursday, Scott Alexander panhandled near a McDonald’s in Brattleboro, in southern Vermont, while running through a mental checklist of the supplies he would need for a move back into the woods nearby.

headline: Creating an Outdoor Kitchen Is Easier Than You Think
abstract: That grill you’ve got in the backyard? With a little help, you can turn it into something more.
lead_paragraph: One of the great pleasures of summer is grilling food outside, over an open flame. If you’re fortunate enough to have some space outdoors, your grill can become more than just a place to flip burgers. With a little design help, you can turn it into an outdoor kitchen — and the center of all your outdoor entertaining.

headline: Collective Force of Head Hits, Not Just the Number of Them, Increases Odds of C.T.E.
abstract: The largest study of chronic traumatic encephalopathy to date found that the cumulative force of head hits absorbed by players in their careers is the best predictor of future brain disease.
lead_paragraph: When Jeffrey Vlk played running back in high school in the 1990s and then safety in college, he took and delivered countless tackles during full-contact football practices. Hitting was a mainstay, as were injuries, including concussions.

headline: Malta, Land of Knights, Sailors and Rainbow Flags
abstract: The Mediterranean island nation is gearing up to show off its history of openness, as well as its Baroque treasures, when it hosts EuroPride in September.
lead_paragraph: I was having a nightcap at the palmy, Art Deco Phoenicia Hotel in Valletta, Malta, when a former British naval officer struck up a chat, quickly confiding in me that he thought Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth II’s husband, was the handsomest man he’d ever seen. The prince and the future monarch spent the early years of their marriage in Malta, the former base of the British Mediterranean fleet, where Philip was posted to a ship.

headline: Blinken Visit Reveals Chasm in How U.S. and China Perceive Rivalry
abstract: Xi Jinping and nationalistic Chinese see recent U.S. actions as an effort to contain another superpower rather than compete with it — and they’re pushing back.
lead_paragraph: An austere greeting on the airport tarmac in Beijing sans a red carpet. A stone-faced handshake from China’s top foreign policy official. A seat looking up at the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, perched at the head of a long table.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Blinken-Xi Meeting, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: What to Know About the Titan Submersible
abstract: Officials believe the vessel that set out to reach the Titanic shipwreck with five passengers suffered a “catastrophic implosion,” a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: A submersible watercraft with five people on board that went missing after setting out early Sunday to explore the Titanic shipwreck in the North Atlantic most likely suffered a “catastrophic implosion” with no survivors, a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman said on Thursday.

headline: Inflation Is Way Down. Is It by Design or Just Luck?
abstract: Falling prices for gas and groceries have been a big help to the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Rapid inflation has been a problem in the United States for more than two years, but the tide appears to be turning.  Annual inflation is now less than half of what it was last summer.

headline: What Republicans Say About Their Risky Balancing Act on Abortion
abstract: The historic Dobbs ruling has hurt the party electorally, but G.O.P. lawmakers are still moving to pass more restrictive laws. These two realities represent the defining political fallout of the end of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: In the year since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, one of the country’s most emotionally charged issues has come to be defined by two seemingly contradictory political realities.

headline: A Job With a Fair Salary? What Pay Transparency Laws Are Revealing.
abstract: Salary disclosure laws have been a boon for workers searching for jobs that pay fairly — but only when the advertised pay bands are narrow enough to be useful.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Yun Yati Naing began searching for the job she would begin after graduating from Baruch College in New York City. It was one month after a law passed by the city went into effect requiring employers with four or more employees to post salary ranges on all new job advertisements.

headline: Republicans Against Inequality
abstract: We’re covering a new breed of Republicans, a missing submersible near the Titanic and Judge Judy’s new TV empire.
lead_paragraph: A rising generation of Republican politicians is more skeptical of the free market and more comfortable using government power to regulate the economy than the party has traditionally been. Consider:

headline: 4 Die in Fire Caused by Batteries in E-Bike Shop Near Chinatown
abstract: The blaze, which left two others in critical condition, began on the first floor of a building at 80 Madison Street shortly after midnight.
lead_paragraph: Four people died Tuesday morning in a fire caused by lithium-ion batteries, just the latest in a series of fatal blazes in New York as delivery people in the convenience-addicted city increasingly rely on electric vehicles.

headline: Sex, Identity and the Eternal Anxieties of Growing Up
abstract: In Haley Jakobson’s compassionate debut novel, “Old Enough,” a college sophomore must navigate her first steps into young adulthood while unpacking the trauma of past abuse.
lead_paragraph: There’s a popular Japanese television show called “Old Enough” that challenges preschool children to perform daily tasks without the help of an adult. The tension lies in watching the child come to terms with their mission and their fears; the joy is in witnessing the child’s profound sense of achievement and the parents’ relief and pride. In Haley Jakobson’s debut novel, “Old Enough,” readers may experience similar feelings while following a 19-year-old bisexual college sophomore, Savannah Henry, as she embarks on a haphazard quest to leave her childhood and trauma behind. We want her to succeed, but we all know growing up isn’t easy.

headline: Business Lessons From Blinken’s Trip to China
abstract: The secretary of state’s talks with Xi Jinping raised hopes that the world’s two biggest economies might stabilize relations, but the big challenges were not resolved.
lead_paragraph: Worries about China’s economic recovery sent stocks and U.S. futures lower on Tuesday morning, despite a promising meeting on Monday between the country’s top leader, Xi Jinping, and Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Beijing.

headline: Andrew Tate Indicted on Charges of Human Trafficking in Romania
abstract: Prosecutors in the country announced an indictment against the antagonistic online personality known for his misogynistic remarks. He had been under house arrest outside Bucharest.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Tate, an antagonistic online personality known for his misogyny, has been indicted in Romania on charges including human trafficking and forming an organized criminal group related to the abuse of women, prosecutors there said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Improper Covid Aid Flowed to Fishery Businesses, Official Finds
abstract: Nearly half of $14.4 million dispensed to seafood processors, charter boats and other businesses in New Jersey during the pandemic may have to be paid back.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection is pressing fishery businesses to pay back almost half of all their federal Covid-19 aid because it was improperly allocated, according to a letter from the state comptroller’s office.

headline: Going Back in Time, M.L.B. Will Play a Game at Rickwood Field
abstract: The Birmingham, Ala., stadium was home to Willie Mays in his Negro leagues days. It will host a game between Mays’s Giants and the Cardinals in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Ala., believed to be the oldest professional baseball stadium in the United States, has played host to some of baseball’s greatest luminaries during its 113-year run, including Babe Ruth and Willie Mays, the latter of whom grew up a short distance from the park.

headline: A New Study Paints a Different Picture of Homelessness in California
abstract: Researchers found that homeless people in California were often living in poverty within the state, until they suddenly lost their home.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of myths about people who are homeless in California: They’re from another state. They don’t want a job. They don’t want a home.

headline: 1948: Paris ‘Métro’ Gets New Name, But Subway-Goers Won’t Use It
abstract: With an eye toward expansion, the company in charge of the French capital’s transport system will be renamed.
lead_paragraph: The Paris subway company announced yesterday that in accordance with a vote taken at a shareholders’ meeting Friday it has changed its name from “Compagnie du Chemin de Fer Métropolitain de Paris” to “Société Générale de Traction et d’Exploitations.”

headline: The U.K. moves to use frozen Russian assets to help Ukraine rebuild.
abstract: The government’s announcement follows a pledge made by Group of 7 nations at their annual gathering last month to freeze Russian assets until Moscow pays for the damage done in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As Russia’s ruinous attacks on Ukraine mount, Britain’s government is proposing legislation that would enable it to divert frozen Russian assets to the rebuilding of Ukraine and keep sanctions in place until Moscow pays compensation to its war-torn neighbor.

headline: Hunter Biden Reaches Deal to Plead Guilty to Misdemeanor Tax Charges
abstract: Under an agreement with the Justice Department, the president’s son agreed to probation for filing his taxes late, and he can avoid a charge that he lied about his drug use when he bought a gun.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden agreed with the Justice Department on Tuesday to plead guilty to two misdemeanor tax charges and accept terms that would allow him to avoid prosecution on a separate gun charge, a big step toward ending a long-running and politically explosive investigation into the finances, drug use and international business dealings of President Biden’s troubled son.

headline: Judge in Trump Documents Case Sets Tentative Trial Date as Soon as August
abstract: The judge, Aileen M. Cannon, set an aggressive schedule for moving the case forward, though the proceedings are likely to be delayed by pretrial clashes.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge presiding over the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump in the classified documents case set an aggressive schedule on Tuesday, ordering a trial to begin as soon as Aug. 14.

headline: We Are Beauty; We Are Dignity
abstract: Our clothing signals who we are, and how we want to be perceived.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: E.U. Takes Aim at China in Proposed Economic Strategy
abstract: A European Commission plan seeks to bar companies from sending sensitive high-tech goods to potentially hostile countries — without naming any names.
lead_paragraph: The European Commission on Tuesday unveiled a new trade doctrine aimed at curbing China’s ability to squeeze Europe’s economy, and at preventing European companies from exporting sensitive, military-linked technology that could give China an edge.

headline: Paul-Henri Nargeolet Has Made More Than 35 Titanic Site Trips
abstract: Mr. Nargeolet, a French maritime expert, is one of the five people aboard the missing submersible. He works for RMS Titanic, which owns the salvage rights to the wreck.
lead_paragraph: Paul-Henri Nargeolet, a French maritime expert who has been on over 35 dives to the Titanic wreck site, is one of the five people aboard the submersible that has been missing since Sunday, according to his literary representative, Mathieu Johann.

headline: Authors and Students Sue Over Florida Law Driving Book Bans
abstract: The authors of a picture book about a penguin family with two fathers sued the state and a school district that removed the book from libraries.
lead_paragraph: A group of students and the authors of a children’s book about a penguin family with two fathers sued a Florida school district and the state’s board of education on Tuesday, saying that restricting access to the book in school libraries was unconstitutional.

headline: Friends, Tourists, Countrymen, See Where Julius Caesar Was Killed
abstract: The site where Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators in 44 B.C., nestled among four ancient temples, has been opened to the public for the first time in a century.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a century, only cats (and presumably the rats they kept at bay) had free rein over an ancient archaeological site in the heart of central Rome. They would prowl among the ruins and preen for the tourists who gathered along the balustrades above, cellphones and cameras in hand.

headline: Can You Still Be a Femme Fatale if You’re Butch?
abstract: The protagonist of K. Patrick’s “Mrs. S,” a boarding school worker questioning her gender expression, falls into a torrid affair with the headmaster’s wife.
lead_paragraph: When we think of bodies in fiction, we generally consider them in relation to other objects or other people. Characters glance in a mirror to examine their features and we’re allowed a brief glimpse of cheekbone, jawline or eye color. Are they tall or short? Nondescript or peculiar? Lanky-limbed or compact and muscular, like a stout pony? We understand how a body moves through a narrative because we’ve received a set of keys and instructions for how to operate the vehicle.

headline: Tai Chi Is a Workout for the Brain and Body
abstract: The mental and physical benefits span cultures and generations. Here’s how to get started.
lead_paragraph: “Parting the Wild Horse’s Mane.” “Wave Hands Like Clouds.” “Embrace Tiger, Return to Mountain.” These are not song titles or poems. Rather, they’re the deceptively complex movements of tai chi.

headline: Proceeds of Chelsea Sale Have Yet to Reach Any Ukraine War Victims
abstract: A $3.1 billion fund was established when Roman Abramovich was forced to sell the club, but the fund’s head says a “bureaucratic quagmire” has kept the money frozen.
lead_paragraph: It was the biggest price paid for a soccer team, and for a while the biggest price paid for a sports team anywhere in the world. And the enormous proceeds were to create what would be one of the biggest humanitarian charities ever established.

headline: Morgan Wallen’s ‘One Thing’ Returns to No. 1 for the 13th Time
abstract: The country singer’s latest album has topped the Billboard chart for more than half the year.
lead_paragraph: Nearly halfway through the year, Morgan Wallen has spent most of it on top.

headline: The Dirty (and Grassy) Secrets Behind the Home Field Advantage
abstract: In an era of expertly manicured fields and shared knowledge among groundskeepers, crews have an unexpected tool in their arsenal: the ban on infield shifts.
lead_paragraph: Greg Elliott, the forward-thinking head groundskeeper for the San Francisco Giants, flies a drone over the pristine grass at Oracle Park five days a week. The device is equipped with an infrared camera that measures the stress levels and overall health of the turf. In the first two months of this season, Elliott had detected a notable difference from the previous two years.

headline: Police Search Paris 2024 Olympics Offices in Corruption Investigation
abstract: French prosecutors said they were investigating potential conflicts of interest, embezzlement and favoritism connected to public contracts signed by organizers of the Games.
lead_paragraph: The French police searched the headquarters of the Paris 2024 Olympics organizing committee and other offices on Tuesday as part of two corruption investigations over contracts signed in connection with the Games, prosecutors said.

headline: Jonathan Majors to Face Trial on Assault Charges in August
abstract: The movie star, who has maintained his innocence, appeared briefly in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: The actor Jonathan Majors appeared in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday morning at a brief hearing where a trial date for his misdemeanor assault case was set for August.

headline: An Alternative to Increasingly Elusive Bottles of Chartreuse
abstract: A San Francisco amaro company offers Chaparral, the owner of La Boîte publishes a Middle Eastern pantry primer and more food news.
lead_paragraph: As OPEC does with oil, the Carthusian monastery that has made Chartreuse liqueurs in Eastern France since 1605 is limiting the flow of the spirit and causing shortages at the bar. (The monks do not plan to increase production to meet demand; better to concentrate on solitude and prayer.) Though the venerable liqueur has a unique recipe, there’s a promising alternative for that Last Word cocktail: Chaparral. It’s one of three amaros by Brucato Amaro, a San Francisco company specializing in that category of drink, all inspired by the California landscape. A base of California brandy is infused with yerba santa, mint, anise and cardamom, resulting in a greenish-amber liqueur scented with warm spices and cool mint, slightly sweet and decidedly herbal on the palate. It’s a little less green and syrupy, but can step into a cocktail without missing a beat.

headline: The New York Times Presents: ‘The Legacy of J Dilla’
abstract: The producer and artist, born James Dewitt Yancey, died in 2006 at 32. The debate continues over who should control his legacy.
lead_paragraph: The producer and artist, born James Dewitt Yancey, died in 2006 at 32. The debate continues over who should control his legacy.

headline: Two of the Passengers Are a Prominent Businessman and His 19-Year-Old Son
abstract: Shahzada Dawood and his son, Suleman, are aboard the missing submersible.
lead_paragraph: The British businessman Shahzada Dawood, 48, and his son, Suleman, 19, are aboard the missing submersible, according to a statement from the Engro Corporation, based in Karachi, Pakistan.

headline: German Spy Agency Says China and Russia Are After Its Secrets
abstract: The country is a growing target for foreign espionage, the agency said, amid rising tensions over the war in Ukraine and rivalries between Washington and Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Foreign intelligence services are increasingly targeting Germany, its domestic intelligence agency said on Tuesday, warning that espionage, cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns, particularly from China and Russia, “pose a serious threat” to the country.

headline: 3 Are Convicted of Harassing Family on Behalf of China’s Government
abstract: The defendants, including a private detective who said he did not realize he was working for an intelligence operation, pursued people living in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Three men were convicted in Brooklyn federal court on Tuesday of stalking a family in the New Jersey suburbs on behalf of the Chinese government.

headline: Taylor Swift, Maestro of Pop, Returns to the Stage
Behind the Scenes of Padma Lakshmi’s “Taste the Nation”
The Life and Courage of Daniel Ellsberg, ‘a True American Hero’
abstract: Readers express gratitude for the risk he took in leaking the Pentagon Papers. Also: Maternal health; the 2024 election; reasons for hope; diversity in orchestras.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Elton John Warns of ‘Growing Swell of Anger and Homophobia’ in U.S.
abstract: “We seem to be going backwards,” the pop superstar warned as he lamented the curtailing of L.G.B.T.Q. rights in the United States, particularly in Florida.
lead_paragraph: The British pop superstar Elton John lamented the “growing swell of anger and homophobia” in the United States and described several laws recently passed in Florida that curtail L.G.B.T.Q. rights as “disgraceful.”

headline: ‘Sublime’ Review: Two Boys, One in Love
abstract: A teenager dreams of pop songs, and his best friend, in Mariano Biasin’s tender gay coming-of-age drama.
lead_paragraph: In high school I had a crush on my best friend. I sat with him when he played piano in church. I was furious inside when he told me he liked a girl. When I came out to him in college he said “so what?” and I cried. Tweak some details and switch the setting from suburban America to a coastal town in Argentina and it’s also the entire plot of Mariano Biasin’s familiar but muted coming-out drama “Sublime.”

headline: What Happens if a Presidential Candidate Is Convicted?
abstract: The Constitution and American law have clear answers for only some of the questions that would arise. Others would bring the country into truly uncharted territory.
lead_paragraph: Not since Eugene V. Debs campaigned from a prison cell more than a century ago has the United States experienced what might now happen: a prominent candidate with a felony conviction running for president. And never before has that candidate been someone with a real chance of winning.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Leslie Kean
abstract: The June 20, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Leslie Kean. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Readers’ Picks: 12 Pride Anthems
abstract: A playlist with personal stories about the ways music plays a vital role in struggles, triumphs and self-expression.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I asked you to submit songs to help create the ultimate Pride playlist. As usual, you delivered. Big time.

headline: Gannett Sues Google, Accusing It of Dominating the Ad Market
abstract: The country’s largest newspaper chain said Google’s power over ad technology has contributed to the decline of local news.
lead_paragraph: Gannett, the country’s largest newspaper chain, filed a lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing the tech giant of violating federal antitrust laws by illegally abusing a monopoly over the technology used by publishers to buy and sell online ads.

headline: In ‘A Simulacrum,’ Steve Cuiffo Has Nothing Up His Sleeves
abstract: The magician worked with the playwright Lucas Hnath to create “a more vulnerable version of magic performance,” Hnath said.
lead_paragraph: Steve Cuiffo began performing magic the way that most kids do. His brother did tricks. So did an older cousin. A grandfather had a routine with a handkerchief and a dime that absolutely killed. While he was in elementary school, he started entertaining at birthday parties, first for $5 and then more. He kept up his routines even as he studied theater at New York University and began to work with avant-garde companies like the Wooster Group.

headline: How Trump Has Tried to Use Hunter Biden as a Way to Attack His Father
abstract: Donald Trump has for years depicted Hunter Biden as corrupt and used unsubstantiated claims to link his Democratic rival to his son’s business dealings.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has been among the most insistent of Republican voices seeking to use Hunter Biden as a way to discredit his father, President Biden — and the guilty plea on Tuesday quickly became yet another point of attack as Mr. Trump seeks the Republican presidential nomination for a third time.

headline: ‘Secret Invasion’ Review: Marvel Welcomes Back Samuel L. Jackson
abstract: Nick Fury gets back in the fight in the latest Disney+ series from the Marvel assembly line.
lead_paragraph: The folks at Disney sent critics only two episodes of the new Marvel mini-series “Secret Invasion,” which is one more than we sometimes get from the Fortress of Spoilertude. (Apologies for the mixed corporate metaphors.)

headline: Ebon Moss-Bachrach Plays a Prickly Fan Favorite in ‘The Bear’
abstract: This thoughtful Brooklyn dad excels at playing stunted men like Richie, his volatile character in the FX hit. Just don’t call them dirtbags: “I get a little sensitive,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The joke on the set of “The Bear,” the hit FX series about a faltering Chicago restaurant, is that there are two Ebon Moss-Bachrachs: New York Ebon and Chicago Ebon. And they are very different.

headline: For Biden, the Troubles of His Son Are Personal and Politically Painful
abstract: Hunter Biden’s plea agreement put him in the cross-hairs of President Biden’s adversaries once again.
lead_paragraph: After more than a half-century in politics, no subject may be more personally painful nor politically problematic for President Biden than his troubled son, Hunter. He is by various accounts a gaping wound in his heart and the most sensitive soft spot in his campaign armor.

headline: ‘It Has It All’: Taking on a Strange, Immense Piano Concerto
abstract: The conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen and the pianist Igor Levit discuss Ferruccio Busoni’s Piano Concerto, a rarity they are performing in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: There are piano concertos, and then there is Ferruccio Busoni’s Piano Concerto.

headline: Republicans, Claiming Double Standard, Vow to Keep Investigating Bidens
abstract: Congressional Republicans accused President Biden of orchestrating a lenient penalty for his son, while Democrats argued that bringing any charges reflected the Justice Department’s independence.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans on Tuesday blasted the plea deal Hunter Biden reached with the Justice Department, accusing President Biden of orchestrating a lenient penalty for his son and promising to intensify their investigations of the Biden family.

headline: Palestinian Gunmen Kill 4 Israeli Civilians in Occupied West Bank
abstract: Two Hamas members carried out the attack outside Eli, a settlement in the northern West Bank, before being shot dead themselves.
lead_paragraph: Two Palestinian gunmen shot and killed four Israeli civilians on Tuesday afternoon outside a Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the Israeli military said, in the deadliest attack on Israelis since January.

headline: Is Taylor Swift Underpaid?
abstract: Superstars in historical perspective.
lead_paragraph: Like almost every other nation, Sweden has been experiencing high inflation recently. Consumer prices have risen 9.7 percent over the past year, reflecting multiple factors: large spending to support households during the pandemic, Covid-related disruptions of supply chains, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and Beyoncé.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Wore an Orange Wig’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: My oldest child and I drove from Massachusetts to New Hampshire to visit my father, who had suffered a stroke. It gave us a rare chance to catch up. After five hours of round trip travel in the car, I reached over to say goodbye. My eldest always saves the biggest news for the last moment. “You know how you have two sons?” my child asked, watching my face. “Now you have a daughter and son.” Confusion and questions swirled inside me. But only one response mattered. I held my daughter tightly, calling my child by her new name, Katy. — Linda Button

headline: SushiDelic Embraces Kawaii With Neon Pink Styling and Individual Sushi Bites
abstract: More sushi openings, a sibling for Gertie and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Sushi’s umbrella shelters many options, from the nearly ceremonial progression by revered master chefs to ready-made at the supermarket. For Sebastian Masuda, a Japanese artist and designer, sushi gives free rein to kawaii, the cutesy component of Japanese culture. On a block that is also home to Flour Shop’s colorful baked goods, his neon-pink sushi restaurant fits right in. Enormous grinning cats dangle from the ceiling, lights look like tubes of lipstick and a sinuous conveyor belt at a 18-seat counter delivers portions of sushi made with tuna and pink rice on savory turquoise macarons; tempura served with a palette of bright dips; and chirashi dappled with beads of salmon roe and piled into a parfait glass. The food on the conveyor is interspersed with Mr. Masuda’s playful, glittering sculptures of sushi and stilettos. Six courses are $85. Table seats are available indoors and out. Mr. Masuda calls it the “new generation of sushi,” as entertaining as it is tasty. The chef, Kyle Puchir, is a Daniel alum. There are also options for takeout, including individual sushi bites wrapped in cellophane like candy. Hiro Nishida, a restaurateur, manages the venture, and Taka Tanaka, whose company Autec makes sushi robots, is a partner. (Opens June 28)

headline: Review: A Genderqueer ‘Cabaret,’ at War With Itself
abstract: A revival of the 1998 revisal of the 1966 musical highlights the stories of trans and nonbinary performers.
lead_paragraph: The revival of “Cabaret” that opened on Sunday at the Barrington Stage Company in Pittsfield, Mass., has a bad case of the Underwear Problem.

headline: British Explorer on Missing Submersible Said He Knew the Risk of Such Voyages
abstract: Hamish Harding, who had set a record on a mission to the deepest part of the ocean, said after that feat: “If something goes wrong, you are not coming back.”
lead_paragraph: Hamish Harding, a British explorer aboard the submersible missing in the North Atlantic, acknowledged in a 2021 interview that he had taken on deep-sea missions in the past knowing that rescue would not be an option.

headline: Shop Owner Who Paid Ex-Worker in Pennies Is Ordered to Pay More
abstract: A federal judge issued a consent judgment that requires the auto shop owner to pay more than $39,000 for retaliating against the former worker and for failing to pay overtime to employees.
lead_paragraph: A court in Georgia has ordered the owner of an auto-repair shop who disbursed a former employee’s wages with about 91,500 greasy pennies left in his driveway to pay nearly $40,000 in back pay and damages. The judgment said that the shop owner retaliated against the worker, who had asked for his final paycheck, and that he failed to pay overtime to the man and eight other employees.

headline: OceanGate Was Warned of Potential for ‘Catastrophic’ Problems With Titanic Mission
abstract: Experts inside and outside the company warned of potential dangers and urged the company to undergo a certification process.
lead_paragraph: Years before OceanGate’s submersible craft went missing in the Atlantic Ocean with five people onboard, the company faced several warnings as it prepared for its hallmark mission of taking wealthy passengers to tour the Titanic’s wreckage.

headline: The Summer Solstice Is Here. What’s New With Our Sun?
abstract: As the Northern Hemisphere tilts toward the sun, let's check in on everything that's happening with our home star.
lead_paragraph: As the Northern Hemisphere tilts toward the sun, let's check in on everything that's happening with our home star.

headline: Restaurant Review: Okdongsik Serves Two Things, and Both Are Outstanding
abstract: The tiny counter from one of South Korea’s star chefs is a near-replica of its counterpart in Seoul.
lead_paragraph: I don’t think I ever understood how any meat broth could be the basis of a restaurant’s reputation until I ate the dweji gomtang at Okdongsik.

headline: The Black-Owned Restaurants of Bed-Stuy
abstract: Watching in real time as a neighborhood changes while trying to cling to its identity.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing better than finding your neighborhood in New York City. The place where you feel the most comfortable in your skin, where you feel immersed in the community and held close by its warmth. For me, as a Black woman, that is Bed-Stuy, where I’ve lived since 2015.

headline: One More Chorus of ‘Humm Baby’ for a Baseball Lifer
abstract: At a memorial service for Roger Craig, a writer recalls time spent with a player, coach and manager who connected generations of baseball history.
lead_paragraph: On the fringe of a quiet golf course in the foothills outside San Diego, music from the Highwaymen galloped from the sound system. Family and baseball, inextricably intertwined, had gathered to say one final goodbye to Roger Craig. Horses and golf, two other staples in this North Carolina country boy’s life, gracefully filled the green pastures and dusty trails of the imagination as the songs rang out.

headline: U.S. Women’s World Cup Roster Reflects a Team in Transition
abstract: Form and injuries affected the players available to Coach Vlatko Andonovski as he picked a soccer team facing perhaps the toughest challenge in its history.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sentence you see every four years: The United States is a favorite to win the Women’s World Cup.

headline: When Submersibles Meet the Titanic, James Cameron Is an Inspiration
abstract: Cameron’s 1997 movie “Titanic” reinvigorated interest in the ill-fated ocean liner, feeding the mystique that spurs some wealthy experience chasers.
lead_paragraph: James Cameron, the Academy Award-winning movie director behind “Titanic,” knows about the risks of deep ocean exploration. A seasoned underwater explorer himself, in 2012 he prepared to plummet nearly seven miles to the world’s deepest known ocean trench.

headline: Virginia Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results from the Virginia primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results from the Virginia primary elections.

headline: Magda Saleh, Influential Egyptian Ballerina, Is Dead at 79
abstract: Trained at the Bolshoi, she became a star of the Cairo Ballet and played a key role in making ballet accessible to people of all classes.
lead_paragraph: Magda Saleh, a Bolshoi-trained Egyptian ballerina who was a star of the Cairo Ballet and played a major role in introducing ballet to wider audiences in her country, and who then led the company’s ballet school and a new opera house, died on June 11 in Cairo. She was 79.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: The Search for the Missing Titanic Sub
abstract: Also, a shake-up at Alibaba and a taste of Singapore’s street food.
lead_paragraph: An international team of rescuers was racing against time to find a deep-diving submersible with five people on board after it lost contact in the North Atlantic during a tour to explore the wreck of the Titanic.

headline: Thousands of Reddit Communities Stay Dark as App Policy Protest Continues
abstract: Users’ anger continued to bubble over changes to the company’s business model.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of volunteer-run message boards on Reddit remained dark on Tuesday, a week after moderators of the communities began what they called a 48-hour protest against Reddit’s planned changes to its business model.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Arkansas Law Banning Gender Transition Care for Minors
abstract: The case had been closely watched as an important test of whether bans on transition care for minors, enacted by more than a dozen states, could withstand challenges.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Arkansas on Tuesday struck down the state’s law forbidding medical treatments for children and teenagers seeking gender transitions, blocking what had been the first in a wave of such measures championed by conservative lawmakers across the country.

headline: Someone to Know: A Lawyer for Forests
abstract: Democratic institutions are reeling in India. Meet the environmental lawyer who is still using them to protect nature.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is welcoming Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India to the White House this week. They want to show the world that the two largest democracies are strengthening their alliance.

headline: The Search for a Missing Titanic Tour Sub
abstract: Also, Hunter Biden agrees to plead guilty. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard was racing against time today to find a deep-diving submersible with five people on board two days after it went missing in the North Atlantic.

headline: What Happens When You Get So Influential That You’re Bored by Your Own Aesthetic?
abstract: In search of a refresh, Athena Calderone, the queen of muted Brooklyn interiors, is moving to Manhattan. She almost went broke renovating the townhouse that cemented her place in the interiors world.
lead_paragraph: Athena Calderone wanted to move, but she had a problem: The home she already had was perfect.

headline: 2 Arrested After a Fatal Stabbing and 3 Slashings on the Subway
abstract: The police added 80 officers to the subway system after a man was fatally stabbed and three women were slashed in the legs in separate attacks over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: After a series of assaults in the subways over the weekend — including a fatal stabbing of a man during a fight and attacks on three women who were slashed in the legs — the Police Department stepped up its presence in the system and arrested two men.

headline: Russia Targets Kyiv and Lviv With Attack Drones
abstract: Moscow’s forces also shot and killed a rescue worker in the flood-stricken city of Kherson, Ukrainian officials said, as both sides battled for territory in the south and east.
lead_paragraph: Russia unleashed dozens of attack drones across Ukraine before dawn on Tuesday, targeting the cities of Kyiv and Lviv, far from the front lines where Ukraine’s counteroffensive made small gains and Russian forces tried to seize more territory in eastern Ukraine.

headline: New York Passes Bill to Shield Abortion Providers Sending Pills Into States With Bans
abstract: The measure is one of several recently enacted by states aiming to expand access to medication abortion for patients who live where it is outlawed.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature gave final approval on Tuesday to legislation that provides legal protection for New York doctors to prescribe and send abortion pills to patients in states that have outlawed abortion.

headline: Tony Awards Give a Box Office Boost to Prize-Winning Shows
abstract: “Leopoldstadt,” which was named best play, and “Kimberly Akimbo,” which won best musical, saw considerable increases in ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: “Leopoldstadt” and “Kimberly Akimbo,” the two shows that took home top Tony Awards last week, saw big bumps at the box office in the days following that ceremony.

headline: Idaho Man Is Charged With Murdering 4 Neighbors
abstract: The shooting came days after the suspect’s family accused one of the victims of indecent exposure, according to an affidavit signed by a state police detective.
lead_paragraph: An Idaho man has been charged with four counts of first-degree murder and one count of burglary after breaking into a neighbor’s home and fatally shooting four people, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: Paxton Whitehead, Actor Who Found Humor in the Stodgy, Dies at 85
abstract: An Englishman with a deep, cultured voice, he played uptight snobs in films like “Back to School” and on shows like “Friends” and “Mad About You.”
lead_paragraph: Paxton Whitehead, a comic actor who earned a Tony nomination for his role in a revival of “Camelot” and played the starchiest of stuffed shirts in films like the Rodney Dangerfield comedy “Back to School” and on hit 1990s sitcoms like “Friends” and “Mad About You,” died on Friday in Arlington, Va. He was 85.

headline: 41 Dead After Riot Erupts in Honduran Women’s Prison
abstract: The inmates were found shot or burned to death in the latest spasm of violence in the country’s troubled prison system.
lead_paragraph: At least 41 inmates were killed on Tuesday morning in central Honduras after a riot broke out at the country’s only prison for women, one of the deadliest outbreaks of violence in the country’s long-troubled prison system.

headline: ‘Surrounded’ Review: Letitia Wright Impresses in an Overbaked Western
abstract: Playing a woman disguising herself as a man, Wright is haunting and haunted, and Michael K. Williams is an energetic presence in one of his last roles.
lead_paragraph: Moses Washington, who goes by Mo, is a former Buffalo Soldier and freed slave seeking to make a new life in the post-Civil-War Wild West. Mo is also a woman disguising herself as a man; she’s played by Letitia Wright.

headline: Take Bobby Kennedy Jr. Seriously, Not Literally
abstract: Could he be the Eugene McCarthy of 2024?
lead_paragraph: In 1968, Senator Eugene McCarthy challenged Lyndon Johnson for the Democratic presidential nomination and ran a close second in the New Hampshire primary. The near upset by McCarthy, a Minnesota progressive, helped convince Johnson that he should not run for re-election, opening the way for Robert F. Kennedy. History might have been very different if tragedy hadn’t intervened that June at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles.

headline: Titan Pilot Is a Booster of Deep-Sea Tourism
abstract: Stockton Rush, the chief executive of OceanGate Expeditions, is one of the five occupants of the missing submersible.
lead_paragraph: Stockton Rush, the chief executive of OceanGate Expeditions and one of the five occupants of the submersible missing this week in the North Atlantic, has advocated for deep-seas tourism in the face of criticism.

headline: Inside the Titan: Quiet and Cramped, With a Single Porthole
abstract: “You just drop like a stone for two and a half hours,” said a writer for “The Simpsons” who made the trip to the Titanic wreckage.
lead_paragraph: Passengers seeking a glimpse of the R.M.S. Titanic aboard the submersible that disappeared in the North Atlantic this week have endured hours in a dangerous drop to the ocean floor aboard a cramped craft with a single porthole.

headline: Rescuers Ramp Up Efforts to Find Craft Missing en Route to Titanic Wreckage
abstract: Coast Guard and international crews redoubled their efforts to find the missing Titan watercraft, amid growing worries about how long the air supply would last deep underwater.
lead_paragraph: With alarm rising and air supply onboard the missing watercraft dwindling, a growing array of international rescuers ramped up their search on Tuesday for the submersible carrying five people that disappeared on Sunday while en route to the wreckage of the Titanic.

headline: To Improve Public Housing, New York City Moves to Tear It Down
abstract: After surveying residents at two developments in Manhattan, the agency is moving forward with a $1.5 billion plan to demolish and replace the buildings.
lead_paragraph: Tearing down public housing has become something of a national trend, except in New York, where the New York City Housing Authority has held onto its stock of aging buildings even as repair bills and tenant complaints mount.

headline: Extreme Travel Rescue Operations Are Vast in Scale and Cost. Who Foots the Bill Is Murky.
abstract: The enormous response has involved the U.S., Canada and France. It is unclear whether taxpayers in those countries will be paying for it.
lead_paragraph: The ongoing search and rescue effort for the missing Titan submersible with five people on board, involving a huge response from American, Canadian and French authorities, is vast in scale, including both the U.S. Navy and the Coast Guard.

headline: How ‘Elemental’ Breathed Life Into Fire, Water, Earth and Air
abstract: The film’s director and production designer encountered challenges and took a few wrong turns as they worked on anthropomorphizing the natural world.
lead_paragraph: A woman made of fire falls for a man made of water.

headline: Garland’s Distance From Hunter Biden Inquiry Fails to Quell Critics
abstract: The attorney general has confronted an unrelenting succession of politically sensitive investigations, underlining the intensely polarized environment he is operating in.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland was 4,000 miles away from Delaware on Tuesday when federal prosecutors announced a deal for Hunter Biden on tax and gun charges that would most likely ensure he does not serve a prison sentence.

headline: Dumped by Her Boyfriend, She Takes a Job Cuddling Others
abstract: The heroine of Jenny Xie’s debut novel, “Holding Pattern,” is back at her childhood home and learning to love herself.
lead_paragraph: As a plane awaits permission from air traffic control to land, it will trace a certain path in the sky — a period in suspension called a “holding pattern.” Jenny Xie’s debut novel, also called “Holding Pattern,” unfurls a similar period of in-between, with the protagonist Kathleen Cheng back in her childhood home in Oakland, Calif. Here she’s stagnant — fresh off a crushing breakup and preparing for her mother’s upcoming wedding, unsure if she wants to continue her graduate program back in Baltimore but not certain where else she’d want to land.

headline: Producer Ryan Murphy Is Expected to Move to Disney
abstract: Mr. Murphy, the force behind hits like “American Horror Story” and “The Watcher,” is coming to the end of his $300 million Netflix deal.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Murphy, the television megaproducer behind hits like “American Horror Story” and “Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story,” is poised to move his operation to the Walt Disney Company, five years after he stunned Hollywood by decamping to Netflix for a $300 million deal.

headline: The doomed ocean liner Titanic continues to intrigue the public after more than a century.
abstract: The mystique has endured long after the vessel, for decades the holy grail of undiscovered shipwrecks, was found on the sea floor in 1985.
lead_paragraph: The five people aboard the missing deep-sea submersible Titan are not the first to risk their lives for a chance to glimpse one of history’s most famous shipwrecks.

headline: Any Living Thing
abstract: Fill up on Jimmy Peniston’s Wednesday grid.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: A Subway Ride With Victor Wembanyama to Yankee Stadium
abstract: Wembanyama, the 19-year-old French basketball star, is in town for the N.B.A. draft. At more than seven feet tall, he’s hard to miss.
lead_paragraph: It was a rather unremarkable Tuesday at Central Park West and Columbus Circle. Vendors sold hot dogs, coffee and overpriced bottled water nearby. A light breeze rustled the sycamore branches hanging over a bicycle rental kiosk filled with neat rows of mint green helmets. Then, at 4:41 p.m., a black Mercedes van crept through the jam of buses, police vehicles and flower-adorned bicycle cabs.

headline: Corrections: June 21, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about Ron DeSantis’s age compared with that of other presidential candidates misstated the number of voters between the ages of 35 and 49 who had a favorable view of Mr. DeSantis, according to a Quinnipiac University poll. It was about two in five, not about one in four.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hidden Horrors of Russian Treatment of P.O.W.s
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It was a good day when you found a potato in your soup.”

headline: Biden Calls Xi a ‘Dictator’ Who Was Kept in the Dark About Spy Balloon
abstract: At a campaign fund-raiser, the president said China’s leader was “very embarrassed” to not be informed about the surveillance craft that was shot down after crossing American airspace.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday night called President Xi Jinping of China a “dictator” who had been kept in the dark by his own government about the spy balloon that crossed into United States airspace this winter before being shot down by an American fighter jet.

headline: What the New, Low Test Scores for 13-Year-Olds Say About U.S. Education Now
abstract: The results are the federal government’s last major data release on the academic effects of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The math and reading performance of 13-year-olds in the United States has hit the lowest level in decades, according to test scores released today from the National Assessment of Educational Progress, the gold-standard federal exam.

headline: 2 Women and 2 Ways of Wielding Power in New York
abstract: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is staying out of local politics right now, while Ingrid Lewis-Martin is a major figure behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at two powerful figures in New York City politics — one who is well-known and one who isn’t. We’ll also get details on a fire that renewed concerns about the dangers of batteries for e-bikes.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Search for a missing submersible craft.
lead_paragraph: An international team of rescuers was racing against time to search thousands of square miles of the North Atlantic for a deep-diving submersible with five people on board and a dwindling supply of oxygen. A staggering list of logistical challenges has complicated the operation.

headline: A Closer Look at the Submersible Lost in the North Atlantic
abstract: On the vessel, there were five passengers packed into a tight interior with no seats and a single view port 21 inches in diameter.
lead_paragraph: On the vessel, there were five passengers packed into a tight interior with no seats and a single view port 21 inches in diameter.

headline: Word of the Day: perfunctorily
abstract: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word perfunctorily has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 19 in “How a Psychologist Confronted Her Own Bipolar Disorder” by Kay Redfield Jamison:

headline: Why Is Narendra Modi So Popular? Tune In to Find Out.
abstract: The Indian leader, who visits Washington this week, has softened his image at home with an old-fashioned radio show, which feeds a vast social media apparatus.
lead_paragraph: Once a month, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, walks into a studio set up at his government bungalow and takes his seat behind a microphone. The air-conditioning is switched off to quiet its hum. Thick curtains maintain the room’s silence even from Mr. Modi’s favorite peacocks in the garden outside.

headline: U.K. Inflation Remains Stuck at 8.7%
abstract: The rate, which had been expected to edge lower in May, shows that Britain’s cost-of-living crisis persists, and is likely to prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates again.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s inflation rate held steady in May, frustrating expectations that price increases would slow down, according to data released Wednesday, the day before the country’s central bank is widely expected to raise interest rates again.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: N.Y. Lawmakers Confront Hot-Button Issues in Rare Return to Albany
abstract: The State Assembly reconvened to consider contentious bills on immigration, abortion, criminal justice and climate change.
lead_paragraph: Come late June, most state legislators in New York are typically far away from the Capitol in Albany, getting a jump on the summer after wrapping up their lawmaking duties for the year.

headline: Property Taxes to Be Cut in Half for Most Older N.J. Homeowners
abstract: The budget deal is expected to result in taxpayer savings of as much as $6,500 a year, representing one of the largest tax cuts in New Jersey history.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey has some of the highest property taxes in the country, a fact often cited by older residents who choose to sell their homes to either downsize or move out of state.

headline: Our Plan to Attract a Flock of Birders
abstract: In its first-ever citizen science project, The Times is encouraging readers to go birding and help researchers gather data on the avian world.
lead_paragraph: We would not count ourselves as birders. Elaine, who visited the Everglades occasionally when she lived in Miami, knows a purple gallinule when she sees one. Alan can tell a red-tailed hawk from a sharp-shinned one, having been dragged as a child every spring to the southern shore of Lake Ontario to watch raptors migrate north. But such traits alone do not a birder make.

headline: Rents for 2 Million New Yorkers to Rise Again This Year
abstract: Rent-stabilized apartments have enabled many people to stay in a city that grows ever more expensive. But for the second year in a row, rents will rise.
lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive year, a New York City panel that regulates the rents for roughly one million rent-stabilized apartments approved Wednesday some of the highest increases in a decade, as inflation and rising expenses for property owners continue to aggravate the city’s affordability problems.

headline: How E-Bike Battery Fires Became a Deadly Crisis in New York City
abstract: City leaders are racing to regulate battery-powered mobility devices, which have been the source of over 100 fires so far this year.
lead_paragraph: His girlfriend told him not to buy the electric scooter.

headline: One Man’s Inspiring Journey to Lift His Country Out of Poverty
abstract: We’re told education can end poverty. The truth is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: We’re told education can end poverty. The truth is more complicated.

headline: These Fish Tacos Couldn’t Be More Brilliant
abstract: Golden pineapple and a deep-red marinade make this dish pop with color and flavor.
lead_paragraph: When Luis Herrera is cooking, Korean gochugaru, Thai curry paste and Venezuelan ají dulce make their way into his pots and pans. They appear as often as guajillo and ancho chiles and fresh masa milled down the block from his Mexican restaurant, Ensenada, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Inspired by the compatibility of various cuisines, the Venezuelan chef finds moments of ingenuity every day, pulling especially from Latin American influences. “I think that’s when greatness happens,” he says.

headline: Mailbag: Does Trump Represent Half the Country?
abstract: Settling a marital dispute, and a question that gets at a tension within today’s conservatism — in this month’s reader mailbag.
lead_paragraph: Whenever possible, it’s important for both partners to feel good with the settlement of a marital dispute. So let me suggest that the answer depends on your preferred definition of a “Trump supporter.”

headline: $450,000 Homes in Oklahoma, Missouri and Rhode Island
abstract: A Craftsman bungalow in Oklahoma City, a Tudor Revival house in St. Louis and a Colonial Revival cottage in Cranston.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Mesta Park, a neighborhood listed on the National Register of Historic Places because of its Craftsman homes dating to the early 20th century. It is within walking distance of a park and a stretch of NW 23rd Street with several Vietnamese restaurants; doughnut, ice cream and coffee shops; and Tower Theatre, a 1937 theater that is now a venue for live entertainment and film screenings.

headline: One Man’s Inspiring Journey to Lift His Country Out of Poverty
abstract: We’re told education can end poverty. The truth is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Around the world we talk a good game about the importance of education, but we rarely act as if we mean it.

headline: The Bargain You Make Living in America May No Longer Hold
abstract: Less for more. That’s the fundamental bargain, as it’s been construed since Roe v. Wade and the Reagan revolution.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the American bargain: less for more. Less from the government, in exchange for more of yourself. More privacy, more speech, more ability to move wherever you might want to go and to associate with whomever you like.

headline: The World’s Digital Memory Is at Risk
abstract: Digital archives are humanity’s collective memory. Who should control them, and how, is a major problem for digital societies.
lead_paragraph: A constant hum drones out of a former church in San Francisco. It is the sound, from hundreds of fans cooling hundreds of computer servers, of the digital past being kept alive. This is the Internet Archive, the largest collection of archived web pages in the world and a constant reminder of the fragility of our digital past. It is also, thanks to a March ruling in a federal court, which found that the archive’s lending practices violate publishers’ rights, just one battlefield in a growing struggle that will define how humanity’s collective digital memory is owned, shared and preserved — or lost forever.

headline: People on Drugs Like Ozempic Say Their ‘Food Noise’ Has Disappeared
abstract: For some, it’s a startling side effect.
lead_paragraph: Until she started taking the weight loss drug Wegovy, Staci Klemmer’s days revolved around food. When she woke up, she plotted out what she would eat; as soon as she had lunch, she thought about dinner. After leaving work as a high school teacher in Bucks County, Pa., she would often drive to Taco Bell or McDonald’s to quell what she called a “24/7 chatter” in the back of her mind. Even when she was full, she wanted to eat.

headline: This Salon Works to Understand Black Women’s Hair
abstract: Each week, the global conglomerate Unilever brings people into a salon to test new products. It’s hoping to get a bigger piece of the long undervalued but growing Black beauty market.
lead_paragraph: On a recent spring afternoon, Marcella Roberts and Brooke Council sat in a salon chatting about how much they liked their hair. The two women, who are Black, were discussing a new cream they had been using to style and moisturize their curly hairstyles.

headline: Child Care Disruptions Expected as Record Funding Nears an End
abstract: Three million children could be affected as the largest investment in child care in U.S. history expires in September.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the United States has been effectively running an experiment in federally funding child care providers. The $24 billion disbursed in pandemic relief has been the largest investment in child care in U.S. history. Child care providers have used the money to raise teachers’ pay, buy supplies and pay mortgages.

headline: Few of Trump’s G.O.P. Rivals Defend Justice Dept. Independence
abstract: The evolution of the Republican Party under the influence of former President Donald J. Trump calls into question a post-Watergate norm.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has promised that if he wins back the presidency he will appoint a special prosecutor to “go after” President Biden and his family.

headline: Chris Christie Is Doing Something Very, Very Important
abstract: He’s telling the unvarnished truth. How gratifying is that?
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie made a complete fool of himself back in 2016, fan-dancing obsequiously around Donald Trump, angling for a crucial role in his administration, nattering on about their friendship, pretending or possibly even convincing himself that Trump could restrain his ego, check his nastiness, suspend his grift and, well, serve America. But then Christie, a former two-term governor of New Jersey, had plenty of company. And he never did style himself as some saint.

headline: Everyone Likes Reading. Why Are We So Afraid of It?
abstract: Book bans, chatbots, pedagogical warfare: What it means to read has become a minefield.
lead_paragraph: Everyone loves reading. In principle, anyway. Nobody is against it, right? Surely, in the midst of our many quarrels, we can agree that people should learn to read, should learn to enjoy it and should do a lot of it. But bubbling underneath this bland, upbeat consensus is a simmer of individual anxiety and collective panic. We are in the throes of a reading crisis.

headline: Dolby Atmos Wants You to Listen Up. (And Down. And Sideways.)
abstract: True believers in the immersive audio format say it could restore a musical appreciation lost to a generation that has come up during the streaming era.
lead_paragraph: After more than 30 years as a producer and engineer, Brad Wood wasn’t sure if he still had a future in music.

headline: The High Price of Petulance in the Senate
abstract: What’s new about the latest version of these Senate holds is the breadth and long-term nature of their effects.
lead_paragraph: Instead of showing up for work last Tuesday, Senator Tommy Tuberville, Republican of Alabama, went to Donald Trump’s golf club in Bedminster, N.J., to hear the former president rail against his latest criminal indictment. Mr. Tuberville’s absence from the Capitol gave the Senate an opportunity to end his one-man blockade of all military promotions, a campaign he has been waging for four months to protest the Pentagon’s policy paying for service members to travel for an abortion if they live in a state where it is illegal.

headline: Is the Inflation Battle Won? Not Yet.
abstract: Inflation has come down from its 2022 heights, but economists are worried about its stubbornness.
lead_paragraph: Inflation is beginning to abate meaningfully for American consumers. Gas is cheaper, eggs cost roughly half as much as they did in January and prices are no longer climbing as rapidly across a wide array of products.

headline: In Los Angeles, Bringing Food, Soap and the Salon to the Homeless
abstract: Through Beauty 2 the Streetz, Shirley Raines helps those without a home by administering a little “spiritual C.P.R.” Millions watch on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.

headline: Living In ... Glastonbury, Conn.
abstract: The Hartford suburb draws residents with its bustling downtown, plentiful activities and long history (including a ferry established in 1655).
lead_paragraph: The Hartford suburb draws residents with its bustling downtown, plentiful activities and long history (including a ferry established in 1655).

headline: Going Bankrupt in the Name of Efficiency
abstract: Two new books offer harsh assessments of private equity firms that specializes in buying up companies only to saddle them with debt and squeeze them for profits.
lead_paragraph: In “These Are the Plunderers: How Private Equity Runs — and Wrecks — America,” a new book by Gretchen Morgenson and Joshua Rosner, the arguments are about as subtle as a wrecking ball. It’s a measure of just how inflamed the rhetoric can be that when I arrived at the chapter called “‘Like When Hitler Invaded Poland in 1939,’” I assumed the authors were the ones drawing the analogy. In addition to the “plunderers” of the title, their book is full of “money-spinners,” “buyout boys,” “pirates,” “pillagers” and “marauders”; a resident at a private equity-owned nursing home was forced to undergo, in the authors’ ghastly description, “a Bataan-like death march of therapy sessions.”

headline: So Your Plant Is Sick? Here’s How to Get a Diagnosis.
abstract: Welcome to the ‘disease garden’: It’s not pretty, but it’s full of answers.
lead_paragraph: In a garden she developed by the corner of a building on Purdue University’s campus, in West Lafayette, Ind., Janna L. Beckerman invites trouble.

headline: Odesa Was Ready to Reclaim Its Beaches. Then a Dam Broke.
abstract: Wartime fears closed the Ukrainian city’s famed beaches last year, but crowds were starting to return — until the destruction of a faraway dam dumped debris and dangers into the Black Sea.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, the beaches that ring the port city of Odesa in southern Ukraine were crowded with volunteers packing sandbags under bluffs where troops were positioned in machine gun nests as the threat of a Russian amphibious assault still loomed.

headline: How It Feels to Have Your Life Changed By Affirmative Action
abstract: Black and Hispanic college graduates, whose lives were directly shaped by race-conscious college admissions, have complicated thoughts about the expected Supreme Court decision.
lead_paragraph: As a top student at his Philadelphia high school in 1968, Granderson Hale knew he stood a decent chance of admission at one of the historically Black colleges that typically sent recruiters to the school, where nearly all of the 2,700 students were Black.

headline: Glastonbury, Conn.: A Friendly Community With Grand Historic Homes
abstract: The Hartford suburb draws residents with its bustling downtown, plentiful activities and long history (including a ferry established in 1655).
lead_paragraph: Diana Gallagher and her husband, Tony Patelunas, ended up in the Hartford suburb of Glastonbury, Conn., almost by chance. In 2021, they were living in Windham and looking for homes in the general vicinity, close to the University of Connecticut, when a colonial-style house in Glastonbury caught their eye.

headline: Italian Men’s Wear Does a Power Edit
abstract: Lauren showed psychedelic tuxedos, Armani and Zegna stripped things down and Chris Pine made the rounds during a potent fashion season in Florence and Milan.
lead_paragraph: Concision — that was the word to come to mind after eight surprising days in this men’s wear capital, and in Florence. Did some unseen force take a blue pencil to all the slack narratives, rehashed inspirations, derivative references that prevailed in recent seasons? Suddenly everything seemed crisp and focused, like early Hemingway after he’d learned how to do Gertrude Stein.

headline: In Hosting Modi, Biden Pushes Democracy Concerns to the Background
abstract: The president who declared “the battle between democracy and autocracy” to be the defining struggle of his time has concluded that he needs to accept some imperfect but important friends.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has declared “the battle between democracy and autocracy” to be the defining struggle of his time. But when he rolls out the red carpet on the South Lawn of the White House for Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on Thursday morning, Mr. Biden will effectively call a temporary truce.

headline: Pink Floyd, ‘The Wizard of Oz’ and Me
abstract: The inside story of a Times reporter’s strange role in a foundational moment in early internet culture: “The Dark Side of the Rainbow.”
lead_paragraph: The inside story of a Times reporter’s strange role in a foundational moment in early internet culture: “The Dark Side of the Rainbow.”

headline: Today’s Top News: The Missing Titan Submersible, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: The Re-Militarization of Germany
abstract: The invasion of Ukraine is forcing Europe’s economic giant to dispense with taboos dating back to the postwar years.
lead_paragraph: In the decades after World War II and the atrocities of the Holocaust, Germany deliberately underinvested in its military. But that’s about to change.

headline: Waiting for the Justices
abstract: We’re covering the coming affirmative action ruling, the search for a submersible and Hunter Biden.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the next 10 days, the Supreme Court is expected to tightly restrict or ban race-based affirmative action in college admissions. The ruling could come as soon as tomorrow or as late as Friday, June 30, before the justices leave for their summer break.

headline: Business Leaders Join Biden in Welcoming Modi to the U.S.
abstract: India’s fast-growing economy is drawing American corporate giants, even as the country faces scrutiny over ties to Russia and limits on political freedoms.
lead_paragraph: The White House is rolling out the red carpet for Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister, with a state dinner on Thursday. High on the agenda: Talks to strengthen economic and security ties as the Biden administration cultivates partners to counter China. Business is watching closely, too, as it pours money into one of the world’s fastest-growing big economies despite the challenges of operating there.

headline: Andrew Tate’s Indictment in Romania: Here’s What to Know
abstract: The online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, appeared in court for the first time since their indictment on charges including human trafficking.
