lead_paragraph: Andrew Tate, a wealth-flaunting online influencer known for his male chauvinism and misogynistic views, has been indicted in Romania for human trafficking and forming an organized criminal group.

headline: The Largest and Fastest Religious Shift in America Is Well Underway
abstract: We’re dechurching at a rapid clip.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth newsletter in a series about Americans moving away from religion. Read part one, part two and part three.

headline: Delaware’s Only House Member Enters Senate Race, Becoming Instant Favorite
abstract: Lisa Blunt Rochester, the handpicked successor to retiring Senator Thomas R. Carper, would be the third Black woman in history to win a Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester, a Democrat, announced her campaign on Wednesday for the Delaware Senate seat being vacated by Senator Thomas R. Carper, beginning as the favorite in a race that could make her the third Black woman in U.S. history to win election to the Senate.

headline: South Korea to Drop ‘Killer Questions’ From College Entrance Exam
abstract: The exam is notorious for extremely difficult problems, some of which seem to have little to do with the test topic. Even the president has complained.
lead_paragraph: Although the standardized test topic was the Korean language, the students had to answer questions about equity capital and risk-weighted bank assets. Problems on the “society” portion of the exam challenged them to decipher three-dimensional hypothetical analyses of Piaget’s theory of cognitive development.

headline: Fed Chair Sees ‘Long Way to Go’ on Inflation Fight
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that most central bank officials expect rates to rise further.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that the United States remains a “long way” away from low and stable inflation even 15 months into the central bank’s campaign to cool the economy and wrestle down rapid price increases.

headline: ‘I Don’t Know How You Can Block the Plate From Behind the Plate’
abstract: A night after Bruce Bochy said a replay ruling was “one of the worst calls I’ve ever seen,” another controversial call on a play at the plate added even more confusion.
lead_paragraph: For years, fans and players alike have complained that no one is sure what constitutes a catch in the N.F.L. It appears that no one knows what blocking the plate means in Major League Baseball either.

headline: Biden Administration Moves to Restore Endangered Species Protections
abstract: New rules would void Trump-era changes that made it easier to remove animals and plants from the endangered list.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration moved on Wednesday to make it easier to protect wildlife from climate disruptions and other threats, restoring protections to the Endangered Species Act that President Donald J. Trump had removed.

headline: My Child’s Friend Asked to Be Called a Name Used by Another Gender. Should I Do It?
abstract: A reader is unsure how to respond to a child’s wish to go by a different name after learning that the child’s mother decided not to honor the request.
lead_paragraph: Our 14-year-old child has a great circle of friends. I am often their chauffeur. The kids and I have friendly conversations in the car. Recently, one of them informed the group they would like to be called a different name — one that is typically associated with a different gender. The kids have obliged their friend, and I would be happy to, as well. But my wife told me that the child’s mother said she wasn’t going along with this request, though she didn’t say that other people shouldn’t. How should I proceed? I don’t want to alienate anyone or damage friendships.

headline: Why California Transit Agencies Are Rebounding at Such Different Rates
abstract: Who rides public transportation has shifted since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In California, already famous for its love of automobiles, our dependence on cars only deepened during the coronavirus pandemic, as millions of people stopped commuting by train or bus.

headline: Israeli Settlers Attack Palestinian Towns After Shooting
abstract: A day after Palestinian gunmen killed four people, Israelis set fires in Palestinian areas and their government hastened plans to expand settlements in the occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Israeli extremists caused widespread damage in a wave of attacks on Palestinian towns that lasted from Tuesday night until Wednesday night in revenge for the killing of four Israelis by Palestinian gunmen outside a nearby settlement in the territory.

headline: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son Shifts to ‘Offense’ in A.I. Race
abstract: After lying low last year and “crying for days,” the founder and chief executive of the tech conglomerate said he was excited again about the future.
lead_paragraph: For months, Masayoshi Son, SoftBank’s voluble founder and chief executive, kept quiet as his tech conglomerate struggled with huge investment losses.

headline: In Iran, Some Are Chasing the Last Drops of Water
abstract: Lawmakers are warning that one province will run out within three months, and the shortage is inflaming tensions with the country’s neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Summer has come to Sistan and Baluchistan province, an impoverished fragment of chapped earth and shimmering heat in Iran’s southeast corner, and all people there can talk about is how to get water.

headline: What Horror Means to Me
abstract: Growing up in 1970s Argentina, fear was everywhere. It was also essential.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Maxine Waters Proposes Billions to Expand Low-Income Housing
abstract: Nearly one in three Americans living on the street and in shelters are in the representative’s home state of California.
lead_paragraph: In a sweeping effort to expand affordable housing and combat homelessness, Representative Maxine Waters of California introduced a package of three bills on Wednesday aimed at narrowing the country’s racial wealth gap.

headline: ‘Dear England’ Review: When Soccer Success Becomes a Moral Victory
abstract: A new James Graham play about the soccer coach Gareth Southgate is a lively romp, but its core message about embracing male vulnerability feels soppy.
lead_paragraph: What makes a good leader? When the unassuming and softly spoken Gareth Southgate was appointed head coach of the England men’s soccer team in 2016, many fans and commentators felt he lacked the kahunas for the role, that he was simply too nice. But in the past seven years he has overseen a remarkable transformation in the England team’s fortunes, making it stronger and more exciting to watch than at any time in recent history.

headline: F.T.C. Accuses Amazon of Tricking Users Into Subscribing to Prime
abstract: The lawsuit is the first time that the Federal Trade Commission under its chair, Lina Khan, has taken Amazon to court.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of illegally inducing consumers to sign up for its Prime service and then hindering them from canceling the subscription, in the most aggressive action against the company to date by the agency’s chair, Lina Khan.

headline: Ukraine’s soccer fans team up to support the war effort.
abstract: At the Corner Pub in Kyiv, supporters are cheering on their team, but they have also become fund-raisers, military boosters and logistics experts providing equipment to the front lines.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — More than 100 people were rooting for Ukraine’s national soccer team in the front of the Corner Pub, but a look at the back rooms of the bar made it clear that its customers were more than just sports fans.

headline: Hidden in a Mini-Mall in Flushing, a Home for Art
abstract: In a Queens neighborhood with a diverse community of East Asian immigrants, an unlikely exhibition in an unexpected place offers a sense of belonging.
lead_paragraph: The flier announcing a new exhibition in Queens, “Home-O-Stasis,” doesn’t give an address. Instead, it has instructions: When you reach the Queens Public Library in Flushing, “go up to Kissena Boulevard till you see the Q17/Q27 stop. Go past the garage gate, enter the mini-mall on the right where scooters and bikes are parked outside.” (How you get to the library is up to you and Google maps.)

headline: The war is worsening the effects of climate change, Kerry says.
abstract: The forced movement of people, the destruction of agricultural land and the increased instability are being felt in Ukraine and beyond, said John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The war in Ukraine is aggravating the painful effects of climate change, causing not only severe damage in Ukraine, but also distress in a wider circle that includes Africa and South Asia, according to John F. Kerry, the United States special presidential envoy for climate.

headline: A Quick and Easy Skillet Chocolate Chip Cookie
abstract: Treat yourself, too, to 7Up sheet cake and sweet cream cold foam to marble into your iced coffee.
lead_paragraph: Surely no one with a sweet tooth and a pulse can resist a skillet-size giant chocolate chip cookie (above). I certainly can’t. It’s so much easier and quicker than the usual cookies you have to scoop and bake in batches, since here you just press the dough directly into the pan. The payoff is eating the slices fresh from the oven, when the slightly too hot wedges sting your fingertips and the chips are just gooey enough. This is the chewy, chocolaty, brown sugar-filled treat that you deserve right now, and it’s an utter snap to make.

headline: Gooped at a Gwyneth Paltrow Drag Show
abstract: Partygoers donned glitter and gowns in homage to the actress and jade egg enthusiast at a party in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Gwyneth Paltrow has been popping up in unexpected places this year. She was in court in March, dressed impeccably, and won $1 after being found not at fault for a ski crash. She was on a cruise ship. And on Friday evening at 3 Dollar Bill, a queer club in the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, she was onstage.

headline: Student Loan Pause Is Ending, With Consequences for Economy
abstract: Three years of relief from payments on $1.6 trillion in student debt allowed for other borrowing and spending — and will shift into reverse.
lead_paragraph: A bedrock component of pandemic-era relief for households is coming to an end: The debt-limit deal struck by the White House and congressional Republicans requires that the pause on student loan payments be lifted no later than Aug. 30.

headline: Two-Time Titan Diver Says Rescue May Depend on Passengers Staying Calm
abstract: Oisin Fanning, the passenger, said that Stockton Rush and Paul-Henri Nargeolet, who are on board the missing Titan, would have taken steps to conserve oxygen from the moment something went wrong.
lead_paragraph: Oisin Fanning, who made two deep-sea dives on the Titan last summer, said the passengers’ ability to survive on the missing submersible could depend on staying calm and avoiding panicked breathing that would use up more oxygen.

headline: Senate Democrats Seek to Highlight G.O.P. Opposition to Abortion Rights
abstract: Democrats brought to the floor a set of bills intended to protect women’s health and reproductive freedom, knowing they would be blocked by Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats on Wednesday forced consideration of measures intended to protect women’s health and reproductive freedom, using the upcoming anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade to remind voters of Republican opposition to measures with broad voter approval.

headline: Shahzada and Suleman Dawood, Father-Son Passengers, Love Science Fiction and Travel
abstract: The expedition to the wreck of the Titanic followed a yearslong passion for science and discovery, according to friends and family.
lead_paragraph: Like the other passengers of the missing submersible, Shahzada Dawood loves adventure.

headline: My Wife Lives in a Nursing Home. Can I Take a Lover?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what is permissible in a marriage.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I have been married for 50 years; she has been “at death’s door” for the last 30 of them and institutionalized for the past seven years because of her poor health. She’s 68, and I’m 71. There has been no love or intimacy for the past 10 years. We can’t afford to divorce. I am raising three grandkids that we adopted. The two older kids are intellectually disabled because of fetal alcohol syndrome and will never live independently.

headline: ‘No Hard Feelings’ Review: How Lucky Can a Nerdy Kid Get?
abstract: That time when Mom and Dad hired Jennifer Lawrence to introduce you to the pleasures of the opposite sex before you started college.
lead_paragraph: The premise that motors “No Hard Feelings,” a new comedy directed by Gene Stupnitsky, is, if not outright indecent, at least a little crass. Via online advertisement, Laird and Allison, megawealthy Montauk residents, are seeking an attractive woman in her early 20s to deflower their socially awkward Princeton-bound son, Percy. In return for this service they’ll bestow a not-quite brand-new car on the kinda-sorta prostitute.

headline: New Erectile Dysfunction Treatment Cleared for Over-the-Counter U.S. Sales
abstract: Eroxon, a topical gel, “helps men get an erection within 10 minutes,” according to Futura Medical, the manufacturer.
lead_paragraph: This month, the Food and Drug Administration approved the marketing of a new treatment for erectile dysfunction, a topical gel called Eroxon, meaning it can be sold over the counter in the United States. It is the first topical treatment for the condition to be made available without a prescription.

headline: At U.N., Narendra Modi Celebrates Yoga, and Joins In on a Pose
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has cracked down on dissent in India. In New York on Wednesday, he stressed inclusivity.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, on a three-day visit to the United States, kicked off a group yoga session for international diplomats on the lawn of the United Nations in Manhattan on Wednesday morning, stressing the nondenominational aspect of the practice that has roots in Hindu spirituality.

headline: The Artist Making Glassware With Solange Knowles and Saint Heron
abstract: Jason McDonald became a glassblower knowing that throughout history, there’s little to no record of Black glassblowers. He’d like to change that.
lead_paragraph: Jason McDonald discovered glassblowing more than two decades ago at an after school program in his hometown, Tacoma, Wash. He was 14 at the time, and it was nothing like anything he had ever seen before, he said: immediate, dangerous and sobering.

headline: ‘Like Doomsday’: How Hope of a Better Life Ended on a Boat in the Mediterranean
abstract: About two dozen of those on the fishing vessel that capsized off Greece came from Bandli, a community in northeastern Pakistan with a long history of young men chasing a brighter future abroad.
lead_paragraph: There was no changing their minds.

headline: A Superyacht Gave a Lifeline to 100 Migrants Thrown Into the Sea
abstract: A $175 million vessel responded to a distress call and helped rescue survivors in one of the Mediterranean’s worst wrecks in decades, reflecting the new inequality of the seas.
lead_paragraph: The superyacht Mayan Queen IV was sailing smoothly in clear weather through the dark and calm Mediterranean in the early hours of June 14 when it received a call about a migrant ship in distress four nautical miles away.

headline: A Britney Spears Jukebox Musical Hopes for #SeeBritney Energy
abstract: “Once Upon a One More Time” is bringing hits like “Toxic” and “Circus” to Broadway. Will Spears’s fiercely protective base embrace it?
lead_paragraph: The book writer for “Once Upon a One More Time,” the Britney Spears jukebox musical opening on Broadway Thursday night, often returns to a memory from five years ago, when Spears sat in a Manhattan theater a few rows in front of him and watched an early reading of the show.

headline: Justice Alito Defends Private Jet Travel to Luxury Fishing Trip
abstract: In an opinion essay in The Wall Street Journal, the justice disputed a ProPublica report, saying he was not required to disclose the trip or recuse himself from his benefactor’s cases.
lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. took the unusual step late Tuesday of responding to questions about his travel with a billionaire who frequently has cases before the Supreme Court hours before an article detailing their ties had even been published.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Agencies May Never Find Covid’s Origins, Officials Say
abstract: The agencies are expected to release declassified material on what they have learned about Covid’s origins. People briefed on the material say there is no smoking gun.
lead_paragraph: For three years, the U.S. government has been tied in knots over the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, frustrated that China’s hindrance of investigations and unwillingness to look critically at its own research have obscured what intelligence agencies can learn about whether the virus escaped from a lab.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal and Donald Trump’s Defense
abstract: Readers discuss the cases of the former president and the current president’s son. Also: New York Harbor; hospice care; prison dancers; Pride flags.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Extreme Heat and More Storms Threaten an Already Battered Oklahoma
abstract: Thousands of people were without power in the state, and days of sweltering temperatures are expected to put further strain on resources there and in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Battered by severe storms that killed at least two people and left thousands without electricity, Oklahoma faced relentless heat and more severe storms on Wednesday as crews worked furiously to restore power in the hard-hit northeast part of the state.

headline: What to Know About the Missing Titan Submersible
SUMMER MOVIES 2023
‘The Flash’: What to Know
Kansas Man Accused of Threatening to Attack Nashville Pride Event
abstract: Joshua Hensley, 25, wrote on Facebook that he planned to make pressure-cooker bombs and to “commit a mass shooting” at Nashville Pride this weekend, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Kansas man has been indicted on charges of threatening to commit violent attacks at a Pride event in Nashville this month, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Is Back. Here’s What to Remember.
abstract: The new season, premiering Thursday on Max, promises the return of beloved figures from the franchise’s past. Here’s a quick primer on who’s who and how they all fit together.
lead_paragraph: “Sex and the City” premiered just over 25 years ago, on June 6, 1998, and since then much has been lost in a franchise that now includes six seasons of the original HBO show, two films and the Max follow-up series, “And Just Like That …”

headline: The Secret in the Spots on Monarch Butterflies’ Wings
abstract: The wings of monarchs that survive a 2,000-mile-long migration tend to be spottier, suggesting that feature may aid the insects’ ability to fly.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, monarch butterflies embark on one of nature’s greatest journeys. These insects flap more than 2,000 miles from their summer homes in Canada down to the mountains of central Mexico. Only about 30 percent survive the trip. Researchers have found a shared trait in the butterflies that make it: The edges of their wings tend to be slightly spottier.

headline: Wes Anderson’s Secret Weapon: The Camera Moves of Sanjay Sami
abstract: Sami brings ingenious design, a D.I.Y. spirit and pure athletic ability to the job of key grip — pushing and pulling heavy camera rigs with exacting precision.
lead_paragraph: Wes Anderson’s intricate films are known for their jewel box sets, vibrant costumes and starry ensemble casts. But there’s another element that gives his movies their distinctive look and feel, and it comes in the form of a 52-year-old grip.

headline: Hundreds of Sea Lions Are Dying. Is an Algal Bloom to Blame?
abstract: Rescuers have been inundated with calls about sick and dying sea lions and dolphins along California’s central coast. They believe the cause is a toxin produced by a harmful algae.
lead_paragraph: The calls came in, one after the other, with reports of sea lions swaying their heads back and forth, foaming at the mouth, or slumped, lifeless on the beach. Rescuers along the central California coast struggled to keep up as they captured the sick animals in the hopes of saving them. Already, hundreds of sea lions and dozens of dolphins had died.

headline: Harsh New Fentanyl Laws Ignite Debate Over How to Combat Overdose Crisis
abstract: Critics say a fierce law-and-order approach could undermine public health goals and advances in addiction treatment.
lead_paragraph: Three teenage girls were found slumped in a car in the parking lot of a rural Tennessee high school last month, hours before graduation ceremonies. Two were dead from fentanyl overdoses. The third, a 17-year-old, was rushed to the hospital in critical condition. Two days later, she was charged with the girls’ murders.

headline: ‘Good Vibrations’ Review: The Saving Power of Punk
abstract: In a big-hearted musical about a 1970s Belfast record store owner and the punk movement he nurtured, music is the real hero.
lead_paragraph: On a nighttime street in 1970s Belfast, Northern Ireland, a D.J. named Terri Hooley runs into a pair of local toughs — young men who’ve found their purpose in the gunfire and explosions of a sectarian conflict pitting Protestants against Catholics.

headline: Biggest Threat to Submersible’s Passengers May Now Be Dwindling Oxygen
abstract: There may be less than a day’s worth of breathable air left in the Titan, limiting the window for possible rescue of the five people on board.
lead_paragraph: As search and rescue teams scour the North Atlantic for the missing submersible Titan, one overriding question may dictate the fate of the five passengers: How much oxygen is left?

headline: Explosion Rocks Central Paris, Injuring at Least 37 People
abstract: The blast, in the Fifth Arrondissement of the French capital, started a blaze that firefighters quickly brought under control. The origin of the explosion, which critically injured four people, was unclear.
lead_paragraph: An explosion tore through an apartment building in central Paris on Wednesday, partly collapsing the structure and injuring at least 37 people, four of them critically, according to the French authorities.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Pharrell Williams at Louis Vuitton and Gunna’s New LP
abstract: What’s the role of global celebrity in high fashion? Why hasn’t hip-hop penetrated the charts this year? And what’s the snack of the week?
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: R.I.P., the Sun Triangle
abstract: A Manhattan installation that pointed to the wonders of astronomy is gone but not forgotten.
lead_paragraph: When you throw a yellow beach ball upward, it slows down, comes to a stop for a moment and then comes back down, gaining speed as it falls. Now imagine that beach ball is the sun, getting higher in the sky each noon from December until June until one day it stops getting higher. That day is the summer solstice — from the Latin “solstitium,” or “point at which the sun seems to stand still.” In the next instant the bright yellow beach ball begins to descend, and we’re on our way to fall and winter.

headline: Rodeo Is Turning America’s Whitest Big City Black
abstract: Like a rider wrestling a bull beneath bright lights, reconciling national narratives is not a pastime for the faint of heart.
lead_paragraph: A Black rodeo sounds like a good time at any time, but this is a particular moment in the near history of Portland, Ore. The city was a staging area for Black Lives Matter protests. That surprised a lot of people. For many years, Portland held the distinction of being the whitest big city in the United States. From its inception, Oregon had laws that restricted the number of Black people within its borders.

headline: How a Scientific Fraud Reinvented Himself
abstract: The rehabilitation of Hwang Woo-suk speaks volumes.
lead_paragraph: Science is known for rigorous self-policing by the research community, yet it can seem that scientific fraud is rampant. Why do frauds think they can get away with it?

headline: Dozens of Migrants Bound for Canary Islands Feared Dead as Boat Sinks
abstract: Twenty-four people were rescued and two confirmed dead, but 35 others were missing after an inflatable vessel heading to the Spanish archipelago sank, an aid group said.
lead_paragraph: At least two migrants died and 35 more were feared dead after an inflatable boat en route to the Canary Islands, a Spanish archipelago off northwestern Africa, sank on Wednesday, according to the Spanish authorities and an aid group.

headline: Daniel Ellsberg, Pentagon Papers Source, Had Uneasy Relationship With The Times
abstract: Mr. Ellsberg took issue with how the newspaper portrayed his role, and how he was treated by the project’s primary reporter.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between The New York Times and its most famous source, Daniel Ellsberg, reads like a thriller, replete with clandestine meetings, top secret documents and a war raging in the background.

headline: Man Who Assaulted Officer on Jan. 6 Is Sentenced to More Than 12 Years
abstract: Daniel Rodriguez, whom the judge called a “one-man army of hate,” received one of the stiffest sentences so far in the Justice Department’s investigation of the Capitol riot.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a rioter who savagely assaulted an officer defending the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, to more than 12 years in prison, calling him a “one-man army of hate” whose severe punishment might act as a deterrent to future acts of political violence.

headline: The Government Must Say What It Knows About Covid’s Origins
abstract: Transparency is how to fight misinformation.
lead_paragraph: Three researchers at a laboratory in Wuhan, China, who had fallen ill in November 2019 had been experimenting with SARS-like coronaviruses under inadequate biosafety conditions, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday, citing current and former U.S. officials.

headline: What’s In Our Queue? ‘The Thick of It’ and More
abstract: I’m a graphics and multimedia editor on The Times's Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a graphics and multimedia editor on The Times's Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Allies Pledge Billions for Ukraine’s Recovery as Zelensky Stresses Urgency
abstract: The price tag for reconstruction has soared, driving debate among U.S. and European officials, legal experts and others about using frozen Russian assets to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: Western countries pledged tens of billions of dollars to rebuild war-torn Ukraine on Wednesday, as leaders gathered at a two-day conference convened by the British government in the shadow of Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia.

headline: What I Got Wrong About My Parents’ Marriage
abstract: The unconventional child of a conventional Indian family realizes she overlooked the affection in her parents’ marriage.
lead_paragraph: As one of the only Indian girls in her tiny Canadian mountain town, Natasha Singh stood out — and she was unafraid of being different. At 13, she shaved her head. By 17, she had run away for good. A few years later, she came out to her mother.

headline: Searchers Cannot Tell Yet if Banging Sounds Are Clues to Missing Vessel
abstract: The underwater sounds, heard on Tuesday and again on Wednesday, come at half-hour intervals, suggesting they might be made by people on the missing submersible.
lead_paragraph: Underwater banging sounds, detected on Tuesday and again on Wednesday, might be an intriguing clue to the disappearance of a submersible on Sunday near the wreck of the Titanic — or they might just be unrelated noise. Searchers do not yet know which.

headline: Dozens Injured in Central Paris Explosion
abstract: Fire and smoke billowed from an apartment building after an explosion in the French capital.
lead_paragraph: Fire and smoke billowed from an apartment building after an explosion in the French capital.

headline: The Best Summer Desserts Are the Classics
abstract: Store-bought ice cream is at the heart of these three easy desserts from Melissa Clark: a nostalgic banana split, a fruity take on a soda shop staple and the next best thing to a Chipwich.
lead_paragraph: Plopping pints of mint chocolate chip or cherry vanilla onto the table after a laid-back dinner is a time-honored summer tradition. Effortless and crowd-pleasing, store-bought ice cream is the beloved finale to countless hot-weather meals.

headline: Emmys May Be Pushed Back Because of Writers’ Strike
abstract: Organizers of the September event are said to be discussing a postponement, possibly for months, if the strike lasts deep into the summer.
lead_paragraph: More fallout from the Hollywood writers’ strike could be on the horizon: a postponed Emmy Awards.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Modi at the White House
abstract: Plus, missing submersible updates and the Kashmir migrants who died off Greece.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi arrived in Washington yesterday, beginning a state visit that the U.S. hopes will draw India closer.

headline: Haim Roet, Who Kept Holocaust Victims’ Names Alive, Dies at 90
abstract: Since he first read the names of people murdered by the Nazis at a protest in 1989, the practice has become a part of memorial ceremonies around the world.
lead_paragraph: Rosina Roet. Adelheid Roet. Abraham Prince.

headline: Alito’s Reply in a Rival Publication Surprises ProPublica
abstract: The Wall Street Journal made the unusual decision to let Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. pre-empt ProPublica’s article about him in its opinion pages.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal faced criticism on Wednesday after its highly unusual decision to let Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. pre-empt another media organization’s article about him by publishing his response in its opinion pages.

headline: Canadian Aircraft Searches for Missing Titanic Submersible
abstract: A Royal Canadian Air Force aircraft searched the surface of the Atlantic Ocean and used sub-surface acoustic detection capabilities to look for the missing submersible.
lead_paragraph: A Royal Canadian Air Force aircraft searched the surface of the Atlantic Ocean and used sub-surface acoustic detection capabilities to look for the missing submersible.

headline: U.S. Approves the Sale of Lab-Grown Chicken
abstract: The Agriculture Department granted approval to cultivated meat producers for the first time in the United States, representing a watershed moment for the alternative protein industry.
lead_paragraph: The Agriculture Department approved the production and sale of laboratory-grown meat for the first time on Wednesday, clearing the way for two California companies to sell chicken produced from animal cells.

headline: Battling Russia, Ukrainian Leaders Also Fight High Expectations
abstract: Seeking to bolster morale and Western support, President Volodymyr Zelensky and his aides say that the slow progress of Ukraine’s counteroffensive is to be expected.
lead_paragraph: As much of the world pays close attention to the slow progress of Ukraine’s counteroffensive, its leaders are trying to tamp down expectations, saying that the fight to expel the Russian invaders was inevitably going to be a hard, bloody slog, not a lightning advance.

headline: Former F.B.I. Analyst Goes to Prison for Taking Classified Documents
abstract: Like former President Trump, the former analyst was accused of violating the Espionage Act, taking home hundreds of classified documents and being unhelpful.
lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. intelligence analyst from Kansas received nearly four years in prison on Wednesday in a case that bears parallels to that of former President Donald J. Trump, including the same charge of willful retention of national security secrets.

headline: Julie Garwood, Best-Selling Romance Novelist, Dies at 78
abstract: She first became known for novels set in the distant past. She later wrote contemporary tales that involved computer hacking and Ponzi schemes.
lead_paragraph: Julie Garwood, a romance novelist whose books — some set centuries ago, some sampling present-day maladies like computer hacking and Ponzi schemes — routinely landed on best-seller lists, died on June 8 at her home in Leawood, Kan., on the Missouri border. She was 78.

headline: Modi’s Pomp-Filled State Visit
abstract: Also, more vessels search for the missing sub. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: At the White House tonight, President Biden will host Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India for a private dinner that will kick off a pomp-filled state visit, matched only by visits from America’s closest allies.

headline: Submersible Pilot’s Spouse Is Descended From a Famous Titanic Couple
abstract: Wendy Rush is a great-great-granddaughter of the retailing magnate Isidor Straus and his wife, Ida, two of the wealthiest people to die aboard the ocean liner.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Rush, the wife of Stockton Rush, the OceanGate chief executive who was piloting the submersible that disappeared Sunday during a dive to the Titanic wreckage, is a descendant of two first-class passengers who died when the ocean liner sank in 1912, archival records show.

headline: Doc Antle of ‘Tiger King’ Is Convicted on Wildlife Trafficking Charges
abstract: Bhagavan Antle, who was found guilty on four felony counts, will be sentenced in September. He was cleared of the misdemeanor animal cruelty charges that he faced.
lead_paragraph: The owner of an animal park in South Carolina who was featured on the popular Netflix documentary “Tiger King” was convicted in Virginia last week on wildlife trafficking charges, state prosecutors announced.

headline: Nightclub Druggings Left 4 Dead in 15 Days, Manhattan Prosecutors Say
abstract: Kenwood Allen’s victims were left unconscious on the street after he robbed them, authorities say. In all, he is accused of victimizing 21 people, killing five.
lead_paragraph: In just 15 days, Kenwood Allen killed four people, prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: The Invasive Giant African Land Snail Has Been Spotted in Florida
abstract: The appearance of the snails caused the state’s agriculture department to place parts of the second-largest county in Florida in quarantine, making it illegal to move the animals.
lead_paragraph: An invasive species of large snail that can grow as large as a human fist and carries a parasite that can cause meningitis has been spotted in Florida’s second-most-populous county, prompting officials to set up a quarantine zone to try to contain it.

headline: Arrest of Mexican Army General Ordered in Case of Missing Students
abstract: The 43 students are believed to have been murdered in 2014, an atrocity that galvanized the country. The arrest warrant names a general and 15 other soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Mexican prosecutors have obtained a warrant for the arrests of an Army general and 15 other soldiers in connection with the disappearance of 43 students in 2014, a crime considered one of the worst atrocities in the country’s recent history.

headline: The Boot Camp for N.B.A. Hot Takes and Analysis
abstract: A two-day camp trains current and former basketball players in the lucrative art of broadcasting, podcasting and throwing verbal bombs on camera.
lead_paragraph: Alan Williams was the first person to brave the anchor desk, tucked away on a chilly set at the University of Southern California that was darkened, save for the spotlight on Williams in his black suit and blue-striped tie. Almost involuntarily, he lifted a hand from the desk’s shiny surface and nervously scratched his face.

headline: Special Counsel Who Hunted for a Deep-State Conspiracy Presents Muted Findings
abstract: John H. Durham, the Trump-era special counsel, criticized the F.B.I. during a six-hour hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: John H. Durham, the Trump-era special counsel who for four years pursued a politically fraught investigation into the Russia inquiry, told lawmakers on Wednesday that F.B.I. officials had exhibited confirmation bias — even as he defended his work against Democratic accusations that he became a partisan tool.

headline: Airman Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Charges in Leaks Case
abstract: The judge rejected a request to reconsider his earlier decision to hold Jack Teixeira without bail indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: Jack Teixeira, the 21-year-old Air National Guardsman accused of posting a trove of secret documents to an online chat group, pleaded not guilty to six counts of federal criminal charges on Wednesday, two months after his arrest.

headline: Oscars’ Best Picture Hopefuls Must Spend More Time in Theaters
abstract: To be eligible for the academy’s top prize, films will need to have an initial theatrical run of a week in one of six U.S. cities, and then expand to other cities across the country.
lead_paragraph: In a move designed to signal Hollywood’s commitment to the moviegoing experience, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Wednesday that it would require an expanded theatrical release for films seeking to be eligible for a best picture nomination.

headline: House Censures Adam Schiff Over His Role Investigating Trump
abstract: The move by the G.O.P.-led House was the first in what could be a series of votes seeking to punish those whom Republicans have deemed enemies of the party.
lead_paragraph: The G.O.P.-led House formally censured Representative Adam B. Schiff, Democrat of California, on Wednesday over his role investigating former President Donald J. Trump, the first in what could be a series of votes seeking to punish those whom Republicans have deemed the party’s enemies.

headline: Three decades ago, a reporter took a plunge into wonder, and danger.
abstract: A dive in Alvin, a three-person submersible, revealed not only an alien world but why people engage in such risky pursuits.
lead_paragraph: We fell for an hour, the views out of our observation ports fading slowly to pitch darkness. That made it all the more interesting when, at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean in our three-person submersible, a mile and a half down, we lost power and the lights went out.

headline: Prosecutors Disclose Discovery of Secret Guantánamo Prison Videos
abstract: A war court prosecutor said the videos, which could cause more delays in the destroyer Cole bombing case, were so sensitive that the public couldn’t see them and the judge couldn’t have a copy.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have discovered secret videos of guards forcibly removing the accused mastermind of the bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole from his cell at Guantánamo Bay around the time federal agents claim he voluntarily confessed to his role in the Qaeda plot, the lead prosecutor told the trial judge on Wednesday.

headline: Undersea Noises Become Focus of Submersible Rescue Effort
abstract: The unexplained sounds offered a slender line of hope to rescuers who have been scouring a patch of the North Atlantic twice the size of Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Unexplained noises detected beneath the waves of the North Atlantic became the focus on Wednesday of an urgent search for five people inside a submersible that disappeared three days earlier during a dive to the wreckage of the R.M.S. Titanic.

headline: Top Donor Provided Ron DeSantis, an Avid Golfer, With a Costly Simulator
abstract: The golf simulator, from a Florida businessman who has lent his plane to the governor, was given as an indefinite loan to the governor’s mansion.
lead_paragraph: A top political donor and close ally to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida who has frequently lent him his plane also gave him an expensive golf simulator, as an indefinite loan to the governor’s mansion, Mr. DeSantis’s office acknowledged on Wednesday.

headline: China’s Cloud Computing Firms Raise Concern for U.S.
abstract: The Biden administration is exploring whether it can mount a campaign against Chinese tech giants like Alibaba and Huawei, potentially fueling tensions with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: In the digital cold war between the United States and China, American officials are increasingly turning their attention to a new target: Chinese cloud computing giants.

headline: ‘Rock & Roll Man’ Review: The Life and Times of a Hype Man
abstract: A bio-show about the radio D.J. Alan Freed, one of rock music’s early popularizers, dutifully plays the hits.
lead_paragraph: The musical “Rock & Roll Man” starts with an attention-grabbing gambit: It is 1965, and J. Edgar Hoover is prosecuting the D.J. and promoter Alan Freed, then at death’s door. Hoover has accused Freed of destroying “the American way of life by inventing the genre of music which you named rock and roll.”

headline: Catch Some Waves
abstract: Michael Baker and Jeff Chen hear what you’re saying.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: June 22, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 22, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about Rome’s bid for the Expo 2030 world’s fair misstated the given name of the designer of the Sail complex. As the article correctly noted, he is Santiago Calatrava, not Francisco Calatrava.

headline: Schumer Lays Out Process to Tackle A.I., Without Endorsing Specific Plans
abstract: The Senate majority leader hopes to give lawmakers a crash course in a technology many say they do not understand as a way to build bipartisan support for regulation.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader, laid out a long-awaited framework on Wednesday to regulate artificial intelligence, hoping to create a path for lawmakers to adopt guardrails many industry insiders say are needed on a technology many members of Congress admit they do not understand.

headline: Tornado Kills at Least 4 in Texas Panhandle Town
abstract: The National Weather Service said the storm battered the small town of Matador. It hit during a heat wave that has spread across much of the region.
lead_paragraph: The Dollar General was a heap of splintered wood. A lone horse stood as if in shock next to a pile of debris. Entire blocks of the small Texas Panhandle town of Matador were completely leveled.

headline: The U.S. Population Is Older Than It Has Ever Been
abstract: New census data shows that the country’s median age is now over 38. In 1980, it was 30.
lead_paragraph: The median age in the United States reached a record high of 38.9 in 2022, according to data released Thursday by the Census Bureau.

headline: How New York Is Regulating A.I.
abstract: The city is setting rules on how companies can use artificial intelligence in hiring and promotion.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at why New York City has emerged as a modest pioneer in A.I. regulation. We’ll also find out about a property tax exemption for a secret society in Brooklyn that has ties to the Underground Railroad.

headline: How India Profits From Its Neutrality in the Ukraine War
abstract: India, a critical security partner of the United States, now buys huge amounts of Russian oil, purchasing one of every two barrels shipped at sea.
lead_paragraph: India, a critical security partner of the United States, now buys huge amounts of Russian oil, purchasing one of every two barrels shipped at sea.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The final hours of oxygen aboard a missing submersible.
lead_paragraph: A submersible that disappeared over the weekend during a dive to the wreckage of the Titanic may have just a few hours of oxygen remaining, as rescue teams continue a desperate search of the North Atlantic for the missing vessel. The area is roughly twice the size of Connecticut and more than two miles deep.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Technology and the Ban on Shifts Help Ground Crews Create Fields of Dreams
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 22, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “As far as tricking the field to manipulate it for your team, that’s in the past. Everything is done for safety and playability of the game.”

headline: Explosion Kills Dozens at Barbecue Restaurant in China
abstract: At least 31 people died in the explosion at a barbecue restaurant in Yinchuan.
lead_paragraph: At least 31 people died in the explosion at a barbecue restaurant in Yinchuan.

headline: What Nine Women in Kansas Wish People Realized About Abortion
abstract: The group discusses the first anniversary of the overturning of Roe v. Wade and the issue of abortion in Kansas.
lead_paragraph: The group discusses the first anniversary of the overturning of Roe v. Wade and the issue of abortion in Kansas.

headline: Narendra Modi Is Not Who America Thinks He Is
abstract: Modi’s version of India is as skewed as Donald Trump’s of the U.S, but Modi has done better at getting the media and global elite to buy into it.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday the White House will roll out the red carpet for Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India to “affirm the deep and close partnership between the United States and India” and “strengthen our two countries’ shared commitment to a free, open, prosperous, and secure Indo-Pacific.” A state dinner and Mr. Modi’s address to a joint session of Congress will crown months of fawning assessments of India by everyone from Bill Gates to Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo. The message couldn’t be plainer: In Cold War II with China, the United States wants India on its side.

headline: Dozens Die After Explosion in a Barbecue Restaurant in China
abstract: The deadly blast, in the northwestern city of Yinchuan, was blamed on a gas leak, and it is likely to prompt closer scrutiny of restaurants that feature gas grills.
lead_paragraph: A gas explosion that ripped through a barbecue restaurant in northwestern China killed at least 31 people, officials said on Thursday, hours after the blast had turned the restaurant into a charred ruin.

headline: A Russian court upholds a Wall Street Journal reporter’s detention.
abstract: Evan Gershkovich, an American journalist who has been based in Russia for years, was arrested in March and charged with spying, which he denies.
lead_paragraph: A Moscow court denied an appeal on Thursday by Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter who asked to end his pretrial detention in Russia, where he was jailed and charged with espionage 12 weeks ago.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: George Santos Was Bailed Out by His Father and Aunt, Court Records Show
abstract: Mr. Santos, a first-term G.O.P. congressman, had tried to keep the names of the people who guaranteed his $500,000 bond sealed, but two judges rejected his efforts.
lead_paragraph: Of the many questions that surround Representative George Santos, one has recently taken center stage: Who guaranteed the $500,000 bond that allowed him to be released from federal custody last month?

headline: What to Know About Modi’s Visit and U.S.-India Relations
abstract: The visit has big implications for U.S.-India relations as President Biden seeks to shore up an alliance against Russia’s aggression and China’s economic influence.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as President Biden hosts Prime Minister Narendra Modi for meetings and a state dinner.

headline: Hotel Corazon Wants to Host Your Hot Girl Summer
abstract: Forget Ibiza. A hip new hotel opening underscores how many in the style set opt for the charms of Majorca instead.
lead_paragraph: The Serra de Tramuntana is a mountain range that runs along the northwestern edge of the island of Majorca, off the coast of mainland Spain. Its towering peaks and valleys are lined with ancient olive groves, lemon orchards and picturesque hilltop villages. The winding pathways that dot the rugged cliffs plunge through pine trees and goat herds to meet the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: How Much Do You Know About the Menstrual Cycle?
abstract: Doctors and laypeople alike have significant gaps in their understanding of this essential process. Test your knowledge with our quiz.
lead_paragraph: Doctors and laypeople alike have significant gaps in their understanding of this essential process. Test your knowledge with our quiz.

headline: On a Caribbean Island, Young People Find Freedom in ‘Bike Life’
abstract: Cabrage, a kind of rodeo on wheels, offers riders exhilarating thrills and a deep sense of camaraderie in Fort-de-France, Martinique.
lead_paragraph: Cabrage, a kind of rodeo on wheels, offers riders exhilarating thrills and a deep sense of camaraderie in Fort-de-France, Martinique.

headline: 36 Hours in Paris
abstract: A different side of the French capital reveals smaller museums, under-the-radar spots in Montmartre and a diverse performance scene.
lead_paragraph: A different side of the French capital reveals smaller museums, under-the-radar spots in Montmartre and a diverse performance scene.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Moving Spiders Inside the House
abstract: A husband fears spiders. A wife thinks they’re natural pest control. Who’s in the right?
lead_paragraph: Evan writes: My wife, Christina, and I live in eastern Tennessee. She recently let me know that she has been moving spiders from our backyard into our house, in the hope that they will kill bugs. I am afraid of spiders. Please make her stop.

headline: Poem: Conditions for Retention
abstract: The coldness of Jennifer Nelson’s title stands in stark contrast to the warmth and vitality of the world evoked in the poem.
lead_paragraph: The coldness of the institutional jargon of Jennifer Nelson’s title stands in stark contrast to the warmth and vitality of the world evoked in the poem. Who knows what “Condition for Retention” means? Perhaps you do, but I don’t, not really. Maybe it means something about what a person has to do to earn the right to stay inside, stifled, employed, even as the earth with all its thunderstruck, sun-dazzled energy waits outside. Whatever purpose the phrase serves, there’s no denying that it sounds grim, like a cluster of words that have never themselves brought anyone joy and were never intended to. This is why Nelson’s poem made me happy. The news here turns out much better than the headline suggests. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: A Family Trio Starts a New Chapter in the City. Where Could They Find Three Bedrooms?
abstract: After years in Quebec, a single mother charts a new course for herself and her teenage twins. But buying sight unseen in New York would be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: After years in Quebec, a single mother charts a new course for herself and her teenage twins. But buying sight unseen in New York would be a challenge.

headline: What Happens When You Stop Being a Superpower?
abstract: Why Biden won’t be discussing India’s creep away from democracy during Modi’s visit to the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the New York Times Audio app here.

headline: ‘Revoir Paris’ Review: Recovering Fragments of Memory
abstract: In Alice Winocour’s taut film, a woman survives a terrorist attack and tries to piece together what happened that day and how it changed her.
lead_paragraph: When Mia, the heroine of the tense French drama “Revoir Paris,” thinks about the night her life changed, her face seems to drain of all feeling, almost as if she were emptying it out. Months earlier, she survived a terrorist attack, but now she can’t remember much of what happened that evening. All she retains are vivid fragments — an image of a birthday cake ablaze with candles, the steady pounding of torrential rain — that she can’t piece together. The past may be a foreign country, but for Mia it’s one that also now lies partly in ruin.

headline: Bookforum Is Returning, Months After Its Closure Was Mourned in the Literary World
abstract: The literary magazine will be back in print in August, with a new publishing partner: The Nation.
lead_paragraph: Bookforum, a literary criticism magazine that closed in December to great uproar in the literary world, will be back in print in August with a new publishing partner: The Nation.

headline: Biden Seeks to Bolster Ties With Modi While Soft-Pedaling Differences
abstract: At the White House, the president emphasized common ground with India’s prime minister and announced joint initiatives without making progress in enlisting help against Russian aggression.
lead_paragraph: President Biden emphasized common ground with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India during a lavish state visit on Thursday, publicly skirting points of friction over the government’s crackdown on human rights in India and Russia’s war in Ukraine in hopes of bolstering economic and geopolitical ties with the world’s most populous nation.

headline: Introducing: The Retrievals
abstract: From Serial Productions. Dozens of women seeking to become mothers came to a fertility clinic at Yale. A five-part narrative series explores the shocking events that unfolded there. Episode 1 arrives on Thurs, June 29.
lead_paragraph: Some of the patients screamed out in the procedure room. Others called the clinic from home to report pain in the hours that followed. But most of the staff members who fielded the patients’ reports did not know the real reason for the pain, which was that a nurse at the clinic was stealing fentanyl and replacing it with saline.

headline: Brian Kemp Refuses to Be a MAGAverse Troll
abstract: Georgia’s governor has gone all in on electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Quick quiz: Which popular governor has been sweet-talking electric vehicle industries and developing E.V. infrastructure in his state, with an eye toward making it “the electric mobility capital of America”?

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episodes 1 and 2 Recap: Relationship Place
abstract: The first two episodes make clear from the start that this will not be another sullen season.
lead_paragraph: And just like that … everybody’s getting laid. We’ve got casual Thursday sex. We’ve got hot married sex. We’ve got queer sex. We’ve got “things are going so great it’s time to meet your family” sex.

headline: Len Deighton Collects Outdated Travel Guides
abstract: “Old illustrated ones are critical for research,” says the author and spy novelist, four of whose early novels are being reissued this month. “You’d be amazed how often roads move and names change.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Kristin Harmel Helped Build the Village That Sustained Her
abstract: When the author of “The Paris Daughter” announced her breast cancer diagnosis, the Friends & Fiction community rallied.
lead_paragraph: In March 2020, Kristin Harmel was gearing up for the paperback publication of her 11th novel, “The Winemaker’s Wife.” Then the world came to a grinding halt (and many of us who aren’t married to a winemaker wished we were).

headline: The Rather Surreal World of Barbie’s Body Double
abstract: Margot Robbie’s stand-in dished on what it was like to fill in for the titular character of Greta Gerwig’s highly anticipated new film.
lead_paragraph: Emma Eastwood had just changed out of Barbie’s tight pink jumpsuit at the Warner Brothers studio in London when she learned she had landed her most high-profile role yet: Barbie’s body double.

headline: The India Quandary
abstract: How the U.S. manages its relationships with elected autocracies is one of its most important strategic questions.
lead_paragraph: Idealism and pragmatism have long made rival claims on American foreign policy, forcing hard choices and sometimes leading to disappointment. There was a moment in the 1990s when the collapse of the Soviet Union looked to clear the way for a universal political and economic order, but that chimera soon gave way to the more complex world we inhabit today, in which the ideals of liberal democracy — often in otherwise well-functioning democracies — sometimes seem to be in conflict with the popularity of strongmen leaders, the desire for security or the forces of xenophobia or grievance.

headline: ‘And Just Like That’ Style Recap: Met Gala Madness
abstract: In the first episodes of the new season, Carrie and her friends prepare for the Super Bowl of fashion, and Lily sells off her clothes to finance her dreams.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Episodes 1 and 2 of the second season of “And Just Like That.”

headline: Christie Lashes Trump, to the Slice of the G.O.P. Open to It
abstract: Missing from Chris Christie’s campaign stop: Republicans who are leaning toward Donald J. Trump but open to an alternative.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie brought his Talking Truth to Donald Trump performance back to New Hampshire on Wednesday evening, aiming a fresh quiver of poison darts at the former president. His talk pleased a small Trump-skeptical crowd, but raised the big question about Mr. Christie’s candidacy: Where are all the other Republican voters?

headline: How Hokusai’s Art Crashed Over the Modern World
abstract: The MFA Boston shows how one of the greatest printmakers, from Edo Japan, inspired a tidal wave of followers, from Gauguin to Lichtenstein.
lead_paragraph: One of the most influential figures in European modern culture never set foot in Europe. Katsushika Hokusai, like all subjects in self-isolated Edo Japan, could not have left the archipelago if he wanted to, and his publishers could not export his prints of Kabuki actors, flowers and Mount Fuji. But a few years after his death in 1849, when the “black ships” of Commodore Matthew Perry sailed into what’s now Tokyo Bay, Japan’s markets were forcibly opened, and Hokusai’s woodblocks started to flutter over the ocean. In France, in Britain, and soon in America, a whole new kind of art would emerge: born in Tokyo, spanning the whole world.

headline: The Bridal Industry Is Having a Swimsuit Moment
abstract: Beaded and bedazzled, fancy and frilly, lacy and Lycra-fitted — bridal bikinis are here. Brides are embracing swimwear for after parties, honeymoons and even ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: Marigo Mihalos Sfaelos brought many outfits to her four-day, event-filled wedding in Karpathos, Greece, last year. There was the silk citrine Greek goddess-style dress, a floral appliqué Estee Couture bridal gown, and a disco ball-inspired floor-length dress for the after party. But the showstopper was worn at the post-wedding beach party: a gladiator-like metal and silver bikini with rhinestones, from the designer Karen Sabag’s Rêver collection, along with a matching overlay skirt.

headline: Why Modi and Other Indian Leaders Stay Single
abstract: India’s politicians need a lot of time to attend to 1.4 billion people. And with corruption widespread, those without families are often seen as less likely to steal.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as President Biden hosts Prime Minister Narendra Modi for meetings and a state dinner.

headline: Belarus Is Fast Becoming a ‘Vassal State’ of Russia
abstract: Allowing Moscow to place tactical nuclear weapons on its soil is just the latest sign of its loss of sovereignty to the Kremlin, military experts and pro-democracy activists say.
lead_paragraph: Schools give patriotic lessons and teach students how to assemble rifles, while textbooks have been rewritten to favor Russia’s view of history. Factories produce uniforms for soldiers fighting Ukraine. Summer camps run by state-owned conglomerates host children from occupied Ukrainian territory.

headline: Countries on Front Lines of Climate Change Seek New Lifeline in Paris
abstract: Hundreds of representatives from about 80 countries are gathering in Paris to talk about rebuilding a monetary system many say is ill-suited to a changing planet.
lead_paragraph: An unusual if guarded optimism has descended upon Paris, along with hundreds of world leaders, bankers and climate activists. They have come for a two-day conference billed as the new Bretton Woods.

headline: A Basement of Horrors in Seoul, Where Past and Present Collide
abstract: A building where South Korean dissidents were interrogated and tortured by a powerful government agency is now home to a popular youth hostel.
lead_paragraph: The hostel in central Seoul has a lot to recommend it. The rooms are tidy and affordable enough for K-pop fanatics on a budget and families in need of lots of space on vacation. It’s perched at the base of Namsan, the scenic, leafy mountain peak in the heart of town. There’s even a rooftop with panoramic views of the city.

headline: The Trillion-Gallon Question: What if California’s Dams Fail?
abstract: One superstorm could send walls of water sweeping through populated areas. There’s not much time to act.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Feb. 7, 2017, two electricians were working on a warning siren near the spillway of Oroville Dam, 60 miles north of Sacramento, when they heard an explosion. As they watched, a giant plume of water rose over their heads, and chunks of concrete began flying down the hillside toward the Feather River. The dam’s spillway, a concrete channel capable of moving millions of gallons of water out of the reservoir in seconds, was disintegrating in front of them. If it had to be taken out of service, a serious rainstorm, like the one that had been falling on Northern California for days, could cause the dam — the tallest in the United States — to fail.

headline: The 25 Most Influential Works of Postwar Queer Literature
abstract: Six opinionated writers debate — and define — the state of L.G.B.T.Q. writing in order to make a list of the most essential works of fiction, poetry and drama right now.
lead_paragraph: If there’s no single definition of what it means to be queer — a word whose meaning seems to shape-shift constantly, just like the culture around it — then there’s perhaps no consensus on what defines queer literature as a genre either. Still, one thing many queer people share is that we first discovered ourselves on the page. Often furtively, we read novels or recited poems or watched plays that seemed not only to speak exclusively to us, but also showed us a way of speaking about ourselves to others.

headline: Today’s Top News: What to Expect from Modi’s State Visit, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Lost 2 Miles Below the Ocean
abstract: Experts had worries about the vessel that has gone missing on its way to the wreck of the Titanic long before it disappeared.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, when passengers set off on a deep sea expedition in the Atlantic Ocean, they were aboard a vessel that many experts had already concluded was dangerously designed.

headline: One Person Missing and 6 Critically Hurt After Blast in Paris
abstract: The origin of the explosion, which gutted a building in the Fifth Arrondissement and injured about 40 people, is still unclear.
lead_paragraph: Rescue workers combed through debris in central Paris on Thursday, a day after a powerful explosion ripped through a building on the Left Bank and injured about 40 people, several of them critically.

headline: The Politics of Class
abstract: We’re covering the class inversion in American politics, severe weather in Texas and the Indian prime minister’s visit to the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The class inversion in American politics — Republicans’ struggles with college graduates and Democrats’ struggles with the working class — is a running theme of this newsletter. To help make sense of it, I asked four Times Opinion writers to join me in an exchange this morning. They are Michelle Cottle, Carlos Lozada, Lydia Polgreen and Ross Douthat, and they’re also the hosts of a new podcast, “Matter of Opinion.”

headline: ‘God Is a Bullet’ Review: Cult, but Not Classic
abstract: A kidnapping cult regrets making off with a detective’s daughter in this wearyingly unsavory movie.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t count the number of times a woman’s face is smashed — by a fist, a boot, a brick wall — in “God Is a Bullet,” Nick Cassavetes’s first feature in almost a decade. But the misogyny of the movie’s risibly sadistic villains is only one distasteful thread in this sleazy saga of rescue and revenge.

headline: ‘2023 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour Review: Small Bites
abstract: From animated partygoers to real families embracing a name, this basket of goodies includes seven titles, among them comedy, tragedy and documentary.
lead_paragraph: Every year, features from the Sundance Film Festival can become critical favorites — “Past Lives” is a notable example — but the fest’s shorter works can fade away. The “2023 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour” brings a seven-film omnibus to cinemas across the country, and Kayla Abuda Galang’s “When You Left Me on That Boulevard” alone is reason enough to see it.

headline: ‘Here. Is. Better.’ Review: A Glimmer of Hope
abstract: Four military veterans go through PTSD treatments in this understated documentary.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Jason Kander, a rising star in politics who was running for mayor of Kansas City, suddenly dropped out of the race, of which he was the front-runner. Kander, a veteran who had spent time as an Army intelligence officer in Afghanistan, announced that he would be seeking treatment for PTSD and depression.

headline: ‘Desperate Souls’ Review: When ‘Midnight Cowboy’ Moved the Culture
abstract: A documentary examines how the winner for best picture of 1969 captured shifts in American life.
lead_paragraph: How many ways did “Midnight Cowboy” occupy the nexus of the cultural changes of the 1960s? The documentary “Desperate Souls, Dark City and the Legend of Midnight Cowboy” cites plenty.

headline: Bank of England Raises Rates More Than Expected, as Inflation Persists
abstract: “We know this is hard,” the central bank’s governor said, after increasing interest rates half a point, to 5 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England raised interest rates half a percentage point on Thursday, a larger-than-expected move, as policymakers struggle to bring down Britain’s persistently high rate of inflation.

headline: Rules for Paxton Impeachment Will Let His Wife Affect Outcome Without Voting
abstract: Rules adopted by the Texas State Senate include a Sept. 5 start date for the trial of the attorney general, in a case that has divided the state’s Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The Texas State Senate adopted rules on Wednesday for its impeachment trial of the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, including a start date of Sept. 5 and a rule barring his wife, State Senator Angela Paxton, from voting on whether to convict or acquit him.

headline: Word of the Day: ominous
abstract: This word has appeared in 339 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word ominous has appeared in 339 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 1 in “An Art Professor Says A.I. Is the Future. It’s the Students Who Need Convincing” by Zachary Small:

headline: Lina Khan Raises the Heat on Amazon
abstract: The F.T.C. chair shot to fame six years ago after publishing an academic article that the company needed to be contained. Legal experts wonder if that time has come.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Lina Khan, then a 29-year-old law student, shot to fame with an academic article about why Amazon should be contained. Cutting against prevailing trends in antitrust law, Khan argued that the e-commerce giant was unfairly dominating huge swaths of the American economy.

headline: Where Do New Yorkers Want to Rent?
abstract: The city’s most popular areas based on traffic to rental listings.
lead_paragraph: If you’re moving to New York City and want to find the most popular rental neighborhoods, it makes sense to follow locals in the know. Recently, RentHop did just that by studying web traffic to New York City listings that originated from within the city. Search volume in February and April of this year was analyzed to rank each neighborhood for popularity, and data from a year earlier was used to find how the rankings changed over time.

headline: Kennedy Center Honorees Include Divas of Hip-Hop, Pop and Opera
abstract: Queen Latifah, Dionne Warwick and Renée Fleming will be recognized, along with Billy Crystal and Barry Gibb.
lead_paragraph: Queen Latifah was in her dressing room on the set of the TV drama “The Equalizer” in Brooklyn when she heard the news: she had been chosen as a Kennedy Center honoree.

headline: Will Hurd, a Former House Republican, Opens ’24 Bid With Attack on Trump
abstract: Mr. Hurd, a moderate who represented a large swing district for three terms, called Donald J. Trump a “lawless, selfish, failed politician.”
lead_paragraph: Will Hurd, a former Texas congressman who was part of a diminishing bloc of Republican moderates in the House and was the only Black member of his caucus when he left office in 2021, announced his candidacy for president on Thursday with a video message that attacked the G.O.P. front-runner, Donald J. Trump.

headline: We’re Adding New Songs to Our California Soundtrack
abstract: The playlist includes 19 new tracks recommended by readers.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite things about writing this newsletter is getting to hear from readers.

headline: A New French Hotel, Perched on a Cliff
abstract: Plus: naturally dyed table linens, a memorial in the form of a closet and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I’m constantly asking my friends what they’re using. My routine also changes based on whom I’m dating sometimes. If that person is more adept at beauty than I am, I will absolutely steal their products and pretend I knew about them the whole time. I use a superlight face wash, sometimes Curology Gentle Cleanser or Aesop Purifying Facial Exfoliant Paste. To exfoliate around my beard area, I’ll use a konjac sponge to make sure I’m preventing ingrown hairs. On my beard, I like the hair oil that my sister makes. I use the Muri Lelu Mauvaise Herbe Indica Oil every other day and Costa Brazil Face Serum. I top those with Algenist Algae Peptide Regenerative Moisturizer. At night, I use Allies of Skin Retinal & Peptides Repair Night Cream. Growing up I was taught that as a Black person I didn’t need to use sunscreen and that is such a lie. Right now I use Koa Mineral Sunscreen.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are on Central Park South, in the East Village and in Mott Haven.
lead_paragraph: A 688-square-foot, one-bath condo with a glass atrium, a galley kitchen with a dishwasher, a sleeping alcove and a walk-in closet, on the third floor of an 18-story doorman building with a gym, shared laundry and a bike room. Melissa Alonso and Isabel Biderman, Nest Seekers International, 917-597-2401; nestseekers.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
abstract: This week’s homes are a five-bedroom in Wyckoff, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Armonk, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 4,120-square-foot stone and cedar-sided house built in 1930, with a formal living room that has a gas fireplace, a newly remodeled kitchen with a sunny breakfast area, a screened porch, a sunroom office, a large third-story playroom, a detached three-car garage and an in-ground pool, on 1.95 acres. Diane Mainardi, Terrie O’Connor Realtors, 201-819-7401; tocr.com

headline: Fortress Investment Group Set to Acquire Vice Out of Bankruptcy
abstract: The company was part of a group of bidders that offered $350 million to acquire the bankrupt media company.
lead_paragraph: A group of buyers including Fortress Investment Group is set to take over the bankrupt Vice Media company after bidding $350 million to acquire it out of bankruptcy, according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Unleashing the ‘Animal Spirits’ That Course Through American History
abstract: In a wide-ranging new book, the scholar Jackson Lears locates a “countercultural” hunger for vigor and spontaneity on the trading floor, the dance floor and beyond.
lead_paragraph: The first traffic jam in U.S. history, Jackson Lears tells us, occurred in February 1913. The cause? A crush of New Yorkers jostling for seats at a lecture (in French, no less) by the celebrity philosopher Henri Bergson. His topic was the élan vital, the notion of a dynamic life force, a “current sent through matter” that “transcends finality” and animates the world. It is Lears’s topic, too: the play of what he calls “animal spirits” across several centuries of American thought. The phrase captures a recurring desire to meld the material and the ethereal, body and soul, self and universe against powerful countercurrents in religious, scientific and commercial culture.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Will Hurd
abstract: Mr. Hurd, a former congressman from a swing district in Texas, is a former undercover C.I.A. officer and a cybersecurity expert.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative Will Hurd, a Republican from a swing district in Texas who served three terms, faces the daunting task of establishing himself in a field of much better-known presidential candidates.

headline: Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells to Reunite in ‘Gutenberg! The Musical!’
abstract: The pair, who were the original co-stars of “The Book of Mormon,” will return to Broadway this fall in a two-man musical comedy.
lead_paragraph: Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells, whose careers were transformed when they co-starred as hapless missionaries in “The Book of Mormon,” will reunite this fall in a comedic two-hander, “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” that has been staged around the world but will now arrive on Broadway for the first time.

headline: Henry Petroski, Whose Books Decoded Engineering, Dies at 81
abstract: He wrote extensively about the design of buildings and bridges and how they failed. He also examined the history of commonplace objects like the pencil.
lead_paragraph: Henry Petroski, who demystified engineering with literary examinations of the designs and failures of large structures like buildings and bridges, as well as everyday items like the pencil and the toothpick, died on June 14 in hospice care in Durham, N.C. He was 81.

headline: Ford’s Battery Joint Venture to Get $9.2 Billion Government Loan
abstract: The money will help finance three plants the automaker and its partner, SK On, are building in Kentucky and Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor and its battery manufacturing partner will receive a $9.2 billion loan to build three battery factories in Kentucky and Tennessee, the Department of Energy said Thursday. The loan is the single biggest financial commitment the Biden administration has made in its effort to build an electric vehicle manufacturing network in the United States.

headline: Report Cites More Than 350 Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Incidents Over 11 Months
abstract: The incidents included online harassment, gatherings of armed protesters outside drag shows, and bomb threats against hospitals that provide gender transition care.
lead_paragraph: There were more than 350 incidents of anti-L.G.B.T.Q. harassment, vandalism or assault in the United States from June 2022 through April 2023, according to a new report, reflecting a climate in which bias against gay and especially transgender people has become widespread.

headline: In the Kitchen, a Soulful Serving of Heritage and Tradition
abstract: What our food says about us, our provenance and the cultural heirlooms we seek to pass on.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Review: ‘I’m a Virgo’ Goes Big
abstract: Boots Riley’s surreal satire about a teenage giant and an authoritarian superhero is a larger-than-life achievement.
lead_paragraph: Boots Riley doesn’t aim small. In his 2018 directorial debut film, “Sorry to Bother You,” the frontman of the revolution-minded hip-hop group the Coup created a chaotic fantasia of corporate exploitation that strained at the seams of its indie-movie clothing.

headline: Imagine Spider-Woman With a Crochet Hook
abstract: In “My Neighbor’s Garden,” an installation at Madison Square Park, Sheila Pepe uses the humble art of crochet to shape space and build community.
lead_paragraph: “My favorite thing is crocheting 20 feet in the air,” the artist Sheila Pepe said at her studio in the Brooklyn Army Terminal. There across the floor last month she was laying out coils of vibrantly colored shoelaces, paracord, rope and garden hose, more than 15,000 yards’ worth, to be strung and spun into her first outdoor installation, opening on June 26 in Manhattan’s Madison Square Park.

headline: Can Supplements Help You Focus?
abstract: Some manufacturers claim certain formulations can sharpen the mind, but experts say the evidence behind that idea is lacking.
lead_paragraph: If a single supplement could boost your mental performance — by increasing alertness and focus, clearing brain fog, sharpening your memory and reducing the urge to procrastinate — you might feel as if you stumbled upon a revolutionary hack for productivity.

headline: Congress Spotlights ‘Serious’ Forced Labor Concerns With Chinese Shopping Sites
abstract: A congressional investigation into Temu and Shein offered new insight into services that are delivering a deluge of cheap and little-regulated products.
