lead_paragraph: Lawmakers are flagging what they say are likely significant violations of U.S. law by Temu, a popular Chinese shopping platform, accusing it of providing an unchecked channel that allows goods made with forced labor to flow into the United States.

headline: Spiraling Violence in the Occupied West Bank Signals a Loss of Control
abstract: The Palestinian Authority is absent from the hotbeds of militancy while Israeli forces have failed to prevent violent reprisal attacks by Jewish extremists.
lead_paragraph: The northern West Bank was once viewed by Israeli, Palestinian and international authorities as a kind of pilot program for Israeli disengagement from the occupied territory, and by some even as a potential prototype for a future Palestinian state.

headline: Elon Musk Proposes ‘Cage Match’ With Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: The technology moguls who run Twitter and Meta appeared to agree to a fight, the latest twist in a long-running feud.
lead_paragraph: Two of the world’s richest and most influential men, who happen to run rival social media networks, appeared to goad each other into agreeing to a fight, setting their platforms abuzz at the notion of a “cage match” between the billionaires.

headline: ‘The Stroll’ Review: Telling Their Own Stories
abstract: In this documentary, transgender sex workers speak for themselves without sanitizing or sensationalizing their experiences.
lead_paragraph: At several points in “The Stroll,” Kristen Lovell and Zackary Drucker’s loving portrait of New York City’s transgender sex workers, moments of striking candor break through the conventions of documentary.

headline: Deadly Storm Flattens Buildings in Texas Town
abstract: The storm produced a tornado that passed through Matador, Texas, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: The storm produced a tornado that passed through Matador, Texas, the National Weather Service said.

headline: ‘The Mother and the Whore’: A Threesome and Then Some
abstract: Jean Eustache’s digitally restored 1973 film, now at Lincoln Center, is part of a full retrospective of his work.
lead_paragraph: Jean Eustache’s unwieldy first feature “The Mother and the Whore” — a transfixing 215-minute talkathon, as well as a cause célèbre since its world premiere at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival — feels less like a masterpiece than a rogue asteroid careening toward your particular home planet.

headline: ‘The Country Club’ Review: Who’s Your Caddy?
abstract: The sisters Fiona and Sophia Robert wrote and star in this broad, pastel-colored golf comedy.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to make a golf comedy without evoking “Caddyshack,” the ribald 1980 classic starring Chevy Chase and Bill Murray, and with its crude humor, farcical innuendo and posh eponymous setting, “The Country Club” certainly warrants the comparison. But the influence the movie more obviously courts is early Wes Anderson, especially his sophomore feature “Rushmore”: The director Fiona Robert (who also co-wrote the film with her sister, Sophia Robert, both of whom star) leans heavily on Anderson’s unmistakable, easily imitated style, using rigidly symmetrical compositions, sudden zooms and a heightened pastel color palette. As if to underscore the similarities, the movie even opens with a handcrafted, pleasantly fastidious title sequence with credits inscribed on tees and golf balls that fairly exudes twee Andersonia.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: For months, I’ve looked forward to accompanying my father and brothers this summer on a fishing trip to western Quebec — an adventure that now looks unlikelier by the day, as wildfires engulf the region and Canada’s government prudently extends travel bans throughout the James Bay area. So I have more than a passing interest in John Vaillant’s gripping new book, “Fire Weather,” which looks at the 2016 Fort McMurray fires in Alberta and concludes that they were a harbinger of worse to come.

headline: Protecting Marine Life Also Benefits the People Nearby, Study Finds
abstract: A study of marine-protected areas off the Central American coast found that people living close to these areas had better food security and greater household wealth.
lead_paragraph: Protecting coastal areas of the ocean from fishing, mining and other human activity can also help people living nearby, according to a study published on Thursday in the journal Nature Sustainability.

headline: A North Korean Dissident Defects to the American Right
abstract: Yeonmi Park’s account of the horrors of North Korea made her a human rights celebrity. Her new claims that America is on the same path have made her a right-wing media star.
lead_paragraph: “The first thing my mom taught me as a young girl living in North Korea was don’t even whisper, because birds and mice could hear me,” Yeonmi Park told the audience that had come to hear her speak in Queens.

headline: Firouz Naderi, NASA Scientist Who Led Mars Missions, Dies at 77
abstract: In a career that was an inspiration to Iranians and Iranian Americans, he oversaw multiple missions to Mars, including two successful landings.
lead_paragraph: Firouz Naderi, an Iranian American scientist who directed the Mars program at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, including two successful landings on the planet, died on June 9 in Los Angeles. He was 77.

headline: Overstock.com Wins $21.5 Million Bid for Bed Bath & Beyond’s Assets
abstract: If the acquisition is approved at a court hearing next week, the company will own the intellectual property of the bankrupt home goods retailer.
lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond, the home-goods retailer that filed for bankruptcy in April, accepted a $21.5 million bid from Overstock.com to acquire its assets, according to a court filing on Thursday.

headline: New Jason Robert Brown Musical Highlights MCC Theater Season
abstract: A honky-tonk lesbian romance and a new musical by Gavin Creel are also slated for the Off Broadway theater’s 2023-24 lineup.
lead_paragraph: A new musical about an aspiring writer by Jason Robert Brown, a honky-tonk lesbian romance and a musical inspired by the singer and songwriter Gavin Creel’s first visit to the Metropolitan Museum of Art are on the roster for MCC Theater’s 2023-24 season.

headline: On View: Bantu Knots and Braids, Sculpted From Recycled Tires
abstract: Kim Dacres, an artist and former teacher, uses discarded rubber to depict hairstyles of students who "reminded me of myself."
lead_paragraph: Kim Dacres, an artist and former teacher, uses discarded rubber to depict hairstyles of students who "reminded me of myself."

headline: Mark the day: Modi fielded live questions from the press.
abstract: The Indian prime minister and his staff have tightly controlled his message and media availability. His appearance with Biden at a White House conference was a notable departure.
lead_paragraph: It’s vanishingly rare for Narendra Modi to directly field live questions from the press throughout a near decade in power. So when the Indian prime minister took two questions from reporters at a White House press event with Mr. Biden on Thursday, it was a notable moment.

headline: The Winners of Our 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: This year’s winning essays — chosen from more than 12,000 entries — take on student journalism, artificial intelligence, fan fiction and more.
lead_paragraph: “My English teacher always tells me to write what I know,” Cindy Chen, a 13-year-old student from Beijing and the author of one of the winning essays of our 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, told us about her writing process.

headline: Teresa Taylor, Butthole Surfers Drummer and a Face of Gen X, Dies at 60
abstract: In addition to playing with the audacious Texas band, she helped define the image of an aimless generation with her role in the 1990 film “Slacker.”
lead_paragraph: Teresa Taylor, a drummer for the Texas acid-punk band Butthole Surfers who became an emblem of Generation X aimlessness and anomie with a memorable appearance in Richard Linklater’s 1990 film “Slacker,” died on Sunday. She was 60.

headline: N.T.S.B. Convenes Hearing in East Palestine to Examine Train Derailment
abstract: Investigators released a trove of documents about the derailment of a Norfolk Southern freight train in Ohio, the subject of a two-day hearing that began Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board released thousands of pages of documents on Thursday about the derailment of a Norfolk Southern freight train in East Palestine, Ohio, providing the fullest account yet of what had led to the accident.

headline: Proud Menstruating Student
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Cindy Chen, age 13.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Cindy Chen, age 13, from Beijing Ritan Middle School in Beijing, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Giving Up on Student Journalism Means Giving Up on Student Voices
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Chantal de Macedo Eulenstein, age 16.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Chantal de Macedo Eulenstein, age 16, from Ames High School in Ames, Iowa, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: The Case for an A.I. Pause
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Gabriel Huang, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Gabriel Huang, 17, from Tower Hill School in Wilmington, Del., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Plot Twist at Turner Classic Movies Upsets Film Fans
abstract: The network’s owner, Warner Bros. Discovery, promised there would be little to no change for viewers despite budget cuts behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: For many people in Hollywood, including lions like Steven Spielberg, Turner Classic Movies is not a cable channel. It is an extension of their identity.

headline: Bronx D.A. Candidates Debate Crime, Rikers and Incarceration
abstract: Darcel Clark, the Democratic incumbent, emphasizes a balance between public safety and justice. Her primary opponent, Tess Cohen, is challenging her from the left, focusing on alternatives to jail.
lead_paragraph: As Darcel Clark, the Bronx district attorney, made her way through the crowd at a Juneteenth celebration on Monday afternoon, it was clear she was in friendly territory. “Hi, D.A.,” a group of women called out. Ms. Clark smiled, hugged the women and asked how they were.

headline: How to Change an Entrenched Police Culture
abstract: Readers discuss police reforms after the George Floyd murder. Also: The submersible; Justice Alito’s ethics; President Trump’s behavior; child care funding.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Senator Rick Scott Has Been Weighing a Presidential Run
abstract: If he runs, Mr. Scott would become the fourth Republican presidential candidate from Florida, joining Donald Trump, Gov. Ron DeSantis and Mayor Francis X. Suarez of Miami.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rick Scott of Florida is considering a late entry into the Republican presidential primary race, a move that would make him the latest high-profile Florida Republican to try to wrest the nomination from Donald J. Trump, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

headline: You Don’t Have to Wait for Peak Tomato
abstract: Tomato sandwiches in the sand, chilled tomato salads in the grass, icy pitchers of gazpacho on the patio. Summer is here.
lead_paragraph: While it has been summer for me mentally since the first warm weekend of May, the season officially kicked off yesterday with the summer solstice, the longest day of the year in the Northern Hemisphere.

headline: E-Cigarette Sales Tapered Off Last Year After Big Surge
abstract: Flavors proliferated and disposable vapes took hold as purchases of vaping devices increased steadily from January 2020 to mid-2022.
lead_paragraph: Sales of e-cigarettes rose by nearly 47 percent from January 2020, just before the pandemic hit the United States, to December 2022, according to an analysis released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Biden Welcomes Indian Prime Minister to the White House
abstract: President Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India emphasized cooperation between the two countries during a state visit.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India emphasized cooperation between the two countries during a state visit.

headline: Microsoft Says It Could Abandon Activision Deal if Judge Delays It
abstract: A five-day hearing over Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition, which the Federal Trade Commission hopes to block, began Thursday in federal court.
lead_paragraph: The first day of a weeklong hearing that could determine the outcome of Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of the video game giant Activision Blizzard opened Thursday with a promise from Microsoft: If a federal judge grants an injunction that would delay the deal’s closing, Microsoft could abandon the deal altogether.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Navajo Nation in Water Rights Case
abstract: The vote was 5 to 4, with the majority finding that an 1868 treaty did not require the federal government to ensure the tribe had access to water.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled against the Navajo Nation on Thursday in a water rights case, rejecting the tribe’s suit against the federal government in a dispute over access to the drought-depleted Colorado River system.

headline: In Turkey, Erdogan Signals Shift to Conventional Economics
abstract: In his choices of top officials, and with a leap in interest rates, Mr. Erdogan aims to tame inflation and defuse a looming economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s central bank sharply raised interest rates on Thursday, the clearest sign yet that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is shifting his country toward more orthodox economic policies in the hope of taming a painful cost-of-living crisis.

headline: ‘Rust’ Armorer Transferred Narcotics on Day of Shooting, Prosecutor Says
abstract: A new charge of evidence tampering was announced as a departing investigator accused the Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Office of “reprehensible and unprofessional” conduct.
lead_paragraph: The original armorer on the film “Rust,” who was charged with involuntary manslaughter after a gun that was loaded with live ammunition fired on the set and killed the cinematographer, will face an additional charge of evidence tampering related to narcotics, a special prosecutor in the case said Thursday.

headline: A House Museum Has a New Message: New York Had Slavery, Too
abstract: Reopening after years of restoration, the Lefferts Historic House in Brooklyn now also acknowledges the enslaved people who lived and worked there.
lead_paragraph: In 1765, a young woman named Flora came to live on the Lefferts family farm in what is now the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn. Skilled in treating illnesses with medicinal herbs and in preparing and preserving food, she took charge of the farmhouse’s kitchen, planning daily meals on the 250-acre property.

headline: Divided House Sidesteps Biden Impeachment Vote but Starts Inquiry
abstract: The Republican-led chamber moved to refer articles of impeachment to two House committees, charging that the president’s immigration policies are an impeachable offense.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led House on Thursday quashed a move to quickly impeach President Biden but voted along party lines to open an investigation into his removal, as reluctant G.O.P. leaders bowed to a member of their hard-right flank who demanded to move forward with charges that his immigration policies constitute high crimes and misdemeanors.

headline: TikTok Shakes Up Leadership Amid Questions About Its Future
abstract: The app’s chief operating officer is stepping down, and the company is bringing in a new executive to run its communications department.
lead_paragraph: TikTok, the popular short-form video app that is facing questions about its future in the United States, said on Thursday that its chief operating officer was leaving the company and that it had hired a new head of operations and a new chief brand and communications officer.

headline: ChatGPT Lawyers Are Ordered to Consider Seeking Forgiveness
abstract: Steven A. Schwartz and Peter LoDuca must pay a fine and send letters to judges named in a brief filled with fiction, a judge ordered.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge on Thursday imposed a $5,000 fine on two lawyers who gave him a legal brief full of made-up cases and citations, all generated by the artificial intelligence program ChatGPT.

headline: Dr. Luke and Kesha Settle Defamation Lawsuit
abstract: The producer and pop singer had been involved in a nearly decade-long legal saga that began with a contract disagreement.
lead_paragraph: The pop super-producer and songwriter known as Dr. Luke has dropped a defamation lawsuit against the singer Kesha, a former protégée who had accused him of rape in a 2014 lawsuit, the two parties announced in a joint statement on Thursday. The announcement signaled the end of a nearly decade-long legal saga that has riveted the music world and come to define both artists’ intertwining public narratives.

headline: ‘The Light in the Piazza’ Review: Outside, Looking In at Love
abstract: A meet-cute on an Italian excursion sends a mother and daughter on parallel journeys of self-discovery in an Encores! staging of the 2005 musical.
lead_paragraph: Encountering a great piece of art can lead to a moment of transcendence. That’s the idea behind the mother-daughter tour of Florence in “The Light in the Piazza,” the 2005 musical romance composed by Adam Guettel and written by Craig Lucas. And for audiences at New York City Center, where an exquisite Encores! revival directed by Chay Yew opened on Wednesday, a sensational performance by Ruthie Ann Miles delivers a feeling close to the sublime.

headline: ‘I’ll Show You Mine’ Review: Couch Trip
abstract: This drama, directed by Megan Griffiths, explores abuse and trauma through a potent and prickly series of conversations.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll Show You Mine” teases viewers with its story of a charged, prickly and flirtatious interview between a best-selling author, Priya (Poorna Jagannathan), and a former model, Nic (Casey Thomas Brown), who is the subject and a co-writer of a new book. He’s also Priya’s nephew by marriage.

headline: Regional Mexican Music Is Finding More Ears. Peso Pluma Is Helping.
abstract: An alternative to nearly all the other best-selling 2020s pop is surging, as acts including Grupo Firme and Natanael Cano present corridos with fresh perspectives.
lead_paragraph: “Génesis,” the album released on Thursday by the Mexican songwriter known as Peso Pluma, could easily become a blockbuster. Its advance singles have already been streamed tens of millions of times. Other songs that Peso Pluma has released this year have racked up hundreds of millions of plays — among them “Ella Baila Sola” (“She Dances Alone”), his collaboration with the band Eslabon Armado, which reached No. 4 on Billboard’s mainstream pop chart, the Hot 100.

headline: Biden and Modi Highlight Strength of U.S.-India Relationship
abstract: President Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India both described shared democratic values as being the foundation of the partnership between the countries.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India both described shared democratic values as being the foundation of the partnership between the countries.

headline: The Importance of Hope in the Pro-Life Movement
abstract: One year after Dobbs, abortion opponents must contemplate their political alliances.
lead_paragraph: This newsletter is ultimately about hope. But I want to start with something else, a question that’s deeply relevant to the Republican Party and its 2024 presidential primary. The perceived answer to this question will likely swing the evangelical vote and decide the nomination.

headline: Oregon County Sues Fossil Fuel Companies Over 2021 Heat Dome
abstract: ExxonMobil, Shell and BP are among the companies that Multnomah County says were responsible for a heat wave that led to the deaths of 69 local residents.
lead_paragraph: The Oregon county that includes Portland on Thursday filed a lawsuit against several fossil fuel companies and their business partners in an effort to hold them responsible for a deadly heat wave in 2021.

headline: Hamish Harding, an Explorer Who Knew No Bounds, Dies at 58
abstract: An aviation tycoon who pushed the limits, he went to the depths of the ocean and the blackness of space before his fateful dive to the Titanic on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Hamish Harding, an aviation tycoon and ardent explorer, made it his quest to probe the heavens as well as the depths, landing him a place in Guinness World Records and ultimately leading him to a fateful plunge to the wreckage of the Titanic some two and a half miles below the surface of the North Atlantic.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Lesser-Known Hip-Hop Lyrics?
abstract: As The New York Times prepares to pay tribute to the genre on its 50th anniversary, we want to hear about the lines that have stuck in your heads and shaped your musical lives.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to pinpoint the exact birth date of a musical revolution. But if you ask most experts when hip-hop burst onto the scene, they’ll tell you it all started with a block party in the Bronx on Aug. 11, 1973.

headline: Liberal Democrats Boycott Modi’s Speech to Congress
abstract: “We must never sacrifice human rights at the altar of political expediency,” four of the protesting House members said, objecting to the Indian leader’s human rights record.
lead_paragraph: A half-dozen liberal House Democrats are boycotting Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s speech to Congress on Thursday afternoon, in protest of what they criticize as his abysmal human rights record, particularly toward Muslim minority groups in India.

headline: At 100, She’s ‘Queen of the Century’
abstract: Roslyn Schlansky threw herself a 100th birthday party this month in the courtyard of the Upper West Side building where she's lived for more than 50 years. Its name? The Century.
lead_paragraph: Roslyn Schlansky threw herself a 100th birthday party this month in the courtyard of the Upper West Side building where she's lived for more than 50 years. Its name? The Century.

headline: Reparations Should Be an End, Not a Beginning
abstract: The focus on housing assistance as compensation for decades of redlining is a promising one.
lead_paragraph: For a long while, reparations for Black Americans has been more a debate topic than a reality. But of late, the reality may be catching up with the debate. Since last year, Evanston, Ill., has been granting $25,000 payments to be applied to housing to Black people who lived in the area from 1919 to 1969, when redlining and other forms of discrimination in housing were common. Their descendants are also eligible. This year, the program has been extended to enable grantees to take simple cash payments. In San Francisco, a task force has suggested that eligible Black people receive onetime payments of $5,000,000 each; a statewide task force has proposed a somewhat more modest plan with a sliding scale of payments topping out at $1.2 million. The New York State Legislature has passed a bill that would create its own commission to consider reparations, and there will doubtless be more such proposals nationwide.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: Golfers will contest the second women’s major of the year, while men’s college baseball will crown a champion.
lead_paragraph: Golfers will contest the second women’s major of the year, while men’s college baseball will crown a champion.

headline: SmileDirectClub to Release Customers From NDAs in Settlement
abstract: The telehealth company is stopping its practice of asking some customers to sign nondisclosure agreements as part of their refunds.
lead_paragraph: SmileDirectClub, which provides orthodontic services through the mail, has agreed to release customers who asked for refunds from nondisclosure agreements, as part of a settlement with the District of Columbia’s attorney general.

headline: State Dinners: Who Gets Them, Who Doesn’t and Why They Matter
abstract: Under the guise of pomp and pageantry, state visits can be a chance to push foreign dignitaries to align with American interests.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden welcomed India’s prime minister to the White House, the two leaders were looking for more than a fine vegetarian meal and a night of glitzy entertainment.

headline: Does Justice Alito Hear Himself?
abstract: His response to ethics concerns demonstrates all the bitterness and superciliousness for which he has become known.
lead_paragraph: For someone who wields unimaginable power and exudes utter confidence in his own moral rectitude, Justice Samuel Alito is an exceptionally touchy guy.

headline: Trump Trial Setting Could Provide Conservative Jury Pool
abstract: If Judge Aileen Cannon sticks to her initial decision to hold the trial in Fort Pierce, Fla., the jury would be drawn largely from counties that Donald Trump won handily in his previous campaigns.
lead_paragraph: When Judge Aileen M. Cannon assumed control of the case stemming from former President Donald J. Trump’s indictment for putting national security secrets at risk, she set the stage for the trial to be held with a regional jury pool made up mostly of counties that Mr. Trump won handily in his two previous campaigns.

headline: Stockton Rush, Pilot of the Titan Submersible, Dies at 61
abstract: A lifelong adventure seeker, Mr. Rush said he took on the risk of deepwater travel because the “ocean is the universe. That’s where life is.”
lead_paragraph: Stockton Rush, the chief executive and founder of OceanGate and the pilot of the Titan submersible, was declared dead on Thursday after his vessel was found in pieces at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, near the rusting wreck of the R.M.S. Titanic. He was 61.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: The Titan Sub’s ‘Catastrophic Implosion’
abstract: Plus, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s meetings at the White House.
lead_paragraph: All five people aboard the submersible that disappeared on Sunday were believed to be dead, the U.S. Coast Guard said yesterday, ending a dayslong rescue effort that gripped much of the world. A debris field from the vessel, called the Titan, was found about 1,600 feet from the bow of the Titanic and was “consistent with a catastrophic implosion,” the Coast Guard commander said.

headline: Chris Paul Headed to Golden State in Trade From Wizards
abstract: Paul, who has spent the past three seasons in Phoenix, is expected to be traded to Washington and then to Golden State.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Wizards plan to trade Chris Paul to Golden State for guard Jordan Poole after reaching an agreement to acquire Paul from the Phoenix Suns earlier this week, according to a person familiar with the deals who was not authorized to discuss them publicly.

headline: With ‘Glamorous,’ Miss Benny Gets a Platform Makeover
abstract: The actor, singer and YouTube makeup expert joins Kim Cattrall to play a makeup expert on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Miss Benny was a makeup-obsessed YouTuber with a few minor TV credits, working photo shoots and various odd jobs, when a call came in about starring in a new series. The main character: a makeup-obsessed YouTuber.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends checking out a new tidying-up show, a darkly comic crime series and an Italian cartoon about a cartoonist.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Gentle Art of Swedish Death Cleaning’When to watch: Now, on Peacock.

headline: The Titan Submersible Suffered a ‘Catastrophic Implosion’
abstract: Also, the South is facing dangerous heat. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard said today that a remote-controlled vehicle found debris from the Titan, the vessel that carried five people on a deep-sea exploration of the Titanic wreckage over the weekend, indicating a “catastrophic implosion.” Everyone aboard the submersible was believed to be dead, the Coast Guard said. The discovery effectively ended the international search that began on Sunday after the submersible lost contact.

headline: DeSantis Dodges Question on Endorsing Trump as 2024 Nominee
abstract: The Florida governor did say he would “respect the outcome” of the primaries while Donald Trump has refused to commit to backing the party’s 2024 nominee if the former president falls short.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Thursday avoided saying directly that he would endorse Donald J. Trump in 2024 should the former president win the Republican nomination, showing his reluctance to make a benign show of support for the man who is beating him by a wide margin in national polls and insulting him nearly every day.

headline: Missiles Strike Russian-Held Bridge Far Behind Ukraine Front Line
abstract: The attack damaged a bridge in the Russian-occupied Crimean Peninsula that Moscow uses to resupply its forces in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A Russian-held bridge far behind the front lines that helps Moscow resupply its forces in Ukraine was hit by missiles on Thursday, Kremlin-backed local officials said.

headline: Accused Art Trafficker’s Estate Forfeits $12 Million to End Case
abstract: The payment will settle a civil suit brought by U.S. officials who accused Douglas A.J. Latchford of being a major dealer of looted antiquities.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials announced Thursday that the daughter of an accused antiquities trafficker had agreed to forfeit $12 million from his estate as part of a settlement of a civil case that accused her father of profiting from the sale of stolen Cambodian artifacts.

headline: Mexican Court Strikes Down President’s Bid to Remake Election Laws
abstract: The ruling from the country’s top court came as President Andrés Manuel López Obrador ramps up his attacks on the judicial system.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s highest court on Thursday struck down a key piece of a sweeping electoral bill backed by the president that would have undermined the agency that oversees the country’s vote, and that helped shift the nation away from single-party rule.

headline: Violent Druggings in Lower Manhattan Left a Trail of Bodies, Police Say
abstract: The police said Kenwood Allen and Sean Shirley targeted 26 victims for robberies, among them an up-and-coming fashion designer found dead in bed.
lead_paragraph: In one robbery, the perpetrators smeared white powder laced with fentanyl under the victim’s nose. In another, they offered someone marijuana laced with the drug and waited for the person to fall unconscious, the police said.

headline: Indian TV Heaps Praise on Modi During His U.S. Trip
abstract: The visuals from the prime minister’s trip played into what he has already set as one of his main campaign themes: tying India’s rise as a major economic power with his rise as a global statesman.
lead_paragraph: “Super King of Diplomacy,” read the ticker placed in bold on top of one news channel. “Long live our friendship,” said another. A third declared, “The Boss in America.”

headline: Former L.S.U. Men’s Basketball Coach Will Wade Suspended for 10 Games
abstract: Wade, who was hired this year to coach at McNeese State, was not cited for the most notorious charge against him: that he lured recruits with illicit payments.
lead_paragraph: Will Wade, the men’s college basketball coach recently hired by McNeese State, has been suspended for 10 games next season, bringing to a close a lengthy N.C.A.A. investigation into the football and basketball programs at Louisiana State, the Southeastern Conference powerhouse Wade formerly coached.

headline: Shahzada Dawood, Executive, 48, and Son, 19, Die Aboard Submersible
abstract: Mr. Dawood, a British Pakistani businessman, was the vice chairman of Engro Corporation, a conglomerate owned by one of the richest families in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Shahzada Dawood, a British Pakistani businessman who was among the five people aboard a submersible journeying deep into the Atlantic to view the Titanic, was killed when the vessel imploded during its descent to the ocean floor, the authorities said Thursday. He was 48.

headline: The Age of Spectacle Is Upon Us
abstract: The Los Angeles Dodgers succumb to pressures from the elite.
lead_paragraph: If I walked onto the field at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles and stomped on a Dodger’s uniform on home plate, I hope that the Dodgers and their fans would be upset. This is the jersey that Jackie Robinson wore, along with Dodgers legends like Sandy Koufax, Orel Hershiser, Tommy Lasorda and Roy Campanella. You don’t dishonor other people’s uniforms. In a pluralistic society, decent people don’t dishonor what others find sacred.

headline: The Full Guest List for Biden’s State Dinner With Modi
abstract: More than 380 guests were invited, including government officials, business leaders, fashion designers and prominent Indian Americans.
lead_paragraph: More than 380 guests were invited to the state dinner President Biden hosted for Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on Thursday night, a list that included government officials, business leaders, star athletes, a renowned violinist, a Hollywood director, the son of a civil rights icon, fashion designers and prominent Indian Americans. Here is the entire list of invitees provided by the White House.

headline: ‘Titanic’ Director James Cameron Points to Flaws in Titan Sub’s Design
abstract: The “Titanic” director and diving expert said he’d had concerns from the start about the vehicle’s hull composition and claims about its network of hull sensors.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve never had an accident like this,” James Cameron, the Oscar-winning director of “Titanic,” said on Thursday.

headline: A Stir-Fry to Convert Green Bell Pepper Skeptics
abstract: In Chinese American pepper steak, crunchy panels of blistered peppers are the star.
lead_paragraph: “The only pepper I cannot abide is a green pepper,” the cookbook author Nigella Lawson once wrote, aptly calling out the fruit’s bitter, undeveloped flavor.

headline: Wyoming Judge Temporarily Blocks State’s Ban on Abortion Pills
abstract: The law was to take effect on July 1. It is the only state law that specifically outlaws the most common abortion method in the country.
lead_paragraph: A Wyoming judge on Thursday temporarily blocked the first state law specifically banning the use of pills for abortion, the most common method in the country.

headline: After Dramatic I-95 Collapse in Philadelphia, State Accelerates Repairs
abstract: A temporary six-lane roadway is expected to be in place by Friday, far sooner than officials had predicted in the days after the accident.
lead_paragraph: The stretch of Interstate 95 that collapsed in Philadelphia almost two weeks ago isn’t going to be shut down for months after all.

headline: 3M Reaches $10.3 Billion Settlement in ‘Forever Chemicals’ Suits
abstract: The deal followed an agreement by Chemours, DuPont and Corteva to pay $1.19 billion to help resolve claims that the chemical manufacturers contaminated drinking water across the country.
lead_paragraph: The chemical and manufacturing giant 3M reached a $10.3 billion settlement on Thursday with U.S. cities and towns over their claims that the company contaminated drinking water with so-called forever chemicals used in everything from firefighting foam to nonstick coatings.

headline: Bob Brown, Intimidator on N.F.L. Offensive Lines, Dies at 81
abstract: As an offensive tackle for three teams in a Hall of Fame career, he said he prided himself on being the “beater” and not the “beatee.”
lead_paragraph: Bob Brown, who was considered one of the N.F.L.’s most intimidating, aggressive offensive tackles in his era, but who had to wait more than 30 years after his retirement in 1973 to be elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame, died on June 16 in Oakland, Calif. He was 81.

headline: U.S. Navy Detected a Possible Implosion Near Titan Sub as Communications Failed
abstract: Two senior Navy officials said the information was shared with the Coast Guard official in charge of the search. But without certainty of a disaster, one said, the search continued.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Navy, using data from a secret network of underwater sensors designed to track hostile submarines, detected “an anomaly consistent with an implosion or explosion” in the vicinity of the Titan submersible at the time communications with the vessel were lost on Sunday, two senior Navy officials said on Thursday.

headline: Meteorologist Who Was Threatened Over Climate Coverage to Leave Job
abstract: Chris Gloninger said his new job as a scientist at a research company would still allow him to make a difference on a subject he is passionate about.
lead_paragraph: The chief meteorologist of a television news station in Iowa said this week that he was leaving his job to start a career in science, citing in large part the post-traumatic stress disorder that he said he had suffered after he was threatened last year over his on-air coverage of climate change.

headline: I.R.S. Agent Told Congress of Hunter Biden Invoking His Father in Business Deal
abstract: A whistle-blower said the tax agency found a message from 2017 in which Hunter Biden pressured a Chinese business partner by saying he was with his father, who was then out of office.
lead_paragraph: The lead I.R.S. agent investigating whether Hunter Biden committed tax crimes told Congress his team uncovered evidence that Mr. Biden had invoked his father, who was then out of office, while pressing a potential Chinese business partner in 2017 to move ahead with a proposed energy deal, House Republicans said.

headline: Deep in the Atlantic, a ‘Catastrophic Implosion’ and Five Lives Lost
abstract: The vast multinational search for the missing submersible ended after pieces of it were found on the ocean floor, 1,600 feet from the bow of the Titanic.
lead_paragraph: A vast multinational search for five people who had descended to view the wreckage of the sunken R.M.S. Titanic ended on Thursday after pieces of the privately owned submersible vessel that had carried them were found on the ocean floor, evidence of a “catastrophic implosion” with no survivors, according to the U.S. Coast Guard.

headline: Victor Wembanyama Drafted No. 1 Overall by San Antonio Spurs
abstract: Wembanyama, the 19-year-old French basketball star, had been perhaps the most-hyped prospect since LeBron James.
lead_paragraph: Victor Wembanyama had grown up in the suburbs of Paris dreaming about this moment since he was 12 years old. He had long felt as though he was different from everyone else, as though he could be great — and not just in basketball.

headline: One Year, 61 Clinics: How Dobbs Changed the Abortion Landscape
abstract: In the year since Roe was struck down, clinic owners have scrambled to adjust to the new legal landscape around abortion. Here’s what happened to them, and their communities.
lead_paragraph: In the year since Roe was struck down, clinic owners have scrambled to adjust to the new legal landscape around abortion. Here’s what happened to them, and their communities.

headline: ‘Once Upon a One More Time’ Review: Cinderella, Liberated (Again)
abstract: The Britney Spears jukebox musical, about fairy tale princesses fighting for their emancipation, comes up short as a narrative of feminist awakening.
lead_paragraph: The Britney Spears jukebox musical “Once Upon a One More Time” is not a bio-show recounting the singer’s life. Rather, it retrofits two dozen of her songs — including “Oops! … I Did It Again,” “Womanizer,” “Toxic,” “Gimme More” and, of course, “ … Baby One More Time” — to tell the story of a fair-haired princess who, realizing she has been played by a handsome rogue and controlled by an omnipresent father figure, rises up and fights for her emancipation.

headline: In This Election, Some Candidates Lost Before a Single Vote Was Cast
abstract: Guatemala’s first round of elections on Sunday is as much about who’s not on the ballot as who is, after courts barred leading candidates from running.
lead_paragraph: A Guatemalan judge walked into a meeting at the American Embassy last spring and pulled out a large quantity of cash: The money, she said, was a bribe from one of the president’s closest allies.

headline: Top Present During the Holiday Season
abstract: Kunal Nabar makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: Joel Fagliano takes a turn at a back-and-forth variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MARCHING BANDS — The New York Times last ran a “Marching Bands” puzzle more than a year ago. Here is a new one and the first of this kind by Joel Fagliano, a member of the Games editing team who over the years has constructed many puzzles, including other variety grids. The rules for “Marching Bands” are intuitive, if you take a moment to see how the grid is labeled. Clues are separated into numbered “rows” and lettered “bands,” instead of acrosses and downs; in most cases, there are multiple clues for each row and band. The entries for the rows run left to right, and the entries for the bands run clockwise, starting where each band’s  letter appears in the grid.

headline: Biden’s State Dinner Ignores the Discord Just Beyond the Gates
abstract: The mix of political adversaries created a dinner scene so dissonant that no amount of glass clinking could have drowned out the partisan undercurrents.
lead_paragraph: State dinners are useful tools for celebrating the culture of the visiting leader, so on Thursday evening, President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, hosted a 400-person soiree replete with sequins, saris and saffron-colored flowers in honor of Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India.

headline: Corrections: June 23, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Thursday about Haim Roet, who created a memorial project that involves annually reading the names of Holocaust victims in public around the world, misstated the surname of one of his relatives who died in the Holocaust. He was Abraham Prince, not Abraham Roet.

headline: Remnants of Cindy Could Redevelop, Meteorologists Say
abstract: An area of low pressure associated with remnants of the tropical storm was well out to sea on Tuesday and was producing disorganized showers and thunderstorms.
lead_paragraph: Remnants of Cindy, the second active tropical storm to threaten the Caribbean in this past week, could redevelop, forecasters said. It was unclear if it will impact any land.

headline: JPMorgan’s Epstein Deal Sets No Cap or Minimum on Victims’ Claims
abstract: A claims administrator will determine how to disburse $290 million in funds from JPMorgan’s deal with alleged victims of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: The proposed $290 million settlement between JPMorgan Chase and sexual abuse victims of Jeffrey Epstein carries no minimum or maximum payout for each individual, leaving that decision to the claims administrator appointed to oversee the process, according to a plan filed in federal court on Thursday.

headline: A ‘Risky Text’ Helped Jump-Start Their Relationship
abstract: Karina Rodriguez and Andrew Levin had crushes on each other early on in high school, but after an “awkward” first date, they avoided each other for two years. Until prom.
lead_paragraph: “We were just two weird kids,” Karina Rodriguez Hilario said of herself and Andrew Levin while reminiscing about their high school days.

headline: Who Was That Knocking at Her Door? That ‘Cute Guy.’
abstract: Meechka Marcelin was studying for a genetics exam in her room off campus when Ian Patrick knocked on her door to invite her to hang out.
lead_paragraph: After two sleepless nights, Ian Joseph Patrick and Meechka Makeba Marcelin rang in 2023 exhausted, but happy, at Wellstar North Fulton Hospital in Roswell, Ga.

headline: They Talked About Age, Yes. They Talked Even More About Fine Wine.
abstract: A difference of four years initially gave Jacqueline Coleman pause, but ultimately Robert Crapsey won her over.
lead_paragraph: Robert Stites Crapsey was feeling pretty sure of himself when he saw Carole Jacqueline Coleman at a June 2017 committee meeting for the Pace Center for Girls Miami.

headline: First a Key to the Apartment, Then to Her Heart
abstract: For years, Katerina Jeng and Jocelyn Ueng were friends on Instagram. When Ms. Jeng visited Ms. Ueng in Copenhagen in 2021, a 48-hour first date kicked off a long-distance relationship.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Jocelyn Carol Ueng would host a five-course themed meal in her loft in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, twice a month for six paying guests at a time. In the hopes of generating publicity for her culinary project, she reached out to an Asian American literary magazine.

headline: My Last Shopping List for Him
abstract: For exhuming my husband’s bones, I was told to bring a bottle of red wine, chlorine, powdered soap and a white bedsheet.
lead_paragraph: Even in death, your teeth are perfect.

headline: After a Single Glance, an Unspoken Connection Blossomed
abstract: Six months after seeing Alexis Bittar at the gym, Jack Miner remained intentionally “aloof” toward him. Once the silence was broken, a relationship and a family followed.
lead_paragraph: A couple decades ago, the accessory designer Alexis Riyad Bittar, who had nearly a dozen tattoos at the time, added an especially meaningful one to the array: an image of a pair of thin wedding bands in navy blue ink, deliberately situated on the ring finger of his left hand.

headline: Tipping Gets ‘More in Your Face,’ and Not Everyone Likes It
abstract: Tipping is not unheard-of in Australia, but an increasing number of apps and payment platforms are actively asking for an extra dollar, or five, on bills.
lead_paragraph: These days, when dining out, you might expect to be asked whether you’d like to add a tip when paying electronically. Ride share services often prompt customers to add an extra dollar, or three or five. Some online ordering or payment platforms will even automatically include a tip in your bill, unless you opt out.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Paris Climate Summit Seeks Financial Reforms to Confront a Crisis
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I grew up being afraid of drowning in my own bedroom.”

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: The discovery of wreckage from the Titan submersible.
lead_paragraph: The five people aboard a submersible that went missing on Sunday were presumed dead after an international search found pieces of the vessel, including the tail cone, near the wreckage of the Titanic. The debris was “consistent with a catastrophic implosion of the vessel,” a U.S. Coast Guard official said.

headline: Word of the Day: persistent
abstract: This word has appeared in 805 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word persistent has appeared in 805 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 24 in “Halle Bailey: ‘The Little Mermaid’ Star Connects With Her Inner Ariel” by Kalia Richardson:

headline: After Midnight at the N.B.A. Draft, Dreams Still Come True
abstract: The crowds had thinned by the second round, but several players lingered in the stands waiting to hear their names called. Dozens of fans waited to cheer them on.
lead_paragraph: Mark Tatum, the deputy commissioner of the N.B.A., had an important job — though not a glamorous one — on Thursday night.

headline: Canada Forces Google and Facebook to Pay News Outlets for Linking to Articles
abstract: A new Canadian law will require technology companies to license news content. Facebook’s owner said it would drop news from the platform.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Parliament has passed a law that will require technology companies to pay domestic news outlets for linking to their articles, prompting the owner of Facebook and Instagram to say that it would pull news articles from both platforms in the country.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Dance Critic Visits an Extraordinary Stage
abstract: Performing rudimentary moves, inmates in the California state prison system were uncommonly open with their stories.
lead_paragraph: I usually write about art, mainly dance, by reporting from theaters or studios. So it was strange when dance drew me inside a penitentiary in March 2020.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Lights, Camera, Criminal Defense: Lawyers Pick Up Cameras to Help Clients
abstract: Wealthy defendants can hire video crews to help them argue for more lenient treatment. Public defenders are trying to get in on it, too.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker set up his tripod outside a South Bronx public housing complex on a recent morning, recording traffic rumbling past aging buildings, playgrounds, older people greeting one another in Caribbean-accented Spanish and a growing line at a church food pantry.

headline: Is There a Price That Keeps Trump Quiet? E. Jean Carroll May Find Out.
abstract: The writer’s lawyers are going after him again for defamation, but is there an award high enough to keep the former president from saying what he wants to?
lead_paragraph: How much money must E. Jean Carroll win to stop Donald J. Trump from talking about her?

headline: Mogul’s Manhattan Casino Pitch: A Location People Won’t Hate
abstract: Larry Silverstein joins a crowded, well-financed field of developers competing for three casino licenses in the New York City region.
lead_paragraph: The scrum of millionaires and billionaires hustling for the right to build a casino in New York City now includes Larry Silverstein, the real estate magnate who redeveloped much of the World Trade Center site after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: ‘World’s Best’ Review: Straight Outta Calculus
abstract: A math prodigy channels the spirit of his rapper father in this lively musical.
lead_paragraph: “World’s Best,” from the director Roshan Sethi, is a vibrant kid’s musical set to a simple beat. The seventh grade calculus prodigy Prem Patel (Manny Magnus) longs to be as cool and confident as his dad, Suresh (Utkarsh Ambudkar), a rapper who died of cancer when the boy was five years old. Prem’s mother, Priya (Punam Patel), is proud to raise a mathlete — until Prem slips on his father’s gold chain necklace and dad magically appears to inspire him to bust a rhyme at the school talent show. “I’m like a memory remixed with a fantasy,” Suresh says with a grin. I’d go with hype man or hype ghost.

headline: A Freewheeling 91-Year-Old Principal Retires
abstract: Elaine Schwartz didn’t have an office because she wanted to “hear the kids.” And the cost (to Trump) of Trump’s big mouth.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. It’s the time of year when school principals often retire. We’ll meet one who is stepping down at age 91. We’ll also look at the latest move by the writer E. Jean Carroll to stop Donald Trump from talking about her.

headline: In Myanmar, Birthday Wishes for Aung San Suu Kyi Lead to a Wave of Arrests
abstract: People across Myanmar wore flowers on Monday to show support for the jailed civilian leader. Since then, the ruling military has been rounding them up.
lead_paragraph: In military-ruled Myanmar, there seemed to be a new criminal offense this week: wearing a flower in one’s hair on June 19.

headline: With a Hand From the U.S. Military, Aid Finally Reaches a Syrian Camp
abstract: “I saw people eating plants that are usually only used to feed animals,” said one resident of a camp for displaced Syrians that sits in the shadow of an American military base but has been cut off from aid for years.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of Syria’s long war, a remote desert camp for thousands of displaced people grew in the shadow of an American military base, just out of reach of Syrian government forces.

headline: Newly Published, From Susan Sontag to the Black Working Class
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN WHITELASH: A Changing Nation and the Cost of Progress, by Wesley Lowery. (Mariner, $29.99.) Beginning with the backlash to the 2008 election of Barack Obama, Lowery examines how American society has fissured in the past 15 years, profiling the victims of white supremacy and the institutions that support it.

headline: Why Is Apple Getting ‘Spatial’?
abstract: The obscure term was recently used by the world’s most valuable company in a product launch, probably in hopes that it inspires, rather than answers, questions.
lead_paragraph: The obscure term was recently used by the world’s most valuable company in a product launch, probably in hopes that it inspires, rather than answers, questions.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Boots Riley's new TV series, "I'm a Virgo."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Boots Riley's new TV series, "I'm a Virgo."

headline: Barbie, Her House and the American Dream
abstract: Take a stop-motion journey with the young, single homeowner of the Dreamhouse. Ken isn’t on the deed.
lead_paragraph: Take a stop-motion journey with the young, single homeowner of the Dreamhouse. Ken isn’t on the deed.

headline: ‘He’s a Hint of the Future’: Our Writers on Vivek Ramaswamy
abstract: A weak candidacy but serious ideological development on the right.
lead_paragraph: As Republican candidates enter the race for their party’s 2024 presidential nomination, Times columnists, Opinion writers and others will assess their strengths and weaknesses with a scorecard. We rate the candidates on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the candidate will probably drop out before any caucus or primary voting; 10 means the candidate has a very strong chance of receiving the party’s nomination next summer. This entry assesses Vivek Ramaswamy, a hedge fund analyst turned biotech executive.

headline: Trump, the Worst Boss You’ve Ever Had
abstract: He believes the presidency belongs to him. It’s a dangerous assumption rooted in the habits and pathologies of the business world.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump did not — and does not — recognize any distinction between himself and the office of the presidency. He is it, and it is him.

headline: Is There Any Twinge of Regret Among the Anti-Abortion Justices?
abstract: A year later, the consequences for women have been alarming.
lead_paragraph: Because Jehovah’s Witnesses believe that saluting the flag or reciting the Pledge of Allegiance amounts to worshiping secular authority, they prohibit their school-age children from engaging in the practice. In 1940, with war raging in Europe and patriotic fervor rising at home, the Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution provided no religious exemption from what many public schools deemed an essential civic duty. The decision upheld a Pennsylvania school district’s expulsion of a Jehovah’s Witness brother and sister. A single member of the court dissented.

headline: When Does Anxiety Become a Problem?
abstract: The president of the American Psychiatric Association answers questions about a new recommendation to screen all adults under 65 for anxiety.
lead_paragraph: How much anxiety is too much?

headline: The Run-Up Goes to Iowa
abstract: In our final episode of the season, we travel to the state that could scramble both parties’ assumption that Donald Trump is the inevitable nominee — and talk to the voters most likely to turn on him.
lead_paragraph: For the past few months, The Run-Up has been reporting on political insiders and the work they’ve quietly been doing to shape the 2024 presidential election.

headline: How NATO Blends Aircraft From 25 Nations
abstract: The alliance’s “Air Defender” exercises, the largest in its history, have focused on communications, particularly on synchronizing multiple encryption systems.
lead_paragraph: Flying a 50,000-pound attack jet while 10,000 feet above Earth may not be the best time for a language lesson. But it was part of the drills that Maj. Greg Kirk of the Idaho Air National Guard had to decipher last week as he sought clarity on his mission from a heavily accented German military air traffic controller issuing the orders.

headline: New Study Bolsters Room-Temperature Superconductor Claim
abstract: A team of researchers verified a key measurement from a study earlier this year that had faced doubts from other scientists.
lead_paragraph: A magical material that could effortlessly conduct electricity at room temperatures would likely transform civilization, reclaiming energy otherwise lost to electrical resistance and opening possibilities for novel technologies.

headline: How to Make Your Walk a ‘Microadventure’
abstract: Start small, look up and let your nose guide you.
lead_paragraph: I’ve loved doing the fieldwork for our monthlong series on walking. (You can find the previous installments here.) This week, we are livening up our walk by turning it into a microadventure, imbued with a sense of curiosity and exploration.

headline: Why This Economist Wants to Give Every Poor Child $50,000
abstract: The economist Darrick Hamilton discusses how policy proposals like “baby bonds” could help the country move toward greater racial and economic equity.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the New York Times Audio app here.

headline: Where Kennedys Sail and Play Football, Others Cook and Clean
abstract: In “White House by the Sea,” Kate Storey gives readers a comprehensive tour of the summer home beloved by a certain political clan.
lead_paragraph: We weren’t invited to hang out with them, and that was the point. At a key juncture in his life, Joe Kennedy wasn’t invited either. In 1922, already wealthy, a Harvard grad furiously propagating, he applied for membership in the prestigious Cohasset Golf Club outside of Boston. The Brahmins took one look at him and saw only the son of an Irish Catholic barkeep, so Joe set about building the most exclusive club of all.

headline: We Muslims Used to Be the Culture War Scapegoats. Why Are Some of Us Joining the L.G.B.T.Q. Pile-On?
abstract: How quickly some have forgotten the lessons of the past two decades.
lead_paragraph: The political right’s exhausting and cruel war on “wokeness” is now aligning with the efforts of some Muslim Americans to attack the L.G.B.T.Q. community under the guise of protecting religious freedoms and parental rights.

headline: To the Conductor Claudio Abbado, the Orchestra Was a Collective
abstract: A collection of 257 CDs and eight DVDs released by Deutsche Grammophon offers the breadth of Abbado’s approach, and its legacy.
lead_paragraph: Claudio Abbado lit a cigar and looked uneasy, as he often did.

headline: Sasha Colby Owned the ‘Drag Race’ Runway. Next Category, the Airport.
abstract: This season’s winner, now serving frequent-flier realness on her victory lap, shares tips for packing (Ziploc bags) and navigating the T.S.A. while transgender.
lead_paragraph: From the time Sasha Colby first took the stage in the latest season of “RuPaul’s Drag Race,” her eventual victory appeared almost inevitable. The 38-year-old — whose tagline is “Your favorite drag queen’s favorite drag queen” — brought her work ethic and two decades of experience to every revealing-yet-revelatory costume, heartfelt lip-sync routine and comically timed neck crack.

headline: Far Right Pushes a Through-the-Looking-Glass Narrative on Jan. 6
abstract: An ecosystem of true believers is promoting a tale of persecution rather than prosecution that has migrated to the heart of presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: Six months since the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol completed its work, a far-right ecosystem of true believers has embraced “J6” as the animating force of their lives.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 23, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: It’s Not Possible to ‘Win’ an Argument With Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
abstract: You can’t win a debate against someone who disregards facts.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2006, I jumped into the ring for a few rounds of debate with Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who was peddling reckless claims about an important issue on which he lacked expertise. It wasn’t vaccines. It was the 2004 presidential race. In an article for Rolling Stone, Kennedy suggested that the election had been stolen from John Kerry — a suggestion that, after thorough reporting, didn’t hold up.

headline: The Vietnamese American Artists Searching for Identity
abstract: Postwar refugees who’ve used their art to express complicated feelings of loss and home.
lead_paragraph: An-My Lê can barely recall the Hawaiian shirt that the blond American wore when he put her into a black cargo van. Though many of the artist’s memories from the spring of 1975 bleed into one another — slanted piles of burlap sandbags encasing her bedroom wall, fallen artillery shells lining the streets near her school like bread crumbs — what has remained with her lucidly from those last few days of the 21-year war that divided her home country against itself, is the profound fear that had engulfed Saigon. The city was bracing for the Quân đội nhân dân Việt Nam, the Communist army of the North, and the Việt Cộng, the guerilla-style militant groups from South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia, to capture the capital of Việt Nam Cộng hòa — what the United States and the rest of the Western Bloc knew as the Republic of Vietnam. Lê spent that night on the military tarmac of Saigon’s Tan Son Nhut Air Base with her father and two brothers. When dawn broke, she took one last glance at the landscape through the windows of the American C-130 aircraft as it disappeared into the clouds. She was 15.

headline: For Mire Lee, Rising Art Star, It All Comes Down to Guts
abstract: The Korean artist’s ingenious machine sculptures, coming to the New Museum, show things that “you don’t actually want to see,” a leading curator says.
lead_paragraph: One morning earlier this month, the artist Mire Lee was sitting outside at a cafe in Seoul as she discussed an artwork that she came up with just as she started planning “Black Sun,” her show opening soon at the New Museum in Manhattan.

headline: It’s a War-Themed Restaurant, but There Is No Need to Pretend
abstract: A restaurant that celebrates Ukraine’s struggles in earlier wars is finding a second life in this one.
lead_paragraph: A knock on the large unmarked wooden door opposite Lviv’s city hall. A man in a military uniform holding a German-made rifle answers. Password, he demands.

headline: Enter the 50-Ton Concert Hall That Hangs Like a Disco Ball
abstract: At the Shed in Manhattan, audience members can take in live, spatially designed music inside a suspended hall called the Sonic Sphere.
lead_paragraph: The lights inside the cavernous McCourt space at the Shed had been dimmed, and a mystical soundtrack was playing. “Your journey begins in five minutes,” a recorded voice announced to the roughly 200 people gathered there on a recent evening.

headline: She’s Calling It: ‘That Moment’ for Women’s Soccer Is Now.
abstract: With the rapid rise of women’s soccer, Y. Michele Kang, the owner of the Washington Spirit, is in the vanguard of transforming ownership and management worldwide.
lead_paragraph: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

headline: Ukraine’s Western-Trained Brigades Begin to Enter the Fight
abstract: The arrival of new units could be pivotal. But progress has been slow for Ukraine in the early stage of its counteroffensive.
lead_paragraph: They are fighting more effectively at night than their Russian counterparts, U.S. officials say.

headline: When Parents Go Their Separate Ways
abstract: Stories, both new and evergreen, to help children of divorce heal.
lead_paragraph: As a Gen X latchkey child of a single mom, I knew the solitude and sadness that come from having only the distracted supervision of one (preoccupied) adult. My parents divorced and my dad died before I started school, so I didn’t move between two homes, but I had plenty of friends who did. Our divorce bible was “It’s Not the End of the World,” by the inimitable Judy Blume, in which Karen, a white sixth grader from New Jersey, tries scheme after scheme to get her parents back together before eventually giving up. Their reasons for separating are vague, so Karen looks for answers in “The Boys and Girls Book About Divorce,” which she special-orders in 1972 for the “very expensive” price of $7.95. (Blume has always understood the power of books to explain and heal.)

headline: How a Year Without Roe Shifted American Views on Abortion
abstract: New and extensive polling shows public opinion increasingly supports legal abortion, with potential political consequences for 2024.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Americans had settled around an uneasy truce on abortion. Even if most people weren’t happy with the status quo, public opinion about the legality and morality of abortion remained relatively static. But the Supreme Court’s decision last summer overturning Roe v. Wade set off a seismic change, in one swoop striking down a federal right to abortion that had existed for 50 years, long enough that women of reproductive age had never lived in a world without it. As the decision triggered state bans and animated voters in the midterms, it shook complacency and forced many people to reconsider their positions.

headline: Reddit’s Chief Says He Wants It to ‘Grow Up.’ Will Its Community Let It?
abstract: As the social media site matures, its users and moderators have made their displeasure about corporate changes known, putting the company into a bind.
lead_paragraph: For the past 11 years, Bucky has put time and effort into stewarding and guiding dozens of communities on Reddit, the sprawling internet message board.

headline: Altitude Meets Adrenaline: Running the Dolomites
abstract: The limestone pinnacles and green meadows of one of the most scenic mountain ranges on earth provide the backdrop to a seven-day adventure in Italy.
lead_paragraph: Rain hammers the windshield as the shuttle van stops at the edge of the village of Sesto, Italy. We pile out without enthusiasm. It’s early September in Südtirol, just south of the Austrian border. Under the drooling eaves of a cafe, we pull on our rain gear. Nadine, the shuttle driver for a local tour company, who has the rosy cheeks of an Austrian but accelerates like an Italian, smiles with sympathy. She’s taking our luggage to tonight’s lodging. “Would anyone care for a ride?” she asks.

headline: A.I. Beach + Vibes-Based R.T.O. + the ‘Black Mirror’ Quamputer
abstract: Generative artificial intelligence can increasingly do the work of creatives — so why aren’t we seeing more A.I. ads and A.I. actors?
lead_paragraph: This week, advertisers swarmed the beaches of southern France for the Cannes Lions advertising festival. Kevin says artificial intelligence is all anyone there can talk about, but admits the conference is making him rethink how quickly generative A.I. will take over the industry — despite the buzz.

headline: In ‘Loisaida,’ Photos of a Bygone New York
abstract: Between 1984 and 1990, Tria Giovan captured everyday life on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Upon moving into a tenement building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in 1984, the 23-year-old photographer Tria Giovan spent her days observing her new neighborhood and its increasingly Puerto Rican and Chinese community for “fleeting moments, gestures, color and light.”

headline: As Lord Mayor, a 22-Year-Old Vaulted From Public Housing Into London’s Elite
abstract: Hamza Taouzzale became the first Muslim and youngest ever Lord Mayor of Westminster, a ceremonial post that outranks many of the capital’s most powerful and privileged.
lead_paragraph: As guests filed into Westminster Abbey for the coronation of King Charles III, a young man wearing a ceremonial robe of blue and gold beneath a glinting chain of office walked up the central aisle and took a prime seat by the choir.

headline: Embracing Their Strength (or Lack Thereof)
abstract: Tampa Bay’s outrageous season has been fueled by home runs. Cleveland barely hits any. Both teams follow the numbers and emphasize what they do well.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Trout or Shohei Ohtani hit home runs, they get a Samurai helmet placed on their head as they return to the Angels’ dugout. The San Diego Padres strike a cheesy pose with their conquering homer heroes and snap a dugout Polaroid.

headline: Chinese Firm Sent Large Shipments of Gunpowder to Russian Munitions Factory
abstract: The previously unreported shipments between a state-owned Chinese company and a Russian munitions factory last year raise new questions about Beijing’s role in Russia’s war against Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: On two separate occasions last year, railroad cars carrying tens of thousands of kilograms of smokeless powder — enough propellant to collectively make at least 80 million rounds of ammunition — rumbled across the China-Russia border at the remote town of Zabaykalsk.

headline: In Charleston, a Museum Honors a Journey of Grief and Grace
abstract: The International African American Museum, in a former slave port, is about more than slavery. It’s about survival and resilience.
lead_paragraph: In Charleston Harbor, where the initiating shots of the Civil War were fired — Fort Sumter is distantly visible — I’m on the site of a former shipping pier known as Gadsden’s Wharf. Here, in the 18th and early 19th centuries, ships carrying tens of thousands of enslaved Africans deposited their human cargo, a population that would, through unthinkable adversity and creative perseverance, utterly transform what “America” meant, and means.

headline: 88 Temples, 750 Miles, Untold Gifts: Japan’s Shikoku Pilgrimage
abstract: A famed route on the smallest of Japan’s four main islands offers breathtaking views and an array of lessons on history, culture and generosity.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks into my trek, as I ascended a steep path toward Yokomine-ji, the 60th of 88 temples along the Shikoku pilgrimage, I found myself enveloped by an unforgiving fog. In an instant, the colorful forest around me — mostly red cedar trees and fern bushes — faded, leaving me in a world of muted gray. Able to make out only the faintest shapes in the surrounded trees, I was convinced that I’d stumbled into an eerie fairy tale.

headline: A New British Arts Venue Tracks Its City’s Changes
abstract: An insurance company bought the naming rights to the $270 million complex in Manchester, in a clear sign of its distance from the D.I.Y. scenes of decades past.
lead_paragraph: Since the late ’70s, Manchester, in the north of England, has been a focal point for British pop culture. The city is still mostly known by the rest of the world for the bands it helped produce: Joy Division, New Order, the Stone Roses, Oasis and the Smiths all have ties to the city.

headline: Texas Heat Wave Shows No Signs of Letting Up
abstract: A record-breaking heat wave is expected to worsen through the weekend as it spreads through nearby states.
lead_paragraph: A weather pattern that has brought unrelenting heat to Texas for more than a week is unlikely to end until at least early July, according to forecast models, with record-breaking heat expected to expand into nearby states this weekend.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Implosion of the Titan Submersible, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Understanding Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
abstract: The Times’s Kyiv bureau chief reports from the front line as the shape of a long-awaited campaign begins to emerge.
lead_paragraph: For months, much of the world has been watching and waiting as Ukraine prepares for a major counteroffensive in its war with Russia. That battle is now underway, and it’s not what was expected.

headline: Democracy and Reality
abstract: We are covering Narendra Modi’s visit to the U.S., the implosion of the missing submersible and the N.B.A. draft.
lead_paragraph: India is arguably the most important swing nation in global politics. It is influential enough to shift the balance of power, and its allegiances are neither obvious nor consistent.

headline: ‘The Perfect Find’ Review: The Actors Put the Spark in This Film
abstract: Fashion media workers, paired on a project that caters to their passion for all things vintage, fall for each other in this romance by Numa Perrier.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Jones had it all: a fabulous career at a fashion magazine, power coupledom with a handsome man named Brian — their combined heat had even melted them into one headline-ready portmanteau entity, Brijenna.

headline: Economists Warn a ‘Summer of Fun’ Could Lead to Autumn Pain
abstract: Consumers are splurging on expensive but fun experiences, from nights out to concerts — and that may force central banks to keep raising rates.
lead_paragraph: Uncomfortably high inflation appears set to linger, forcing central bankers to inflict further pain on consumers and businesses by raising borrowing costs again and again.

headline: With Slashed Funding, British Museums Turn to Philanthropy
abstract: Britain’s National Portrait Gallery reopened Thursday after a three-year, $53-million renovation. Raising the money in the current climate was tough.
lead_paragraph: On a recent tour of London’s National Portrait Gallery, Nicholas Cullinan, the museum’s director, pointed out some of the major British figures from history and pop culture whose likenesses lined the walls: Shakespeare, King Henry VIII, the Vogue editor Anna Wintour.

headline: The B.Q.E. Wasn’t Built for Delivery Trucks. Its Cracks Are Showing.
abstract: Wildfires and truck crashes bring a new sense of urgency to fixing New York’s worst highways — and a search for radical alternatives.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, the city of Boston embarked on a plan for the most ambitious and expensive highway project in the country’s history, one that replaced a crumbling, six-lane elevated artery of Interstate 93 with a tunnel and two bridges crossing the Charles River.

headline: Who Won the N.B.A. Draft Fashion Game?
abstract: Tailoring, bling and Louis Vuitton, oh my.
lead_paragraph: The fact that the N.B.A. draft occurred smack in the middle of the Paris men’s wear shows was something of a cosmically appropriate coincidence.

headline: Sheldon Harnick, ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Lyricist, Dies at 99
abstract: His collaborations with the composer Jerry Bock also included “Fiorello!” — which, like “Fiddler,” was a Tony winner — and “She Loves Me.”
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Harnick, the lyricist who teamed up with the composer Jerry Bock to write some of Broadway’s most memorable musicals, including the Tony Award winners “Fiddler on the Roof” and “Fiorello!,” died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

headline: L.A. Opens Its New Light-Rail Link
abstract: Known as the Regional Connector, the link allows riders to travel from East Los Angeles all the way to Santa Monica without transferring.
lead_paragraph: A city famous for its choked freeways and crawling commutes has a new claim to fame: the longest light-rail line in the world.

headline: Robert Gottlieb Didn’t Just Shape Manuscripts. He Shaped Dance, Too.
abstract: The esteemed editor, who died last week at 92, was a balletomane who was known to program New York City Ballet seasons from his offices at Alfred A. Knopf and The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: The world of letters has been mourning Robert Gottlieb, who died last week at 92, as a reader and editor of qualities that became legendary. The world of dance has been mourning him as well. He neither performed nor choreographed, but he played a major role, often behind the scenes, in fostering American dance.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by June 30 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 11.
lead_paragraph: Update, June 30: You can submit your response for Week 4 here.

headline: Stock Market Rally on Pause as Investors Take Cue From the Fed
abstract: Investors this week appeared more cautious, ending a long streak of market gains after the Fed also erred on the side of caution last week.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Federal Reserve held off raising interest rates after 10 increases in a row, instead waiting to assess how the economy has responded to the sharp rise in rates so far. This week, stock investors also paused for reflection, putting the recent rally on hold until the outlook becomes clearer.

headline: It’s Time to Move Beyond ‘Asian American’
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Megha Khemka, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Megha Khemka, age 17, from Walter Payton College Preparatory High School in Chicago, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: ‘Not Real Chinese’: Why American Chinese Food Deserves Our Respect
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Kelley Kwok, age 16.
