lead_paragraph: This essay, by Kelley Kwok, age 16, from Staten Island Technical High School in New York, N.Y., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Want to Run a World-Record Time? Follow the Green Lights.
abstract: Wavelights have helped runners stay on a pace to break multiple world records. They were developed by a former pacer.
lead_paragraph: Jakob Ingebrigtsen was ready to become a Pac-Man when he stepped on the track in early June.

headline: It Is So Hard to Be Trans
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Callisto Lim, age 16.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Callisto Lim, age 16, from Kinder High School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Houston, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Yes, There Are Alternatives to Stocks
abstract: At the moment, money market funds and many bonds are not only less risky, but at current interest rates, they are compelling.
lead_paragraph: The stock market has been strutting into the spotlight lately, with talk — however premature — of a new A.I.-driven bull market popping up nearly everywhere you turn.

headline: Power Grids Are Teetering Worldwide. Here’s Why.
abstract: Extreme heat is increasing electricity demand as people crank up the AC. The strain could be too much.
lead_paragraph: It’s really hot in Texas right now. Many parts of the state are hotter than they’ve ever been at this time of year. In the coastal city of Corpus Christi, the heat index, a combined measure of heat and humidity, reached a shocking 125 degrees Fahrenheit, or about 52 Celsius.

headline: How ‘I’m a Virgo’ Pulled Off Old-School Movie Magic
abstract: The star Jharrel Jerome and senior members of the creative team discuss how they created the distinctive look of this ambitious new Amazon series.
lead_paragraph: In the world of “I’m a Virgo,” the adventurous new series from the writer-director Boots Riley (premiering Friday on Amazon Prime Video), laws aren’t to be trusted.

headline: These Bronze Statues Reveal Ancient Healing Rituals
abstract: Discovered in a dig at a thermal spring in Tuscany, Italy, the well-preserved items offer a glimpse into medical practices from the Etruscan and Roman eras.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition that opened Friday at Rome’s Quirinal Palace could be described as a classic rags-to-riches story.

headline: Supreme Court Revives Biden Immigration Guidelines
abstract: The guidelines, setting priorities for which unauthorized immigrants should be detained, were blocked by a federal judge in Texas.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that the Biden administration could set priorities for which undocumented immigrants to arrest and which to leave alone, rejecting a challenge from two conservative states that pressed for more aggressive enforcement and handing a major victory to President Biden.

headline: Pope Hosts Artists in Sistine Chapel, Even Some Who Attracted Controversy
abstract: The event was part of a broader effort to engage with artists as the Roman Catholic Church did in the past. Pope Francis also urged them to pursue social justice through their work.
lead_paragraph: As Pope Francis met with dozens of international artists at the Sistine Chapel on Friday, he sought both to reaffirm the Roman Catholic Church’s commitment to artistic endeavors and to enlist the artists to act as catalysts for change in areas like social justice.

headline: Facing Brutal Heat, the Texas Electric Grid Has a New Ally: ‌Solar Power
abstract: The amount of solar energy generated in Texas has grown exponentially. Some Republicans question the state’s increasing reliance on renewable power.
lead_paragraph: Strafed by powerful storms and superheated by a dome of hot air, Texas has been enduring a dangerous early heat wave this week that has broken temperature records and strained the state’s independent power grid.

headline: Maitreyi Ramakrishnan Is Done With School. On TV, Anyway.
Final Fantasy XVI Takes On Its ‘Star Wars’ Problem
Classic Lemon Tart Recipe
Chocolate Lava Cake Recipe
Three Summery, Swoonworthy New Romance Novels
abstract: Want to dip your brain into a jar of serotonin?
lead_paragraph: A new love is more fun to live through than to hear about secondhand from a friend — but the friend is usually better placed to observe your new relationship’s pitfalls. The genius of the romance genre is it offers the reader both the first-person feelings and the second-person perspective at once. It also, unfortunately, makes mere plot summaries ring hollow, because they lack the irreducible emotional resonance of the reading experience.

headline: Mentaiko Spaghetti Is Creamy, Briny, Rich and Spicy
abstract: Tarako and mentaiko add oomph to potato salad and cream cheese, and fried chicken is a satisfying end to a summer Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Tarako is a Japanese word meaning “children of cod.” It describes the salt-cured roe sacs of Alaskan pollock, a fish in the cod family, and it is a popular ingredient in Japanese cuisine. It’s found in Korean cooking, too, as well as in some French and Russian dishes: salty and rich with umami, tasting more of the sea than of, like, fish. You can find it at big-box Asian supermarkets, packaged in frozen trays alongside its spicier marinated cousin, mentaiko, a word that translates, a little more directly, as “children of Alaskan pollock.”

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s chilling picks, creepypasta and killer pasta, too.
lead_paragraph: In Joaquín del Paso’s new gut punch of a morality tale, a group of teenagers master machismo at an exclusive summer camp in the Mexican countryside. The true-believer counselors are devoted to training the boys to become Christian tough guys, and if that means looking the other way as the kids bully the possibly gay kid, so be it.

headline: Secrets and Systems, Lost in the Video Age
abstract: Technology democratized scouting and made hidden gems a thing of the past. But innovation is a moving target.
lead_paragraph: Udinese knew about Alexis Sánchez long before he had been called up to play for the Chilean national team. It knew about him before he had played in the Copa Libertadores, before the rest of South America discovered him and before he had caught the acquisitive eyes of Europe’s biggest, richest teams.

headline: A Comic With Many Questions About Jews and Whiteness
abstract: Alex Edelman thrives on doubt in “Just for Us” on Broadway. It’s the result of years of revision and notes from Seinfeld, Birbiglia and the late Adam Brace.
lead_paragraph: When Jerry Seinfeld talked to the comic Alex Edelman after seeing him perform “Just for Us,” his solo show that began previews on Broadway this week, he gave him one note: Don’t acknowledge the audience’s response to a joke onstage.

headline: ‘The Flash’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Andy Muschietti narrates a sequence featuring Ezra Miller.
lead_paragraph: The director Andy Muschietti narrates a sequence featuring Ezra Miller.

headline: The Super Connector Who Built Sam Bankman-Fried’s Celebrity World
abstract: Michael Kives, a former Hollywood agent, connected FTX’s founder to Katy Perry, Orlando Bloom, Bill Clinton and others. His firm got $700 million in exchange, a lawsuit claims.
lead_paragraph: About 10 months before he was arrested on fraud charges, the cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried posed for a photograph at the 2022 Super Bowl in Inglewood, Calif.

headline: Watch a Falling-Baby Rescue in ‘The Flash’
abstract: The director Andy Muschietti narrates a sequence featuring Ezra Miller.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Why Some Americans Buy Guns
abstract: Sociologists are just beginning to understand who is buying guns and how gun ownership makes them feel.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, while many communities were under Covid lockdowns, protesters were flooding the streets and economic uncertainty and social isolation were deepening, Americans went on a shopping spree. For firearms.

headline: Suddenly, It Looks Like We’re in a Golden Age for Medicine
abstract: We may be on the cusp of an era of astonishing innovation — the limits of which aren’t even clear yet.
lead_paragraph: Hype springs eternal in medicine, but lately the horizon of new possibility seems almost blindingly bright. “I’ve been running my research lab for almost 30 years,” says Jennifer Doudna, a biochemist at the University of California, Berkeley. “And I can say that throughout that period of time, I’ve just never experienced what we’re seeing over just the last five years.”

headline: Beck and Phoenix’s Bouncy Synth-Pop Team-up, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Palehound, Jaimie Branch, Aphex Twin and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Review: A Composer’s ‘Lear’ Freshens a Shakespeare Evening
abstract: The Met Orchestra’s season-ending concert at Carnegie Hall featured the premiere of Matthew Aucoin’s “Heath (‘King Lear’ Sketches).”
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera orchestra’s uneven, season-ending concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday had a sleepily evergreen theme: Shakespeare.

headline: Going Abroad, Modi Receives a Gift for Image-Building at Home
abstract: For an audience in India, the prime minister is linking his diplomatic reception abroad, and himself, to the country’s growing importance on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: His grip on the levers of national power secure, his hold on India’s domestic imagination cemented, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has increasingly turned to advancing himself on a new horizon: the global stage.

headline: The TikTok Search for the Titanic Sub
abstract: Tragedies can be good business on social media.
lead_paragraph: This week, like much of the world, I have been fixated on the submersible Titan, which disappeared on a trip to the wreck of the Titanic with five people inside.

headline: The Big Number: 70 Billion
abstract: A federal judge is hearing arguments on whether Microsoft's deal for the video game giant Activision can go ahead.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge is hearing arguments on whether Microsoft's deal for the video game giant Activision can go ahead.

headline: Abortion Politics Takes Center Stage at Evangelical Event, but Trump Remains the Focus
abstract: At a gathering of evangelicals, the former vice president and other top Republican candidates backed a ban that is more strict than what former President Donald J. Trump has said he would support.
lead_paragraph: In a speech one year after the reversal of Roe v. Wade, former Vice President Mike Pence challenged the entire 2024 Republican presidential field to support a national abortion ban at 15 weeks, demanding that the party go farther than its primary front-runner, former President Donald J. Trump, has so far been willing to go.

headline: Submersible Expert Raised Safety Concerns After 2019 Trip on Titan
abstract: After hearing a loud cracking sound during the dive, the expert, Karl Stanley, emailed OceanGate’s C.E.O., Stockton Rush, to urge him to hold off on future trips.
lead_paragraph: During a trip on board the Titan off the coast of the Bahamas in April 2019, Karl Stanley, an expert in submersibles, knew immediately that something was off: He heard a cracking noise that got only louder over the two hours it took for the submersible to plunge more than 12,000 feet.

headline: Starbucks Union Plans to Strike Over Pride Décor and Labor Practices
abstract: Walkouts were called at more than 150 stores in the next week after workers said Pride Month decorations had been banned in some, a claim the company denied.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of workers at organized Starbucks stores across the nation will stage strikes over the next week, their union said on Friday, after workers in some states said management prohibited them from putting up decorations for Pride Month.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Darrick Hamilton
abstract: The June 23, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Darrick Hamilton. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Assessing Modi’s Leadership of India
abstract: Readers discuss whether criticism of him is valid as he met with Biden. Also: Making sense of Trump; politicizing the homeless; annoying noise.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A long-running feud has broken into open confrontation. Here’s the latest.
abstract: The claims from Yevgeny V. Prigozhin including a veiled threat of an uprising against Russia, prompted the F.S.B. to open a criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Russian generals late on Friday accused Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the outspoken mercenary tycoon, of trying to mount a coup against President Vladimir V. Putin, as the Russian authorities opened an investigation into Mr. Prigozhin for “organizing an armed rebellion.”

headline: Why I’m Not a Liberal Catholic
abstract: The problem with adapting to a culture that’s rushing away from Christianity.
lead_paragraph: During Lent, in a spirit of self-criticism, I wrote an installment of this newsletter outlining the things that I think the liberal tendency within Roman Catholicism gets right, relative to the more conservative tendency to which I myself belong. Specifically, I argued that liberal Catholics have a strong case that the ways the church has changed already, both since the Second Vatican Council and previously, create a more unsettled landscape for believers than conservatives sometimes like to admit, with vexed questions that simple appeals to papal authority aren’t likely to resolve and room for good-faith debate about what the changes we’ve already seen imply about the nature of the church’s authority.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be an Asian American Brewer?
abstract: Across the U.S., Asian beer makers are putting their mark on an industry that is still predominantly white.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, Leah Wong Ashburn’s father, Oscar, did something very few, if any, Chinese Americans had tried before: He opened a craft brewery.

headline: An Easy Risotto to Top However You Please
abstract: Kay Chun’s classic Parmesan risotto is a rich canvas for personalization — perfect for appeasing picky eaters.
lead_paragraph: What is a weeknight recipe? It wiggles a bit depending on the dish, but generally I feel a weeknight recipe has as few ingredients as possible, requires minimal active work (and pans to clean), and can be done relatively quickly. You can make it at the end of the day and aren’t too tired to actually enjoy it.

headline: U.S. Will Host Club World Cup in 2025
abstract: A year before the World Cup comes to North America, an expanded soccer competition for the top global club teams will be contested in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A year before 48 of the best men’s national soccer teams come to North America for the World Cup, 32 of the best club teams will arrive in the United States for the first edition of an expanded Club World Cup in 2025.

headline: Sheldon Harnick, Musical Theater’s Great Marriage Broker
abstract: In lyrics of rare humor, elegance and compassion, the man who put words to “Fiddler on the Roof” and “She Loves Me” explored the complex emotional architecture of love.
lead_paragraph: The twilight golden years of the Golden Age of musical theater, which archaeologists date from about 1959 to 1981, produced three great lyricists. One, of course, was Stephen Sondheim, setting words to his own music with a neurotic complexity that defined that time and ours. Another was Fred Ebb, the longtime songwriting partner of John Kander, who if poppier in outlook was a genius at prosody, shooting off syllables (“one day it’s kicks, then it’s kicks in the shins”) that never failed to bruise.

headline: Pink Floyd, ‘The Wizard of Oz’ and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: A New Line of Subtle, Glamorous Clothes
abstract: The debut collection from the designer Michelle Rhee’s namesake line balances romantic draping with precise men’s wear-inspired silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: As a child, the fashion designer Michelle Rhee was rather shy and fascinated by how, in lieu of spoken words, clothes could communicate on behalf of their wearer. “That always gave me a sense of confidence,” says Rhee, who’s drawn to minimal but evocative aesthetic objects of all kinds. No wonder that, when she studied art history in college, she was taken with German Expressionism, the early 20th-century movement whose practitioners dispensed with strict realism, leading instead with their emotions. “There’s a classicness to those paintings, and yet they’re charged with so much energy,” says Rhee, 33. The same might be said of the 18 pieces that make up the inaugural collection of her namesake label, which launched earlier this month and stands to become a favorite of women who want to dress simply but not quietly.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles from Annie Proulx, Beth Macy and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles from Annie Proulx, Beth Macy and more.

headline: The Majesty of the Cure’s Live Show
abstract: Robert Smith’s band cast a spell on New York this week. Listen to a playlist that showcases the long-running group’s onstage power.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I was listening to “Pictures of You,” one of the many great singles by the British band the Cure, on the subway. It’s a song I’ve heard approximately one million times, and yet when I put it on, time still seems to slow down and everything around me becomes suspended in a romantic haze. I am almost positive the strangers sitting across from me were engaged in a simple conversation about directions. But as Robert Smith yelped dreamily — “Remembering you standing quiet in the rain, as I ran to your heart to be near” — I convinced myself that one of them was actually expressing their unrequited love.

headline: U.S. Charges 4 Chinese Firms With Selling Chemicals to Make Fentanyl
abstract: The indictments are part of a strategy attacking every stage of the supply chain for the opioid, which kills thousands each year.
lead_paragraph: Four chemical companies based in China and eight Chinese nationals have been charged with trafficking chemicals used by Mexican drug cartels to manufacture vast quantities of fentanyl later sold in the United States, federal officials said on Friday.

headline: Review: In ‘Like Water for Chocolate,’ Plot Overtakes Ballet
abstract: American Ballet Theater opened its summer season with Christopher Wheeldon’s new three-act ballet, inspired by a novel and film.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine compared choreography to gardening. “Dancing disintegrates,” he once said. “Like a garden. Lots of roses come up, and in the evening they’re gone.”

headline: How to Talk to Someone With Alzheimer’s
abstract: The family of the celebrity zookeeper Jack Hanna is speaking publicly about the difficulties communicating with him now that he has Alzheimer’s. Experts say that such interactions take patience and sensitivity.
lead_paragraph: The family of Jack Hanna, the celebrity zookeeper and media personality, has opened up about his Alzheimer’s diagnosis, offering an intimate look at the challenges of communicating with a man who no longer remembers who most of them are.

headline: ‘One Woman Show’ Review: Unlikable for Laughs
abstract: Liz Kingsman plays a messy attention-seeker grasping at relevance in a sharp satire of the trend of female comics playing chaotic train wrecks.
lead_paragraph: Liz Kingsman’s stupendously silly spoof “One Woman Show” arrives in New York with enough buzz for an apiary. The rare solo comedy that moved from small theaters to the West End in London, it has received gushing reviews, topped year-end best-of lists and inspired more than one profile proclaiming its star the “queen of comedy.”

headline: Weather Warnings Can Save Lives. Here’s What Makes Them Effective.
abstract: A weather warning can be issued for events including tornadoes, hurricanes and blizzards. Here’s what makes people act on — or ignore — those messages.
lead_paragraph: Severe weather can happen any day of the year. If you are in its path, you’ll probably get a warning in the form of a shrill alarm on your cellphone or text scrolling across the TV screen.

headline: Supreme Court Narrows the Right to Confront One’s Accuser in Joint Trials
abstract: In a murder-for-hire conspiracy trial, the majority allowed a defendant’s confession implicating a co-defendant to be used, with limitations.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday upheld the conviction of an American who participated in a plot to assassinate a real estate agent in the Philippines in 2012, rejecting his claim that his constitutional rights had been violated in allowing testimony about a confession from an accomplice.

headline: The Many Minds Behind Biden’s Biggest Economic Idea
abstract: Key White House players have different views on what “worker-centric” policy should look like.
lead_paragraph: Factory floors and union halls are President Biden’s happy places. Here’s the president speaking to the International Union of Operating Engineers Local 77 in Accokeek, Md., on April 19: “I make no apologies — and I mean this sincerely — for being the most pro-union president in American history. [Applause.] It’s not just because I grew up with you all. It’s because it’s true.”

headline: My Friend Has Become Obese. Should I Intervene?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on respecting a loved one’s boundaries when concerned about their health.
lead_paragraph: My friend of 50 years has recently become morbidly obese. She now must be 100-plus pounds overweight on a very small frame. She has great difficulty breathing, and her legs are bowed out from being crushed under her weight. She can no longer perform simple household tasks like cleaning.

headline: The Dark Incentives That Led to a Refugee Tragedy
abstract: To those who see refugees as a burden or threat, border security is a zero-sum game that can be “won” by keeping potential asylum seekers out or by forcing them into other countries.
lead_paragraph: At the core of the global asylum system lies one simple idea: Every country is obligated to offer protection to any foreign citizen within its borders who meets the legal definition of a refugee, even if they arrived without permission.

headline: Can Plants Think?
abstract: In “Planta Sapiens,” Paco Calvo addresses our “plant blindness.”
lead_paragraph: In “Planta Sapiens,” Paco Calvo, a philosopher of plant behavior, and his co-author, Natalie Lawrence, present the idea that flora are intelligent — that is, capable of cognition. In Calvo’s opinion, people pay more attention to animals than plants and this may explain why some of plants’ remarkable abilities have been overlooked. Our evolutionary history may also shape our reduced attention to the subject; plants are, after all, unlikely to attack people.

headline: How to Turn Your Chatbot Into a Life Coach
abstract: A chatbot can be an effective motivator that helps you set goals and organize your schedule to achieve them.
lead_paragraph: Hello! We’re back with another edition of On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.

headline: 7.5 Million Baby Shark Bath Toys Are Recalled After Reports of Children Being Injured
abstract: At least a dozen people have reported being injured by the toy. The top fins pose a risk of “impalement, lacerations and punctures,” the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
lead_paragraph: About 7.5 million Baby Shark bath toys are being recalled after reports that at least a dozen children were injured by them, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday.

headline: Garland Pushes Back at G.O.P. Claims of Bias in Hunter Biden Investigation
abstract: The attorney general denied assertions that he had interfered with the case and blocked a prosecutor from lodging more charges.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland defended the Justice Department’s five-year investigation of Hunter Biden on Friday, forcefully rebutting claims promoted by House Republicans that he blocked federal prosecutors in Delaware from expanding the inquiry to encompass a greater range of crimes.

headline: Jails Officer Faked Suicide Prevention Training for 74 Guards, D.A. Says
abstract: Vinette Tucker-Frederick falsified records as Rikers staff were under pressure to stop a rash of suicides, prosecutors said. Her lawyer said she is innocent.
lead_paragraph: Amid a suicide crisis in New York City’s jails, a correction officer falsified records to show that scores of her peers had taken a suicide prevention course that they had not actually completed, Bronx prosecutors and the Department of Investigation said on Friday.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How to spend 36 hours in Paris. Also: The significance of Barbie's Dreamhouse, and John Corbett on reprising his “Sex and the City” role.
lead_paragraph: How to spend 36 hours in Paris. Also: The significance of Barbie's Dreamhouse, and John Corbett on reprising his “Sex and the City” role.

headline: How to Use Your Dishwasher Better
abstract: Even a mediocre dishwasher can get your dishes completely clean.
lead_paragraph: Even a mediocre dishwasher can get your dishes completely clean.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Free Speech Challenge to Immigration Law
abstract: In a 7-to-2 decision, the court gave a narrow reading to a statute that made it a crime to encourage unauthorized immigrants to come to or stay in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court avoided a difficult First Amendment question on Friday, ruling that an unusual 1986 federal law that makes it a crime to “encourage” or “induce” unauthorized immigrants to come to or stay in the United States should be read narrowly to require complicity in a criminal conduct.

headline: Joni Mitchell Finally Returned. Her Fans Were Waiting.
abstract: The crowd at the singer-songwriter’s first announced concert in more than two decades was intergenerational and grateful.
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 10 at the majestic Gorge Amphitheater in George, Wash., on the lip of the Columbia River, the 79-year-old singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell played her first headlining show in 23 years. Her appearance had the air of a comet’s return: rare, breathlessly awaited and well worth camping out all night. That many concertgoers had traveled long distances made the experience feel all the more like a Mitchell song — perhaps one of the poetic highway travelogues recorded on her 1976 album “Hejira,” or even one of the romantic, intercontinental voyages she sang about on her 1971 landmark “Blue.” It was a crowd dotted with tie-dye and graying braids, yes, but also one full of lifelong friends reunited, mothers and children bonding over intergenerational musical tastes and enough homemade Mitchell T-shirts to rival Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour. As Mitchell said to the adoring crowd as it held glowing cellphone lights aloft, paraphrasing one of her most memorable songs, “You’re stardust, and golden.”

headline: House G.O.P. Uses Spending Bills to Pick Partisan Policy Fights
abstract: Republicans are tucking dozens of policy mandates into government funding bills, in an effort to use their majority to force politically charged votes.
lead_paragraph: American military installations would be explicitly banned from having drag queen story hours for children.

headline: Why Eric Adams Issued His Second-Ever Veto Over Housing Bills
abstract: Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker, immediately criticized the veto and said that the Council had enough votes to override it.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams vetoed a package of New York City Council bills on Friday, arguing that they would worsen the city’s housing crisis.

headline: At Attractions About the Titanic, Pondering the Fate of the Titan
abstract: More than a century after the Titanic sank, its story is still told in exhibitions and shows. But those who went this week had a newer disaster to consider.
lead_paragraph: Jo-B Sebastian had just entered an exhibit about the Titanic and its more than 1,500 lost passengers when a friend received a news alert on his smart watch on Thursday afternoon: the five people whose submersible had gone missing during a deep dive to explore the Titanic’s wreckage had been declared dead.

headline: Judge Rules Against Florida Law Restricting Drag Shows
abstract: In issuing a preliminary injunction, the judge in Orlando found that a law restricting “adult live performances” would very likely be unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Florida temporarily blocked a new law allowing the state to penalize businesses that admit children to “adult live performances” such as drag shows.

headline: At Titanic Site, the Grim Job Now Is Assessing the Submersible’s Debris
abstract: With hopes for rescue dashed, searchers are turning to documenting and perhaps retrieving parts of the imploded vessel, as an investigation of the disaster gets underway.
lead_paragraph: Now that the world knows what happened to the Titan, the submersible that vanished on Sunday on a dive to view the wreck of the R.M.S. Titanic, officials are turning their attention to learning how and why the vessel apparently imploded, killing everyone aboard.

headline: 5 Deaths at Sea Gripped the World. Hundreds of Others Got a Shrug.
abstract: Many see harsh realities about class and ethnicity in the attention paid to the Titan submersible and the halfhearted attempts to aid a ship before it sank, killing hundreds of migrants. But there are other factors.
lead_paragraph: On one vessel, five people died on a very expensive excursion that was supposed to return them to the lives they knew. On the other, perhaps 500 people died just days earlier on a squalid and perilous voyage, fleeing poverty and violence in search of new lives.

headline: Wagner’s leader said the Kremlin attacked his forces
abstract: Plus, small town U.S.A. in “Asteroid City”
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin accused the Russian military of attacking his private forces, shortly after he released a scathing video that described the invasion of Ukraine as a “racket” meant to enrich Russia’s corrupt elite.

headline: New Orleans Officers Lose Credentials 18 Years After Katrina Shootings
abstract: The officers had pleaded guilty for their roles in opening fire on six residents, two of whom died, on the Danziger Bridge just days after the levees broke.
lead_paragraph: A police oversight board in Louisiana on Thursday permanently stripped the credentials of four former New Orleans officers who were convicted for their roles in killing unarmed civilians on a bridge in the chaotic days after Hurricane Katrina nearly 20 years ago.

headline: Paul-Henri Nargeolet, Known as ‘Mr. Titanic,’ Dies at 77
abstract: One of the five people aboard the Titan submersible when it imploded, he died near the Titanic wreckage that he had visited dozens of times.
lead_paragraph: Paul-Henri Nargeolet, a renowned French maritime expert and submersible pilot, became a leading authority on the R.M.S. Titanic through 37 successful journeys to its wreckage. He was killed on his 38th attempt when the submersible craft in which he was traveling with four others imploded, the U.S. Coast Guard announced on Thursday. He was 77.

headline: Remembering Cormac McCarthy and Robert Gottlieb
abstract: Two giants of the literary world died last week. In this episode, the Book Review celebrates their lives.
lead_paragraph: Last week was a somber one in the world of letters. June 13 saw the death of the great novelist Cormac McCarthy, author of “All the Pretty Horses,” “No Country for Old Men” and “The Road,” among many other acclaimed books. Then, June 14 saw the death of the great editor Bob Gottlieb, who worked with writers from Toni Morrison to Joseph Heller to John le Carré — and, maybe most famously, with Robert Caro, the author of “The Power Broker” and a multivolume biography of Lyndon B. Johnson that remains to be finished.

headline: Money Can Buy a Visit to Space or the Deep Sea, but It Can’t Guarantee Safety
abstract: The Titan submersible tragedy spotlights the issues around rescue operations and government oversight as an increasing number of wealthy thrill seekers undertake risky adventures and expeditions.
lead_paragraph: Mountaineers have long climbed atop Mount Everest, and scientists in submersibles have descended into the Antarctic Ocean. In recent decades, travelers with deep pockets and little expertise have joined these explorers or even ventured further, paying to visit the bottom of the ocean or the edge of space, touching the literal bounds of Earth. But as the deaths of five people aboard the Titan submersible make evident, there are no clear safeguards in place when something goes wrong.

headline: Former Trump Campaign Official in Talks to Cooperate in Jan. 6 Inquiry
abstract: The office of the special counsel is negotiating with Michael Roman, who was closely involved in the efforts to create slates of pro-Trump electors in states won in 2020 by Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: Michael Roman, a top official in former President Donald J. Trump’s 2020 campaign, is in discussions with the office of the special counsel Jack Smith that could soon lead to Mr. Roman voluntarily answering questions about a plan to create slates of pro-Trump electors in key swing states that were won by Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Margaret Gilleo, 84, Dies; Made a Yard Sign a Free-Speech Beacon
abstract: An antiwar sign she put up in 1990 led to a legal clash with a wealthy suburb of St. Louis. The case made it all the way to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Gilleo, who turned a local dispute over an antiwar sign on her lawn into a freedom-of-speech showdown at the Supreme Court, died on June 8 at her home in Ladue, Mo. She was 84.

headline: ‘The Bear’ Finds Optimism in the Dysfunctional World of Hospitality
abstract: With a gentler tone and reverence for restaurants, the Hulu show reaches beyond the chef to give other workers the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for the Hulu series “The Bear.”

headline: Biden Denounces Abortion Bans, Warning That Privacy Is Next
abstract: The president sought to galvanize supporters a year after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade as Democrats hope the issue helps them win next year’s elections.
lead_paragraph: President Biden denounced on Friday new restrictions on abortion imposed in Republican-led states in the year since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and warned that the right to privacy, which has been the foundation for other rights like same-sex marriage and access to birth control, could be at risk next if Democrats do not win next year’s elections.

headline: Arizona Governor Says Prosecutors Cannot Enforce Abortion Law
abstract: Gov. Katie Hobbs, a Democrat, says she is doing what she can to protect abortion rights in a state with a 15-week ban on the procedure.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Katie Hobbs of Arizona on Friday stripped local prosecutors of the power to criminally charge abortion providers, a move aimed at protecting abortion rights in a narrowly divided political battleground.

headline: Barry Diller Ends Talks to Sell The Daily Beast
abstract: Mr. Diller said he had considered combining The Daily Beast with Ankler Media, a start-up co-founded by Janice Min, a longtime magazine editor.
lead_paragraph: The media mogul Barry Diller has pulled The Daily Beast off the auction block.

headline: OceanGate Founder Pushed to Expand Deep Sea Travel Despite Chorus of Concerns
abstract: After his early astronaut dreams were cut short, Stockton Rush was determined to open up underwater exploration and saw his company as the “SpaceX for the ocean.”
lead_paragraph: From the start, the plan had been to push boundaries — to go where no one had gone before, as Richard Stockton Rush III liked to say. One partner was experienced in start-ups and passionate about “making humanity a multiplanet species.” The other, Mr. Rush, was an aerospace engineer and investor with a family fortune. Both had once dreamed of going to space.

headline: Google News Blocked in Russia as Feud With Mercenary Leader Intensifies
abstract: At least five telecommunications companies have blocked the service, which aggregates news from various sources, according to an analysis from NetBlocks, an internet observatory.
lead_paragraph: Several Russian internet service providers are preventing users inside the country from accessing Google News after Russian generals accused a mercenary leader, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, of attempting a coup.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Report Finds No Clear Evidence of Covid Origins in Wuhan Lab
abstract: A declassified report says that the illnesses of three laboratory researchers in 2019 do not support or refute the theory that the virus that causes Covid could have slipped out of a lab.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence agencies do not believe the case of three workers from a laboratory in Wuhan, China, who became ill in 2019 can help shed light on whether the Covid-19 pandemic originated from an accidental lab leak, according to a report made public Friday.

headline: Who is Yevgeny Prigozhin, the mercenary leader Russia accused of mounting a coup?
abstract: Mr. Prigozhin has risen from a businessman known as President Vladimir V. Putin’s “chef” to a symbol of wartime Russia, controlling a private army operating from Ukraine to Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin became rich through his personal ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, winning lucrative catering and construction contracts with the Russian government while building a mercenary force known as Wagner.

headline: Line on a Map?
abstract: Spencer Leach and Quiara Vasquez combine forces on a scintillating Saturday challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This crossword represents the meeting of two minds that we first encountered earlier this year in sparkling debut puzzles. Quiara Vasquez shared a byline with Dan Ziring on a popular themed Thursday grid in January; Spencer Leach’s first effort was a witty Saturday one from just six weeks ago.

headline: Hollywood Directors Ratify Their Contract as Writers Continue to Strike
abstract: The vote prevented the doomsday scenario of three major Hollywood unions striking simultaneously. The actors’ union is still negotiating.
lead_paragraph: Unionized movie and television directors approved a new three-year contract with Hollywood studios on Friday, with 87 percent voting in support.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Delay Trump Documents Trial to December
abstract: The special counsel argued that the August date set by the judge did not allow enough time to deal with the complications of classified evidence, but still proposed a relatively speedy timetable.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel, has asked a federal judge to move back the start of the trial of former President Donald J. Trump and his co-defendant, Walt Nauta, in the classified documents case from August to Dec. 11, according to a Justice Department filing made public late Friday.

headline: Debris From Russian Missile Kills Three in Kyiv Apartment Building
abstract: The capital came under attack as anxiety grew in Russia over a confrontation between Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces fired more than 20 missiles at Ukraine’s capital in a predawn assault on Saturday that left at least three people dead.

headline: Quotation of the Day: If You Can Outrun the Green Flashes, You’ll Set a Record
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We used to start running barefoot, then we got shoes, then they got spikes and now they have carbon plates. That’s sport. Now we have a Wavelight, and in 50 years there will be something different again.”

headline: Corrections: June 24, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about President Biden’s attempt to bolster ties with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India incorrectly characterized Mr. Modi’s joint news conference with Mr. Biden. It was a rare instance of Mr. Modi taking questions from reporters at a news conference during his nine years leading India, but not the first time.

headline: Wagner Chief Prigozhin Appears in Videos at a Russian Military Headquarters
abstract: The head of the mercenary group claimed to have control of parts of the complex in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the mercenary Wagner group, claimed to have control of several important military facilities in southern Russia in the city of Rostov-on-Don. Video verified by The New York Times shows that he had entered a key military complex on Saturday morning.

headline: Video Shows Wagner Fighters Surrounding Military Headquarters
abstract: Men in military uniforms, whom filmers and bystanders identified as Wagner fighters, surrounded and then occupied a Russian military headquarters compound in the city of Rostov-on-Don on June 24.
lead_paragraph: Men in military uniforms, whom filmers and bystanders identified as Wagner fighters, surrounded and then occupied a Russian military headquarters compound in the city of Rostov-on-Don on June 24.

headline: What’s happening in Russia? Here’s what we know.
abstract: A powerful mercenary chief sent his forces on the move against the Russian military establishment, raising tensions in the country to a level not seen in decades.
lead_paragraph: A powerful mercenary military leader brought in by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to help salvage his floundering invasion of Ukraine turned his guns on the Russian Army this weekend, and his tanks prowled the streets of his own country.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Harvard Scholar Who Studies Honesty Is Accused of Fabricating Findings
abstract: Questions about a widely cited paper are the latest to be raised about methods used in behavioral research.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two decades, dozens of behavioral scientists have risen to prominence pointing out the power of small interventions to improve well-being.

headline: Democrats Feel the Heat From the Right in New York Primaries
abstract: The Queens district attorney and several City Council members face more conservative challengers who are criticizing them on issues including public safety.
lead_paragraph: When Melinda Katz ran for Queens district attorney in 2019, her principal opponent in the Democratic primary was a public defender and democratic socialist with a platform of ending cash bail and eventually abolishing the police.

headline: After Extra Large Rate Increase, Bank of England’s Critics Multiply
abstract: Pressure is building in Britain for the bank’s governor, Andrew Bailey, to show that policymakers have a handle on the inflation problem.
lead_paragraph: “Mortgage misery for millions.” “Rate rise nightmare.” These were just two of the grim headlines on Britain’s front pages taking aim at the Bank of England on Friday, the day after it announced a surprisingly large increase in interest rates.

headline: What to Know About the Election in Sierra Leone
abstract: In Saturday’s vote, President Julius Maada Bio is seeking a second five-year term to pursue an ambitious if unfulfilled education initiative, while the country is facing a crippling economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: Since he became president of the small West African nation of Sierra Leone in 2018, Julius Maada Bio has dedicated 22 percent of the country’s budget to education, a policy that has sent an additional one million children to school and received attention from international backers.

headline: John Williams on ‘Indiana Jones’ and His Favorite Scores
abstract: In a long career making music for the movies, the composer has made an indelible contribution to cinema. Williams shares his thoughts on some landmark works.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic honored the work of the film composer John Williams this past spring, the director Steven Spielberg introduced a clip of the opening scenes of “Raiders of the Lost Ark” — without the music. The effect, he noted apologetically, was like something out of the French new wave.

headline: Lessons Learned From a Decade of Answering Your Real Estate Questions
abstract: In her final entry as The New York Times’s Ask Real Estate columnist, Ronda Kaysen reflects on what it means to give endless advice.
lead_paragraph: Q: For 10 years, Ronda Kaysen answered New Yorkers’ questions each week as The New York Times’s Ask Real Estate columnist. Now, as she shifts her focus to writing more feature articles for The Times, she looks back on what she’s learned. How did she answer the hardest questions and what parting words would she give to anyone seeking housing advice?

headline: Want to Avoid a Rainy Ceremony? This Weather Expert Can Help.
abstract: If you’re planning a wedding, Andrew Leavitt can help you bypass snowstorms, avoid wet feet during high tides and pinpoint the time of the day with the most shade.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Leavitt can advise couples on where to hold their wedding ceremonies, what hairstyles work best outside or whether to forgo the buttercream frosting on a wedding cake — all based on the weather.

headline: Is That ‘Hava Nagila’ I’m Hearing at the Club?
abstract: The beloved Jewish folk song, which is about a century old, is appearing more and more at sporting events, private parties and trendy bars.
lead_paragraph: On a Monday afternoon in May, “Hava Nagila,” the infectious Jewish folk song, was reverberating through the Monte-Carlo Beach Club, a resort on the Mediterranean Sea in Monaco. The music was coming from a cliff-side, open-air venue, where revelers dressed in suits and dresses were dancing in circles and swirling cloth napkins in the air.

headline: Five Things to Know One Year After the Dobbs Decision
abstract: The Supreme Court ruling that overturned Roe v. Wade has produced some unexpected legal and political changes, as well as a shift in public opinion.
lead_paragraph: In the year since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, some of the results of the decision have been unsurprising — more than a dozen Republican-led states have moved to ban most abortions, and dozens of abortion clinics have closed. Yet there have also been unexpected legal and political changes that have left Americans on both sides of the issue scrambling to adapt. Here are five major changes detailed in The New York Times’s coverage of the first anniversary of the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, which ended the constitutional right to abortion after nearly 50 years.

headline: Scientists Debut Lab Models of Human Embryos
abstract: Four teams have coaxed human stem cells to organize themselves into embryo-like forms. The advance could shed light on fertility.
lead_paragraph: In its first week, a fertilized human egg develops into a hollow ball of 200 cells and then implants itself on the wall of the uterus. Over the next three weeks, it divides into the distinct tissues of a human body.

headline: How Did a $2 Billion Trove of Art End Up in a Random Attic in France?
abstract: In a new book, Michael Finkel tells the story of Stéphane Breitwieser, “perhaps the most successful and prolific art thief who has ever lived.”
lead_paragraph: At first, Stéphane Breitwieser, the subject of Michael Finkel’s “The Art Thief,” appears to be having an enviable amount of fun. Twenty-five years old and living with his girlfriend, Anne-Catherine Kleinklaus, in a small set of upstairs rooms in his mother’s home in a “hardscrabble” manufacturing suburb in eastern France, Breitwieser is unburdened by such quotidian concerns as a job, making rent or planning for the future. He fancies himself a purer sort of soul, so devoted to beauty he must, in Finkel’s words, “gorge on it.” Over the course of a dizzying 200 pages that are also an effective advertisement for Swiss Army knives (Breitwieser’s only tool), he removes artwork after artwork from museums — a.k.a. “prisons for art” — and becomes “perhaps the most successful and prolific art thief who has ever lived.” He piled all $2 billion worth of artifacts he amassed over eight years into that same attic in his mother Mireille Stengel’s “nondescript” stucco house.

headline: Pride’s Last Chance in a Tennessee City
abstract: Last year, drag shows at the Franklin, Tenn., Pride celebration turned into a national scandal. We followed a teenage member of Franklin Pride’s board during this year’s embattled process of throwing a small-town Pride festival.
lead_paragraph: Last year, drag shows at the Franklin, Tenn., Pride celebration turned into a national scandal. We followed a teenage member of Franklin Pride’s board during this year’s embattled process of throwing a small-town Pride festival.

headline: Sterling K. Brown Is on His Best Behavior, Just in Case
abstract: The Emmy-winning actor and star of the new movie “Biosphere” is sweet on vegan cookies, his Audi e-Tron and Toni Morrison’s “The Bluest Eye.”
lead_paragraph: The first time Sterling K. Brown read the script for “Biosphere,” his new sci-fi movie with Mark Duplass, he thought, “‘This is very non-Randall-esque,’ which is always one of the criteria that I’m looking for in the next project.”

headline: Stymied by Congress, Biden Seeks to Rally Voters on Abortion
abstract: A year after the end of Roe v. Wade, Biden administration officials are working with a limited set of tools, including executive orders and the bully pulpit, to galvanize supporters.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after the Supreme Court voted to overturn Roe v. Wade last summer, a group of West Wing aides raced to the Oval Office to brief President Biden on the decision. As they drafted a speech, Mr. Biden was the first person in the room to say what has been his administration’s rallying cry ever since.

headline: The Race to Prevent ‘the Worst Case Scenario for Machine Learning’
abstract: A.I. companies have an edge in blocking the creation and distribution of child sexual abuse material. They’ve seen how social media companies failed.
lead_paragraph: Dave Willner has had a front-row seat to the evolution of the worst things on the internet.

headline: TikTok Is Our DJ Now. It’s Playing a Lot of Meghan Trainor.
abstract: The video app drives streams on Spotify and influences the Billboard charts. Years after she broke through as a musician, the singer is gaining new fans, one viral dance soundtrack at a time.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Trainor, the pop star, is sitting in an empty marble bathtub, fully clothed and flanked by two of her friends. The three of them begin soulfully crooning an a cappella version of “Made You Look,” the hit single Ms. Trainor released in the fall, nailing every note for about half a minute. Then they stop, look at one another and scream with delight.

headline: ‘The Impossible Became Possible’: The Women Celebrating a Year Without Roe
abstract: For anti-abortion activists, the anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision eliminating the national right to abortion is festive, but also a time to acknowledge challenges.
lead_paragraph: It has been exactly a year since Bethany Bomberger gathered in an impromptu huddle outside a hotel ballroom with fellow anti-abortion activists, overcome with gratitude and optimism as news broke that the Supreme Court had overturned Roe v. Wade just hours before the Pro-Life Women’s Conference officially opened.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 17-23
abstract: In pursuit of Queen Bee, it was good to find “king” and hard to find “nankeen.”
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: ‘Padam Padam’: You Hear It and You Know It’s Pride
abstract: Kylie Minogue’s latest single appears to be on the fast track to gay-classic status. We asked D.J.s booked for Pride events to weigh in on the track’s devoted cult following.
lead_paragraph: When “Padam Padam,” the Australian pop star Kylie Minogue’s 77th (77th!) single, was released last month, it was embraced almost instantaneously by a certain type of listener. L.G.B.T.Q. people, especially gay men, greeted the campy song with gleeful incredulity, and its infectious chorus quickly spawned memes upon memes upon memes.

headline: Tiny Bundles of Hope: Critically Endangered Turtles Hatch in Myanmar
abstract: Local conservationists at Indawgyi Lake captured the first known videos of rare Burmese peacock turtles hatching.
lead_paragraph: Small miracles are popping out of the mud around Myanmar’s largest lake: Burmese peacock softshell turtles, just hatched from their eggs. For what may be the first time, humans were there to witness the birth of these rare creatures.

headline: Saudi Arabia Wants Tourists. It Didn’t Expect Christians.
abstract: In a fluid new age for the conservative Islamic kingdom, evangelicals have become some of its most enthusiastic visitors.
lead_paragraph: The caravan of five Toyota Land Cruisers raced across Saudi Arabia’s rocky desert, weaving onto a highway so new it was not on the map. At the cleft of sea that splits the kingdom from Egypt, they stopped on a barren beach. Fifteen tourists spilled out and gathered around Joel Richardson, a Kansas preacher.

headline: This City Had Quietly Celebrated Pride Before. In 2023, That Was Not an Option.
abstract: After right-wing activists portrayed a Pride event in Franklin, Tenn., as a threat to children, the small city unexpectedly found itself at the center of a backlash.
lead_paragraph: As dozens of cars snaked their way onto the grounds of a refurbished horse farm on a sweltering June afternoon in Franklin, Tenn., a few volunteers stood at the entrance, cheerfully welcoming visitors to the local Pride festival.

headline: What Is Love? For This Fractured Family, the Answer Is Not So Clear.
abstract: In Thao Thai’s debut novel, “Banyan Moon,” the contentious relationship between a mother and daughter comes to a head when their family’s beloved matriarch dies.
lead_paragraph: In Thao Thai’s debut novel, “Banyan Moon,” Huong Tran, one of the story’s protagonists, confides, “After years of living with my mother, her prudishness and stingy love caging me tight, I longed desperately for something free, something that felt attached to me and no one else.” Feelings of entrapment and spite are prominent in this book, a multi-perspective family saga that chronicles the lives of three Vietnamese women from 1960s Vietnam to present-day Florida.

headline: Family Politics as a Predictor of Mayhem on a Bigger Scale
abstract: In her new novel, “Little Monsters,” Adrienne Brodeur takes readers on a stressful march toward a patriarch’s 70th birthday party.
lead_paragraph: Adrienne Brodeur’s “Little Monsters” is cleverly calculated to push all the buttons for a wide swath of women. Like her 2019 memoir “Wild Game,” which examined the role Brodeur played in her mother’s long affair with a family friend, “Little Monsters” is a tale of dysfunction and buried secrets, set in and around moneyed Cape Cod.

headline: Why Hunter, Britain’s Best Known Wellie, Fell From Grace
abstract: Blaming supply chains, inflation and changing weather patterns, the Wellington boot brand stumbled toward the brink of extinction this week. Can it be saved by a new (American) owner?
lead_paragraph: For decades, one fashion accessory was more synonymous with Britain’s most famous music festival, Glastonbury, than any other: Hunter Wellington boots.

headline: Greek Youths, Shaped by Debt Crisis, Plan to Vote for Stability
abstract: Many children of Greece’s traumatic years of economic collapse have opted for pragmatism over radicalism and say they will back a conservative on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Days before this Sunday’s election in Greece, three young women with piercings and ironic T-shirts who sat outside a hipster coffee shop in an Athens neighborhood best known as a hub of anarchist fervor said they wanted stability.

headline: In the U.S., an Accomplished Cuban Boxer Takes His First Pro Steps
abstract: Andy Cruz won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics for Cuba. Now he’s learning to fight like a professional in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: When the timer chimed to begin Round 3, Andy Cruz stalked Rostyslav Sabadash behind a stiff jab.

headline: Killing of Sikh Leader Raises Fears in British Columbia
abstract: Members of the Sikh community in Surrey believe that Hardeep Singh Nijjar, the president of a local temple, was killed because of his political views.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, after riddling a car with bullets in a parking lot, two masked, heavyset men made a run for it and jumped into a getaway vehicle near a Sikh temple in Surrey, British Columbia, the police said.

headline: U.S. Government Moves to Expand Health Care to Pacific Veterans
abstract: Citizens of three Pacific Island nations, eligible to serve in the U.S. military, have faced a Catch-22 in gaining access to certain benefits. That may change soon.
lead_paragraph: After decades of neglect, the U.S. government is one step closer to eliminating longstanding obstacles to free health care for veterans from three Pacific Island nations.

headline: Religious Controversies on Many Fronts in the U.S.
abstract: Readers discuss ordaining women, separation of church and state, and Christian nationalism.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: We Need to Talk About Overturning the Dobbs Decision
abstract: It won’t be easy, and it probably won’t be quick. But there needs to be a plan in place.
lead_paragraph: The end of Roe v. Wade spawned a momentous realignment of abortion politics and legal strategy in the United States. Almost a third of states in this country now ban almost all abortions, while more than a third have passed new laws protecting abortion rights — with many legal battles playing out in state and federal courtrooms. The issue has dominated elections, from surprise ballot initiative results in red states to an anomalous midterm election.

headline: The Conservative Position on Birth Control Is About Individual Responsibility
abstract: At the heart of the conservative position on birth control is whether contraception is a positive right or a personal choice.
lead_paragraph: Most Republican voters — 84 percent of them, according to a 2022 poll on behalf of the organization where I work — support safe and accessible birth control. But after Roe v. Wade was overturned last year, Republicans in Congress blocked legislation that would have enshrined a federal right to contraception. And it was Republicans who opposed requiring health insurance policies to cover birth control in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010.

headline: Coming Out Late — and Finding a New Life in Midlife
abstract: Many people, including me, come out in later adulthood. Our stories are not only uplifting but also illuminating and educational.
lead_paragraph: “I’m from Harlem. Born, bred, toasted, buttered, jelly-jammed and honeyed in Harlem.”

headline: The Real Lesson From the Hunter Biden Saga
abstract: It isn’t about presidential corruption but a determined parent battling his son’s addiction with unconditional love.
lead_paragraph: One of our most urgent national problems is addiction to drugs and alcohol. It now kills about a quarter-million Americans a year, leaves many others homeless and causes unimaginable heartache in families across the country — including the family living in the White House.

headline: I Thought No One Had Felt Grief Like Mine. Then I Saw ‘The Bear.’
abstract: A lot of television shows portray the experience of grieving. But after my own tragic experience, only “The Bear” felt authentic to me.
lead_paragraph: The pilot episode of “The Bear,” FX’s frenetic series about a high-end chef who takes over his family’s blue-collar sandwich shop, opens with an unsettling image. In the dead of night in Chicago, a man in an apron — we later learn that this is Carmen (Carmy) Berzatto, played by Jeremy Allen White, the series’s main character — walks over a fog-enshrouded bridge, cautiously approaching a large cage. Inside it, something is growling. The man swings the door open wide and confronts a great, angry bear. At first, he tries to soothe the beast, whispering, “I know.” But the bear lunges at him. The man wakes — it’s a dream and, we suspect, not the first time he’s had it — and heads off to face the suffocating anxiety that marks his daily life.

headline: Go Ahead. Debate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
abstract: If no one contests him publicly, how can the curious be persuaded away from his ideas?
lead_paragraph: In my younger and more vulnerable years, I was asked to fill in for a debate on the shores of Nantucket, after a last-minute cancellation by a more prominent combatant. The subject was God and religion, and I served as defender of faith against the prosecutorial efforts of Christopher Hitchens.

headline: Save Turner Classic Movies
abstract: Movies from the past shape our present.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I co-starred with Sir Alec Guinness in a movie where a submersible travels down to the Titanic, springs a leak and implodes.

headline: Listen Early to This American Life: Greetings, People of Earth
abstract: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Crisis in Russia
abstract: A Russian mercenary leader claimed he controls a military headquarters in southern Russia, and Vladimir Putin vowed to take action.
lead_paragraph: A long-running feud over the invasion of Ukraine between the Russian military and Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of Russia’s private Wagner military group, escalated into an open confrontation over the past day.

headline: Extreme Travel Is Inspiring New Types of Insurance
abstract: Some offer evacuations and others provide coverage for accidental death or injury to cater to the growing adventure tourism market.
lead_paragraph: The tragic deaths of five people on a tour to see the Titanic shipwreck this week have put the risks of extreme travel into focus. But despite the dangers, travel to out-there locations like the South Pole, remote mountaintops, shark-infested waters and space is becoming more popular.

headline: H. Lee Sarokin, Federal Judge Who Freed Hurricane Carter, Dies at 94
abstract: In his 15 years on the U.S. District Court bench in Newark, he also ruled on high-profile cases involving the tobacco industry and the rights of homeless people.
lead_paragraph: H. Lee Sarokin, who as a federal judge in New Jersey overturned the triple-murder conviction of the star boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, voided a public library’s ban against a homeless man and angered cigarette companies that claimed he had shown bias against them, died on Tuesday in the La Jolla section of San Diego, where he and his wife, Margie, lived in retirement. He was 94.

headline: Putin embraced turmoil, and now it is rattling his leadership.
abstract: For more than two decades, the system helped President Vladimir V. Putin secure his unrivaled authority, ensuring that he personally held the keys to wealth and influence in modern Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia always seemed to thrive on chaos. Then it threatened to consume him.

headline: With Reversed Hind Legs and a Loose Tongue, a New Ugly Dog Champion Is Crowned
abstract: “In the cutest way possible, he kind of reminds me of a hairy hippopotamus,” said Catherine Liang, a judge in the competition.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was Scooter’s resemblance to a glossy black jelly bean that earned him the title on Friday night as champion of the World’s Ugliest Dog Contest.

headline: Paul Ickovic, Photographer at Home on the Street, Dies at 79
abstract: His camera captured the variety of the human experience, but changing tastes in photography kept him from the acclaim he sought — as did his own idiosyncrasies.
lead_paragraph: Paul Ickovic, a peripatetic photographer whose sensuous black-and-white portraits and evocative images of street life captured in India, Nepal and Cuba, as well as European cities like Paris and Prague, harked back to the heyday of street photography at midcentury, died on May 23 at his home in Prague. He was 79.

headline: Republicans Serve Up Red Meat for a Reason
abstract: Why haven’t we heard a serious discussion on climate change from G.O.P. candidates?
lead_paragraph: There are, as of Saturday, at least 13 people running for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination: former President Donald Trump; his U.N. ambassador Nikki Haley, his vice president, Mike Pence; Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida; Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota; the former governors Chris Christie of New Jersey and Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas; Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina; the former representative Will Hurd of Texas; Mayor Francis Suarez of Miami; and the entrepreneurs and media personalities Vivek Ramaswamy, Perry Johnson and Larry Elder.

headline: The Hollywood Producer Who Could Bring Down Israel’s Netanyahu
abstract: Arnon Milchan, the movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of Benjamin Netanyahu, is about to testify at the Israeli prime minister’s corruption trial.
lead_paragraph: The life story of Arnon Milchan, billionaire Hollywood mogul and secret agent, could have been made for the silver screen: He produced blockbusters like “Pretty Woman,” “Mr. & Mrs. Smith” and “Bohemian Rhapsody,” and also made a fortune from arms dealing, including covert exploits procuring weapons for Israel, his native country.

headline: Extreme Floods and Heat in China Ravage Farms and Kill Animals
abstract: China’s leader has made it a national priority to ensure the country can feed its large population. But weather shocks have disrupted wheat harvests and threatened pig and fish farming.
lead_paragraph: The downpour began in late May, drenching the wheat crops in central China. As kernels of wheat blackened in the rain, becoming unfit for human consumption, the government mobilized emergency teams to salvage as much of the harvest as possible. In a viral video, a 79-year-old farmer in Henan Province wiped away tears as he surveyed the damage.

headline: How a Crypto Fugitive Upended the Politics of a Troubled Balkan Nation
abstract: Only days before an election in Montenegro, a letter from Do Kwon, the fugitive founder of the Luna digital coin, claimed that crypto “friends” had provided campaign funding to a leading candidate.
lead_paragraph: Already notorious as an agent of market mayhem, the crypto industry has now unleashed political havoc, too, upending a critical general election in Montenegro, a troubled Balkan nation struggling to shake off the grip of organized crime and the influence of Russia.

headline: Ship That Launched Ill-Fated Titan Submersible Returns to Newfoundland
abstract: Investigators boarded the Polar Prince, which docked at the Atlantic headquarters of the Canadian Coast Guard, looking for answers.
lead_paragraph: Escorted to a Canadian Coast Guard base, the ship that launched the ill-fated Titan submersible returned from international waters to its home port, St. John’s, Newfoundland, on Saturday morning, where investigators boarded it looking for answers.

headline: Tracking the Military Convoys on the Route to Moscow
abstract: Wagner’s leader announced that his troops marching on Moscow would “turn around.”
lead_paragraph: Military convoys believed to belong to Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s Wagner forces have been seen at various points along Russia’s major M-4 highway, which leads to Moscow. In at least two areas along the route, clashes have broken out. The route shown here is approximate.

headline: Living in a Barbie World, Through the Decades
abstract: A new project from the Real Estate desk uses stop-motion to take readers inside Barbie’s Dreamhouses.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon last summer, Anna Kodé, a reporter on the Real Estate desk at The New York Times, and Nikita Stewart, the desk’s editor, were talking about the upcoming “Barbie” film when, naturally, the conversation turned to Barbie’s personal pad, the Dreamhouse.

headline: Timeline: What Led to the Standoff Between Russia and Prigozhin
abstract: The leader of the Wagner mercenary group had kept a low profile for years, only acknowledging his force’s existence in September of last year.
lead_paragraph: For years, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner mercenary leader who conducted a brief rebellion against the Russian military, had been a loyal supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: As Putin’s Trusted Partner, Prigozhin Was Always Willing to Do the Dirty Work
abstract: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the mercenary leader of the Wagner Group, had earned the trust of Vladimir V. Putin. Then he staged a mutiny that rattled the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the mercenary leader who led an armed rebellion in Russia on Saturday, was never afraid of a dirty task, many say.

headline: Rebel Wagner Forces, Threatening March to Moscow, Abruptly Stand Down
abstract: The mercenary group had seized the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, the center of Moscow’s military operations in Ukraine, posing a grave threat to President Vladimir Putin’s government.
lead_paragraph: A domestic security crisis that threatened the government of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared to ease late Saturday, when a mercenary tycoon, whose forces had seized critical facilities in southern Russia and begun an armed march on Moscow, abruptly stood down after cutting a deal that allowed him and his fighters to escape prosecution.

headline: Opposites Attracting
abstract: John Westwig delivers a Sunday puzzle that’s simply dazzling.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Georgia Police Department Apologizes for Using Targets With Photo of a Black Man
abstract: The mayor called for an investigation after the Villa Rica Police Department shared photos of a gun safety training with attendees firing at targets with a photo of a Black man on them.
lead_paragraph: A police department in Georgia apologized this week after its use of firing range targets with photos of a Black man on them at a gun safety class prompted outrage in the community.

headline: Three San Antonio Police Officers Charged With Murder in Woman’s Shooting Death
abstract: The officers fired at Melissa Perez after responding to a call outside her home.
lead_paragraph: Three San Antonio police officers were charged with murder on Friday after police shot and killed a 46-year-old woman, who swung a hammer in their direction and appeared to be in distress, in her home, officials said.

headline: Victor Wembanyama Buzz Has San Antonio Businesses Eager to Cash In
abstract: The Spurs selected Wembanyama, a French basketball star, No. 1 overall in the N.B.A. draft on Thursday. San Antonio has been celebrating for weeks.
lead_paragraph: Mark Burnett can’t get Victor Wembanyama out of his head. Well, he could, but it would be like taking a knife to the “Mona Lisa.”

headline: U.S. Suspected Prigozhin Was Preparing to Take Military Action Against Russia
abstract: The information was considered both solid and alarming because of the possibility that a major nuclear-armed rival of the United States could descend into chaos.
lead_paragraph: American intelligence officials briefed senior military and administration officials on Wednesday that Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of the mercenary Wagner Group, was preparing to take military action against senior Russian defense officials, according to officials familiar with the matter.

headline: Short-Lived Mutiny in Russia Sheds Light on Putin’s Hold on Power
abstract: The armed standoff on the road to Moscow, brief as it was, represented the most dramatic struggle for power in Russia in decades.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, American officials have quietly asked themselves a question they would not dare pose in public: Could Russia’s botched invasion of Ukraine eventually lead to the downfall of President Vladimir V. Putin?

headline: Montana Derailment Sends 10 Freight Cars Into the Yellowstone River
abstract: Cars carrying molten sulfur or asphalt plunged into the river after a Montana Rail Link train derailed and a bridge collapsed on Saturday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Ten cars from a freight train plunged into the Yellowstone River in Montana on Saturday after a derailment and a bridge collapse, causing asphalt and molten sulfur cargo to spill into the water, the authorities said.

headline: How a Rebellion in Russia Unfolded Over 36 Hours
abstract: From 11 a.m. Friday to 11 p.m. Saturday, here are the key events from Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s armed uprising.
lead_paragraph: From 11 a.m. Friday to 11 p.m. Saturday, here are the key events from Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s armed uprising.

headline: In Pitch to Evangelicals, Trump Casts Himself as Christian Crusader Who Helped End Roe v. Wade
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump told an evangelical gathering that no president had done more for Christians than he did.
lead_paragraph: One year after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, former President Donald J. Trump reminded a gathering of evangelical activists in the nation’s capital how he had shaped the court’s conservative supermajority that ended nearly 50 years of constitutional protections for abortion.

headline: ‘Everybody in the N.F.L. Understands That It’s a Violent Game’
abstract: Luke Kuechly retired from the N.F.L. while at his peak and has worked to raise awareness of brain trauma. The former linebacker discussed his love for football and what he tells parents of the 12-year-olds he coaches.
lead_paragraph: When Luke Kuechly retired from the N.F.L. in 2020 at 28, he had played eight stellar years as a linebacker for the Carolina Panthers and had sustained at least three documented concussions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: H. Lee Sarokin, 94, Judge Who Freed ‘Hurricane’ Carter, Is Dead
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “If we wish to shield our eyes and noses from the homeless, we should revoke their condition, not their library cards.”

headline: Corrections: June 25, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 6 this weekend about an immersive “The Great Gatsby” theatrical performance misstates how the character Jay Gatsby comes to an end. He is found dead in a pool, where he has been shot, not drowned.

headline: Dancing, Jubilation, and Worries About L.G.B.T.Q. Rights at Pride March
abstract: Support for L.G.B.T.Q. people has risen, but so have attacks against them, even in a city known for the strength of its community.
lead_paragraph: An unbroken parade of marchers — some dancing and jubilant, some set with determined purpose — filled Fifth Avenue and the streets of Greenwich Village in Manhattan on Sunday for the New York City Pride March, even as a foreboding backdrop from threats both local and national hung over the day’s slate of events.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Badge of Solidarity
abstract: The U.S. government named 22 defendants in its suit to stop The Times from publishing the Pentagon Papers. Two Times journalists designed a way to show support for their colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Vietnam War protesters whose tactics made them the target of government prosecution won notoriety in the 1960s and ’70s under collective designations like the Chicago Seven, the Harrisburg Seven and the Catonsville Nine.

headline: ‘His Friends Joined In Excitedly and Filmed the Encounter’
abstract: A birthday on the 1 train, a terrific coat stands out and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: He Was Handcuffed and Hospitalized. Now He’s on Track for Housing.
abstract: A contentious New York City policy to send more mentally ill homeless people to hospitals has helped some move into permanent homes.
lead_paragraph: On the coldest night of the winter, Mazou Mounkaila was sleeping under an overpass in the Bronx when the ambulance crew arrived.

headline: How Far Would You Go for Midcentury Furniture?
abstract: The owners of Lanoba, a shop that specializes in Danish modern design, find most pieces by going door to door.
