lead_paragraph: The credenza in the back of the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter van groaned as Lars Balderskilde drove through the woodlands near Vejle, a city on a fjord about two and a half hours from Copenhagen.

headline: He Tried to Save a Friend. They Charged Him With Murder.
abstract: They bought $30 worth of fentanyl before making it into rehab. One overdosed. The other was charged in his death.
lead_paragraph: Josh Askins woke up in the crawl space of an abandoned house with nausea, chills and a shooting pain in his legs. It had been seven hours since he last smoked fentanyl, and already he could feel his withdrawal symptoms worsening by the minute. He rolled over in his sleeping bag and stared at the graffiti he’d carved into the rotting floorboards. “Fentanyl is HELL,” he had written a few weeks earlier, but now he got up to start looking for more.

headline: ‘Twilight Zone: The Movie’ and the Deadly Accident That Plagued It
abstract: It’s been 40 years since the release of the film, but questions of what risks are permissible in the making of art have persisted.
lead_paragraph: When the anthology film “Twilight Zone: The Movie” opened on June 24, 1983, reviews were mixed; The New York Times’s Vincent Canby deemed it “a flabby, mini-minded behemoth,” and that was a fairly representative view. A middling box office performer, the film may well have been forgotten entirely were it not for another news event, related to the picture, reported that same day: the unsealing of the grand jury indictments against five of the filmmakers, including the director John Landis, for their responsibility in a stunt gone horrifyingly awry, killing three people during the picture’s production.

headline: Just Made a Queer Memory? Drop a Pin.
abstract: Queering the Map, a crowdsourced digital atlas, has collected over half a million intimate recollections from anonymous contributors.
lead_paragraph: Name an L.G.B.T.Q. landmark. Perhaps it’s the Stonewall Inn on Christopher Street in Manhattan. Maybe it’s Castro Camera, Harvey Milk’s shop in San Francisco, or even the Coral Sea Islands, where activists started their own micronation to advocate the legalization of gay marriage in Australia.

headline: As Legal Fees Mount, Trump Steers Donations Into PAC That Has Covered Them
abstract: A previously unnoticed change in Donald Trump’s online fund-raising appeals allows him to divert a sizable chunk of his 2024 contributions to a group that has spent millions to cover his legal fees.
lead_paragraph: Facing multiple intensifying investigations, former President Donald J. Trump has quietly begun diverting more of the money he is raising away from his 2024 presidential campaign and into a political action committee that he has used to pay his personal legal fees.

headline: For Natalia Ginzburg, ‘The Road to the City’ Was Strewn With Hurdles
abstract: The Italian writer’s first book, a novella originally published in 1942, establishes the themes — including thwarted desire and the challenges of family life — for which she became known.
lead_paragraph: What a ridiculous undertaking adolescence is, that span of years when one is bulldozed by uncontrollable and unknowable chemical spasms, when the past is deemed useless and discarded immediately, and the future — whatever that is — is the only thing that matters. One races toward it blindly, with the emotional sensitivity of a cannonball, while simultaneously being forced to decide, ingloriously, prematurely, who to be. It’s good not to take adolescence too seriously, but is there any other way to take it?

headline: New England Island Life Meets Spy Thriller? Look No Further.
abstract: In “The Beach at Summerly,” Beatriz Williams weaves two standbys of summer fiction into one escapist story.
lead_paragraph: There are moments when busy bibliophiles on holiday want to use precious downtime to bury their Coppertoned noses in a novel designed to be read poolside. These books might conjure memories of summers past: romances that flourished under the hot sun but cooled with autumn’s onset, a state of innocence that didn’t yet connect recklessness with consequences, the bittersweet awareness that summer invariably passes in the flash of a lightning bug.

headline: Becoming ‘Self-Made’ Stars in a Secular Age
abstract: In a breezy new history of personal branding, Tara Isabella Burton comes face to face with Oscar Wilde, Frederick Douglass, Kim Kardashian and more.
lead_paragraph: The Kardashians have sold so much to America — shapewear, cosmetics, beverage upon beverage — why not throw ideas onto the pile?

headline: How a Recycling Leader Spends His Sundays
abstract: Ryan Castalia, the head of the nonprofit “Sure We Can,” is also part of an experimental theater group.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Ryan Castalia was juggling jobs to support his acting habit when he started working at Sure We Can, a recycling and sustainability hub in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Two years later, he was named the executive director of the nonprofit, which also provides support for canners, or those who collect recyclables for a living.

headline: Barbiecore Is Surging Its Way into Home Décor and Interior Design
abstract: The upcoming movie and maximalism have sparked a palette made up primarily of hot pink.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Hansen loves a hot pink moment. “I think I just naturally am such a pink froufrou girl. All my stuff. Everything I buy is always a little bit Barbie-esque,” she said. “So it has taken over.”

headline: A.I.’s Use in Elections Sets Off a Scramble for Guardrails
abstract: Gaps in campaign rules allow politicians to spread images and messaging generated by increasingly powerful artificial intelligence technology.
lead_paragraph: In Toronto, a candidate in this week’s mayoral election who vows to clear homeless encampments released a set of campaign promises illustrated by artificial intelligence, including fake dystopian images of people camped out on a downtown street and a fabricated image of tents set up in a park.

headline: Putin’s Beast That Would Now Devour Him
abstract: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the paramilitary Wagner Group, has been driven to fury by a mismanaged war in Ukraine. He turned on his creator, before apparently reversing course.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of a month I spent in the Russian capital, the red-and-black billboards of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s Wagner paramilitary group multiplied. “Join the team of victors!” they said, beneath an image of menacing mercenaries in balaclavas and masks, only their eyes visible.

headline: Jury in Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial to Begin Weighing Death Penalty
abstract: Over the next several weeks, lawyers for Robert Bowers will try to persuade the jury that convicted him to spare his life.
lead_paragraph: This week the real trial begins for Robert Bowers, the man who killed 11 worshipers in a Pittsburgh synagogue on Oct. 27, 2018.

headline: What Financial Planning Looks Like for L.G.B.T.Q. People
abstract: The cost of family planning and transition care — and other personal finance stories from L.G.B.T.Q. people.
lead_paragraph: I married my wife last October in a backyard wedding that my parents hosted and covered for $5,000. My wife’s mother gave us an equivalent honeymoon fund to fly us to France, and our guests were also generous, giving us — to our surprise — a few thousand dollars to start our new lives.

headline: Taiwan Faces a #MeToo Wave, Set Off by a Netflix Hit
abstract: A torrent of sexual harassment accusations has prompted questions about the state of women’s rights on an island democracy that has long been one of Asia’s most progressive places.
lead_paragraph: In the past few weeks, a wave of #MeToo allegations has raced to the very top of Taiwan’s political, judicial and arts scenes, forcing a new reckoning of the state of women’s rights on a democratic island that has long taken pride in being among Asia’s most progressive places.

headline: How to Build a Scent Smorgasbord for Mosquitoes
abstract: To study how the African malaria mosquito homes in on its human targets, researchers built an enormous “flight cage.” in rural Zambia.
lead_paragraph: For a bloodthirsty, global health threat, the African malaria mosquito, Anopheles gambiae, has surprisingly discriminating taste. It prefers feeding on humans to other animals, is more attracted to some people than others and even then appears to have a particular predilection for feet.

headline: Philip Schuyler Is Knocked Off His Pedestal in Albany
abstract: A statue of the Revolutionary War general, newly prominent thanks to the musical “Hamilton,” has been removed from its place outside Albany City Hall because he enslaved people.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when one probably had to be a committed Revolutionary War buff or an aficionado of early Albany aristocracy to know the name Philip J. Schuyler.

headline: Here’s a Look at the Water Crises That Might Be Coming to You Soon
abstract: Bangladesh, a river delta nation, is on the front line of climate change. Its coping strategies could offer lessons for the wider world.
lead_paragraph: Bangladesh is a land of water. Its silty rivers rush down from the Himalayas, spill into a filigreed maze of ponds, wetlands and tributaries before emptying into the blustery, black Bay of Bengal.

headline: Jenna Lyons, Unlikely Housewife
abstract: The famously stylish former president of J. Crew has joined the rebooted “Real Housewives of New York City.” Why?
lead_paragraph: Here is how it happened: Jenna Lyons was at the Wing in SoHo in December 2021, giving an interview to a podcast called “Dyking Out,” having recently been advised that she wasn’t doing enough to represent her community of gay women.

headline: Guatemala Voters Cast Ballots in Contentious Election
abstract: The election in the Central American nation is marked by the exclusion of top candidates and calls to crack down on violent crime.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Guatemala, the most populous nation in Central America, cast ballots on Sunday in presidential elections that are drawing attention to what many observers called the erosion of the rule of law.

headline: A Vast Lake Has Captivated California Where Farms Stood a Year Ago
abstract: Tulare Lake re-emerged after intense storms battered the state this winter, and will likely remain in the Central Valley for months — and maybe years — to come.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like the sea and approaches the size of Lake Tahoe. Its wind-driven waves are unexpectedly silky and warm. Tulare Lake seems to go on forever on the immense brown and green flat of California’s Central Valley, shimmering like a great blue mirage.

headline: As a Gay Man, I’ll Never Be Normal
abstract: As a closeted teen, I prayed fervently to be normal. What I was really praying for is comfort.
lead_paragraph: L.G.B.T.Q. folks have a peculiar interest in normalization. Normalize men in dresses. Normalize trans athletes. Normalize throuples. Normalize fetishes. Here a norm, there a norm, everywhere a norm-norm. Every norm everywhere all at once.

headline: The Legal Foundation of Women’s Sports Is Under Fire
abstract: Evidence is overwhelming that there is a significant average difference between male and female athletic performance.
lead_paragraph: What is the legal foundation for women’s sports? It’s a simple question with a surprisingly complex answer. After all, the most potent federal statute supporting parallel men’s and women’s sports leagues would appear — on its face — to also prohibit separate leagues. Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972 states, “No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity receiving federal financial assistance.”

headline: Death and Displacement Return to Darfur
abstract: The violent conflict in Sudan is expanding quickly.
lead_paragraph: ADRE, Chad — The janjaweed are back.

headline: It’s Not Too Late for the Republican Party
abstract: The G.O.P. needs to have the reckoning with Trump that it vainly hoped would never be necessary.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump this month became the first former or incumbent American president to be charged with crimes against the nation that he once led and wishes to lead again. He cynically calculated that his indictment would ensure that a riled-up Republican Party base would nominate him as its standard-bearer in 2024, and the last few weeks have proved that his political calculation was probably right.

headline: The Pittsburgh Gunman Didn’t Just Kill 11 Jews. He Killed a Minyan.
abstract: Jews need 10 Jews to pray. When one of the 10 is killed, our religious practice is radically altered.
lead_paragraph: During the trial of Robert Bowers, who was convicted of the 2018 murders of 11 Jews in Pittsburgh at the Tree of Life synagogue building, I kept thinking about the testimony of Stephen Weiss. Mr. Weiss, a retired public school science teacher and longtime ritual director for Tree of Life, was one of the 11 people who survived the attack. During the trial, he told the court that in the years since the event, “We don’t have the same attendance.” He explained that the synagogue lost members who could be counted on to make the minyan, the essential quorum of 10 Jews required for certain prayers. “They were killed.”

headline: Crisis Abated
abstract: Vladimir Putin averted a threat that came closer than anything else has to endangering his hold on power.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin has apparently survived the boldest challenge to his 23-year autocratic rule in Russia.

headline: Overlooked No More: Dolores Alexander, Feminist Journalist and Activist
abstract: She was a reporter, executive director of the National Organization for Women and owner of the restaurant Mother Courage, which became a hub for women.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Hollywood Tycoon Testifies in Netanyahu’s Corruption Trial
abstract: Arnon Milchan, a movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, is a key witness. He gave the Netanyahus gifts, he said, sometimes at their request.
lead_paragraph: In one of the more dramatic moments in the yearslong corruption trial of Benjamin Netanyahu, Arnon Milchan, a Hollywood movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of the Israeli prime minister, took the stand on Sunday as a key witness for the prosecution in an alleged gifts-for-favors affair known as Case 1000.

headline: Can Everyone Take a Sabbatical?
abstract: We all need a rest.
lead_paragraph: Olatunde Sobomehin, the chief executive and co-founder of StreetCode Academy, a Silicon Valley-based nonprofit that offers free tech classes to people from communities of color, thought that taking a sabbatical would be impossible. But his thinking began to change as he read and learned more about the practice.

headline: After the Club Q Shooting, Questions of Money and Justice for Victims
abstract: Just before they are set to face the accused shooter in court, some survivors of the Colorado mass shooting are frustrated over payouts from a fund to help them.
lead_paragraph: Ashtin Gamblin never realized how expensive it would be to survive a mass shooting.

headline: Are Biofuels Bad for the Environment?
abstract: Responses to an essay warning against the environmental and humanitarian risks of farm-grown fuels. Also: Single-payer health care; whitewashing history.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fish Tacos al Pastor, Stained Delicious With a Complex, Brick-Red Adobo
abstract: Serve with a pineapple pico de gallo and plenty of warm corn tortillas.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. One of the great joys of being a reporter for the Food section of The New York Times is the chance to go into restaurant kitchens to learn how a chef prepares a dish you love, and then figure out how to make that same dish at home.

headline: Pope Offers Prayers for ‘Vatican Girl’ Who Disappeared 40 Years Ago
abstract: Francis expressed “closeness” to the family of Emanuela Orlandi, whose disappearance has captivated Italians for decades — and now the world, thanks to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Sunday marked the 40th anniversary of the kidnapping of Emanuela Orlandi, the 15-year-old daughter of a Vatican employee whose disappearance remains one of Italy’s most enduring mysteries and recently was the subject of a Netflix series.

headline: At 80, Meredith Monk Is Still Seeking Ways to Communicate
abstract: The staged premiere of her new work “Indra’s Net” in Amsterdam comes as a set of recordings offers a retrospective of one of our most humane artists.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Monk stepped out onto a circular stage, her stride paced yet fluid. She wore an all-white costume that seemed to belong to neither time nor place, and her signature braids, flowing from a neat part at the top of her head, bounced lightly over her shoulders. She didn’t sing at first, but when she did, she let out a clear, clean soprano sound.

headline: One Big Winner of Kremlin-Wagner Clash? The Dictator Next Door.
abstract: The strongman leader of Belarus, a dependable ally of Vladimir Putin’s, may see a chance to rebrand himself as a statesman.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir V. Putin is known for his tight control over the news media in Russia. His onetime ally, the Wagner military group founder Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, is himself the owner of a conservative media outlet and a flamboyant showman on social media.

headline: Human Remains Found in Area Where Actor Julian Sands Went Missing
abstract: Mr. Sands, 65, was reported missing in January after he went hiking alone on a trail on Mount Baldy in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Southern California recovered human remains on Saturday near the mountain where search crews have been looking for the British actor Julian Sands, who was reported missing in January.

headline: Harry Markowitz, Nobel-Winning Pioneer of Modern Portfolio Theory, Dies at 95
abstract: He overturned the traditional approach to buying stocks by examining the relationship between risk and reward.
lead_paragraph: Harry M. Markowitz, an economist who launched a revolution in finance, upending traditional thinking about buying stocks and earning the Nobel in economic science in 1990 for his breakthrough, died on Thursday in San Diego. He was 95.

headline: A Séance With Ryuichi Sakamoto at the Shed
abstract: “Kagami,” a new mixed-reality presentation, features a virtual likeness of the late composer. It becomes, mostly despite itself, an affecting meditation on grief.
lead_paragraph: “Kagami,” the new “mixed reality” concert of Ryuichi Sakamoto’s music by the production company Tin Drum is meant to be a profound experience, a groundbreaking achievement in virtual reality that expands the visual limits of recorded performance. In practice, it feels like a wake in a laser tag arena. In some ways that’s unavoidable; Sakamoto, one of Japan’s most internationally recognized artists, died in March, so any presentation of his music so soon is hard pressed to avoid a funereal pallor. This one doesn’t escape that fate.

headline: Blinken Says Wagner Rebellion Shows the Cracks in Putin’s Power
abstract: A brief revolt by the leader of the Wagner mercenary group was a challenge to the authority of President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the secretary of state said during TV appearances on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Sunday that the brief rebellion led by the head of the Wagner Group, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, revealed cracks emerging in President Vladimir V. Putin’s hold on power and cast doubt on the future of his war in Ukraine.

headline: In Texas, Heat That Can Make You Faint
abstract: Soaring temperatures above 100 degrees are expected to linger across much of the state well into the coming week.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage as brutal heat and humidity engulfs the U.S.

headline: With Resounding Win in Greece, Kyriakos Mitsotakis Tightens Grip on Power
abstract: His party’s election victory comes as the country experiences strong economic growth, with voters seemingly willing to look past scandals and disasters that have tarnished his government.
lead_paragraph: Greek voters on Sunday overwhelmingly re-elected the conservative New Democracy party, preliminary results showed, setting the stage for its leader, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, to strengthen his grip on power with an absolute majority and what he called a “strong mandate” for the foreseeable future.

headline: With Wagner’s Future in Doubt, Ukraine Could Capitalize on Chaos
abstract: The group played an outsize role in the campaign to take Bakhmut, Moscow’s one major battlefield victory this year. The loss of the mercenary army could hurt Russia’s ambitions in the Ukraine war.
lead_paragraph: To some Ukrainian forces, soldiers from the Wagner Group were the best-equipped fighters they had seen since Russia invaded last year. To others, it was their training that distinguished them: Ukrainian soldiers recalled battlefield stories of aggressive tactics or a sniper downing a drone with a single shot.

headline: Thompson Twins Are Ready for the N.B.A., but Not to Split Up
abstract: Amen and Ausar Thompson said they’ve never spent more than two days apart. This is how they spent their last week together before heading to their new N.B.A. teams.
lead_paragraph: Amen Thompson and his twin brother, Ausar, sat side by side amid a swirl of tourists at Carmine’s restaurant in Times Square on Monday around 8 p.m. They had flown into New York that morning for the N.B.A. draft at Barclays Center, and now they were trying to decide what dishes to share with their family. Their father, Troy, who is also their agent, ordered sautéed chicken, spaghetti with shrimp and a Caesar salad with anchovies on the side.

headline: Revolt Raises Searing Question: Could Putin Lose Power?
abstract: Russians with ties to the Kremlin expressed relief that the mercenary leader’s mutiny did not spark a civil war. But they agreed that Vladimir Putin had come off looking weak in a way that could be lasting.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin long styled himself as Russia’s guarantor of stability and the uncompromising protector of its statehood.

headline: Rita Reif, Antiques and Auctions Columnist, Dies at 94
abstract: She worked at The Times for decades, and she made news herself when she challenged ownership of a painting thought to have been looted by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Rita Reif, who worked her way up from low-rung newspaper jobs to spend decades covering the worlds of antiques and auctions for The New York Times, and who made news herself in the late 1990s when she challenged the ownership of an Egon Schiele painting thought to have been stolen from a relative of her late husband by the Nazis, died on June 16 in Washington. She was 94.

headline: Russia’s State Media Blamed Prigozhin, But Some Criticism of Putin Surfaced
abstract: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of Wagner forces, appeared to have little popular support for his uprising. Still, some voices expressed criticism of President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: The opening line of the Kremlin’s flagship weekly news program on Sunday night made the official position clear regarding the 24-hour mutiny staged by Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the mercenary leader who sent his troops marching on Moscow only to pull them back at the last moment.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of a Russian Revolt
abstract: Also, a gunpowder shipment from China and a #MeToo wave in Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: The day after an armed rebellion by Wagner mercenaries against Vladimir Putin’s government was defused at the last minute, neither Putin nor the mercenary leader, Yevgeny Prigozhin, made a public appearance, adding to the sense of uncertainty and confusion pervading Russia. The swirl of events over the last few days has left questions about Putin’s authority and the future of the war in Ukraine.

headline: Don Harold, Sneaky Subway Preservationist, Dies at 91
abstract: He played an essential role in the creation of the New York Transit Museum by helping to save vintage train cars — sometimes using subterfuge.
lead_paragraph: Don Harold, a subway aficionado who sometimes used subterfuge to save vintage train cars from the junkyard — cars that are now among the star attractions of the New York Transit Museum in Downtown Brooklyn — died on June 14 in a nursing home in Bayside, Queens. He was 91.

headline: Little Bitty
abstract: Delight in this choice puzzle by Taylor Johnson and Christina Iverson.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: Gripped by Uncertainty After Mutiny, Russians Note Absence of Kremlin Leaders
abstract: Neither Vladimir V. Putin nor the leader of the Wagner mercenary group made public appearances on Sunday, a day after an armed rebellion shook the nation.
lead_paragraph: Confusion and uncertainty pervaded Russia on Sunday, with neither President Vladimir V. Putin nor Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the head of a mutinous mercenary group, appearing anywhere in public a day after the most profound government crisis in three decades — an open military rebellion — appeared defused.

headline: At Least 1 Dead After Tornadoes Are Reported in Indiana
abstract: An official in Martin County, Ind., said that one person died and another was injured, but that rescuers were continuing to search for victims.
lead_paragraph: At least one person was killed and another was injured in southern Indiana on Sunday when storms battered parts of the South and the Ohio River Valley, causing power outages to hundreds of thousands of customers.

headline: Opposition Accuses Sierra Leone’s Military of Election Weekend Assault
abstract: Supporters and party officials from the All People’s Congress were sifting through polling data from the presidential vote when the military surrounded party headquarters.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Senior officials from Sierra Leone’s main opposition party on Sunday accused the country’s military of shooting live ammunition and tear gas into their headquarters, raising tensions in the small West African nation a day after presidential elections.

headline: Jesse McReynolds, Lead Singer in Long-Running Bluegrass Duo, Dies at 93
abstract: Also a mandolinist, he performed alongside his brother, Jim, in an act that lasted 55 years. He continued performing after his brother’s death.
lead_paragraph: Jesse McReynolds, who for 55 years was the lead singer and mandolin player with the first-generation bluegrass duo Jim & Jesse, died on Friday at his home in Gallatin, Tenn. He was 93.

headline: A Pill Form of Ozempic Is on the Horizon
abstract: Research published Sunday evaluates the effectiveness of the active ingredient in injectable diabetes and obesity drugs when taken orally.
lead_paragraph: The next iteration of Ozempic and Wegovy — the much-discussed, hard-to-obtain injectable medications known for their ability to induce weight loss — may come in pill form.

headline: ‘Invisible’ Review: Brown, British and Overlooked
abstract: As part of the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, Nikhil Parmar’s solo play is a drama-tinged satire that morphs into a grisly revenge parable.
lead_paragraph: In the world of Nikhil Parmar’s funny, fantastical solo play “Invisible,” the mind-set of Britain has undergone a significant shift. One of the West’s favorite boogeymen — the Islamic fundamentalist — has vanished from the public imagination. Chinese terrorists are the designated bad guys now.

headline: Trump Campaigns in Michigan, a Battleground That’s Tinted Blue
abstract: With their party out of power, some Republicans in the state are worried that the former president could cost Michigan its status as a swing state.
lead_paragraph: In front of a sold-out crowd on Sunday evening in Novi, Mich., former President Donald J. Trump lamented the decline of the automobile industry under Democratic rule and said he “stood up to China” to save thousands of manufacturing jobs.

headline: Intensifying Rains Pose Hidden Flood Risks Across the U.S.
abstract: In some of the nation’s most populous areas, hazardous storms can dump significantly more water than previously believed, new calculations show.
lead_paragraph: As climate change intensifies severe rainstorms, the infrastructure protecting millions of Americans from flooding faces growing risk of failures, according to new calculations of expected precipitation in every county and locality across the contiguous United States.

headline: Sprinting Toward Running’s Red Carpet
abstract: The fashion runway to the locker room has become ubiquitous in professional sports like basketball and football. Can the walk into a running event become the same thing?
lead_paragraph: A few hours before some of the world’s fastest runners would run a few hundred meters very quickly, they were invited to walk some 30 meters very slowly.

headline: Salary Law Requires Transparency, Up to a Point
abstract: The law now mandates that companies post salaries, but some are listing broad ranges.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll see how a New York City law that took effect late last year is helping workers entering the job market.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: The fallout from an attempted mutiny in Russia.
lead_paragraph: Confusion and uncertainty pervaded Russia yesterday, with neither Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, nor Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of a mercenary force known as Wagner, appearing in public the day after an open military rebellion led by Prigozhin appeared defused. (Here’s how the mutiny unfolded.)

headline: No Corrections: June 26, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Bachelorette’ and ‘Casa Susanna’
abstract: The 20th season of the reality dating show premieres on ABC, and PBS presents a documentary about a safe home for trans women in the ‘50s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 26 — July 2. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Deal for Formula 1 Team Reflects Growing U.S. Interest in the Sport
abstract: The actor Ryan Reynolds, the private equity firm RedBird Capital and Otro Capital are among the investors taking a stake in Renault’s Alpine team.
lead_paragraph: As media companies and big technology firms vie for sports viewers, investors have begun to look beyond the traditional avenues to teams and sports that only a few years ago had low profiles in the United States.

headline: Word of the Day: betrothal
abstract: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word betrothal has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 27 in “‘Polite Society’ Review: Pride and Plenty of Fists” by Amy Nicholson:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: What Is Happening in the Housing Market?
abstract: Home construction surged in May and prices have ticked up, even with interest rates at a 15-year high. The resilience has surprised some economists.
lead_paragraph: Gianni Martinez, 31, thought that it would be fairly easy to buy an apartment.

headline: Day Care for Less Than $10: How Canada Is Easing the Burden for Parents
abstract: A national program is reducing day care fees to as low as 10 Canadian dollars, about $7.60, per day, a relief for families even as a surge in demand has created obstacles.
lead_paragraph: As Susana Ibarra’s maternity leave was ending and she was preparing to return to her office outside Toronto, she still faced a big challenge: finding care for her son and then figuring out how to pay for it.

headline: Why Mark Ruffalo and Wendell Pierce Are Fighting for a Crumbling Church
abstract: Congregants of the West Park Presbyterian Church, a Manhattan landmark, want it torn down and replaced by condos. Celebrities are joining the fight to save it.
lead_paragraph: For years, a conflict over whether to tear down one of New York City’s historic churches, a 19th-century Romanesque Revival building on the Upper West Side, has been cast in epic terms, as a battle between the little people and big business.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: How the Shortage of a $15 Cancer Drug Is Upending Treatment
abstract: Older generic chemotherapy drugs remain scarce, forcing doctors to put a priority on the patients who have the best chance of survival.
lead_paragraph: Tony Shepard learned he had vocal cord cancer this spring, but he was encouraged when his doctor said he had an 88 percent chance at a cure with chemotherapy and radiation.

headline: A High-Profile Primary Tests Black Buffalo’s Political Power Structure
abstract: Zeneta Everhart, whose son was gravely wounded in the racist mass shooting in Buffalo, and India Walton, who nearly unseated the city’s mayor, are facing off on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — They are two of the most prominent Black women in Buffalo politics: India Walton, a celebrated progressive insurgent, jarred by a painful election loss; and Zeneta Everhart, a rising newcomer, galvanized by a singular terrifying event.

headline: Trapped in the Crossfire of the U.S.-China Rivalry
abstract: Suriname, a tiny nation ravaged by recession, inflation and impossible debts, saw its relief held up by superpower politics. It won’t be the only country.
lead_paragraph: Inside his capacious office, his tan curtains drawn against the tropical sun, the president of Suriname expressed sympathy with the striking teachers who were massing outside, taunting him while demanding higher wages.

headline: How Short Is Too Short for Men’s Pants?
abstract: A reader wants to experiment with higher hemlines — but men’s exposed ankles have been a source of fashion world strife.
lead_paragraph: The male ankle! Or mankle. (I love word hybrids.) Of all the body parts to be a source of controversy, this is one of the oddest. Yet the question of whether to show or not to show the masculine talus (the official name of that knobby bone between the tibia, fibula and heel) has been a topic of debate for years. In 2005, Thom Browne, the designer who has almost single-handedly been trying to raise men’s hemlines, told The New York Times that the ankle was “the new male cleavage.”

headline: 75 Years Ago, ‘The Lottery’ Went Viral. There’s a Reason We’re Still Talking About It.
abstract: “The Lottery” is a classic short story because of its power to unsettle us. Too bad readers today are losing their appetite for discomfort.
lead_paragraph: On a warm, sunny June morning, village residents gather in the tranquil main square. They’ve assembled to conduct an ancient ritual, the meaning of which has been lost to time. One by one, they draw slips of paper from an old wooden box.

headline: We All Live in ‘South Park’ Now
abstract: Farhad Manjoo on how the offensive cartoon encapsulates America.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts and narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows that we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: The Nature of Joy
abstract: We all exist in a magnificent, fragile body, beautiful and vulnerable at once.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Thanks to a Covid infection early in the pandemic, my blood pressure goes haywire when the temperature and dew point are both very high, and I have trouble breathing when the air quality is poor, too, so I stay indoors much of the summer now. But last Sunday I woke early to the most beautiful day in the history of the world, as my brother calls every day of his life. All around my yard, the world was renewing itself.

headline: $1.7 Million Homes in California
abstract: An 1888 Craftsman home in Berkeley, a midcentury retreat in Palm Springs and a French Normandy house in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: This was one of the first homes built in Panoramic Hill, a neighborhood named for its sweeping views of the surrounding area and, on a clear day, San Francisco Bay. Built in the late 19th century, it was altered and moved to its present location in the early 20th century. Edward Taylor Parsons, an early owner, was a director of the Sierra Club and entertained important naturalists of the day in the library.

headline: A Dangerous Shift Is Underway in the West Bank
abstract: Ultranationalist West Bank settlers who have recently attacked Palestinian towns and villages seem to want to wedge out their Palestinian neighbors.
lead_paragraph: In April 1988, as a reporter for Haaretz, I attended the funeral of a 15-year-old West Bank settler, Tirza Porat, who was accidentally shot to death by a fellow settler. Ms. Porat was participating in a hike of teens from a settlement near the city of Nablus when, following a confrontation with Palestinian rock throwers in a nearby village, a young settler opened fire, mistakenly killing Ms. Porat.

headline: The Uneven Effect of Remote Work, in One List
abstract: This ranking of jobs by percentage of remote work also helps explain why the pandemic has left more scars in certain areas.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of the pandemic, economists have extensively studied the effects of remote work on many facets of life, including office demand and the housing market. And, well, writers like those of us at The Upshot have extensively written about all of this, too.

headline: While We Wait for the Supreme Court to Make Up Its Mind …
abstract: The fine print is what really matters when it comes to affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, I hope your summer is off to a great start. We’re in the season of Supreme Court decisions, waiting any day for the Harvard and U.N.C. ruling to come down. Assuming the court overturns affirmative action for private and public universities, and maybe beyond that, what do you think the effect will be?

headline: Club Q Shooter Pleads Guilty in Court
abstract: A plea deal means the 23-year-old shooter will spend a lifetime in prison for a rampage at an L.G.B.T.Q. bar in Colorado Springs last year that left five people dead.
lead_paragraph: The 23-year-old assailant who carried out a deadly shooting rampage at Club Q in Colorado Springs pleaded guilty on Monday to dozens of charges of murder and attempted murder, avoiding a prolonged trial over an attack on members of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

headline: How Are New Yorkers Handling the Costs of Child Care?
abstract: The New York Times is interested in exploring how New York City residents are navigating the costs and challenges of care.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is interested in exploring how New York City residents are handling child care. We are hoping to speak with people about navigating the costs and other challenges.

headline: How Review-Bombing Can Tank a Book Before It’s Published
abstract: The website Goodreads has become an essential avenue for building readership, but the same features that help generate excitement can also backfire.
lead_paragraph: Cecilia Rabess figured her debut novel, “Everything’s Fine,” would spark criticism: The story centers on a young Black woman working at Goldman Sachs who falls in love with a conservative white co-worker with bigoted views.

headline: Prigozhin and the Long and Infamous History of Failed Russian Rebellions
abstract: Putin may emerge weakened, strengthened or vindictive.
lead_paragraph: Whatever Yevgeny Prigozhin intended his rebellion to achieve, it proved short and senseless. Less than 24 hours after he sent his tanks and troops trundling on the main highway toward Moscow, the mercenary chief was persuaded to turn them around and take refuge himself in Belarus. The question now is what will happen in the next act, particularly whether the failed mutiny will leave President Vladimir Putin weakened, strengthened or vindictive.

headline: ‘Flamin’ Hot’ Is So Bad, It Burns
abstract: By depicting a world in which Latinos need the approval of white people to feel good about ourselves, it reinforces the myth of white superiority.
lead_paragraph: “Flamin’ Hot,” a movie released this month and recently screened on the South Lawn of the White House, is a piece of propaganda designed to make Mexican Americans, and Latinos more broadly, feel good about ourselves. There’s nothing inherently wrong with creating a film that seeks to make a person or a group feel good. (See: the genre of feel-good movies.) It can even be affirming to see yourself reflected in various media.

headline: U.S. Vaccine Program Now Flush With Cash, but Short on Key Details
abstract: A $5 billion federal program aims to make better Covid vaccines. But vaccine makers are confused by murky regulatory guidance.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to develop the next generation of Covid vaccines are running up against bureaucratic hassles and regulatory uncertainty, scientists say, obstacles that could make it harder to curb the spread of the coronavirus and arm the United States against future pandemics.

headline: How to Stop Sweating So Much
abstract: Excessive swampiness can be an inconvenience, especially in the summer, but several treatments are available.
lead_paragraph: Summer is the season of swimming, sunbathing — and sweating. As the heat index climbs, our bodies work hard to keep us cool.

headline: Sally Saul Is Finally in Control
abstract: At 77, the artist’s clay sculptures are fiercer than ever.
lead_paragraph: Entering the sculptor Sally Saul’s studio in Germantown, N.Y., two hours north of New York City, it feels as though you’ve happened upon some strange conference between man and animal. There is very little hanging on the white walls of the work space, which occupies the first of two floors in a building that, covered with green corrugated metal, resembles an upgraded shed. But across the floor and atop tables are lumpy earthen depictions of tree-dwelling creatures beside prominent historical figures like the American novelist Gertrude Stein. The cross-species interactions are mostly benign, as in a vignette where a girl seated on a stump is flanked by two kind-looking roosters. But some have more of an editorializing bite: To address her frustrations with Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s abortion rulings, Saul cast him as being eternally tormented by three pudgy spiders. “Some pieces are sweeter, and then I think, ‘I want to make something that’s fiercer,’” she says. “I go back and forth.”

headline: Umbria by Train: A Journey Into the ‘Green Heart of Italy’
abstract: Three hill towns in this landlocked region offer cultural riches, culinary delights and wondrous views. Here’s how to get to them from Rome and Florence.
lead_paragraph: Calling itself the green heart of Italy, the landlocked region of Umbria is known for its truffles and olive oil, roast pork and sausage, wine and cheese.

headline: French Montana Lists His Los Angeles Mansion
abstract: The seven-bedroom house also has garages for five cars, a game room and a wine cellar, but the rapper is ready to move on and diversify his real estate portfolio.
lead_paragraph: Karim Kharbouch, better known by his stage name French Montana, is bidding adieu to his 1.35-acre compound in Los Angeles’s exclusive Hidden Hills neighborhood, asking $22.75 million for the seven-bedroom, nine-bath home in one of the city’s most celebrity-studded communities.

headline: A Big Leaguer Lost His Fastball but Not His Will to Compete
abstract: Julio Teheran’s journey from All-Star to the independent leagues and back has been crucial for the Brewers. It doesn’t matter that he can’t break 90 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: Julio Teheran is a big leaguer. This is a statement of fact, because he pitches for the Milwaukee Brewers now, and not the Staten Island FerryHawks, as he did last season. But it’s also an identity, a presence. Many players wear a major league uniform, but not all have the moxie to go with it.

headline: Why the 1932 Movie ‘Freaks’ Is a Touchstone for Disability Representation
abstract: Though it has detractors, scholars and advocates have largely embraced this film for the way it shows people just living their lives while disabled.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s track record for portraying people with disabilities has been sketchy at best. There have been inspirational figures, noble martyrs and lovable oddballs — some of these performances garnering Academy Awards — but there aren’t a lot of people simply living their lives.

headline: 75 Years After ‘The Lottery’ Was Published, the Chills Linger
abstract: Stephen King, David Sedaris, Carmen Maria Machado and others on how Shirley Jackson’s eerie classic first got under their skin.
lead_paragraph: In its June 26, 1948, issue, The New Yorker published Shirley Jackson’s unsettling story “The Lottery,” and it’s not an overstatement to say that readers freaked out. They wrote letters in droves, angry or unsure about what this slowly unfolding portrait of small-town mob violence was doing in a literary-minded magazine. Now considered an American classic, the story went on to become a classroom mainstay, and a bracing influence on artists prone to see the rot in the flower bed. Here, 75 years later, 13 writers and filmmakers — plus Jackson’s graphic-novelist grandson — recall reading “The Lottery” for the first time, and why it’s stayed with them since.

headline: Bingeing in Comfort This Summer
abstract: Dinner and a show — that is, eating in front of the TV — only gets easier with the right furniture and a can-do attitude.
lead_paragraph: The finale of “Succession” might have left die-hard fans wondering what Kendall was going to do with the rest of his life, but everyone else can now turn their attention to the summer television season.

headline: Review: ‘The Bear’ Changes Course(s)
abstract: Season 2 of the restaurant dramedy is more uplifting, more team-focused and more magnificent.
lead_paragraph: This review discusses plot points throughout Season 2 of FX’s “The Bear,” now airing in full on Hulu.

headline: In Isolated Guam, Abortion Is Legal. And Nearly Impossible to Get.
abstract: The tiny U.S. territory in the western Pacific Ocean is thousands of miles from the nearest state, and has no resident doctors who perform abortions. Court decisions could cut access to pills, the only legal option left.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Pregnancy Control Clinic, tucked inside a squat, beige building around the corner from a bowling alley, handled most of the abortions on Guam, a tiny U.S. territory 1,600 miles south of Japan.

headline: Let’s Talk About the Bathroom Scene
abstract: Bodily functions rarely get the spotlight in fiction and poetry. But for some writers, they drive action and help create indelible characters.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock once told François Truffaut he wanted to make a film that would examine a city entirely through food and, unusually, waste. He would show the arrival of meat and produce into a metropolis, “its distribution, the selling, how it’s fixed up and absorbed. And gradually, the end of the film would show the sewers, and the garbage being dumped out into the ocean.”

headline: Minefields and Menace: Why Ukraine’s Pushback Is Off to a Halting Start
abstract: The Ukrainian Army is encountering an array of challenges that has complicated the early stages of its counteroffensive, especially the large swaths of minefields. But its leaders are urging patience, insisting the main push is yet to come.
lead_paragraph: The column of Bradley armored vehicles rumbled forward, filled with Ukrainian soldiers, bringing a new and potent American weapon to the war’s southern front.

headline: The Buffet Is Back, Stretching Dollars and Slinging Crab Legs
abstract: These big, communal all-you-can-eat spreads faltered amid pandemic fears, but inflation and a hunger for an experience are giving them new life and variety.
lead_paragraph: The buffet got creamed during the pandemic. Even when diners crept back into restaurants covered in hand sanitizer, a model of eating based on shared serving spoons and food seasoned with the breath of strangers seemed like a goner.

headline: They Ride and Lasso Like Texans. They Live 8,000 Miles Away.
abstract: In the Philippines, men and women compete in an annual rodeo that celebrates a thriving cowboy culture with roots in the Spanish and American colonial eras.
lead_paragraph: A honky-tonk twang echoes across a fairground as cowhands wrangle cattle inside a dirt-floored stadium. The scene would be typical in Texas, but this rodeo is happening about 8,000 miles away, on an island in the Philippines.

headline: Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York, Had Surgery for Breast Cancer
abstract: Ms. Ferguson, the ex-wife of Prince Andrew, had a single mastectomy after a routine mammogram. A spokesperson said her prognosis was good.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York and ex-wife of Prince Andrew, the disgraced son of Queen Elizabeth II, underwent a single mastectomy after a breast cancer diagnosis, she said during an episode of her podcast that was released Monday.

headline: After Cutting Ties With Russia, a Hermitage Museum Outpost Rebrands
abstract: The Hermitage Amsterdam broke away from its St. Petersburg mother ship and will now be called H’Art Museum, presenting works from the Smithsonian, the Centre Pompidou and the British Museum.
lead_paragraph: In March 2022, a week after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the Hermitage Amsterdam museum severed ties with the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg.

headline: Today’s Top News: Harsh New Fentanyl Laws, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Delaware Lawmaker Aims to Be First Openly Transgender House Member
abstract: Sarah McBride is no stranger to firsts: In 2012, she became the first openly transgender person to work at the White House, during the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Sarah McBride announced on Monday that she would run for Delaware’s at-large U.S. House seat — a bid that, if successful, would make her the first openly transgender member of the U.S. Congress.

headline: A 36-Hour Rebellion in Russia
abstract: What does the brief mutiny by the Wagner mercenary force tell us about the future of political power in the country?
lead_paragraph: An armed rebellion in Russia over the weekend stunned the world and amounted to the single biggest challenge to President Vladimir V. Putin’s rule since he came to power 23 years ago.

headline: Belgium Was Out of Hurdlers. So a Shot-Putter Agreed to Run.
abstract: Jolien Boumkwo’s 100-meter hurdles debut was not a stunt. Her team needed the points, and she volunteered.
lead_paragraph: The runner to watch was in Lane 2, and she was hard to miss: Jolien Boumkwo of Belgium was a head taller than every other woman in the second heat of the 100-meter hurdles.

headline: Olivia Chow Elected New Mayor of Toronto, Out of 102 Candidates
abstract: As the leader of Toronto, once considered an affordable model city, Ms. Chow will be tested by the same issues confronting other hubs trying to recover from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Toronto chose Olivia Chow, a left-leaning, veteran politician, as their new mayor at a moment when the city is confronting a litany of issues that are also facing other urban powerhouses trying to rebound from the pandemic.

headline: Murders, on the Decline
abstract: The recent spike in murders already seems to be over.
lead_paragraph: When murder rates spiked three years ago, experts worried that the U.S. was slipping into a violent era that recalled the period between the 1970s and ’90s. But the data this year offers hope that the increase was temporary.

headline: The Most Expensive Team in Baseball Is Not Getting Any Better
abstract: For the Mets, another dispiriting defeat felt like more of the same. “Hopefully,” one Met said, “there’s light at the end of the tunnel.”
lead_paragraph: Nearly halfway through the 2023 season, the most expensive team in Major League Baseball history is closer to last place than first. After a dispiriting 7-6 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday, the Mets and their nearly $500 million roster — once luxury taxes are considered — were left with a 35-42 record, dwindling odds of reaching the playoffs and a growing number of questions.

headline: How New Democracy Surged to Victory in Greece
abstract: Voters seemed to embrace Kyriakos Mitsotakis’s approach to the economy and tough stance on migration, and were less concerned about revelations of spying on the opposition.
lead_paragraph: Kyriakos Mitsotakis, the leader of the conservative New Democracy party who has presided over a period of economic stability and tough anti-migration policies in Greece, was sworn in on Monday for a second term as prime minister after a landslide victory that gave him a clear mandate for the next four years.

headline: Inside Yevgeny Prigozhin’s Money-Making Machine
abstract: The man who led a rebellion against President Vladimir Putin built a multinational commercial enterprise that helped fund his military operations.
lead_paragraph: Global markets are fairly calm on Monday morning after a weekend of turmoil in Russia. And there’s been no word from either President Vladimir Putin of Russia or his rebellious military chief-for-hire, Yevgeny Prigozhin, after Mr. Prigozhin’s aborted march on Moscow.

headline: In his first remarks since his revolt, Prigozhin claims he wasn’t trying to overthrow Putin.
abstract: The Kremlin had said an investigation into Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s role in the brief uprising against Russia’s military command was dropped, but Russian news media reports say the case remains open.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the leader of the Wagner mercenary group who mounted a brief uprising against Russia’s military command over the weekend, broke a long period of silence on Monday to deny, once more, that he had any intention of seizing power with his march on Moscow.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of June 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: How to Stay Safe in California’s Roaring Rivers This Summer
abstract: Melt water from the snowpack that piled up in the Sierra Nevada over a stormy winter has turned normally tame rivers into deadly, raging torrents.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially summer, and for lots of Californians — particularly those who live many miles inland from the beach — that usually means it’s river season: a time for seeking relief from the heat in cool water, wading in shallows or floating in inner tubes.

headline: In Poorer Countries, Obesity Can Signal Financial Security
abstract: A study found that loan officers in Uganda, where information is scarce, were more likely to offer credit to heavier-looking people.
lead_paragraph: In the world’s wealthiest countries, the richer people are, the thinner they tend to be.

headline: How Our New Game, Connections, Is Put Together
abstract: The editor of the game talks about how she makes it feel fun.
lead_paragraph: Connections is a daily game about finding common threads between words. Players must select four groups of four words without making more than four mistakes. Connections beta opened on June 12.

headline: The Terror of Threes in the Heavens and on Earth
abstract: Physicists have long explored how phenomena in groups of three can sow chaos. A new three-body problem, they warn, could lead to not only global races for new armaments but also thermonuclear war.
lead_paragraph: Isaac Newton was baffled. He was already famous for discovering how gravity holds the universe together and for using that knowledge to predict the movements of celestial bodies, such as the moon’s path around the Earth. Now, by taking the sun’s gravitational tugs into account, he sought to improve his lunar predictions. Instead, it made them worse.

headline: Richard Ravitch, Rescuer of the Subways and New York’s Finances, Dies at 89
abstract: He helped New York City avoid bankruptcy in the mid-1970s, ran the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and later served as lieutenant governor.
lead_paragraph: Richard Ravitch, a politically savvy, civic-minded developer and public citizen who helped rescue New York City from the brink of bankruptcy and its decaying subways from fiscal collapse, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: ‘The Idol’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Just a Jealous Guy
abstract: Destiny goes undercover as tensions rise at Jocelyn’s mansion. Tedros’s hair evolves from rattail to ponytail.
lead_paragraph: On the track that plays over opening and closing of this week’s episode of “The Idol,” the Weeknd sings: “I didn’t mean to hurt you. I’m sorry that I made you cry. I didn’t mean to hurt you. I’m just a jealous guy.” It’s the classic text of an abuser now made to sound pretty in Abel Tesfaye’s sensitive warble.

headline: The Republican Field Is Heading to New Hampshire
abstract: Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis and other presidential candidates are traveling to the Granite State this week.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis and other presidential candidates are traveling to the Granite State this week.

headline: Farro With Blistered Tomatoes and Pesto Is a Half-Hour Hero
abstract: Also on the table in 30 minutes (or less): grilled tofu tacos, jerk chicken meatballs and a very versatile ginger-dill salmon.
lead_paragraph: One of the unsung heroes of my prodigious pantry is the pesto in the freezer (I consider my freezer to be part of the pantry). It might not be as chic as chili crisp or as multitask-y as mayo, yet it adds an herby, garlicky brightness to all kinds of meals and requires no extra work (unless you made the pesto yourself and froze it, in which case, yay past you!).

headline: Kelly Clarkson’s ‘Chemistry’ Draws on Familiar Formulas
abstract: With a big voice and big personal changes to sing about, Clarkson ends up with arrangements that don’t match the power and rawness of the emotions fueling them.
lead_paragraph: When a musician known in part for her fiery breakup anthems announces the dissolution of her marriage, fans can sometimes react with an impolite if somewhat understandable presumption: “Well, at least the divorce album will be good.”

headline: 14-Story Building Collapses in Egypt, Injuring at Least 4
abstract: The collapse is one of a several similar disasters in Egypt in recent years. Rescuers were trying to determine if more people were trapped under the rubble.
lead_paragraph: A 14-story apartment building popular with vacationing Egyptians collapsed Monday in Alexandria, Egypt’s second-largest city, and rescuers were working to clear the debris, officials said. At least four people were injured, and others were possibly still missing as of Monday night.

headline: For This Museum, Russian-German Collaboration Got Awkward
abstract: As a Berlin museum with Russian trustees commemorates an allied victory over the Soviet Union, it is also negotiating the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As preparations get underway for the 75th anniversary of the Berlin Airlift, a Cold War victory for western allies over a Soviet blockade, one of the museums mounting a commemorative exhibition is negotiating the fallout from a more recent geopolitical conflict.

headline: An Exhibit Chronicles the Fight for 15
abstract: The exhibit features items worn or carried by labor advocates from around the world.
lead_paragraph: The exhibit features items worn or carried by labor advocates from around the world.

headline: Morgan Wallen Enters Adele Territory With 14th Week at No. 1
abstract: The country singer’s latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” has now notched more weeks atop the Billboard chart than any album in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The country star Morgan Wallen is back on the road after six weeks of rest, and back once again at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, notching his 14th nonconsecutive week on top since the release of his latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” in March.

headline: A.I. May Someday Work Medical Miracles. For Now, It Helps Do Paperwork.
abstract: The best use for generative A.I. in health care, doctors say, is to ease the heavy burden of documentation that takes them hours a day and contributes to burnout.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Matthew Hitchcock, a family physician in Chattanooga, Tenn., has an A.I. helper.

headline: In Classrooms, Teachers Put A.I. Tutoring Bots to the Test
abstract: Newark public schools are cautiously trying out a new automated teaching aid from Khan Academy. The preliminary report card: “could use improvement.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, Cheryl Drakeford, a third-grade teacher at First Avenue Elementary School in Newark, projected a challenging math question on her classroom’s whiteboard: “What fraction of the letters in the word MATHEMATICIAN are consonants?”

headline: Flipping Out
abstract: In danger of scrolling her life away, a writer gets a vintage cellphone.
lead_paragraph: I started flirting with the idea of getting a flip phone while watching a TikTok livestream of someone shaving a grape at 2 a.m.

headline: Teen and Stepfather Die on Hike in Near-Record Texas Heat
abstract: The high-pressure “heat dome” that has engulfed Texas and Oklahoma for several days is forecast to shift eastward this week, bringing dangerous temperatures to the Gulf States.
lead_paragraph: A teenage boy and his stepfather hiking in Big Bend National Park in Texas died as temperatures there rose to 119 degrees Fahrenheit on Friday — the second-highest mark ever recorded in the state — during a triple-digit heat wave that was forecast to spread to the Southeast this week.

headline: John B. Goodenough, 100, Dies; Nobel-Winning Creator of the Lithium-Ion Battery
abstract: An unassuming professor who remained active into his 90s, he is credited with the breakthrough that gave rise to the batteries powering today’s electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: John B. Goodenough, the scientist who shared the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his crucial role in developing the revolutionary lithium-ion battery, the rechargeable power pack that is ubiquitous in today’s wireless electronic devices and electric and hybrid vehicles, died on Sunday at an assisted living facility in Austin, Texas. He was 100.

headline: Asia Society Names New Leader
abstract: Yasufumi Nakamori, a curator at the Tate, will be director of the New York museum showcasing Asian art, artifacts and culture.
lead_paragraph: Yasufumi Nakamori, a senior curator of international art at the Tate Modern in London, will become director of the Asia Society in New York, the museum announced Monday.

headline: Expectations of ‘Perfect’ English Are Elitist and Unrealistic
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Megan Luong, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Megan Luong, age 17, from Notre Dame High School in San Jose, Calif., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Parental Incarceration Is a Silent American Epidemic More Common Than Childhood Asthma
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Joshua Martoma, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Joshua Martoma, age 17, from Pine Crest School in Boca Raton, Fla., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Why We Should Be Fans of Fan Fiction
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Megan Ray, age 16.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Megan Ray, age 16, from Maynard High School in Maynard, Mass., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Worrying About the Judge and the Jury for Trump’s Trial
abstract: Readers fear that the judge may be biased and the jury intimidated. Also: The revolt in Russia; migrants and New York’s suburbs; climate education.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In a First, Germany’s Far Right AfD Party Will Take Control of a District
abstract: The election victory was a breakthrough for the Alternative for Germany party: It gained a majority in a district, albeit a tiny one, and will have bureaucratic authority over it.
lead_paragraph: A candidate for the resurgent far-right party Alternative for Germany has won a district administrator seat, the first time since the party was founded a decade ago that it has captured such a prominent regional post.

headline: Jesse Watters to Fill Tucker Carlson’s Old Slot as Fox Shuffles Prime-Time Lineup
abstract: Fox’s prime time ratings have consistently been the highest in cable news but have fallen off by roughly one-third since the network took Mr. Carlson off the air.
lead_paragraph: Fox News shook up its prime-time lineup on Monday in the first major reorganization to its most popular programming since the beginning of the Trump administration. The moves include permanently filling the 8 p.m. slot, which has been vacant since the network canceled Tucker Carlson’s show in April.

headline: Google Pixel Fold Review: Foldable Phones Are Improving
abstract: Google’s new $1,800 gadget proves that phones with bendable screens are something people might want. Now they just need to get cheaper.
lead_paragraph: When I recently turned on Google’s new Pixel Fold smartphone and unfolded it as if it were a book, it transformed into a miniature tablet, similar to an iPad Mini or an Amazon Fire. Then something unexpected happened.

headline: Love Letter: The Strongest Bone
abstract: “Gruesome? Perhaps, but I need something of you with me, and this will have to do.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s stunning Modern Love essay is one of the most striking, human and moving essays I’ve had the pleasure of coming across in our ever-growing submission inbox.

headline: What an Election Surprise in Central America Means for Democracy
abstract: Bernardo Arévalo, a professorial lawmaker, stunned Guatemala’s establishment by advancing to a second round against Sandra Torres, a former first lady.
lead_paragraph: Judges and prosecutors driven from the country. Independent news media under attack. Top presidential candidates barred from running.

headline: U.S. and Allies ‘Were Not Involved’ in Russia Revolt, Biden Says
abstract: President Biden said the United States and its NATO allies had “nothing to do with” a rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group in Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said the United States and its NATO allies had “nothing to do with” a rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group in Russia.

headline: Review: In ‘The Gospel According to Heather,’ the Messiah Has Homeroom
abstract: A lonely high school student discovers she may be a divine messenger in Paul Gordon’s half-baked new Off Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: “Do you like Kierkegaard?” As flirtatious chit-chat goes, this one sets 17-year-old Heather (Brittany Nicole Williams) apart. You can also see why the jock she’s asking (Carlos Alcala) just walks away. Sadly, this is par for the course for Heather, a pescatarian brainiac who is ostracized by classmates at her Ohio high school for being a “freak,” and quietly stifled at home by a loving but clueless widowed mother (Lauren Elder).

headline: A Mutiny That Showed the Stress on Putin’s System of Rule
abstract: A member of Russia’s elite marched on his rivals, with a mercenary army at his back, suggesting that Vladimir V. Putin’s grip over a coalition of powerful figures may be more brittle than it appeared.
lead_paragraph: Since it began last year, Russia’s war in Ukraine has hinged not just on battlefield results, but also a question in Moscow: Could President Vladimir V. Putin’s grip on power withstand the strain of fighting a long and costly war, with no end in sight?

headline: Publishers Clearing House Pays $18.5 Million in ‘Dark Patterns’ Suit
abstract: The case comes less than a week after the Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon, which was accused of similar deceptive practices.
lead_paragraph: Publishers Clearing House, the direct marketing company that uses sweepstakes to sell magazine subscriptions, agreed on Monday to pay $18.5 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the Federal Trade Commission, which accused the company of using what’s known as dark patterns to trick customers into paying for products or giving up their data.

headline: Diwali Is Set to Become a School Holiday in New York City
abstract: Local officials called the decision to close schools in honor of Diwali a victory for the thousands of New Yorkers who celebrate.
lead_paragraph: Diwali, the South Asian Festival of Lights, is set to become a public school holiday in New York City, Mayor Eric Adams announced on Monday, calling the moment a major victory for local families.

headline: Do You Know These Comics and Their Specific Screen Adaptations?
abstract: Many summer blockbusters and streaming hot television shows started as comic books. Try this quiz to test your knowledge on the topic.
lead_paragraph: Many summer blockbusters and streaming hot television shows started as comic books. Try this quiz to test your knowledge on the topic.

headline: A Renowned Economist’s New Idea for Stopping Climate Change
abstract: Carbon-linked bonds could save carbon pricing from its fatal flaw.
lead_paragraph: Robert Litterman is a legend on Wall Street. He earned a doctorate in economics from the University of Minnesota in 1980. In his 23 years at Goldman Sachs he oversaw quants, managed risk and developed, with the great applied mathematician Fischer Black, the Black-Litterman model for portfolio allocation. Now he’s a founding partner and the risk manager at Kepos Capital, a New York-based investment company with $2 billion under management.

headline: Pakistan’s Military Fires 3 Commanders, Cracking Down After Khan Protests
abstract: They were among 18 officers disciplined for their handling of protests by supporters of Imran Khan, a former prime minister, sending a message that support for him would not be tolerated in the ranks.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s military on Monday fired three senior army commanders and disciplined 15 top officers over their conduct during recent protests that supported former Prime Minister Imran Khan, in what analysts called the strongest action the military has taken against its own members in decades.

headline: DeSantis Calls for ‘Deadly Force’ Against Suspected Drug Traffickers
abstract: Campaigning in a Texas border city, the Florida governor laid out a series of hard-right immigration proposals, including some that would face legal roadblocks or test the limits of presidential authority.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Monday proposed a host of hard-right immigration policies, floating the idea of using deadly force against suspected drug traffickers and others breaking through border barriers while “demonstrating hostile intent.”

headline: ‘National Dish’ Charts a World Tour of Iconic Dishes
abstract: New American-made Lodge Dutch ovens, a sake recommendation service and more food news.
lead_paragraph: The way the food writer Anya von Bremzen sees it, many cuisines can be defined by iconic dishes. In her latest book, “National Dish,” she examines six of them through a personal lens while consulting a gaggle of experts, from academics to local butchers. Beginning with French pot-au-feu in a country of richly globalized cooking, she moves on to Naples (pizza and pasta), Tokyo (ramen and rice), Seville (tapas and the ingredients they require), Oaxaca (maize, mole and mezcal), Istanbul (mezze and more), and her native Russia and also Ukraine (borscht). The histories of essential ingredients, how they flourished in particular countries and her connection to the various cultures are woven throughout this compelling read. The cover is illustrated by Roz Chast.

headline: Princess Leia’s Dress From the Original ‘Star Wars’ Is Up for Bids
abstract: A ceremonial gown worn by Carrie Fisher was believed to be destroyed after the production of “A New Hope,” but it was recently found in an attic and restored.
lead_paragraph: The long, white dress worn by Carrie Fisher as Princess Leia in the final scene of the original 1977 “Star Wars” movie, “A New Hope,” was once thought to have been long gone, destroyed after the film’s production.

headline: DeSantis Proposes Using Force on Suspected Drug Traffickers
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida proposed a series of hard-right immigration policies during a campaign stop in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida proposed a series of hard-right immigration policies during a campaign stop in Texas.

headline: Congestion Pricing Plan in New York City Clears Final Federal Hurdle
abstract: The program, which could begin next year, would charge drivers to enter Midtown Manhattan, with the revenues going to improve mass transit.
lead_paragraph: Congestion pricing in New York City has cleared its final federal hurdle, officials said on Monday, all but ensuring that the first such program in the nation will begin next year with the aim of reducing traffic and pollution in Manhattan and funding improvements to mass transit.

headline: The Dangerous Heat Wave Will Continue to Bake the U.S. This Week
abstract: Oppressive heat will expand out of Texas to blanket an area from Arizona to Florida.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage as brutal heat and humidity engulfs the U.S.

headline: Jury to Decide Fate of Deputy Who Did Not Confront Parkland Gunman
abstract: A Florida jury began deliberations in the case against Scot Peterson, in a rare trial against a police officer over inaction in a school shooting.
lead_paragraph: A Florida jury will soon decide if a former police officer should be convicted of crimes for failing to confront the gunman who killed 17 people and wounded 17 others at a Parkland high school five years ago.

headline: Brooklyn Academy of Music Lays Off 13 Percent of Its Staff
abstract: The organization, which made Brooklyn a destination for pathbreaking performances, is reducing programming next season as it seeks to rebound from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Academy of Music, one of the most important cultural organizations in New York, has laid off 13 percent of its staff members and reduced its programming as it seeks to plug a “sizable structural deficit” during a challenging time for the arts, officials confirmed on Monday.

headline: A New Penn Station Is Coming, With or Without Office Towers, Hochul Says
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul has severed ties with the development plan that relied on the building of office towers by Vornado Realty Trust.
lead_paragraph: The proposed $7 billion overhaul of Pennsylvania Station in New York City will go forward with or without the development of several office towers that were supposed to help pay for the project, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Monday.

headline: The U.S. and its allies had ‘nothing to do with’ the rebellion in Russia, Biden says.
abstract: Western nations agreed on a conference call not to let President Vladimir Putin of Russia blame them for the short-lived uprising, the American president said.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its allies had “nothing to do with” the Wagner mercenary group’s uprising against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his military command, President Biden said on Monday, his first public comments on the short-lived rebellion that incited an extraordinary weekend of crisis in Russia.

headline: Uber Rider Who Killed Driver Said She Thought She Was Being Kidnapped
abstract: The passenger, who is charged with murder, told the authorities that she shot Daniel Piedra Garcia in the head as she worried he was taking her across the border to Mexico instead of to an El Paso casino.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Piedra Garcia had been an Uber driver for three weeks when he picked up a rider on June 16 who was headed to the Speaking Rock Casino in El Paso. It was near the end of his work day, but Mr. Piedra had picked up the rider anyway, his family said.

headline: Putin Forcefully Rebukes Wagner’s Rebellion in National Address
abstract: In a taped speech released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin said he gave direct instructions to avoid bloodshed during the mercenaries’ brief revolt and thanked his military.
lead_paragraph: In a taped speech released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin said he gave direct instructions to avoid bloodshed during the mercenaries’ brief revolt and thanked his military.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin Addresses Russia
abstract: Also, Pakistan’s military fired three top commanders.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin addressed the rebellion over the weekend by the Wagner mercenary group, led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, in a short televised speech yesterday. In his first public comments since Saturday, Putin tried to project unity and stability as questions swirled about the strength of his grip on power.

headline: A Boy’s Life on the Front Lines
abstract: In a Ukrainian town once teeming with families, an 11-year-old navigates a childhood transformed by war.
lead_paragraph: In a Ukrainian town once teeming with families, an 11-year-old navigates a childhood transformed by war.

headline: Putin condemns the Wagner revolt as a failure
abstract: Tonight, watch the new season of “The Bachelorette”
