lead_paragraph: Bobby Osborne, the singer and mandolin player who joined with his younger brother, Sonny, to lead one of the most groundbreaking bands in the history of bluegrass, died on Tuesday in Gallatin, Tenn., a suburb of Nashville. He was 91.

headline: Hunter Biden Isn’t Hiding. Even Some Democrats Are Uncomfortable.
abstract: Hunter Biden’s public appearances came across as a message of defiance by the president, who is determined to show that he stands by his son.
lead_paragraph: During last week’s state dinner at the White House, Hunter Biden seemed to be everywhere. Upbeat and gregarious, he worked the pavilion with grins and gusto, shaking hands and hugging other guests.

headline: New York Primary Election Results
abstract: See all results from the New York primary election.
lead_paragraph: See all results from the New York primary election.

headline: New York City Council Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results from the New York City Council primary election.
lead_paragraph: See full results from the New York City Council primary election.

headline: Putin Casts Mutiny as Proof of Solidity, as Belarus Opens Doors to Rebels
abstract: Belarus said it had taken in the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and might welcome his Wagner troops, while Russia dropped a criminal investigation of him for the weekend uprising.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday tried to recast the weekend rebellion by the mercenary chief Yevgeny V. Prigozhin as a heroic episode for a rock-solid Russian state, while neighboring Belarus said Mr. Prigozhin had gone into exile there, and signaled that it would be open to taking in his battle-hardened troops, as well.

headline: PGA Tour Board Meets as Scrutiny of Saudi Deal Swells
abstract: The 11-member board did not vote on the surprise pact, whose most significant details are still being negotiated.
lead_paragraph: The PGA Tour’s board, with its members gathered in the same room for the first time since a fraction of them negotiated a deal with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund to reshape golf, signaled Tuesday that it intended to move ahead with the agreement and past an outcry that has stretched from clubhouse locker rooms to Capitol Hill.

headline: 4 More Arrested in Human Smuggling Case That Left 53 Dead in Texas
abstract: Four men from Mexico were arrested this week, bringing to six the number of people charged after a tractor-trailer was found carrying dead migrants near San Antonio last year.
lead_paragraph: Four more men have been arrested in Texas in connection with a human smuggling operation that left 53 people dead on the outskirts of San Antonio last year, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: Russian General Knew About Mercenary Chief’s Rebellion Plans, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of Wagner, may have believed he had support in Russia’s military.
lead_paragraph: After this article was published, the Kremlin’s spokesman, Dmitri S. Peskov, issued a curt response and insisted on Wednesday that Russia’s army and people had unified around Mr. Putin.

headline: Completely Disoriented
abstract: Matt Fuchs and Victor Sloan have us cross-eyed.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: German Defense Minister Vows Stronger Geopolitical Role Ahead of U.S. Visit
abstract: In an interview before his first official trip to Washington, Boris Pistorius made clear he is intent on helping the United States by taking a more assertive stance.
lead_paragraph: In an interview before his first official visit to Washington, Germany’s defense minister staked out a broad geopolitical vision, taking pains to indicate that his country is ready to assume a more assertive stance in the face of growing international instability.

headline: The M.T.A. Does Not Have a Property Empire
abstract: The authority owns some real estate, but a lot less than people may think.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll answer one of your questions about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from a few weeks ago. We’ll also find out why Mayor Eric Adams says public school students should take a deep breath. And another. And another.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Prigozhin’s whereabouts.
lead_paragraph: The mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin arrived in Belarus yesterday, according to Belarusian state media, ending days of speculation over his whereabouts after he called off a weekend uprising that marked a dramatic challenge to the rule of President Vladimir Putin of Russia.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Suggestions of Pizza’s Past in a Pompeii Fresco
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It’s an archeo-pizza.”

headline: Corrections: June 28, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about restoring ecological health to Ireland misstated the name of the organization that Padraic Fogarty works for. It is the Irish Wildlife Trust, not Wildlife Ireland. The article also misstated the status of the lynx in Scotland. While reintroducing the animal into the wild has been widely discussed, it has not yet happened.

headline: Word of the Day: vainglorious
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word vainglorious has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 25 in “Seeing Beyond the Beauty of a Vermeer” by Teju Cole:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: No Job, No Marriage, No Kid: China’s Workers and the Curse of 35
abstract: It’s widely discussed in China: Employers don’t want you after 35. Some job listings say it plainly, leaving a generation of prime-age workers feeling defeated.
lead_paragraph: When Sean Liang turned 30, he started thinking of the Curse of 35 — the widespread belief in China that white-collar workers like him confront unavoidable job insecurity after they hit that age. In the eyes of employers, the Curse goes, they’re more expensive than new graduates and not as willing to work overtime.

headline: Richard Ravitch and the Matzo Summit That Saved New York
abstract: In the 1970s, New York City was rescued by a collaboration of union leaders and money men. Could such an alliance happen today?
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 17, 1975, New Yorkers learned from the morning papers that the city was more or less finished. The big bill — $453 million that City Hall owed its creditors after years of borrowing — was due at 4 o’clock that afternoon.

headline: The Secret Deal for a Tribal Casino and Why It Imploded
abstract: As a deadline looms for reaching a gambling deal with the Seneca Nation of Indians, Gov. Kathy Hochul’s office tried to give the tribe a new casino near Rochester. It backfired.
lead_paragraph: For months, talks over a new casino deal between New York State and the Seneca Nation of Indians have been at an impasse, with the two sides deadlocked over the size of the state’s cut of hundreds of millions of dollars in gambling revenue, and what the tribe would get in return.

headline: What to Know About Kevin Spacey’s U.K. Sexual Offenses Trial
abstract: The actor will appear in a London courtroom on Wednesday to face a four-week trial over allegations of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning actor Kevin Spacey is scheduled to go on trial in London on Wednesday, facing multiple allegations of sexual assault.

headline: How Might Congestion Pricing Actually Work in New York?
abstract: The tolls will mostly be collected electronically through the E-ZPass system, and drivers should expect penalties for late payments.
lead_paragraph: New York City is ready to build a first-in-the-nation congestion pricing program, designed to collect billions of dollars to fund mass transit while discouraging drivers from jamming up Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Can China Export Its Way Out of Its Economic Slump?
abstract: No country has had more export success than China. But Beijing faces risks in turning to the tested method of selling more abroad.
lead_paragraph: China dominates the global sale of solar panels and has caught up with Japan as the world’s largest car exporter. ‌It is even gaining in ‌the worldwide ‌sale of low-tech products like shoes.

headline: FIFA Will Allow Rainbow Armbands at Women’s World Cup
abstract: Captains will be offered choices reflecting several anti-discrimination efforts. The rainbow-colored design is similar to one banned at the men’s World Cup in Qatar.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE, Friday, June 30: FIFA on Friday confirmed the rules for the armbands team captains can wear at the Women’s World Cup described in this article. One design includes a rainbow-colored design, but FIFA took pains to differentiate its from a familiar pride design some teams have worn for years. This article has been updated to note the approved slogans and designs.

headline: $630,000 Homes in Virginia, North Carolina and Louisiana
abstract: A three-bedroom rowhouse in Richmond, a hillside retreat in Black Mountain and a 1908 cottage in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: This house is on a tree-lined street a few blocks from West Cary Street, putting it within walking distance of the Byrd Theatre, a 1928 movie theater listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is also close to a Japanese grocery store, a record shop and a toy store, as well as numerous restaurants, including those serving Greek food and homemade ice cream.

headline: How Easy Is It to Fool A.I.-Detection Tools?
abstract: We tested five services that claim to detect what is real and what isn’t.
lead_paragraph: We tested five services that claim to detect what is real and what isn’t.

headline: Biden Says He Is ‘Turning Things Around’ on the Economy
abstract: President Biden hopes to claim credit for what the White House describes as a record-breaking economic revival in America.
lead_paragraph: President Biden began a concerted campaign on Wednesday to claim credit for an economic revival in America, powered by policies that he said represent a fundamental break from the Republican approach “that has failed America’s middle class for decades.”

headline: A Tiny, Wonderful Rebellion Against the Tyranny of Time Has Begun
abstract: The Muslim holiday is a reminder that there is more than one way to think about time.
lead_paragraph: I always struggle to explain Eid al-Adha. It’s not just the story of the holiday that’s inaccessible to your average American — at its meaty core is a tale of animal slaughter — but also its timeline. I explain that the holiday commemorates how willing a prophet was to sacrifice anything for God — including his own son. (Spoiler alert: He lives.)

headline: Translating Tolstoy While Inciting Revolution
abstract: The radical politics of Russian literature’s most famous English translator, Constance Garnett.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever killed anybody?” a journalist asked the visitor from Russia. The reply, The New York Times reported the next day, was a no as emphatic as you would expect from someone yet to be caught for killing the head of the Russian secret police. The man went by the name Stepniak, a revolutionary nom de guerre — Russian for “man of the steppe.”

headline: The Philosophers Who Used Word Puzzles to Understand the World
abstract: “A Terribly Serious Adventure,” by Nikhil Krishnan, brings to life the 20th-century Oxford thinkers whose methods of linguistic analysis were deeply influential and vigorously debated.
lead_paragraph: When setting out to write “A Terribly Serious Adventure: Philosophy and War at Oxford, 1900-1960,” Nikhil Krishnan certainly had his work cut out for him. How to generate excitement for a “much-maligned” philosophical tradition that hinges on finicky distinctions in language? Whose main figures were mostly well-to-do white men, routinely caricatured — and not always unfairly — for being suspicious of foreign ideas and imperiously, insufferably smug?

headline: How Hard Could It Be to Translate a Picture Book?
abstract: With so few words, most of them kid-friendly, it should be a piece of cake. But it depends on who’s holding the whisk.
lead_paragraph: In “Where the Wild Things Are,” the boy Max finds himself sailing off, in a private boat, “through night and day / and in and out of weeks / and almost over a year,” to the eponymous land. There are about a thousand little components that combine to make “Where the Wild Things Are,” for me, one of the greatest of American books, and among them is that brief phrase “in and out of weeks.” It is entirely new, yet comprehensible, positioning the reader right in the middle of that experience of time passing.

headline: 21 Miles of Obstacles
abstract: The Ukrainian counteroffensive faces an enemy nearly as daunting as the Russians: the terrain.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian counteroffensive faces an enemy nearly as daunting as the Russians: the terrain.

headline: ‘That’s Not Us!’: Blank Slate Coffee Would Like You to Know It Is Not Blank Street
abstract: A Manhattan coffee outpost changed its name this month in an effort to distance itself from a fast-growing chain that elicits strong feelings from New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Jaffe, an owner of Blank Slate Coffee + Kitchen in Manhattan, started getting confusing messages from friends and customers in 2021. Every few weeks, a new one would arrive, congratulating her on opening another location of her cafe.

headline: A Dessert Recipe So Good, I Was Sworn to Secrecy
abstract: A friend told our columnist never to write about this easy Hawaii-style sherbet. Lucky for you, she did anyway.
lead_paragraph: So few childhood treats stand the test of time.

headline: Are Democrats Actually Winning Older Voters?
abstract: Some intriguing signs that the party may be doing better among seniors than is commonly thought.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the 2020 presidential election, the polls showed something strange: Joe Biden was faring far better than expected among voters over age 65. Some polls showed him ahead by 10 points or more.

headline: The Myth That May Have Doomed the Titan
abstract: Government is not an obstacle to new ideas.
lead_paragraph: As details emerged about the implosion last week of the Titan submersible in its descent to the wreck of the Titanic nearly two and a half miles below the surface of the North Atlantic, there was widespread anger that its owner and pilot knowingly took civilians on an uncertified vessel to a depth of crushing pressure.

headline: The Slave Sale That Saved — and Stained — Georgetown
abstract: “The 272,” by Rachel L. Swarns, recounts the decision by the university’s early leaders to sell nearly 300 people enslaved on Jesuit-owned plantations in Maryland in 1838.
lead_paragraph: During the War of 1812, a large extended family of Mahoneys lived and labored as enslaved people on several plantations in southern Maryland. They were descendants of a Black woman named Ann Joice, who had arrived from England in approximately 1676 as an indentured servant. For years she served one of Maryland’s richest men, Charles Calvert, as a domestic in his manor house. In 1684 she was transferred to Calvert’s cousin Henry Darnall, a wealthy Catholic, who promptly burned her indenture papers, rendering her a slave for life.

headline: Can You Mix Booze and Exercise?
abstract: You really shouldn’t drink alcohol before, after or during an intense workout. But if you do, here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: You’re at brunch with friends, and mimosas are on the house. You’re tempted, but you also want to go for a run later. What should you do? Will drinking doom your workout?

headline: City of Light, Camera, Action
abstract: Paris men’s wear caught fire during a week of zillion-dollar spectacles, skinny fits and Jay-Z’s surprise appearance at Pharrell Williams’s debut for Louis Vuitton.
lead_paragraph: Models on Ozempic, dazzling guys in sequins, superstars everywhere you turned: Look, it’s King James! Sheesh, there goes Rihanna! OMG, Beyoncé! Those screams you’re hearing? Fangirls losing their minds for Cha Eun-woo, the pretty singer from the K-pop boy group Astro.

headline: The Christian Pop Star Bringing Latino Evangelicals to the Pews
abstract: How Marcos Witt is shaping faith in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The sanctuary of Northside church in Charlotte, N.C., is built for joyous adoration. Enormous speakers hang from its domed ceiling, along with an elaborate system of colored lights. Its semicircular stage has wide, carpeted steps that lead down on all sides to rows and rows of wine red pews, which hold about 2,700 people. The evening I visited last February, they filled to capacity with Latino families who had come to see the evangelical superstar Marcos Witt.

headline: The Supreme Court Rejected a Dangerous Elections Theory. But It’s Not All Good News.
abstract: A weaker version of the independent state legislature theory will loom over the 2024 elections.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court decision in Moore v. Harper rejected the most extreme version of the so-called independent state legislature theory. In doing so, the court avoided any immediate and significant disruption of the structure of federal elections.

headline: ‘His Ability to Do Pretty Much Everything Is Crazy’
abstract: Corbin Carroll is off to a blazing start with the Arizona Diamondbacks. The rookie outfielder is already being compared to Mike Trout and Mookie Betts.
lead_paragraph: The slugger could not bunt. This was no surprise — when you slug .600, why play small ball? — but it bothered Corbin Carroll.

headline: More Clematis, Please: How to Make Those Flowers Last All Season
abstract: Because there’s no such thing as too much Clematis, here’s how to get a little more — and make it last a little longer.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine that the aphorism warning about too much of a good thing could ever apply to Clematis, whose charming flowers and mostly lightweight climbing vines make them irresistible.

headline: Wagner’s Mutiny Has Century-Old Echoes of Another Russian Debacle
abstract: Amid a flagging war effort, a popular commander turned his troops toward Russia’s own capital, undermining the government. It happened last weekend — and in 1917.
lead_paragraph: As Russian soldiers braced in their trenches in Ukraine, a charismatic military leader suddenly marched his forces on the capital. He promised to save the nation from traitors who were pushing it toward catastrophic military defeat.

headline: It’s Never Too Late to Become a Nurse
abstract: During the pandemic, Joanna Patchett spent 18 harrowing months in the intensive care unit. She discovered that medicine isn’t just about science — it’s also about heart.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Never Too Late” is a series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.

headline: How Migrants Flown to Martha’s Vineyard Came to Call It Home
abstract: Florida flew 49 migrants from Texas to the liberal enclave last year. Since then, a few of them have found work, friends and a new life on the wealthy island.
lead_paragraph: On a sprawling Martha’s Vineyard estate not far from the seashore, Deici Cauro adjusted a baseball cap to keep the burning sun at bay. She was crouching to pull weeds with her bare hands when a familiar voice called out from the other side of the yard.

headline: Want One of India’s Best Jobs? You and 1,800 Other Applicants.
abstract: In some places, educated young people are desperate for steady employment in the world’s most populous nation. In others, factory owners struggle to retain workers.
lead_paragraph: The grubby lanes of Musallahpur, in the north Indian city of Patna, heave with the foot traffic, banners and vending carts familiar to commercial hubs across India. Here, though, the cacophony is directed toward a single goal: helping young people land a government job.

headline: Red States, Rainbow Towns
abstract: Fire Island or Provincetown? Not exactly. We asked L.G.B.T.Q. people in four queer-friendly enclaves what they love about their communities and why they’re worth a visit.
lead_paragraph: A wave of legislation targeting L.G.B.T.Q. people has swept conservative-led statehouses since 2021, when Arkansas passed a law banning hormone therapy and puberty blockers for transgender youths under 18. So far this year, according to the advocacy group Human Rights Campaign, more than 500 bills have been introduced in such places as Arizona, Oklahoma and South Carolina.

headline: Deconstructing Men’s Dress Codes
abstract: Outside the men’s wear shows in Milan and Paris, almost everything seemed possible when it came to getting dressed.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a stretch to say that men’s wear has long been seen by many as simpler and less creative than women’s wear. But as more men have found ways to personalize even the most traditional staples, they have shown that there are far wider possibilities than once thought.

headline: What Opera Singers Gained, and Lost, Performing While Pregnant
abstract: Women in the industry are speaking out about what they feel are cancellations motivated by their appearance rather than sound, even as there is a belief that pregnancy and childbirth have positive effects on the voice.
lead_paragraph: “It’s adjustable, yes?” Standing in a dressing room in the opera house in Montpellier, France, in May, the soprano Maya Kherani tugged at the waistband of her tiered skirt. A draper kneeling behind her shook out the hem while the costume designer looked on with satisfaction.

headline: Barred From Grocery Stores by Facial Recognition
abstract: British merchants are increasingly using the technology to combat shoplifting, raising questions about its spread as artificial intelligence rapidly improves it.
lead_paragraph: Simon Mackenzie, a security officer at the discount retailer QD Stores outside London, was short of breath. He had just chased after three shoplifters who had taken off with several packages of laundry soap. Before the police arrived, he sat at a back-room desk to do something important: Capture the culprits’ faces.

headline: Religious Freedom Arguments Underpin Wave of Challenges to Abortion Bans
abstract: In lawsuits challenging state abortion bans, lawyers for abortion rights plaintiffs are employing religious liberty arguments the Christian right has used for decades.
lead_paragraph: For years, conservative Christians have used the principle of religious freedom to prevail in legal battles on issues like contraceptive insurance mandates and pandemic restrictions. Now, abortion rights supporters are employing that argument to challenge one of the right’s most prized accomplishments: state bans on abortion.

headline: Something Was Messing With Earth’s Axis. The Answer Has to Do With Us.
abstract: Scientists knew the planet’s centerline could move. But it took a sharp turn sometime around the start of the 2000s.
lead_paragraph: Around the turn of the millennium, Earth’s spin started going off-kilter, and nobody could quite say why.

headline: In Battle Over Direction of Texas, an Unlikely Casualty: Water Breaks
abstract: A new law pre-empting local labor rules is part of an effort by Republicans in the Capitol to exert control over the state’s Democratic-led major cities.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage as brutal heat and humidity engulfs the U.S.

headline: This Is Why Trump Lies Like There’s No Tomorrow
abstract: It’s a strategy, and it works.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump can lay claim to the title of most prodigious liar in the history of the presidency. This challenges commonplace beliefs about the American political system. How could such a deceitful and duplicitous figure win the White House in the first place and then retain the loyalty of so many voters after his endless lies were exposed?

headline: In ‘The Bear,’ Molly Gordon Is More Than the Girl Next Door
abstract: A new addition to the cast for Season 2, the actress plays Chef Carmy’s love interest — “a human woman,” she said, “not just this sweet, sweet girl.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday afternoon, the actress Molly Gordon ambled through Manhattan’s SoHo neighborhood. Gordon, a wry and sprightly presence in movies like “Booksmart,” “Good Boys” and “Shiva Baby,” wore chunky sneakers, a schoolgirl skirt and sunglasses that made her look like a cat with an active Vogue subscription.

headline: What to Know About Canadian Wildfires and U.S. Air Quality
abstract: The ongoing outbreak of fires in Canada is sending new waves of smoke into the American Midwest, and the pollution has been seen as far away as Europe.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the wildfires and air quality.

headline: Misery Engulfs the South as Heat Wave Spreads
abstract: Temperatures will be up to 20 degrees above normal for much of the region through at least the weekend, with no nighttime relief.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage as brutal heat and humidity engulfs the U.S.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Supreme Court Rules in a Major Election Law Case, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: What Churches Offer That ‘Nones’ Still Long For
abstract: Houses of worship are, uniquely, one-stop shops of meaning, continuity and support.
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth and final newsletter in a series about Americans moving away from religion. Read part one, part two, part three and part four.

headline: Suspicion, Cheating and Bans: A.I. Hits America’s Schools
abstract: Teachers and students on how ChatGPT is changing education.
lead_paragraph: Since its introduction less than a year ago, ChatGPT, the artificial intelligence platform that can write essays, solve math problems and write computer code, has sparked an anguished debate in the world of education. Is it a useful research tool or an irresistible license to cheat?

headline: ‘A Sight for Sore Eyes’: How One Man’s Ocean Rescue Unfolded
abstract: An American man’s rowboat had capsized in the Pacific. Low on battery, he put out a call for help.
lead_paragraph: After his 23-foot rowboat lost battery power in mid-May as he tried to circle the globe, Aaron Carotta spent more than a month at the mercy of ocean currents that pulled him across the Pacific.

headline: Conservative Court, Moderate Decision
abstract: A bipartisan Supreme Court majority preserved democratic checks and balances.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Supreme Court took a step in a high-profile case to preserve democratic checks and balances.

headline: Losing Their Way to the Playoffs
abstract: The Minnesota Twins could join the ignominious list of postseason teams with losing records. But that’s nothing compared to what’s happening in the U.S.F.L.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in an ordinary Major League Baseball season, a team with a losing record could make the playoffs.

headline: ‘Rock Hudson: All That Heaven Allowed’ Review: Living a Double Life
abstract: Stephan Kijak’s new documentary seems keenly interested in the ways in which the closeted actor’s sexuality manifested itself, largely unintentionally, in his movies.
lead_paragraph: “Rock Hudson’s Home Movies,” the director Mark Rappaport’s landmark 1992 video essay about the life and death of the famous gay actor, is a playful, provocative and singular meditation on celebrity, homosexuality and the nature of truth onscreen. Through a combination of archival footage from Hudson’s filmography and invented narration by an actor playing Hudson, the movie offers a speculative, pseudobiographical portrait of Hudson’s innermost thoughts, using what we know about him now to imagine what he might have been thinking then.

headline: Protests and Sorrow After Fatal Police Traffic Encounter in France
abstract: The shooting of a teenage driver in a suburb of Paris fed into longstanding complaints about the French police. Protesters burned cars and clashed with riot officers.
lead_paragraph: In a working class Paris suburb, two police officers confront a 17-year-old driver in a canary yellow Mercedes who was stopped in traffic. They shout at him, video footage shows, and one officer appears to have his gun drawn. The teenager is then fatally shot in broad daylight.

headline: Trump Countersues E. Jean Carroll, Claiming She Defamed Him This Time
abstract: The former president, who was found liable for sexually abusing Ms. Carroll, argued that she should not have said he raped her.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has been found liable for sexually abusing and defaming the writer E. Jean Carroll, has countersued, accusing her of defaming him in turn by repeating her contention that he had raped her.

headline: The A.I. Chips War Could Heat Up This Summer
abstract: Shares in the semiconductor giants Nvidia and AMD fell on a report that the Biden Administration is weighing new restrictions on A.I.-related exports.
lead_paragraph: Shares in high-flying chipmakers like Nvidia and AMD were down in premarket trading today, after The Wall Street Journal reported that the Biden administration is weighing new restrictions on exporting artificial intelligence-related semiconductors to China.

headline: As rescuers sift through the rubble of a Kramatorsk restaurant, distraught relatives wait for news.
abstract: The Ria Lounge eatery, known to many as Ria Pizza, was a long-running haunt popular with Ukrainian soldiers, foreign journalists and aid workers.
lead_paragraph: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — Rescuers were combing through the rubble in Kramatorsk on Wednesday as the death toll from a Russian missile strike on a popular restaurant in the eastern Ukrainian city climbed.

headline: ‘Run Rabbit Run’ Review: No Child of Mine
abstract: A splendid Sarah Snook battles weak plotting in this atmospheric, derivative ghost story.
lead_paragraph: Buried trauma and resurrected guilt get quite the workout in Daina Reid’s “Run Rabbit Run,” a ludicrous Australian psychodrama that forces the fabulous Sarah Snook to interact with a creepy bunny.

headline: DoorDash, Shifting Business Model, Will Offer Drivers Hourly Pay
abstract: The company said the option would give couriers greater choice. It could also help DoorDash find people who will make less desirable deliveries.
lead_paragraph: DoorDash said on Wednesday that it would begin giving its delivery drivers the option to be paid an hourly minimum wage, instead of earning money for each delivery.

headline: Kevin Spacey Begins Trial on Sexual Assault Accusations
abstract: The actor faces 12 charges related to incidents that prosecutors say involved four men and occurred between 2001 and 2013.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Spacey, the two-time Academy Award-winning actor, appeared briefly on Wednesday in a London courtroom for the first day of a trial on multiple charges of sexual assault.

headline: How Do I Ask a Close Friend’s Husband to Be Our Sperm Donor?
abstract: After getting an initial thumbs up that may have been in jest, a reader wonders how to make a sensitive request that is more likely to be taken seriously.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I are women in our early 30s, and we would like to have a baby soon. One of my best friends has a very handsome husband. I mentioned to her that we would like to conceive our baby using his sperm. She seemed to agree — but did so as if in jest. What is the best way to broach this subject again, but more seriously this time? Should we ask in person because of the intimate nature of the request? Or should we write an email, so they have time to process and respond without pressure?

headline: Heat Wave Is Expected to Bake California This Weekend
abstract: An abrupt shift from cooler-than-average temperatures to triple digits in the state will increase the risk of heat-related illnesses, experts say.
lead_paragraph: California is in for a heat wave.

headline: Victoria Bailey Wants Audiences to Get Bigger, and Broader
abstract: The Theater Development Fund’s departing director reflects on two decades of work expanding access to theater and the paths that lie ahead for Broadway.
lead_paragraph: When Victoria Bailey assumed the leadership of the nonprofit Theater Development Fund in 2001, she was told that the organization’s marquee program, the TKTS discount ticket booth, had not missed a day in nearly three decades of operation.

headline: In a Young Face, the Price of War
abstract: Lynsey Addario, a photojournalist, noticed a boy idling in a town near the front line in Ukraine. Then she spent more than a week living with his family.
lead_paragraph: In her 20 years of working as a photojournalist, Lynsey Addario has covered war and conflict in Afghanistan, Iraq, South Sudan, Congo, Yemen and Libya. To her, the most important moments to document are often away from the fighting — “the nuances that happen in the emptiness and the silence,” she said in a recent interview.

headline: Welcome Aboard the Aquidaban, the Floating Jungle Supermarket
abstract: The Aquidaban has long attracted colorful characters as the only ferry in one of South America’s most remote stretches. Now it may disappear.
lead_paragraph: Up the wooden gangplank in a single-file line, nearly an entire Indigenous village squeezed onto the Aquidaban’s front deck. The Tomárahos had taken the boat downriver to vote in Paraguay’s national elections, and then had slept outside for four days, waiting for the Aquidaban to take them home.

headline: Daniel Penny Pleads Not Guilty to Manslaughter Charge in Subway Killing
abstract: Mr. Penny, a Marine veteran, is accused of fatally choking a homeless man, Jordan Neely, on an F train last month.
lead_paragraph: The Marine veteran whose choking of a homeless man crystallized New York City’s challenges with homelessness, mental health and violence in its subways pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide.

headline: Wildfire Smoke and High Heat Have Something in Common. Guess What.
abstract: Human-caused climate change is making high temperatures more common and intensifying the dryness that fuels catastrophic wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage as brutal heat and humidity engulfs the U.S.Between the dangerous heat baking Texas and the Southeast, and the wildfire smoke filling the skies throughout the Upper Midwest and into the Mid-Atlantic, people across a huge part of the United States have been seeking relief from the outside world in recent days.

headline: Kiki or Bouba?
abstract: Nearly a century after a landmark psychology study was conducted, we revisit its findings — with your help!
lead_paragraph: Nearly a century after a landmark psychology study was conducted, we revisit its findings — with your help!

headline: Is Originality Even a Worthy Ambition Anymore?
abstract: In this age of reboots and remakes, a magic show seeks “a total invention” even as it deconstructs that desire, showing how rare a truly new work is.
lead_paragraph: Is originality overrated?

headline: Democrats Reach Milestone: 100 New District Court Judges
abstract: Democrats have filled more seats on that level than the Senate had by this point in Donald J. Trump’s presidency, but some progressives want leaders to pick up the pace.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Democrats, largely stymied by Republicans from enacting their policy agenda, have transformed the Senate into a judicial confirmation factory that has just passed a major milestone in its drive to remake the federal courts, approving the 100th district court nominee since Mr. Biden took office.

headline: A Potato Salad That Packs a Serious Umami Punch
abstract: Serve with barbecue slathered in one of Steven Raichlen’s three new sauces and Millie Peartree’s sweet-tart Hennessy coladas.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Melissa Clark, who’s on vacation. I’ll start with a confession: For most of my life, I was a potato-salad hater. Too much mayonnaise, too many lackluster celery chunks, too much meh. Why smush potatoes into mayo when you could shingle them with cheese or roast them until crispy?

headline: The ‘Forbidden Planet’ That Escaped a Fiery Doom
abstract: The giant world Halla should have been swallowed by its star long ago. Scientists now think they know how the planet cheated death.
lead_paragraph: All across the Milky Way, dying stars are gobbling up their planets. Even Earth is likely to perish this way about five billion years from now, when the sun expands and devours its innermost worlds.

headline: Climate Change Can Turn Snow Into Rain, Raising Risks in Mountain Zones
abstract: High-altitude regions will get more extreme rain than previously thought, making floods and landslides more likely, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: As the climate warms, mountain regions will get more extreme rainfall than previously thought, and more of the dangers that come with it, according to a study published on Wednesday in the journal Nature.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ has an Obsession With Logos
abstract: The clothes on the show often serve as their own plot points, and are more memorable than any dialogue.
lead_paragraph: And just like that, stealth wealth, the aesthetic made viral by “Succession,” with its toxic billionaires in their Loro Piana baseball caps and Tom Ford hoodies locked in a C-suite cage match to the death, has been swept off screen.

headline: Fatal Police Shooting of Teenager Ignites Protests in France
abstract: Demonstrators clashed with riot police officers in the Paris suburb of Nanterre after the police fatally shot a 17-year-old driver during a traffic stop.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators clashed with riot police officers in the Paris suburb of Nanterre after the police fatally shot a 17-year-old driver during a traffic stop.

headline: How Do You Replace an Elite?
abstract: This book tries to give new answers to a question conservatives have been asking for decades.
lead_paragraph: In January of 2018, just a year after Donald Trump assumed the U.S. presidency, the political theorist Patrick Deneen published “Why Liberalism Failed,” an ideally timed argument about how the inner logic of modern liberalism had led to social decay and political misrule.

headline: Mixtape Sites Like DatPiff Propelled Rap. Can They Be Preserved?
abstract: Websites offering up free — and not always legal — music flourished in the gap between the fall of the CD era and the rise of streaming. Keeping those archives intact is proving difficult.
lead_paragraph: The hip-hop mixtape website DatPiff had not been a major talking point among enthusiasts for some time, until this past March, when it appeared to be vanishing.

headline: Mark Your Calendars: ‘Barbenheimer’ Is Coming
abstract: The “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” movies look very different. But some fans are planning a double feature for their release on July 21.
lead_paragraph: Barbie is everything. He’s just … Robert Oppenheimer.

headline: Exit Hector, Again and Again: How Different Translators Reveal the ‘Iliad’ Anew
abstract: Over the years, some 100 people have translated the entire “Iliad” into English. The latest of them, Emily Wilson, explains what different approaches to one key scene say about the original, and the translators.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most moving and memorable scenes from the “Iliad,” the great Trojan warrior Hector says farewell to his wife, Andromache, who has urged him not to risk his life by fighting on the plain. He gives their baby back to her, tells her to go home, and reiterates his decision to advance on the enemy.

headline: ‘Building Something Together’: Translators Discuss Their Art
abstract: The Times convened five notable translators who bring literature from other languages into English, and asked them about the joys and challenges of the job.
lead_paragraph: There are as many ways of translating a literary text as there are translators. The act of carrying a work from one language to another — an art as much as a craft — is anything but mechanical: Translators’ choices are informed by their sensibilities, their emotional landscape, their background.

headline: My Best Friends Are Taking Ozempic. Can I Share My Disapproval?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on judging people who use prescription drugs to lose weight.
lead_paragraph: Recently, two of my good friends (neither of whom is obese) have joined the masses taking semaglutide for weight loss. Because the three of us live in different parts of the country, our friendship is maintained by annual visits and frequent texts. Lately in our text thread, all they can do is rave about how these drugs have been “life-changing” in helping them drop the stubborn 20 pounds they’ve been wanting to lose since hitting their 40s. I’m conflicted about the safety and popularity of these drugs for weight loss, and so I’ve remained silent whenever this topic comes up. Our annual trip is coming up, and I fear I’ll be forced to offer my opinion about their weight loss, especially since the trip involves time at the pool. Should I compliment them to keep the peace? Or is there a tactful way to make my differing opinion about these drugs known? — Name Withheld

headline: A Wedgie War Zone
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Leah N. Scarpa, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Leah N. Scarpa, age 17, from St. Teresa’s Academy in Kansas City, Mo., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Kennedy, Condemning ‘Censorship,’ Hits Democrats and Courts the Disaffected
abstract: His family name, libertarian bent and support from the tech world, along with his views on censorship and vaccines, have given Robert F. Kennedy Jr. a foothold in the 2024 contest.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at a festival hosted by a libertarian group in New Hampshire, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. railed against the “mainstream media” for serving as “propagandists for the powerful.” Each time he mentioned the perfidy of the press — for silencing dissent, for toeing the government line, for labeling him a conspiracy theorist — he drew a supportive hail of jeers.

headline: The Unlimited Possibilities of Animation
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Sylvia Woodbury, age 19.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Sylvia Woodbury, 19, who is taking a gap year, in Sharon, Mass., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.

headline: Lowell Weicker, Senator Whose Star Rose During Watergate, Dies at 92
abstract: A liberal Republican who became a third-party governor, he was known for his fierce criticism of Nixon and later termed Donald Trump “a total con artist.”
lead_paragraph: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a liberal Republican who earned a national reputation for pugnacious political independence — first as a young United States senator during the Watergate hearings and later as a third-party governor of Connecticut — died on Wednesday at a hospital in Middletown, in central Connecticut. He was 92.

headline: Giuliani Sat for Voluntary Interview in Jan. 6 Investigation
abstract: The onetime personal lawyer for Donald Trump answered questions from federal prosecutors about the former president’s efforts to remain in power after his 2020 election loss.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who served as former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, was interviewed last week by federal prosecutors investigating Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Who Knew About Prigozhin’s Wagner Revolt Before It Happened?
abstract: Some Russian generals and foreign intelligence agencies appear to have gotten early signals of the mercenary leader’s plans.
lead_paragraph: As details emerge about the aborted rebellion in Russia last weekend led by Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, it is becoming clear that some Russian officials and foreign intelligence agencies knew about it in advance.

headline: Simone Biles Signals a Return to Elite Gymnastics
abstract: Biles, a seven-time Olympic medalist, last competed at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when she withdrew from some events because of a mental block.
lead_paragraph: The star gymnast Simone Biles, whose expected dominance at the 2021 Tokyo Olympics was disrupted by mental health issues and who has not competed since, may be planning a comeback a year before the Paris Games.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Rejection of a Disputed Legal Theory on Elections
abstract: A majority on the court ruled against the “independent state legislature” theory. Also: Race and class; tax relief; reading; the German far right.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Biden Administration Weighs Further Curbs on Sales of A.I. Chips to China
abstract: Reports that the White House may clamp down on sales of semiconductors that power artificial intelligence capabilities sent tech stocks diving.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is weighing additional curbs on China’s ability to access critical technology, including restricting the sale of high-end chips used to power artificial intelligence, according to five people familiar with the deliberations.

headline: Top Central Bankers Expect More Rate Increases Amid Stubborn Inflation
abstract: The heads of the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank and Bank of England said that while inflation was moderating somewhat there was still more work to be done.
lead_paragraph: Central bankers from the world’s leading economies said on Wednesday that while they had raised interest rates significantly, additional increases would very likely be needed to wrestle inflation back under control given the strength of labor markets.

headline: Private Firm Announces Competing Vision for Penn Station Redesign
abstract: In a move that has stoked conflict with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a private developer unveiled a renovation plan that it says would save at least $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: A private development firm with an alternative vision for the remaking of Manhattan’s Pennsylvania Station said on Wednesday that its plan would be significantly cheaper than a rival proposal backed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Historians Criticize Moms for Liberty Event at Museum in Philadelphia
abstract: Several leading scholarly groups have criticized the Museum of the American Revolution in Philadelphia for renting space to the group, which has pushed for book bans.
lead_paragraph: A half-dozen scholarly groups, including the nation’s two largest associations of professional historians, have criticized the Museum of the American Revolution in Philadelphia for renting space to Moms for Liberty, calling it a dangerous normalization of an organization that supports book bans and restrictions on teaching about race and gender.

headline: Eyeing Expanding Revenue, N.F.L. Players Tap a Business Executive to Lead Their Union
abstract: Lloyd Howell Jr. was elected executive director of the union, replacing DeMaurice Smith, as gambling, new media and an expanding schedule generate more business for the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: After a 16-month search, the N.F.L. Players Association chose Lloyd Howell Jr. as its new executive director. He’ll be the fourth since the league’s 1970 merger and replace DeMaurice Smith.

headline: NATO Stresses Risk of Wagner Group’s Potential Relocation to Belarus
abstract: “Belarus is unpredictable and dangerous, and this has not changed,” the Estonian prime minister, Kaja Kallas, said in Brussels at a news conference with NATO’s secretary general. “We are ready for any developments.”
lead_paragraph: Ahead of an annual NATO summit scheduled for next month, the leaders of alliance members Estonia and Poland on Wednesday stressed the need for vigilance over the Wagner mercenary group’s potential relocation to Belarus.

headline: Hurricane Adrian Churns Off the Coast of Mexico in the Eastern Pacific
abstract: The storm was more than 400 miles off Mexico’s west coast on Thursday. It was forecast to stay offshore.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Adrian continued to move westward off the coast of Mexico on Thursday, a day after it rapidly intensified to become the first hurricane in the eastern Pacific region this year, the National Hurricane Center said.

headline: Ukraine Diary: Kyiv hosts Ukraine’s first-ever L.G.B.T.Q. film festival.
abstract: A landmark happening in its own right, the seven-day event also took place during a war — one that rights advocates said has increased visibility and acceptance of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
lead_paragraph: This is one in an occasional series of dispatches about life amid the war in Ukraine.

headline: Nursing Homes Defrauded Taxpayers of $83 Million, Lawsuit Says
abstract: The nursing homes illegally misused Medicare and Medicaid funds for personal enrichment and neglected patients, according to the New York attorney general, Letitia James.
lead_paragraph: The owners and operators of four nursing homes siphoned off more than $83 million in taxpayer funds while neglecting residents, leading to injuries and death, according to the New York State attorney general, Letitia James, who filed a lawsuit against the owners on Wednesday.

headline: DeSantis’s Taxpayer-Funded Helicopter Ride in Texas Draws Scrutiny
abstract: It’s not the first time that the Florida governor has faced accusations of inappropriately blurring the lines between his official duties and his presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: It was a photo op intended to turbocharge Republican voters, one showing Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida posing in front of a helicopter on Sunday at the southern border in Texas.

headline: Some South Koreans Just Became Younger Overnight
abstract: A South Korea law that went into effect on Wednesday standardized how the government counts ages, instantly making residents one or two years younger.
lead_paragraph: South Koreans became a year or two younger on Wednesday after a law standardizing the way the government counts age took effect.

headline: School Official Convicted After Students Ate Chicken With Bits of Metal
abstract: Eric Goldstein, who oversaw the feeding of New York schoolchildren, took bribes to allow food with bits of bone and plastic in cafeterias.
lead_paragraph: In late 2016, Somma Food Group had a problem with its chicken tenders.

headline: What’s In Our Queue? ‘The Silences of the Palace’ and More
abstract: I’m The Times’s North Africa bureau chief. Here are five things I've read, seen and watched lately.
lead_paragraph: I’m The Times’s North Africa bureau chief. Here are five things I've read, seen and watched lately.

headline: A Cherry Pie That’s as Sweet (or Sour) as You Want It to Be
abstract: Use whatever kind of cherries — fresh or frozen, sour or sweet — in this adaptable cherry pie from Melissa Clark.
lead_paragraph: Apple pie may rule fall, but cherry pie is summer’s queen, lording over all other flavors for the few brief weeks when fresh cherries are in season. Because, while cherry pies made with frozen fruit are perfectly delightful, nothing beats the juicy bite of seasonal cherries, baked until syrupy and wrapped in a buttery crust.

headline: What Old-School Economics Doesn’t Get About Democracy
abstract: Danielle Allen makes the case that taxation and redistribution are poor proxies for true equality.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Allen grew up, in her own words, “in an opinionated, fractious, loving family.” Her father, “lean and bald,” was a rare Black Reagan Republican. Her Aunt Roslyn, “lesbian and built like a Mack truck, with a huge belly laugh,” was in the Peace and Freedom Party. They debated endlessly but respectfully.

headline: The Myth of Early Pandemic Polarization
abstract: When Covid arrived, partisanship had little to do with how officials responded.
lead_paragraph: I’d like to tell you a story about the pandemic, one that may sound so gauzily hopeful, it would qualify today as a public health fairy tale.

headline: Putin Moves to Punish Prigozhin Allies
abstract: Russia’s president indicates that associates of the Wagner group’s leader in government and the military will face punishment.
lead_paragraph: As President Vladimir V. Putin seeks to assert control in Russia, he is moving to punish people who enabled the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s rebellion over the weekend, but Mr. Prigozhin’s deep connections with the ruling elite are complicating those efforts.

headline: What’s Really Happening When a Cuttlefish Seems to Vanish
abstract: Their camouflage seems almost magical, but scientists have observed some tricks the cephalopods use to blend in with their surroundings.
lead_paragraph: Put a cuttlefish on the spot — or, to be more exact, a series of spots — and it will disappear. These relatives of the squid and the octopus mimic the color and texture of their surroundings, camouflaging themselves to blend in with seaweed, sand or stone, which helps them escape predators.

headline: Biden Has Begun Using a CPAP Machine for Sleep Apnea
abstract: Sleep apnea is a common disorder in which one’s breathing is interrupted as one sleeps. The president has had the condition for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has begun using a CPAP machine in recent weeks to help deal with sleep apnea, a common disorder in which one’s breathing is interrupted as one sleeps, White House officials said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny’ Review: Turning Back the Clock
abstract: The gruff appeal of Harrison Ford, both de-aged and properly weathered, is the main draw in this generally silly entry in the long-running franchise.
lead_paragraph: What makes Indy run? For years, the obvious answer was Steven Spielberg, who, starting in 1981 with “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” guided Harrison Ford’s hunky anthropologist, Dr. Henry Walton Jones Jr., in and out of gnarly escapades and ripped shirts in four box-office behemoths. By the time Spielberg directed Ford in their last outing, “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” (2008), Indy was in his late 50s and fans were speculating that the character was immortal, even if the franchise itself had begun running on fumes.

headline: Sex on the Run? No, We Parked.
abstract: An artist learns the ropes of car sex later in life — and finds a husband in the process.
lead_paragraph: Having sex in a car is usually a last resort, born from the trappings of youth. For Susan Silas, it was a midlife necessity.

headline: ‘No Hard Feelings’ Review
Overstock Sees a Future in Calling Itself Bed Bath & Beyond
abstract: The online retailer is renaming its website and its mobile app after buying the intellectual property of the bankrupt home-goods store.
lead_paragraph: Soon, Overstock.com will become Bed Bath & Beyond — at least in digital form.

headline: ‘Asteroid City’: Wes Anderson and His All-Stars Go Meta
Our Best Fourth of July Recipes
A Night Out for Dinner Ends in Destruction and Death
abstract: A Russian missile strike on a popular restaurant in Kramatorsk, Ukraine killed at least 11 people, wounded dozens more, and showed the peril of trying to claim pieces of ordinary life during war.
lead_paragraph: Mykyta Karagodin and his friends had just gotten their mango-passion fruit drinks and placed their dinner order on the terrace of the Ria Lounge on Tuesday night — a lazy summer evening at a popular restaurant in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kramatorsk. Then they heard a whistle.

headline: The Best Beach Umbrella Is Not Actually an Umbrella
The Best Cheap Sunglasses
Get to Know Elin Hilderbrand
The Best Carry-On Luggage
Popcast (Deluxe): Kim Petras’s New LP and Jennifer Lawrence’s Return
abstract: Up for discussion this week: “The Idol” approaches its finale, the conclusion of Kesha and Dr. Luke’s legal battle and more.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Stress Tests Show Largest Banks Are Sturdy, Fed Says
abstract: The Federal Reserve tested banks’ ability to endure a real estate crash, high unemployment and trading turmoil.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that the largest U.S. banks were well capitalized and prepared to withstand large economic and financial market shocks, after it subjected them to a series of hypothetical disaster scenarios.

headline: Debris and Presumed Human Remains From Lost Titan Are Recovered
abstract: Debris from the Titan was returned to land off Newfoundland, nearly a week after an international search-and-rescue effort for the vessel ended and its five passengers were presumed dead.
lead_paragraph: Debris and presumed human remains from the Titan submersible have been recovered and returned to land, the U.S. Coast Guard announced Wednesday night, nearly a week after an international search-and-rescue operation ended and the vessel’s five passengers were presumed dead.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Who knew about the mutiny?
abstract: Also, China looks to boost its exports.
lead_paragraph: My colleagues in Washington reported that Gen. Sergei Surovikin, who was once Russia’s top commander in Ukraine, knew about the planned revolt. Yesterday, a Kremlin spokesman called The Times’s reporting, based on interviews with U.S. officials, “speculations” and “gossip,” but did not deny it.

headline: Ben Helfgott, Holocaust Survivor Turned Weight Lifter, Dies at 93
abstract: He was one of more than 700 child survivors flown to Britain after World War II. He later became a leader in efforts to remember the Nazi horrors.
lead_paragraph: Ben Helfgott, a Polish Jew who, after being liberated from Nazi imprisonment in 1945 weighing a skeletal 80 pounds, became an Olympic weight lifter for Britain, his adopted country, and who later dedicated himself to a public life of Holocaust education and remembrance, died on June 16 at his home in London. He was 93.

headline: Summer Airline Woes Are Here: What to Expect Traveling This Weekend.
abstract: Delays and cancellations have hit airports in the Northeast, just in time for the July 4 holiday. Airlines and regulators are bickering about who is to blame. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: A dayslong disruption of flights into and out of the Greater New York area is raising concerns about how prepared airlines are for the Fourth of July holiday, a weekend that is forecast to have record numbers of air travelers.

headline: The Emerging Science of Tracing Smoke Back to Wildfires
abstract: An upcoming study links smoke pollution across the United States to individual wildfires and could help predict which fires will be most harmful to public health.
lead_paragraph: As smoke from wildfires crosses state and international borders more frequently, tracking and studying it is increasingly important for shaping air quality and health measures around the world.

headline: Judges Block Transgender Care Bans for Minors in Kentucky and Tennessee
abstract: The rulings extend a winning streak in court for transgender-rights advocates, who are trying to block new state laws that ban gender-transition care.
lead_paragraph: Federal judges in two states intervened on Wednesday to temporarily block laws that would ban gender-transition care for minors, the latest instances where legislation targeting transgender people have been halted by the judiciary.

headline: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
abstract: This month’s picks obsess over the methods of Pablo Picasso and Stanley Kubrick; and dissect three minutes of film footage taken in Poland in 1938.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Satellite images show rapid construction at a deserted military base in Belarus. Is it Wagner’s new home?
abstract: The images reveal a possible location for the mercenaries who were given the option of relocating to Belarus after the group’s failed rebellion against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: Satellite imagery shows that Belarus is rapidly building what appear to be temporary structures at a deserted military base, revealing a possible location for Wagner fighters who were given the option of relocating to the country after the group’s failed mutiny against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: The emerging science of tracing smoke back to wildfires.
abstract: As smoke from wildfires crosses state and international borders more frequently, tracking and studying it is increasingly important for shaping air quality and health measures around the world.
lead_paragraph: As smoke from wildfires crosses state and international borders more frequently, tracking and studying it is increasingly important for shaping air quality and health measures around the world.

headline: Victims of Convicted Gynecologist Confront Him in Sentencing Hearing
abstract: Robert A. Hadden lured women across state lines to molest them, spurring a federal case. His punishment will be decided next month.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 11 years to the day after Laurie Kanyok ran out of her gynecologist’s office in Manhattan and reported him for sexual assault, she stood in front of him in a federal court yet again.

headline: Wildfire Smoke Is Back, This Time in the Midwest
abstract: Also, the Kremlin insisted that the army has Putin’s back. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after dangerous air choked the Northeast, residents of several major cities in the Midwest — including Chicago, Detroit and Indianapolis — were urged to stay indoors today as smoke again blanketed large parts of the country.

headline: Auto-Industry Group Assails Biden’s Plan to Electrify America’s Cars
abstract: The E.P.A.’s plan is “neither reasonable nor achievable,” the lobbying group said, using strong language in the face of the urgency to cut planet-warming emissions from vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The auto industry’s largest lobbying organization has come out against the Biden administration’s most ambitious climate change regulation, a proposed rule designed to ensure that two-thirds of new passenger cars sold in the United States are all-electric by 2032.

headline: Madonna Postpones ‘Celebration’ Tour After ‘Serious Bacterial Infection’
abstract: The 64-year-old pop icon was hospitalized for several days and remains under medical care, her agent said. A new start date for her tour has not been announced.
lead_paragraph: Madonna was hospitalized for several days with a “serious bacterial infection,” forcing her to postpone her forthcoming “Celebration” tour, her manager said on Wednesday.

headline: Smoky Skies Menace U.S. Cities, Driving Residents Indoors
abstract: Across the nation’s middle, unhealthy air from Canadian wildfires sent summer campers home and left residents coughing, and asking when this would end.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the smoke and air quality.

headline: Microsoft and Activision Chiefs Testify Merger Will Benefit Consumers
abstract: In federal court, Satya Nadella and Bobby Kotick opposed an attempt by the F.T.C. to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of a video game giant.
lead_paragraph: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, appeared in federal court on Wednesday to pledge his support for open platforms and consumer choice, underscoring the tech giant’s commitment to closing its $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard over regulators’ objections.

headline: Costco Is Cracking Down on Membership Sharing
abstract: The wholesale retailer announced on Wednesday that it will require identification at all registers, including self-checkout lanes, eliminating a popular shopping secret.
lead_paragraph: The success of Costco’s business model relies on rigor. The wholesale retailer, which uses a membership system, strictly monitors entrances and exits and double checks customer receipts.

headline: Mississippi Deputies Are ‘Terminated’ After 2 Black Men Claim Abuse
abstract: A federal lawsuit against the former deputies from Rankin County said that they assaulted the men with a sex toy and shot one in the face. An internal investigation is ongoing.
lead_paragraph: Several Mississippi deputy sheriffs who were accused of sexually assaulting two Black men and shooting one of them in the face have been fired or have resigned, the Rankin County Sheriff’s Office said on Tuesday.

headline: Grand Jury Declines to Indict Man in Fatal Subway Stabbing
abstract: Jordan Williams acted in self-defense, his lawyer said. He had argued with the victim, Devictor Ouedraogo, on a J train, resulting in the fifth killing on the subway this year.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury voted not to indict a man who stabbed a passenger on a subway train this month in Brooklyn, ending the case, the man’s lawyer said.

headline: In Harlem and Beyond, N.Y.C. Election Points to Generational Power Shift
abstract: Yusef Salaam, exonerated as part of the Central Park 5 in 2002, appeared to be heading toward a City Council victory as voters embraced more moderate candidates.
lead_paragraph: Walking down 125th Street the day after taking a commanding lead in the race for a City Council seat in Central Harlem, Yusef Salaam couldn’t make it half a block without someone congratulating him on his likely victory.

headline: The Wannabe Putin in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Why would Biden reset relations with a crown prince who seeks a nuclear program?
lead_paragraph: American leaders have peered into Vladimir Putin’s eyes to sense “his soul,” have praised him as “very straightforward and trustworthy” or even a “genius.” They have “reset” relations, tolerated invasions of Georgia and Crimea, averted eyes from atrocities and even gone so far as to blame “U.S. foolishness” for strains in Russia-American relations — because they wanted a steady relationship, and Putin was unmistakably in control of an important country.

headline: Review: A Drowsy Night at ‘Grief Hotel’
abstract: Liza Birkenmeier’s abstract play is a unique exploration of romantic relationships but suffers from sleepy direction and a lack of character enrichment.
lead_paragraph: Absurdist theater is like the naturalistic play’s overachieving older sibling. Traditional theater attempts to describe the chaos of the human condition, but absurdist works dare to enact it. Liza Birkenmeier’s “Grief Hotel” is one of those enactors, a strange, snack-sized play that closes out Clubbed Thumb’s 2023 Summerworks series — a proud incubator for strange plays.

headline: You’re So Vain, You Probably Think This Campaign Is About You
abstract: R.F.K. Jr. is a walking, talking conspiracy theory.
lead_paragraph: Let’s start with some positive things about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s campaign for president.

headline: Mets Owner Preaches Patience While Resetting Expectations
abstract: Steven A. Cohen said his manager and general manager are safe, but he acknowledged his struggling club with a record payroll could soon trade away some of its stars.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen did not expect to be in this position when the season began. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the Mets, had committed nearly $500 million to free agents this off-season, looking to improve a roster that was coming off a 101-win season. And yet there he was on Wednesday, sitting in the Citi Field news conference room fielding questions about the sorry state of his fourth-place team.

headline: A Record 100,000 People in New York Homeless Shelters
abstract: An influx of migrants has contributed to record numbers of people entering the city’s shelter system.
lead_paragraph: New York City passed a woeful milestone this week, spurred by an influx of migrants from the nation’s southern border: For the first time, there are now over 100,000 people in homeless shelters here, city officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Republicans’ Anti-Woke, Anti-Vote Crusade Has Crashed Into the Constitution
abstract: G.O.P. politicians today aren’t constitutional absolutists. They’re constitutional opportunists.
lead_paragraph: Before the dust had cleared on the 2020 election, Republicans in statehouses across the country had already regrouped and coalesced around a core crusade — revived and revitalized — that was anti-woke and anti-vote.

headline: ‘Anthem’ Review: Flying High
abstract: In this naïve, nostalgic documentary, a pair of musicians go on a road trip with the ambitious mission of creating a new national anthem.
lead_paragraph: “Anthem” opens with a series of archival scenes from American history: from John F. Kennedy’s 1961 address championing space travel to Barack Obama speaking about the necessity of dissent; from members of the Ku Klux Klan waving the American flag to the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol; from the Black Power protest at the 1968 Olympics to Colin Kaepernick taking a knee on a football field. The montage strikingly illustrates the idea that nationalism can take wildly different forms that have little to do with national symbols.

headline: The Cosmos Is Thrumming With Gravitational Waves, Astronomers Find
abstract: Radio telescopes around the world picked up a telltale hum reverberating across the cosmos, most likely from supermassive black holes merging in the early universe.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, an international consortium of research collaborations revealed compelling evidence for the existence of a low-pitch hum of gravitational waves reverberating across the universe.

headline: Chris Printup, Founder of Streetwear Brand Born X Raised, Dies at 42
abstract: Mr. Printup, known as “Spanto,” died on Wednesday morning in Albuquerque, N.M., from injuries sustained in a car accident on Sunday, the brand confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Chris Printup, a founder of the streetwear brand Born X Raised, which became a fixture in Los Angeles’s fashion scene, died on Wednesday morning at a hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 42 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: A Symbol of Commitment
abstract: A deep apology to Simeon Seigel.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Review: This ‘Hamlet’ Under the Stars Is No Walk in the Park
abstract: The Public Theater’s alfresco production has plenty to offer audiences who know the play already. But it may not be so easy for newcomers.
lead_paragraph: For those who remember the 2019 Shakespeare in the Park production of “Much Ado About Nothing” — as I do, fondly — the sight that awaits them at this summer’s “Hamlet” in the same location is disturbing.

headline: Yankees Pitcher Throws M.L.B.’s First Perfect Game Since 2012
abstract: Domingo Germán was masterful, cruising through the Oakland Athletics and securing baseball’s 24th perfect game.
lead_paragraph: During bids for no-hitters and perfect games, conventional baseball superstition demands that the pitcher throwing the gem not be disturbed. Teammates and coaches shy away.

headline: At a Theater in Midtown, New York Will Honor One of Its Own
abstract: Today is Lloyd Richards Day, in recognition of an esteemed theater figure who directed August Wilson’s plays on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday, and it’s also Lloyd Richards Day, according to a proclamation from the Manhattan borough president. We’ll find out how the day became official. We’ll also check on the Canadian wildfires and the air quality today in New York.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Warnings of a crackdown on those affiliated with the head of Wagner.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, has indicated that he will punish people who enabled the Wagner mercenary boss Yevgeny Prigozhin’s rebellion over the weekend. But the Wagner leader’s deep ties to the ruling elite are complicating those efforts.

headline: Aleksandr Lukashenko Is Trying to Get Our Attention
abstract: The Belarusian leader is once again trying to burnish his global image after the failed coup in Russia.
lead_paragraph: Belarus’s president, Aleksandr Lukashenko, is trying to get our attention. He is preening on the global stage, making the rounds in the media to take credit for brokering an end to the armed mutiny in Russia last weekend. Just weeks before, the Belarusian strongman proudly announced the delivery of the first Russian tactical nuclear weapons to Belarus, boasting that he would not hesitate to use them.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Creators Sue Montana, It’s TikTok Footing the Bill
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We walked into the lion’s den almost a whole week before TikTok decided to come and back us up on this, because we see how important this is.”

headline: Corrections: June 29, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Republican criticism of the Justice Department’s investigation of Hunter Biden referred incorrectly to a letter that Representative Jim Jordan sent to David C. Weiss. It did not address his use of the term “ultimate authority.” It also misstated the day the letter was sent. It was sent last week, not on Monday.

headline: A History of Yankees Perfect Games
abstract: A look at the four perfect games thrown by Yankees pitchers, from Don Larsen all the way to Domingo Germán.
lead_paragraph: A look at the four perfect games thrown by Yankees pitchers, from Don Larsen all the way to Domingo Germán.

headline: Word of the Day: lucent
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word lucent has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 10 in “‘Where We Belong’ Review: A Performer Wonders, What’s in a Name?” by Naveen Kumar:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Reverberations of Pain and Its Dismissal
abstract: On ‘The Retrievals,’ a new podcast presented by Serial Productions and The New York Times, a dozen women speak about their traumatic experiences at a fertility clinic, where pain medication was secretly swapped out for saline.
lead_paragraph: In November 2021, Susan Burton came across a news article from a local Connecticut outlet that detailed the experiences of several women who had visited the Yale Fertility Center. During their egg retrieval procedures, a first surgical step in some fertility treatments, a nurse had secretly swapped out their pain medication, fentanyl, for saline, a solution of salt and water.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: How Bad Will the Ticks Be This Summer?
abstract: Thanks to migrating birds and deer vasectomies, new tick species are settling in New York City, as some experts prepare for the worst.
lead_paragraph: If you end up becoming one of the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers expected to be bitten by a tick this summer, don’t be surprised.

headline: Tour de France: Vingegaard vs. Pogacar Is the Race to Watch
abstract: The 110th edition of cycling’s greatest race begins Saturday in Spain. Here’s a primer on the stars, the squads and the story lines.
lead_paragraph: The Tour de France, cycling’s most famous race, and perhaps its greatest competitive challenge, kicks off its 110th edition on Saturday.

headline: Domingo Germán Proves Perfection Can Come at Any Time
abstract: Booed off the mound in his last start for the Yankees, Germán joined a fraternity of pitchers that runs the gamut from Hall of Famers to otherwise forgettable fill-ins.
lead_paragraph: In his first start of the 1956 World Series, Don Larsen could not complete two innings. He faced only 10 batters, and six reached base. By the time the game was over, the Brooklyn Dodgers had pelted the Yankees for 13 runs.

headline: 36 Hours on Martha’s Vineyard, Mass.
abstract: Seafood shacks, charming cottages and wild beauty are just a few of the draws that lure visitors to the Massachusetts island year after year.
lead_paragraph: Seafood shacks, charming cottages and wild beauty are just a few of the draws that lure visitors to the Massachusetts island year after year.

headline: Exclusive: Inside a Ukrainian Battlefield Hospital
abstract: The New York Times gained rare access to a military field hospital in eastern Ukraine, capturing the relentless toll of Russia’s war through the eyes of frontline combat medics and wounded soldiers.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times gained rare access to a military field hospital in eastern Ukraine, capturing the relentless toll of Russia’s war through the eyes of frontline combat medics and wounded soldiers.

headline: ‘It’s a Struggle Against Death’: Ukrainian Combat Medics Race to Save Lives
abstract: Every day in Ukraine, combat medics are racing to save the lives of wounded soldiers. In this exclusive video, The New York Times spent a week inside a military field hospital to capture the relentless toll of Russia’s war.
lead_paragraph: Every day in Ukraine, combat medics are racing to save the lives of wounded soldiers. In this exclusive video, The New York Times spent a week inside a military field hospital to capture the relentless toll of Russia’s war.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Playing Monopoly
abstract: Is it OK to change the rules?
lead_paragraph: Scott writes: My partner wants to change the house Monopoly rules, limiting the number of houses we can build on each property in order to make the game last longer. Please order her to stop.

headline: Jennifer Croft Knows a Good Translation When She Reads One
