lead_paragraph: The first question at a community conversation with Mayor Eric Adams in Washington Heights on Wednesday night was about New York City’s housing crisis.

headline: In Nahel M., a Stranger Killed by Police, French Protesters See Friend and Kin
abstract: “We don’t forget, we don’t forgive,” crowds chanted as they denounced the shooting death of a 17-year-old from the Paris suburb of Nanterre.
lead_paragraph: They called him their son, their brother, their friend, and they came by the thousands to grieve, to vent and to revolt.

headline: Biden’s Iran Envoy Is Placed on Leave Amid Security Clearance Review
abstract: Even before the news about his leave, Robert Malley seemed to be playing a less prominent role in U.S. policy toward Iran in recent months.
lead_paragraph: The State Department placed President Biden’s envoy for Iran, Robert Malley, on unpaid leave on Thursday amid a review of his security clearance.

headline: Ex-Social Worker, 32, Pretended to Be a Boston High School Student, Police Say
abstract: Shelby Hewitt forged documents and enrolled at three different public high schools, according to records. Her motive for doing so was unclear.
lead_paragraph: At English High School, she went by Ellie. At Jeremiah E. Burke High School, she introduced herself as Daniella.

headline: Police Shooting in France Presents New Challenge for Macron
abstract: Protests over the fatal police shooting of a teenager come as President Emmanuel Macron seeks to restore a sense of calm after his pension overhaul ignited turbulence in the streets.
lead_paragraph: The deadly shooting of a teenager, a French citizen of Algerian and Moroccan descent, by a police officer outside Paris has ignited a wave of violent protest that once again confronts President Emmanuel Macron with turmoil in the streets and has revived accusations of endemic racism in France’s law enforcement agencies.

headline: In Affirmative Action Ruling, Black Justices Take Aim at Each Other
abstract: Even as Justices Clarence Thomas and Ketanji Brown Jackson appeared to agree over the policy’s aim, they harshly criticized each other’s conclusions on what to do.
lead_paragraph: In an extraordinary exchange that played out among the pages of a landmark decision by the Supreme Court declaring race-conscious admissions at colleges and universities across the nation unlawful, two Black justices battled over the merits of affirmative action.

headline: Corrections: June 30, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 30, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about restoring ecological health to Ireland misstated Randal Plunkett’s age. He is 40, not 30.

headline: Easy Mode: Clues for Friday, June 30, 2023
abstract: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.

headline: French Thinker
abstract: Carly Schuna’s second New York Times crossword makes me look forward to their third.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Mark Halpin returns with a quiet acrostic that resonates.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s puzzle, constructed by Mark Halpin, draws from a hefty historical novel called “Wolf Hall,” by Hilary Mantel, which won the Man Booker Prize in 2009. The book is the first in a trilogy that provides a fictional portrait of Thomas Cromwell, who was chief minister to King Henry VIII from 1534 until Cromwell’s demise by beheading in 1540. An awful lot happened in those six years, much of which is depicted in “Wolf Hall” and its sequels, “Bring Up the Bodies” and “The Mirror and the Light.” There were battles, there were more beheadings and there was a plague — the kinds of things that provide context for this acrostic’s excerpt, which concerns loss and a sort of sensory residue that loss leaves behind.

headline: N.Y.C. Mayor Compares Housing Activist to Plantation Owner
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams told Jeanie Dubnau to “treat me with the same level of respect I treat you” and compared her to a plantation owner when she pointedly asked about back-to-back rent hikes.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams told Jeanie Dubnau to “treat me with the same level of respect I treat you” and compared her to a plantation owner when she pointedly asked about back-to-back rent hikes.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Teen’s Killing Revives Conversation on Race, Power and Identity
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I’m afraid for my children. I don’t worry about robbers. I worry about the Republic coming for them.”

headline: The End of LIBOR Is (Finally) Here
abstract: It has been an arduous process to get the financial system to stop relying on the tarnished interest-rate benchmark.
lead_paragraph: The arduous, decade-long process to end the financial system’s reliance on a tarnished interest-rate benchmark, which once underpinned trillions of dollars in contracts across the globe, is almost over. From next week, the rate, known as the London Interbank Offered Rate, or LIBOR for short, will cease to be published.

headline: Was I Married to a Stranger?
abstract: I thought I knew my husband of 20 years. I didn’t — and still don’t.
lead_paragraph: When the lockdown started in March 2020, my husband and I decided to quarantine with our two youngest children, then 15 and 12, at our house on Martha’s Vineyard. We arrived on March 15 and settled in for a long stay, unpacking sweaters and boots, textbooks and cellos.

headline: A Bond Built Over Coffee Leads to Success in Love and Business
abstract: Sahra Nguyen and Erics Kun’s connection grew slowly during early morning meetups at Brooklyn cafes. Now, they are partners in life and at Nguyen Coffee Supply, founded by Ms. Nguyen.
lead_paragraph: Erics Kun was fighting yawns the first few times he and Sahra Nguyen got together in the fall of 2016. This was no reflection on her. After staying up all night in his bartending job, he couldn’t pass up the chance to see her for early morning coffee.

headline: She Said Yes in a House of Worship
abstract: Elan Cooperman and Sydney Berger went on a date after years of frequenting the same temple, but it was their almost religious fervor for New York sports teams that sealed the deal.
lead_paragraph: Bagels, lox and N.F.L. marathons — that’s how Elan David Cooperman grew up spending nearly every Sunday at his childhood home in Roslyn, N.Y.

headline: After Several ‘Unofficial Dates,’ the Real Romance Began
abstract: Isabella Reyes and Andrew Sublett met in college 13 years ago and developed a friendship that included cafeteria lunches and yogurt runs.
lead_paragraph: The first time Isabella Delgado Reyes realized that Andrew Charles Sublett really liked her was when the two were having lunch together on Feb. 17, 2010 at the University of California, Berkeley. He brought her a tube of mini M&M’s, her favorite candy.

headline: From Mom Friends to So Much More
abstract: When Lauren Pariani and Kate Schatz first met on a school playground, they had no idea where life would lead them.
lead_paragraph: In September 2018, Lauren Davis Pariani and Kate Elizabeth Schatz met on a school playground. Their sons, who had just started kindergarten, soon after became best friends and during multiple play dates the two women forged a close bond.

headline: A French Newsroom on Strike After Appointment of ‘Far-Right’ Editor
abstract: Journalists at a leading newspaper, Le Journal du Dimanche, have walked out over fears that Geoffroy Lejeune will turn it into a right-wing platform.
lead_paragraph: In its 75-year history, Le Journal du Dimanche, France’s leading Sunday newspaper, has almost never missed publication. But its operations ground to a halt this week after an editor with a far-right track record was abruptly appointed just ahead of a takeover of the paper by the French billionaire Vincent Bolloré, prompting a mass walkout by journalists and igniting a firestorm in French media and political circles.

headline: Man Accused in Jan. 6 Riot Is Arrested With Weapons Near Obama’s Home
abstract: A law enforcement official said that weapons, ammunition and materials that could make explosives were found inside the man’s nearby van.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the Capitol was arrested Thursday afternoon near the Washington home of former President Barack Obama, as police found weapons, ammunition and materials that could make explosives inside the suspect’s van, according to a law enforcement official familiar with the case.

headline: A Good Day for Libraries, but Others Feel a Budget Squeeze
abstract: The deal between the mayor and the City Council will mean cuts that affect services at Rikers and MetroCards for low-income New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the deal for a $107 billion city budget. We’ll also see why this could be a particularly bad tick season.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A blow to affirmative action in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: In a 6-3 decision, the Supreme Court rejected race-conscious affirmative action at colleges and universities, declaring that admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were unlawful and sharply curtailing a policy that had long been a pillar of higher education.

headline: Putin Thinks He’s Still in Control. He’s Not.
abstract: His system of rule simply can’t go on much longer.
lead_paragraph: The Scarlet Sails festival is one of Russia’s most popular holidays. A celebration of high school graduates held in St. Petersburg, it culminates in a spectacular light show, where ships — including one with scarlet sails — pass along the Neva River, fireworks cracking above them. Teenagers mill about the city and drink on the banks of the river while members of the Russian elite, officials and oligarchs alike, congregate to drink champagne on their luxurious yachts. No one enjoys the occasion more than President Vladimir Putin, who loves this student holiday in his hometown and never misses a private party on the river, watching the ships go by.

headline: Word of the Day: hackles
abstract: This word has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word hackles has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 13 in “BBC Ends Suspension of Top Sports Host After Staff Mutiny” by Mark Landler:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Tracking What Happened to Abortion Providers After the Dobbs Decision
abstract: A current list of clinics that had closed, altered services or relocated didn’t exist — so two Times reporters made one.
lead_paragraph: Amy Schoenfeld Walker, a reporter and graphics editor who covers abortion for The New York Times, spotted an article in March by Shalina Chatlani, a New York Times local investigative fellow.

headline: New York’s Shelters Were Packed. Now They Are Bursting at the Seams.
abstract: The population of homeless people touched a record 100,000 this week, driven by an influx of migrants. The system is straining to adapt.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, New York’s shelter system was under strain, with 61,000 residents. Officials said it was at capacity — or over.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Protecting Australia’s Most Charismatic Murder-Bird
abstract: Cassowaries play a critical role in the Australian ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: Meet an Australian supermodel for the ages: six feet tall with a sculptured visage, endless legs and piercing orange eyes.

headline: What Makes a Diva?
abstract: A new exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum, in London, tracks the term’s shifting meanings from the 19th-century opera house to the stadium gigs of today.
lead_paragraph: Opera singer. Style icon. Outspoken woman. Divine being. High-maintenance nightmare.

headline: Keep Teenagers Home, Macron Urges Parents After New Night of Unrest
abstract: Over 800 people were arrested in France as a third night of protests over the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old rocked cities around the country. Many protesters were teenagers, too, officials said.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France urgently appealed to parents on Friday after a third night of unrest over the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old, with French officials saying that the protests were driven mostly by angry young people who had coordinated and copied one another on social media.

headline: Don’t Take It From a ‘Thinkboi’
abstract: You can do a lot of work for a long time and hope you are someday rewarded with success. Or you can skip the grueling, boring part and tweet as if you already are a success.
lead_paragraph: You can do a lot of work for a long time and hope you are someday rewarded with success. Or you can skip the grueling, boring part and tweet as if you already are a success.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of “Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny.”
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of “Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny.”

headline: 5 Fascinating Space and Astronomy Images From June
abstract: Take a look at a visit with the planet Mercury and other new views from around the cosmos.
lead_paragraph: Take a look at a visit with the planet Mercury and other new views from around the cosmos.

headline: Newly Published, from Young Adult Novels to Political Tumult in Translation
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: THE GRIMOIRE OF GRAVE FATES, created by Hanna Alkaf and Margaret Owen. (Delacorte Press, $18.99.) Eighteen young adult authors each write a different character’s perspective in this novel, which follows students at a magic school trying to solve a professor’s mysterious murder.

headline: The Supreme Court Turns ‘Equal Protection’ Upside Down
abstract: Its ruling on affirmative action in college admissions overturns decades of precedents and programs that helped thousands of American students.
lead_paragraph: In striking down affirmative action in higher education on Thursday, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority said it had to do so because the Constitution forbids any form of racial distinction. With a single opinion, the justices overturned decades of precedents that upheld race-conscious admissions policies as consistent with the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause and ignored the reality of modern America, where prejudice and racism endure.

headline: Me Walk Pretty One Day
abstract: Nothing gets between the humorist David Sedaris and his 21,000 daily steps.
lead_paragraph: Over the past month of our walking series, we’ve cultivated awe, encouraged conversation, stepped up our workouts and looked for microadventures. I want to end on a more lighthearted note. David Sedaris, an avid walker, humorist and author of 13 books, including “Me Talk Pretty One Day” and “Happy-Go-Lucky,” is the perfect person to help me.

headline: 5 Scenic E.V. Road Trips
abstract: Want to hit the road with your electric vehicle? These U.S. road trips offer gorgeous overlooks, welcoming stops and ample charging stations.
lead_paragraph: A record 43.2 million travelers are expected to hit the road this weekend for the Fourth of July holiday, according to the automobile owners group AAA, an increase of 1.7 million or 4 percent over 2019. But compared to the pre-pandemic times, more road trips now have the potential to veer green, thanks to the steady uptick of electric car interest and availability, as well as an expanding number of routes with the necessary infrastructure.

headline: Wall St. Foresees a Rosy 6 Months. Corporate America Isn’t So Sure.
abstract: As companies begin to report earnings and make forecasts, investors are looking for signs of resilience, while executives are playing cautious.
lead_paragraph: Stubbornly high inflation, a debt ceiling brawl, a brief banking crisis and the prospect of even higher interest rates: The past six months brought much to unsettle even the most optimistic investor.

headline: Bridget Jones Deserved Better. We All Did.
abstract: Helen Fielding’s ditzy heroine was all the rage when she was introduced to American audiences in 1998. Today, her nuttiness and self-loathing read like a relic from another time.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, why am I so unattractive? Why?”

headline: Are We Seeing Cracks in Putin’s Regime?
abstract: The Russia scholar Stephen Kotkin discusses how Russia’s war in Ukraine and the recent Wagner mutiny are shattering Putin’s ‘mystique of power.’
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, in the course of about 36 hours, Vladimir Putin faced — and then survived — one of the most serious challenges to his rule in over 20 years. An armed rebellion led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of a Russian mercenary group, took control of a southern military town, and then advanced toward Moscow, coming within about 125 miles of the city. Then, as suddenly as the rebellion began, it was over: Prigozhin was quickly exiled to Belarus without facing criminal charges — an outcome that shocked many Russia watchers.

headline: Is A.I. Poisoning Itself?, Billionaire Cage Fight and Cooking With ChatGPT
abstract: The missing ingredient in A.I. content might soon be human-generated content.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s on TikTok or Twitter, A.I.-generated content is already flooding the web. So, what happens when the technology — prone to confidently making things up — starts ingesting itself?

headline: What Frederick Douglass Knew That Trump and DeSantis Don’t
abstract: Birthright citizenship is the constitutional provision that makes a multiracial democracy of equals possible.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment during the Trump administration when the president and his most ideologically committed advisers searched for a way to end birthright citizenship.

headline: Despite Battle Over Politics, Florida Tourism Rolls On
abstract: Even as civil rights groups suggest travelers should rethink trips to the state because of policies enacted by its Republican lawmakers, it remains a tourism juggernaut. And some visitors say their spending actually supports opposition to the new laws.
lead_paragraph: For months leading up to Jean Franco Rivera’s one-year wedding anniversary, he had the perfect plan to celebrate: Travel to Disney World and go on all his favorite rides with his husband, Ahmed, and brother-in-law, Luis. The three men, all gay and Latino, are originally from Puerto Rico, but now live in Texas. As the trip approached, ‌Jean Franco, 42, said they felt somewhat concerned about traveling to a state that had passed legislation targeting L.G.B.T.Q. people in recent months.

headline: Gas-Powered Cars Are an Environmental Catastrophe. I’ll Miss Them Anyway.
abstract: Electric cars aren’t nearly as fun to drive.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been driving for nearly 30 years, but until recently, I hadn’t ever changed my car engine’s oil by myself. Of course I hadn’t: By the time I got my first car, in the mid-1990s, cars had long since become reliable enough that you could go years without popping the hood. In Southern California, where I grew up, there’s a quick-lube place on just about every other corner. Owning a car meant pulling into one as regularly as you visited a dentist, catching up on old magazines in the lounge as a technician mucked about under your ride for a half-hour before you went on with your day.

headline: The True Threat of Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Technology forged by private markets won’t solve the world’s problems. It will only amplify them.
lead_paragraph: In May, more than 350 technology executives, researchers and academics signed a statement warning of the existential dangers of artificial intelligence. “Mitigating the risk of extinction from A.I. should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war,” the signatories warned.

headline: William Lauder Buys Another Park Avenue Co-op. Is He Thinking ‘Duplex’?
abstract: The chairman of Estée Lauder paid nearly $25 million for a full-floor unit at 778 Park, one floor below the full-floor apartment he already owns in the building.
lead_paragraph: The cosmetics scion William P. Lauder picked up another high-profile property with the purchase of a sprawling Upper East Side apartment from the estate of Claudia Cohen, the gossip reporter and socialite.

headline: Five Ways College Admissions Could Change
abstract: The Supreme Court’s affirmative action decision could upend how students apply to college, and how they are judged. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Students may change what they write about in the college essay. And they may no longer be tortured by the SAT and ACT.

headline: The Most Exciting Show in Baseball
abstract: It took less than three weeks for Elly De La Cruz, a Cincinnati Reds infielder, to establish himself, and his team, as a force to be reckoned with in the N.L. Central.
lead_paragraph: Elly De La Cruz was relaxing with a group of teammates in the visitors’ clubhouse at Camden Yards on Monday when news broke that he had been named the National League Player of the Week after only his 17th game in the big leagues.

headline: Repeal of Affirmative Action Is Only the Beginning
abstract: Opponents of diversity are opponents of any racial consciousness. They want to prevent us from understanding the ways that the past informs the present.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest about the painful reality: America has functioned as a full democracy — guaranteeing the franchise to all — for less than one human lifetime. In practice, our democracy is younger than me.

headline: We Have a Dopamine Problem
abstract: The neurochemical has become a boogeyman for people worried about addiction and indulgence. But the real story is a lot more complex.
lead_paragraph: The neurotransmitter dopamine is eliciting a lot of panic these days.

headline: Why Buy Anything You Could Borrow (Especially If You’re Renting)?
abstract: The sharing economy has come to apartment buildings — and landlords have discovered a new way to attract tenants.
lead_paragraph: Brooke Renteria moved to a studio in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, from California two years ago. All she had to unpack were her suitcases. The unit of less than 400 square feet in Caesura, an apartment building cater-corner from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, came with a Murphy bed, a built-in table/desk and a 49-inch smart TV.

headline: The Man Who Pictured Ghana’s Rise at Home and Abroad
abstract: James Barnor, Ghana’s first photojournalist and an influential fashion photographer in London, stars in a major survey at the Detroit Institute of Arts.
lead_paragraph: The 94-year-old British-Ghanaian photographer James Barnor calls himself “Lucky Jim” — he’s been “at the right place at the right time and met the right people” during a career spanning more than six decades and two continents, he said in a recent telephone interview from his London home.

headline: How ‘Nimona’ Helped Its Creator Explore His Emerging Identity
abstract: The graphic novelist ND Stevenson wrote the trans allegory long before he came out. When it was time to adapt it for a new film, he was ready to go further.
lead_paragraph: In the new Netflix animated film “Nimona,” the titular character makes its first appearance as a redheaded teenage girl before transforming into a charging rhino, then a grizzly, then a songbird and so on, with brief stopovers as a gorilla, an ostrich and an armadillo.

headline: Ancient Art or Fashion Forward? Both, Says a Top Batik Designer
abstract: Josephine Komara has redefined a cultural expression that was intricate and lovely but so locked in tradition it bordered on staid. “Tradition is the way we are,” she says. “Modern is the way we think.”
lead_paragraph: Josephine Komara was depressed. She had recently divorced. She had moved into a small house. Her business supplying fabric for lampshades was lucrative but unfulfilling. Ms. Komara sipped her wine and smoked a cigarette. She sank to the floor, dipping her hands into two wooden chests filled with antique Indonesian textiles.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and the Coalition of the Distrustful
abstract: The people who believe he is going to save America.
lead_paragraph: Before Covid, Gabe Whitney, a 41-year-old from West Bath, Maine, didn’t think much about vaccines. He wasn’t very political — he didn’t vote in 2020, he said, because he thought Donald Trump was a “psycho” and Joe Biden was “corrupt.” It wasn’t until the pandemic that Whitney started regularly watching the news, but as he did, he felt like things weren’t adding up. He doubted what he called “the narrative” and struggled with the hostility his questions about vaccines and other mitigations elicited from those close to him. He described being “blamed and labeled as someone who’s part of the problem because you’re questioning. Like not taking a stance on it, but just questioning. That was the worst.”

headline: As the South Stews, Temperatures Are Set to Rise in the West, Too
abstract: In the South, oppressive temperatures are expected to continue through Sunday in southern Texas and places along the Gulf of Mexico. Out West, an arid heat will take hold.
lead_paragraph: When forecasters predicted that oppressive heat would settle over much of the South for days this month, one of the first thoughts for staff members at the Mobile Botanical Gardens was how to protect their most sensitive plants.

headline: Corporate Gay for Pay
abstract: Ten companies that could make even more out of Pride next year.
lead_paragraph: Every June, it seems more and more corporations are trying to speak to and for the L.G.B.T.Q.I.A.+ community during Pride Month. This year was no different, even in the face of rising homophobia and anti-trans legislation. Whether it was Bud Lite partnering with a prominent trans influencer or the C.I.A. posting a banal message of inclusivity or Disneyland’s Clarabelle Cow being called a rising queer icon after serving in a rainbow dress during the park’s inaugural Pride Nite, companies are clamoring for a chance to make Pride about them.

headline: Shattered Nerves, Sleepless Nights: Pickleball Noise Is Driving Everyone Nuts
abstract: The incessant pop-pop-pop of the fast-growing sport has brought on a nationwide scourge of unneighborly clashes, petitions, calls to the police and lawsuits, with no solution in sight.
lead_paragraph: It sounded like popcorn warming in a microwave: sporadic bursts that quickened, gradually, to an arrhythmic clatter.

headline: French Police Won Authority to Shoot at Drivers, but Got ‘No Training Whatsoever’
abstract: Data showed a spike in fatal shootings like the one that has incited angry protests. Experts say it’s an unintended consequence of a rushed response to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: For years, French police unions argued that officers should get broader discretion over when to shoot at fleeing motorists. Time and again, lawmakers refused.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 30, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: NASCAR to Start Its Engines Along an Unlikely Course: Downtown Chicago
abstract: The race along city streets will be the first of its kind for NASCAR. Some Chicagoans are puzzled.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Lori Lightfoot announced a deal to bring NASCAR to Chicago’s downtown streets, the idea was met locally with surprise and bewilderment.

headline: Russia Destroyed Their Town. They’re Not Leaving.
abstract: Avdiivka, Ukraine, once had a prewar population of about 30,000. By March, only around 1,700 people remained.
lead_paragraph: In the town of Avdiivka, in eastern Ukraine, the near-constant Russian shelling has reduced the city to rubble.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Slows, but Underlying Price Pressures Persist
abstract: The annual rate of inflation fell to 5.5 percent in June, compared with 6.1 percent the month before. But “core” inflation edged higher.
lead_paragraph: Inflation across most economies in Europe eased last month but concerns about continuing price increases in sectors like services and food are likely to prompt the European Central Bank to raise interest rates yet again despite slowing growth and the risk of higher unemployment.

headline: Cambodian Ruler’s Facebook Account Goes Dark After Spat With Meta
abstract: Prime Minister Hun Sen, an avid user of the platform, had vowed to delete his account after Meta’s oversight board said he had used it to threaten political violence.
lead_paragraph: The usually very active Facebook account for Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia appeared to have been deleted on Friday, a day after the oversight board for Meta, Facebook’s parent company, recommended that he be suspended from the platform for threatening political opponents with violence.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Overturning of Affirmative Action, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Seeking Normalcy Amid the War’s Threats in Zaporizhzhia
abstract: The city of Zaporizhzhia in Ukraine faces three portentous risks from Russia’s war: fighting, a huge drying-up lake and potential nuclear disaster. But people in the city, which I visited, strive for a semblance of normal life. Here is what I saw.
lead_paragraph: The city of Zaporizhzhia in Ukraine faces three portentous risks from Russia’s war: fighting, a huge drying-up lake and potential nuclear disaster. But people in the city, which I visited, strive for a semblance of normal life. Here is what I saw.

headline: 11 Have Died in Rip Currents Along the Gulf Coast. Here’s How to Escape One.
abstract: Experts advise swimmers to pay attention to warning flags and beach forecasts and to not panic if they find themselves in a rip current.
lead_paragraph: At least 11 people have drowned after getting caught in rip currents that have been wreaking havoc along the Gulf of Mexico coastline in recent weeks, as rising temperatures have pushed swimmers into cooler waters.

headline: The Supreme Court Ends Affirmative Action
abstract: The decision sharply curtails a policy that has long been a pillar of American higher education.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Supreme Court overturned decades of precedent by striking down affirmative action and declaring that the race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were unlawful.

headline: The End of Affirmative Action
abstract: We’re covering the Supreme Court’s affirmative action ruling, heat in the South and a fast-fashion blunder.
lead_paragraph: The current Supreme Court has been out of step with public opinion in some of its highest-profile rulings, including on abortion and environmental protection. Yesterday’s ruling restricting race-based affirmative action at colleges and universities was different.

headline: For a Documentary on Intersex Lives, a Director Champions the Power of Activism
abstract: With “Every Body,” Julie Cohen looks at both what her subjects have been through and how they are translating those experiences into action.
lead_paragraph: The new documentary “Every Body” gets intimate with its subjects, from their birth records to their body parts. The film is about being intersex, an umbrella term for people who were born with anatomic or genetic characteristics that don’t match the typical definition of male or female.

headline: ‘The Democracy Project’ Puts America Onstage, Warts and All
abstract: In a show staged in Federal Hall, five prominent playwrights tell the story of the site of significant events in the country’s founding, without glossing over the uglier parts.
lead_paragraph: Tourists who pause outside Federal Hall, a Wall Street memorial maintained by the U.S. National Park Service, will find its neoclassical facade covered in scaffolding. Its front steps, which host a bronze statue of George Washington, are occluded, too. But until July 22, the man himself can be found inside, fussing over his dentures, his sleep and his coming inauguration.

headline: Group Accuses Ukraine of Using Prohibited Land Mines
abstract: Human Rights Watch found evidence in May that Ukrainian soldiers had fired 15 rockets at Russian forces, each containing hundreds of small antipersonnel land mines.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian soldiers fired artillery rockets containing antipersonnel land mines into a Russian-controlled area of eastern Ukraine last year in apparent violation of international agreements banning the use of such weapons, a leading human rights group said in a report released Friday.

headline: Smoky Conditions Persist Across Large Parts of U.S.
abstract: Smoke driven by the wildfires in Canada lingered over the Northeast and Midwest on Friday. Conditions were expected to improve over the Fourth of July weekend.
lead_paragraph: At least 10 states from the Midwest to the Northeast on Friday were again facing smoky conditions created by raging wildfires in Canada, capping a week in which millions of people struggled to cope with poor air quality.

headline: Kevin Spacey Called ‘Sexual Bully’ by Prosecutor in U.K. Trial
abstract: The prosecution outlined its case against the actor, who has pleaded not guilty to 12 sexual assault charges.
lead_paragraph: The actor Kevin Spacey is “a sexual bully” who “delights in making others feel powerless and uncomfortable,” a prosecutor told a British jury on Friday. Speaking at Southwark Crown Court, the prosecutor, Christine Agnew, outlined her case against the Academy Award-winning actor, who is on trial in London facing multiple charges of sexual assault.

headline: Why Corporate America Is Worried About Affirmative Action
abstract: Many businesses have adopted policies to diversify hiring but the Supreme Court’s ruling to end the policy in universities endangers those efforts.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday to strike down affirmative action at colleges and universities sent shock waves throughout higher education. But the effects of the 6-3 ruling, which found that race-conscious admissions programs were unlawful, promise to go much wider.

headline: To Unlock His Potential, He Needed to Come Home
abstract: Harrison Bader loved St. Louis but couldn’t thrive there. A weekend series between the Yankees and the Cardinals offers a reminder of a trade that helped both teams.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before Major League Baseball’s trading deadline last season, Paul DeJong, the shortstop for the St. Louis Cardinals, received a notification on his phone. It was a message in the team group chat from center fielder Harrison Bader, one of DeJong’s closest friends.

headline: Consumer Spending Stalled Last Month
abstract: The slowdown is good news for policymakers worried about inflation, but a sign that the engine of the economy could be losing steam.
lead_paragraph: Consumer spending slowed sharply last month — good news for policymakers worried about inflation, but also a sign that a crucial engine of the economic recovery could finally be losing steam.

headline: Key Inflation Gauge Cooled in May, a Glimmer of Good News for the Fed
abstract: The Federal Reserve is monitoring “core” price increases for a hint at how inflation will develop. They slowed slightly in May.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure cooled in May, mildly encouraging news that could give policymakers confidence that price increases are still moderating — though progress remains slow.

headline: Polish Authorities Detain Athlete on Charges of Being Russian Spy
abstract: It was the 14th arrest stemming from the dismantling of what officials say was a plot to sabotage arms shipments to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Poland said on Friday that it had detained a professional athlete on charges of spying for the Russian government, in the 14th arrest stemming from the dismantling of what the authorities say was a Russian spy ring that aimed to sabotage arms shipments to Ukraine.

headline: How Sweet It Is, if You’re the Boss
abstract: C.E.O. pay has risen again, reaching levels that were unthinkable a generation ago. Google, Hertz, Peloton and Live Nation lead the list.
lead_paragraph: It’s good to be the boss.

headline: Two California Companies Will Soon Sell Lab-Grown Meat
abstract: Upside Foods and Good Meat, both based in the Bay Area, are the first companies approved by the U.S. to sell meat grown from animal cells.
lead_paragraph: A state long known for pushing the envelope, California is once again at the center of a new technological trend: lab-grown meat.

headline: Retiree Medical Costs Are Expected to Moderate, but Still High
abstract: An estimate puts the average cost over a 20-year retirement at about $157,000. That’s almost double the estimate in 2002.
lead_paragraph: Retirees just got some encouraging news: Coming changes to Medicare rules for prescription drugs may help rein in their health costs.

headline: From Up Here, You Can See Manhattan, and Houses Left to Crumble
abstract: Neither development nor demolition has occurred in a community on a cliff in New Jersey since an investor group bought 12 houses in the late 2000s.
lead_paragraph: For decades, waves of immigrants and artists have caught glimpses of sea and skyline from the hills of Union City — a New Jersey town just across the Hudson River from New York City.

headline: ‘Now, Let’s Be a Starfish!’: Learning With Ms. Rachel, Song by Song
abstract: The YouTube star of “Songs for Littles,” an online video series that pulls millions of views, says she’s found her calling in encouraging children to speak.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Griffin Accurso was rushing to grab pastries on her way to a recording studio one spring morning in Manhattan. She grew hot as she left the subway with the sun beating down on her, and she took her jacket off without thinking.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 4: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 7 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 18.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Week Four of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Let’s Talk About Sex Drive
abstract: Have you experienced discrepancies in sexual desire, or do you have sexual-health related questions?
lead_paragraph: Hello, I’m Catherine Pearson, a reporter for The New York Times’s Well section, where I cover families and relationships.

headline: ‘The Bear’ Returns and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A proto-pizza emerges from a fresco in Pompeii. Also in this edition: why game shows continue to thrive, and the “Barbenheimer” double feature.
lead_paragraph: A proto-pizza emerges from a fresco in Pompeii. Also in this edition: why game shows continue to thrive, and the “Barbenheimer” double feature.

headline: Read the Document
abstract: The Supreme Court has ruled, 6-to-3, in favor of a Colorado website maker who does not want to make wedding websites celebrating same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has ruled, 6-to-3, in favor of a Colorado website maker who does not want to make wedding websites celebrating same-sex marriages.

headline: Alan Arkin, Comic Actor With a Serious Side, Dies at 89
abstract: He got laughs and won awards on Broadway in “Enter Laughing” and in movies like “Little Miss Sunshine.” But he also had a flair for drama.
lead_paragraph: Alan Arkin, who won a Tony Award for his first lead role on Broadway, received an Academy Award nomination for his first feature film, and went on to have a long and diverse career as a character actor who specialized in comedy but was equally adept at drama, died on Thursday in San Marcos, Calif. He was 89.

headline: ‘Past Lives’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Celine Song narrates a sequence from her film, featuring Greta Lee and Teo Yoo.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Celine Song narrates a sequence from her film, featuring Greta Lee and Teo Yoo.

headline: Read the document
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that the Biden administration had overstepped its authority with its plan to wipe out more than $400 billion in student debt.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled that the Biden administration had overstepped its authority with its plan to wipe out more than $400 billion in student debt.

headline: Watch an Emotional Reunion in ‘Past Lives’
abstract: The writer and director Celine Song narrates a sequence from her film featuring Greta Lee and Teo Yoo.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Soccer’s Next Big Thing Is Buying in Bulk
abstract: Networks of clubs help top teams streamline their scouting, methods and player acquisition. But who do they really serve?
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, the Colombian club Atlético Huila decided to treat its players and its coaching staff to what could be best thought of as an office night out. Huila has had a rough season. It finished at the bottom of the Apertura, the first half of the Colombian campaign. It won only five of its 20 games. A field trip was more a restorative than a reward.

headline: Ways You Can Still Cancel Your Federal Student Loan Debt
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision on student loan cancellation does not change programs that help public servants and low-income or disabled borrowers.
lead_paragraph: There are still plenty of ways to get your student debt wiped away.

headline: The ground has shifted on gay marriage for conservative Christians.
abstract: Once a focus of the nation’s culture wars, the issue has taken a back seat to gender issues.
lead_paragraph: For decades, opposition to same-sex marriage was a marquee issue for the religious right in the United States. Activists like Anita Bryant, Jerry Falwell and James Dobson characterized homosexuality as a threat to traditional family life.

headline: LIV Golf Resists Senate Request for Greg Norman’s Testimony on Saudi Deal
abstract: Less than two weeks before a planned hearing about a transaction that could reshape golf, lawmakers are struggling to assemble a witness list.
lead_paragraph: The Capitol Hill meeting room has been booked, the senators’ calendars cleared. But less than two weeks before a Senate subcommittee wants to hold a hearing about the PGA Tour’s planned venture with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, the panel’s ambitions for high-profile witnesses are encountering significant resistance.

headline: In the Kitchen With ‘The Bear’ Season 2
Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a visually stunning documentary about garbage, a lesbian comedy from Spain, a drama about a Bollywood-obsessed teen in 1980s Afghanistan and more.
lead_paragraph: This documentary by Nikolaus Geyrhalter is something of a visual oxymoron: it is a visually gorgeous, even pristine, movie about, well, garbage. The Austrian filmmaker weaves together observational portraits of trash and its handlers from across the world, from immigrant cleaners at an island resort in the Maldives, to a mechanized sorting plant in Austria, to volunteers who pick up after Burning Man in the Nevada desert. But this is no navel-gazing exercise in aestheticizing detritus or finding beauty in ugly places. Rather, Geyrhalter’s keen, rigorous tableaux provoke us to think about the massive global industry required to deal with the rubbish we so casually generate in our everyday culture of disposability.

headline: Saimin Noodles, Pork and Vegetable Pinakbet and Mochiko Chicken
abstract: New recipes for Hawaiian local food favorites are comforting, versatile and deeply delicious.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Elyse Inamine has a cool story in our pages this week about “local food” in Hawaii, food that reflects the blurred culture of all those who’ve settled on the islands over the centuries, from Polynesian settlers, British and American plantation owners and laborers from China, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Puerto Rico, Portugal and Spain. Local food is the food of the future, some in Hawaii say, an amalgamation of all that is delicious: the food local people eat, and revere.

headline: You Really Are a Tick Magnet
abstract: By studying how the arachnids respond to static electricity, researchers may have found a new reason to dread the bloodsucking creatures.
lead_paragraph: Most people try, or at least hope, to avoid ticks. The tiny arachnids spread a variety of harmful diseases, as they expand their range to new areas. But two scientists recently set out on a counterintuitive mission to collect as many bloodsucking ticks as possible.

headline: United Airlines Struggles to Resolve Flight Disruptions
abstract: The airline has had to cancel and delay more flights than other carriers after storms and other problems disrupted air travel around the country this week.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines was struggling on Friday to recover from a week of flight delays and cancellations, testing the resilience of its operation as people head to airports ahead of the busy July 4 holiday.

headline: In a Mutiny or Coup, the Scramble to Persuade and Pick a Side Is Critical
abstract: Experts say plotters’ most crucial task is to convince other soldiers and officers that success is assured. Plus, our columnist’s recommendations for reading up on coups, and modern Russia.
lead_paragraph: Coups are the ultimate fake-it-til-you-make-it endeavor. Talk to experts, and they’ll tell you that coup plotters’ most crucial task is to convince other soldiers and officers that success is assured, and that throwing their lot in with the putsch is therefore the path of prudent self-interest.

headline: Student Loans Decision Unravels One of Biden’s Signature Efforts
abstract: President Biden has a new challenge: how to respond to the disappointment of millions of his supporters who whose thousands of dollars in debt is coming due.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s rejection on Friday of President Biden’s student debt relief plan instantly unravels one of the president’s signature efforts and ratchets up the pressure on him to find a new way to make good on a promise to a key constituency as the 2024 presidential campaign gets underway.

headline: Stream These 8 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in July
abstract: The best James Bond movie of recent years is among a handful of great titles leaving soon for U.S. subscribers.
lead_paragraph: This July, several Oscar-nominated performances will depart from Netflix in the United States, along with two top-notch genre films and one of the most successful entries in the James Bond franchise — and that’s saying something. Here are a few of the highlights. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Brazil Set to Bar Bolsonaro From Office for Election-Fraud Claims
abstract: Brazil’s electoral court had enough votes to block former President Jair Bolsonaro from office until 2030 for spreading false claims about voting.
lead_paragraph: Brazilian election officials on Friday appeared poised to block former President Jair Bolsonaro from seeking public office for the next eight years, removing a top contender from the next presidential contest and dealing a significant blow to the country’s far-right movement.

headline: What is the HEROES Act?
abstract: Lawyers for the Biden administration told the Supreme Court that it could cancel billions of dollars in student debt because Congress had given it that authority using the HEROES Act in 2003.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Biden administration told the Supreme Court that it could cancel hundreds of billions of dollars in student debt because Congress had given it that authority in the Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003, which is usually called the HEROES Act.

headline: Don’t Use A.I. to Cheat in School. It’s Better for Studying.
abstract: Generative A.I. tools can annotate long documents, make flashcards, and produce practice quizzes.
lead_paragraph: Hello! We’re back with another bonus edition of On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.

headline: Congress has the power to forgive student loans, but it’s exceedingly unlikely to do so.
abstract: The Supreme Court said that such an expansive program needed explicit approval by Congress.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday striking down President Biden’s student debt cancellation initiative effectively punts the issue to Congress, where it is all but certain to go unaddressed.
